Description: GLFC ADMINISTRATIVE ACTIVITIES

THE PUERTO RICO DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES (DNER) HAVE BEEN IMPLEMENTING CORRECTIVE ACTIONS IN RESPONSE TO THE FINDINGS OF AUDIT REPORT NUMBER 2020-CR-022 FOR GRANTS UNDER THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION AND SPORT FISHING PROGRAM. AS A RESULT, GRANT ADJUSTMENTS AND CONSOLIDATIONS WERE REQUESTED BY THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND HAVE BEEN IMPLEMENTED IN THE DIFFERENT PR-WSFR PROGRAMS. WITH THIS PROPOSAL THE DNER SEEKS TO CONSOLIDATE FOUR ONGOING PROGRAMS WITH SIMILAR OBJECTIVES MANAGING WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH RESOURCES WITHIN SEVEN PROTECTED LOCATIONS IN PUERTO RICO.THE SUGGESTED PROJECT WILL PROMOTE STRATEGIES SUCH AS THE MAINTENANCE OF FACILITIES, HABITAT MANAGEMENT RESEARCH, SURVEY, DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS, EDUCATION OF THE PUBLIC, AMONG OTHERS IN THE BOQUERN WILDLIFE REFUGE, HUMACAO NATURAL RESERVE AND NORTHEAST ECOLOGICAL CORRIDOR, TORTUGUERO NATURAL RESERVE, CERRILLOS RESERVOIR WILDLIFE REFUGE, LUCCHETTI RESERVOIR WILDLIFE REFUGE AND LA PLATA RESERVOIR WILDLIFE REFUGE. THE FIRST FOUR PROTECTED AREAS ARE A COLLECTION OF UNIQUE COMPLEX HABITATS COMPOSED OF BRACKISH LAGOONS AND COASTAL WETLANDS WHILE THE LAST THREE AREAS ARE FRESHWATER RESERVOIRS CONSTRUCTED FOR WATER SUPPLY. THESE AREAS PROVIDE HUNTERS WITH A VARIETY OF WATERFOWL RESOURCES (EXCEPT IN THE RESERVOIRS), ANGLERS WITH VARIOUS ATTRACTIVE FISH, AND THE PUBLIC WITH RECREATIONAL TRAILS FOR THE ENJOYMENT OF WILDLIFE.
THIS GRANT PROJECT WILL PRODUCE A WEEKLY REPORT SUMMARIZING CURRENT FISHING CONDITIONS. THE REPORT SHALL CONTAIN INFORMATION ABOUT TEXAS  COASTAL AND INLAND WATER BODIES.

THIS GRANT IS FOR THE OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF MOTORBOAT ACCESSES WITHIN THE STATE OF MISSOURI. THIS GRANT WILL PROVIDE THOUSANDS OF BOATERS, ANGLERS, HUNTERS, AND OTHER OUTDOOR ENTHUSIASTS WITH MORE AND BETTER OPPORTUNITIES TO PURSUE THEIR RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES ON MISSOURI S PUBLIC WATERS, SPECIFICALLY FOR RECREATIONAL BOATING AND SPORT FISHING. PROPER MAINTENANCE WILL KEEP THESE AREAS SAFE AND INVITING TO THE PUBLIC, MINIMIZE LIABILITY CONCERNS, PROLONG THE USEFUL LIFETIME OF THE FACILITIES, AND LEAVE AREA USERS WITH GOOD IMPRESSIONS ABOUT THE MISSOURI DEPARTMENT OF CONSERVATION AND ITS RESOURCE MANAGEMENT CAPABILITIES.THE DEPARTMENT IS THE STATE AGENCY CHARGED WITH IMPROVING BOATING AND FISHING OPPORTUNITIES IN THE STATE OF MISSOURI. AS PART OF THIS GRANT THIS YEAR, THE DEPARTMENT WILL OPERATE AND MAINTAIN 270 MOTORBOAT ACCESS AREAS LOCATED THROUGHOUT THE STATE AS NEEDED AND PERFORM CYCLICAL MAINTENANCE OR UPGRADING AT 10 MOTORBOAT ACCESS AREAS.
PROJECT PROVIDES OPPORTUNITIES, SURVEYS, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, HATCHERY OPERATIONS, AND RESEARCH OF ALABAMA SPORT FISH POPULATIONS.

THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO RESEARCH AND DEVELOP A HUMAN DIMENSIONS SURVEY FOR ATTITUDES AND UNDERSTANDING OF FRESHWATER FISHERIES IN RHODE ISLAND. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE EDUCATION OF STAFF IN THE HUMAN DIMENSIONS FIELD, DEVELOPMENT OF A SURVEY, RESEARCH, DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE INCREASED CAPACITY OF STAFF TO PERFORM HUMAN DIMENSIONS RESEARCH TO SUPPORT R3 ANALYSIS AND DEVELOPMENT OF TARGETED ACTIVITIES FOR R3 PARTICIPANTS IN RHODE ISLAND. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE DIVISION TO HAVE MORE CAPACITY AND FOR THE RI GENERAL PUBLIC TO HAVE OUTREACH THAT SUPPORTS THEIR TARGETED NEEDS. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES BUT THERE WILL BE A CONTRACTUAL AGREEMENT WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF RHODE ISLAND TO SUPPORT A PORTION OF THE PROJECT.
TO PROVIDE COORDINATION OF GRANT MANAGEMENT PROCESSESS FOR AL MARINE SPORT FISH PROJECTS FUNDED BY WSFR.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS THE COORDINATION OF DELAWARE S SPORT FISH RESTORATION GRANT MANAGEMENT PROCESSES AND MAINTENANCE OF DELAWARE S PROGRAM ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE COORDINATION AND ADMINISTRATION OF PROGRAMMATIC AND FINANCIAL ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH SPORT FISH RESTORATION GRANT APPLICATIONS AND AGREEMENTS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE DELAWARE S ELIGIBILITY FOR PARTICIPATION IN THE SPORT FISH RESTORATION GRANT PROGRAM, TIMELY SUBMISSION OF GRANT APPLICATION PACKAGES AND PERFORMANCE REPORTS, EFFECTIVE COMMUNICATION AND COORDINATION OF ALL ASPECTS OF THE PROGRAM AND GRANT ACTIVITIES WITH WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM, AND EFFECTIVE COMMUNICATION, COORDINATION AND TRAINING FOR DELAWARE S LEADERSHIP, MANAGEMENT, PROJECT LEADERS AND STAFF. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE CONSERVATION MANAGERS AND SCIENTISTS IMPLEMENTING GRANT-FUNDED PROJECTS AIMED AT IMPROVING THE FISHERIES AND FISHERIES HABITAT IN DELAWARE FOR THE BENEFIT OF RECREATIONAL ANGLERS. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THIS PROJECT.

THE FISH LIFE HISTORY ANALYSIS PROGRAM OBJECTIVE IS TO GAIN A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF CRITICAL LIFE HISTORYPARAMETERS OF CORAL REEF FISHES HARVESTED IN THE COMMONWEALTH OF THE NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS. LIFE HISTORYPARAMETERS SUCH AS AGE AND REPRODUCTION OF FISHES INFORM FISHERIES MANAGERS ABOUT THE LIFE SPAN, AGE AT MATURITY,AND SIZE AT MATURITY OF FISH THAT ARE STUDIED. THESE DATA COULD THEN BE APPLIED TO FISH STOCK ASSESSMENTS, WHICHIS NECESSARY FOR THE SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT OF FISH SPECIES.
MICHIGAN FISH PRODUCTION AND STOCKING  F-62-D-37

THE PROPOSED PROJECT AIMS TO DELINEATE THE MOVEMENTS AND SPACE USE OF VARIOUS TELEMETERED FISHERIES SPECIESWITHIN MISSISSIPPIS WATERS AND THE GULF OF MEXICO. WE KNOW LITTLE OF THE INTER- AND INTRA-BASIN MOVEMENTS OF AVARIOUS FISHERIES SPECIES WITHIN MISSISSIPPI SOUND AND THE SURROUNDING WATERS. THESE DATA ARE USEFUL FROM AMANAGEMENT STANDPOINT TO GATHER DATA ON THE TIMING OF LIFE-HISTORY RELATED MOVEMENTS (E.G., SPAWNING,IMMIGRATION EMIGRATION, RESIDENCE IN SUBSYSTEMS) AND USE OF HABITATS BEING RESTORED OR PROPOSED FOR RESTORATIONPURPOSES. FURTHERMORE, AND UNDERSTANDING OF THE TIMINGS OF MOVEMENTS IN OFF SHORE MAY PROVIDE INSIGHT OFDIFFERENTIAL FISHING PRESSURE BETWEEN MISSISSIPPIS WATERS, FEDERAL WATERS, AND THOSE OF OTHER STATES. ACOUSTICTELEMETRY DATA FROM THE ITAG NETWORK AND OTHER SHARING NETWORKS WILL BE DOWNLOADED OBTAINED ALONG WITH DATA FROMNEARBY TELEMETRY USERS (MDMR, GCRL, OTHER LOCAL UNIVERSITIES, ETC.). THESE DATA WILL BE COMPILED INTO ONETELEMETRY DATABASE AND QAQCED IN ORDER TO STREAMLINE THE DATA SHARING PROCESS. DATA COMPILATIONS EXPECTED TO TAKE PLACE MONTHLY AS NEW DATA ARE OBTAINED BY EACH USER GROUP. ADDITIONALLY, ENVIRONMENTAL AND HYDROLOGICAL DATA WILL BE COMPILED FROM A VARIETY OF SOURCES TO BE USED IN CONJUNCTION WITH ACOUSTIC TELEMETRY DATA FOR FUTURE ANALYSES.DATA WILL BE DOWNLOADED FROM EXISTING ACOUSTIC RECEIVERS AND ANALYZED IN CONJUNCTION WITH TELEMETRY DATA COMPILEDFROM OTHER SOURCES FOR TARGETED SPECIES PREVIOUSLY TAGGED BY MDMR AND THE GCRL (I.E. RED DRUM, SOUTHERN FLOUNDER, GREY SNAPPER, AND ATLANTIC TRIPLETAIL) AS WELL AS FOR ADDITIONAL SPECIES TAGGED IN THE FUTURE. PARTICIPANTS AIM TO SUMMARIZE RESULTS AND DEVELOP VISUALIZATIONS TO EXAMINE THE SPACE USE OF THESE VARIOUS SPECIES IN MS WATERS AND BEYOND. RESULTS WILL BE COMPARED ACROSS MULTIPLE REGIONS AND PRESENTED TO MDMR AND REGIONAL STAKEHOLDERS.

THE ATTACHED GRANT SUPPORTS VERMONT FISH AND WILDLIFE S WORK COMPLETING SURVEYS AND INVENTORIES OF VERMONT S FISH POPULATIONS IN LAKE CHAMPLAIN. UNDER THIS GRANT, WORK WILL BE COMPLETED RELATED TO WALLEYE MANAGEMENT, SALMONID MANAGEMENT, RESTORATION OF LAKE STURGEON, CREEL SURVEYS, AND SEA LAMPREY CONTROL IN LAKE CHAMPLAIN.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AFA IS TO PROVIDE SAFE AND ADEQUATE PUBLIC ACCESS TO MAINE S WATERWAYS THROUGH THE PROPER MAINTENANCE, RENOVATION AND IMPROVEMENTS OF THE DEPARTMENT S WATER ACCESS SITES LOCATED THROUGHOUT THE STATE.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INCREASE OPPORTUNITIES FOR SPORT FISHING AND RECREATIONAL BOATING ON NORTHERN CASCO BAY THROUGH THE CONSTRUCTION OF A SINGLE VEHICLE PARKING FACILITY ADJACENT TO THE MERE POINT WATER ACCESS SITE ON PROPERTY OWNED BY THE MAINE DEPARTMENT OF INLAND FISHERIES AND WILDLIFE. THE FACILITY WILL INCLUDE A PAVED PARKING AREA AND PAVED ADA ACCESSIBLE PATHWAY SIDEWALK FROM THE PARKING LOT TO THE ENTRANCE OF THE EXISTING MERE POINT FACILITY.

THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO REPLACE COLLAPSED CULVERTS AND REPAIR THE ROAD OVER BROOKSVALE STREAM LOCATED IN NAUGATUCK STATE FOREST, HAMDEN, CT. THIS WILL RESTORE CONNECTIVITY FOR AN IMPORTANT HEADWATER STREAM FOR WILD BROOK TROUT AND TO ALLOW SAFE AND EFFICIENT ACCESS FOR OPERATING AND MAINTAINING WILDLIFE HABITAT AND PHEASANT STOCKING AREAS. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE ENGINEERING DESIGN, PERMITTING AND CONSTRUCTION. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PUBLIC WHO USE AND APPRECIATE THESE NATURAL RESOURCES. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS, ENVIRONMENTAL CONSULTANTS, PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, BUSINESSES, LOCAL MUNICIPALITIES, FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES, AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS IN CONSULTATION FOR HIGHWAY, BRIDGE, OTHER PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION PROJECTS, ENERGY PROJECTS, ALTERATIONS OF FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITATS, AND OTHER DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS TO AVOID, MINIMIZE, AND OR MITIGATE IMPACTS OR LOSS OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS IN NEW HAMPSHIRE. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE WILL ALSO BE PROVIDED FOR PROJECTS DIRECTLY INVOLVED WITH PRESERVATION, RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT OR AQUATIC AND RIPARIAN HABITATS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE REVIEW OF PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION AND ENERGY PROJECTS AND OTHER PROJECTS POTENTIALLY IMPACTING FISH AND WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS AND PARTICIPATION ON RELATED TECHNICAL COMMITTEES. PERSONNEL WILL ATTEND MEETINGS, REVIEW PROPOSED PROJECTS, CONDUCT SITE VISITS, MAKE TELEPHONE CALLS, WRITE CORRESPONDENCE, AND PREPARE SCIENTIFIC SUMMARIES TO PROVIDE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR ALTERNATIVES OR MODIFICATIONS TO PROJECTS OR TO PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION METHODS TO MINIMIZE ADVERSE EFFECTS TO FISH AND WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND THEIR HABITATS, OR TO ENHANCE THE SUCCESS OF HABITAT RESTORATION EFFORTS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE THE AVOIDANCE, MINIMIZATION, AND MITIGATION OF ADVERSE IMPACTS TO FISH AND WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS. IN ADDITION, NEW HAMPSHIRE S FISHERIES HABITATS WILL EXHIBIT SELF-SUSTAINING NATURAL PROCESSES AND LINKAGES AMONG ITS TERRESTRIAL, RIPARIAN, AND AQUATIC COMPONENTS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE LAND USE PLANNERS AND DECISION MAKERS WHOSE ACTIVITIES CAN AFFECT THE HEALTH OF THE STATE S FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES, AS WELL AS THOSE GROUPS WHO ARE IN A POSITION TO PROTECT, CONSERVE, OR ENHANCE THESE RESOURCES. THE PUBLIC WILL BENEFIT FROM APPROPRIATE CONSERVATION OF THE STATE S FISH AND WILDLIFE. THERE ARE NO ANTICIPATED SUBRECIPIENTS PREFORMING WORK UNDER THIS AWARD.

THE FRANKLIN COUNTY BOARD OF COUNTY COMMISSIONERS WILL USE FEDERAL DOLLARS TO CONSTRUCT IMPROVEMENTSTO THE BOAT RAMP AND SEAWALL AT THE OLD FERRY DOCK BOAT RAMP IN FLORIDA. THE NEW RAMP WILL BE A TWO-LANE RAMP, EACH 20 FEET WIDE, PREVENTING TRAILERS FROM RUNNING OFF THE SIDE OF THE RAMP. THERE WILL BE A LOADING DOCK BETWEEN THE TWO RAMPS.

THE MISSION OF THE AQUATIC EDUCATION PROGRAM AND THIS GRANT IS TO FOSTER AN AWARENESS AND APPRECIATION IN CHILDREN AND ADULTS FOR THE STATES AQUATIC RESOURCES, FOCUSING UPON THE SPORT OF FISHING TO INTRODUCE THE OUTDOORS IN AN ENJOYABLE, SAFE AND RESPONSIBLE MANNER.

ODWC WILL SUBAWARD THIS GRANT TO THE JENKS AQUARIUM AUTHORITY. THIS GRANT WILL COST-SHARE MAINTENANCE OF A PORTION OF THE AQUATIC OKLAHOMA GALLERY AT THE OKLAHOMA AQUARIUM. THE REMODEL WILL ENHANCE THE PUBLIC S UNDERSTANDING OF WATER RESOURCES, AQUATIC LIFE FORMS, AND SPORT FISHING, AND DEVELOP RESPONSIBLE ATTITUDES AND ETHICS TOWARD THE AQUATIC ENVIRONMENT. THE UPDATE WILL RE-CREATE REGIONS OF AQUATIC HABITATS FOUND IN OKLAHOMA AND WILL INCORPORATE THE IMPORTANCE OF MANAGING OUR RIVERS AND STREAMS, PONDS AND LAKES, AND SWAMPS AND ENSURING GOOD WATER QUALITY AND FISHERIES FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS. THE AQUATIC OKLAHOMA GALLERY VISION IS TO EXPOSE MILLIONS OF CHILDREN AND ADULTS TO A ONE-OF-A-KIND INTERACTIVE EXPERIENCE THAT FEATURES THE MANY FISH SPECIES FOUND WITHIN THE STATE, WHICH ECOSYSTEMS THEY INHABIT, AND THE BENEFITS OF VISITING THE REGIONS SPECIFICALLY WHILE SPORT FISHING. THE GALLERY IS MEANT TO INSPIRE VISITORS TO EXPLORE NATURE, ENJOY THE AMAZING AND DIVERSE HABITATS WITHIN OKLAHOMA, LEARN WHERE TO SPORTFISH, AND ENCOURAGE THE CONSERVATION OF OUR AQUATIC RESOURCES.

THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO COORDINATE DOEES SPORT FISH RESTORATION GRANT MANAGEMENT PROCESSES AND MAINTAIN DOEES PROGRAM ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE SUBMITTING PROJECT PROPOSALS AND REPORTS, MANAGING BUDGETS, PURCHASING SUPPLIES, ENSURING COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL GRANT REGULATIONS, AND COMMUNICATING WITH USFWS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE ACHIEVING FISHERIES MANAGEMENT, BOATING ACCESS, AND EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE DOEE STAFF. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

ALABAMA AQUATIC RESOURCES ARE AS DIVERSE AS THE FRESHWATER FISH SPECIES THAT INHABIT THEM. CULTIVATING ANGLING SKILLS AND EDUCATIONAL STRATEGIES WILL SUSTAIN PARTICIPATION AND APPRECIATION IN ALABAMA S AQUATIC RESOURCES.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH   WILDLIFE (CDFW) AQUATIC RESOURCE EDUCATION PROGRAM (AE) IS ADMINISTEREDTHROUGH THE OFFICE OF COMMUNICATIONS, EDUCATION AND OUTREACH. AE IS DIVIDED INTO FOUR PROJECTS: CONSERVATIONEDUCATION, CLASSROOM AQUARIUM EDUCATION PROGRAM (CAEP), FISHING-IN-THE-CITY (FIC) AND INTERPRETIVE SERVICES.THESE PROGRAMS WORK TOGETHER TO ACCOMPLISH THE OVERALL GOALS AND MISSION OF THE DEPARTMENT.CDFWS AE PROGRAM BROADENS PUBLIC AWARENESS, ENCOURAGES EDUCATORS TO INCLUDE CONSERVATION EDUCATION TOPICS INTO THEIR INSTRUCTIONAL MATERIALS AND CREATE STEWARDS OF CALIFORNIA S VITAL AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS. THIS IS ACCOMPLISHEDBY PROMOTING BOTH INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL PARTNERSHIPS IN EDUCATION, RECREATION AND CONSERVATION. THE AE PROGRAMPROVIDES THE DEPARTMENT WITH A CRITICAL TOOL THAT PROMOTES THE WISE USE AND ENJOYMENT OF CALIFORNIA S AQUATICNATURAL RESOURCES.

THIS GRANT PROVIDES FUNDING TO THE UTAH DIVISION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES (UDWR) FOR THE COMPLETION OF SPORTFISHWORK ACROSS THE STATE. THE WORK IS DIVIDED ACROSS SIX PROJECTS. THE FIRST PROJECT COVERS THE MONITORING OFUTAHS FISH POPULATIONS AND HABITAT. THE UDWR USES GRANT FUNDING TO SAMPLE FISH POPULATIONS USING VARIOUSMETHODS SUCH AS NETTING AND ELECTROFISHING. ADDITIONAL BIOLOGICAL DATA THAT IS COLLECTED INCLUDES THE MONITORINGOF INVERTEBRATES AND FISH SPECIES THAT PROVIDE FORAGE FOR SPORTFISH. EFFORTS TO MONITOR ANGLER SUCCESS ANDPREFERENCES THROUGH CREEL, REWARD TAG, AND ONLINE SURVEYS IS ALSO INCLUDED AS PART OF THIS PROJECT. THE UDWRALSO USES GRANT FUNDS TO MONITOR FISH HABITAT THROUGH ACTIONS SUCH AS COLLECTING TEMPERATURE, OXYGEN, AND OTHERABIOTIC INFORMATION (E.G., SUBSTRATE SIZE, STREAM WIDTH, ETC.). IN ADDITION, THE GRANT COVERS THE MONITORING OFAQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES POPULATIONS. THE PROGRAM HAS HISTORICALLY FOCUSED ON DREISSINID MUSSEL POPULATIONMONITORING BUT IS EXPANDING TO COVER THE MONITORING OF OTHER AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES.THE SECOND PROJECT COVERS ACTIONS THAT DIRECTLY MANIPULATE FISH POPULATIONS. ACTIONS INCLUDE COLLECTING FISH FORSPAWNING PROGRAMS AND TRANSPORT OF FISH TO REMOTE LOCATIONS FOR STOCKING. AS A NOTE, UTAHS FISH HATCHERYPROGRAM ITSELF IS COVERED BY A SEPARATE GRANT. AS A RESULT, THIS GRANT COVERS SPAWNING AND STOCKING EFFORTS THATARE NOT UNDER THE HATCHERY GRANT. OTHER ACTIONS COVERED UNDER THIS PROJECT INCLUDE THE CHEMICAL AND MECHANICALREMOVAL OF NON-NATIVE OR INVASIVE FISH SPECIES.THE THIRD PROJECT COVERS DAM, HABITAT, AND ANGLER ACCESS IMPROVEMENTS AND MAINTENANCE. CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS INTHESE AREAS ARE COVERED UNDER SEPARATE GRANTS. THIS GRANT IS USED TO COVER THE STAFF TIME REQUIRED TO MONITORDAMS, HABITAT, AND ANGLER ACCESS AREAS AND TO DESIGN AND OVERSEE PROJECTS IN THESE AREAS. ADDITIONAL POSTCONSTRUCTIONMONITORING WORK IS ALSO COVERED BY THIS GRANT.THE FOURTH PROJECT INVOLVES EFFORTS TO EDUCATE THE PUBLIC ABOUT FISHING AND UTAHS AQUATIC RESOURCES. GENERALLY,EDUCATIONAL AND OUTREACH PROGRAMS ARE IDENTIFIED AND DESIGNED BY THE UDWR OUTREACH DEPARTMENT UNDER A SEPARATEGRANT. AQUATICS STAFF INVOLVEMENT UNDER THIS GRANT IS GENERALLY LIMITED TO PROVIDING AQUATICS STAFF EXPERTISE ATEVENTS (E.G., ANSWERING QUESTIONS AT BOOTHS). THE AQUATICS STAFF ALSO REGULARLY DOES INTERVIEWS WITH THE MEDIA.STAFFING OF THE UTAH STATE FAIR AND THE CREATION OF DELIVERABLE MATERIALS SUCH AS SIGNS AND BROCHURES IS ALSOCOVERED UNDER THIS PROJECT.THE FIFTH PROJECT COVERS STAKEHOLDER INVOLVEMENT. ACTIONS UNDER THIS PROJECT INCLUDE HOLDING MEETINGS WITH OTHERSTAKEHOLDERS AND ASSISTING STAKEHOLDERS BY REVIEWING PERMIT APPLICATIONS. THE INTENT OF THIS PROJECT IS TOFOSTER GOOD RELATIONSHIPS WITH THESE STAKEHOLDERS AND TO ASSIST THEM WITH THEIR WORK.THE SIXTH PROJECT INVOLVES PROVIDING TECHNICAL SUPPORT. ACTIONS UNDER THIS PROJECT INCLUDE THE INVESTIGATION OFFISH KILLS AND INSPECTING PRIVATELY OWNED FISH PONDS TO ENSURE THAT THESE PONDS HAVE MINIMAL RISK TO PUBLICFISHERIES. ADDITIONALLY, THIS PROJECT INCLUDES THE REVIEW OF INTERNALLY AND EXTERNALLY DEVELOPED PROJECTPROPOSALS.EXPENSES UNDER THIS GRANT ARE GENERALLY DIRECTED TOWARDS PERSONNEL SERVICES CHARGES UNDER THE UDWR SPORTFISHPROGRAM AND COVERING SMALL DOLLAR, NON-FIXED ASSET PURCHASES SUCH AS THE PURCHASE OF FUEL, WADERS, TAGGINGSUPPLIES OR BASIC FIELD SUPPLIES SUCH AS NETS AND BUCKETS. PENDING THE NEED AND AVAILABILITY OF FUNDING AT THEEND OF THE FISCAL YEAR, LARGER, FIXED ASSETS SUCH AS ELECTROFISHING UNITS OR BOAT MOTORS MAY BE PURCHASED.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO PROTECT SPORTS FISH AND THEIR HABITATS WITHIN THE STATE OF WASHINGTON THROUGH REVIEW, INVESTIGATION, AND COMMENT ON VARIOUS RESOURCE PROTECTION PERMITS AND ENVIRONMENTAL DOCUMENTS IN ADDITION TO PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE RELATING TO THE PROTECTION AND ENHANCEMENT OF FISH HABITAT. URBAN, SUBURBAN, AND INDUSTRIAL EXPANSIONS ARE INCREASING THE IMPACT ON THE REMAINING FISH HABITAT BASE. PRESSURE IS EXERTED ON SHORELINES, LAKES, WETLANDS, RIPARIAN AREAS, STREAMS AND RIVERS, AND OTHER CRITICAL AREAS WITHIN WASHINGTON S WATERSHEDS THAT DIRECTLY AFFECT FISH HABITAT.

THE CNMI SPORT FISH RESTORATION (SFR) PROGRAM MANAGEMENT PROJECT PROVIDES PROGRAMMATIC SUPPORT TO SFR PROJECTS. SUPPORT IS PROVIDED THROUGH THE MAINTENANCE OF PROGRAM ASSETS, INFRASTRUCTURE IMPROVEMENT, SUPPORT OF PROGRAM OPERATIONS AND TECHNICAL GUIDANCE. SUPPORT FOR PROGRAM PROJECTS AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF FUTURE PROGRAM PLANS WILL RESULT EFFICIENT AND TIMELY DELIVERY OF PROGRAM BENEFITS THAT MEETS COMPLIANCE REQUIREMENTS OF PROGRAMREGULATIONS AND POLICIES.

OBJECTIVES:1.COLLECT STANDARDIZED FISHERIES DEPENDENT AND INDEPENDENT DATA ON A MINIMUM OF 20 IMPORTANT WATER BODIES AND ANALYZE POPULATION AND COMMUNITY METRICS TO INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS.2.EVALUATE THE EFFICACY OF FLORIDA BASS STOCK ENHANCEMENT STRATEGIES ON A MINIMUM OF TWO LAKES TO INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS.3.COLLECT AND ANALYZE SPORTFISH BIOLOGY, POPULATION DYNAMICS AND OR FISHERY DATA ON A MINIMUM OF 25 WATER BODIES TO FILL INFORMATION GAPS AND INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS.

THIS GRANT WILL PROVIDE FUNDING FOR THE OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF 1,046 STATE-OPERATED DEVELOPED BOATING ACCESS SITES, AND 19 STATE HARBORS ON THE GREAT LAKES TO PROVIDE QUALITY PUBLIC BOATING ACCESS AND FISHING OPPORTUNITIES.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE S (CDFW) INLAND DESERTS REGION (IDR) MANAGES SOME OF THE BEST AND MOST POPULAR TROUT FISHING IN CALIFORNIA. THIS GRANT WILL FUND THE COLLECTION OF INFORMATION THAT WILL INFORM VARIOUS MANAGEMENT ACTIONS INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO: STOCKING REQUIREMENTS, HERITAGE AND WILD TROUT MANAGEMENT PLANS, AND PUBLIC USE DOCUMENTS.

THERE IS A NEED FOR SAFE, ACCESSIBLE, AND FUNCTIONAL BOATING FACILITIES IN ARIZONA. PARKER CANYON IS IN NEED OF A NEW BOAT LAUNCH THAT WILL ACCOMMODATE THE NEEDS AT THIS LAKE. THIS WILL INCLUDE A NEW TWO LANE LAUNCH WITH GANGWAY AND COURTESY DOCK, MAKE READY AREA, ADDITIONAL PARKING INCLUDING ADA PARKING FOR TRAILER VEHICLES AND NON TRAILER VEHICLES, ACCESS ROAD TO THE NEW LAUNCH, AND NEW VAULT TOILET. THESE IMPROVEMENTS WILL PROVIDE GREATER ACCESS TO THE LAKE, INCREASING THE NUMBER OF BOATER USE DAYS ON PARKER CANYON LAKE.

THE PROJECT WILL MONITOR RECREATIONAL FISHERIES ON THE WASHINGTON COAST AND WORK THAT WOULD BE COMPLETED WOULD INCLUDE OPPORTUNISTIC CREEL OF STEELHEAD FISHERIES FROM NOVEMBER THOUGH APRIL IN RIVERS ON THE WASHINGTON COAST.

CALIFORNIA HAS AN ESTIMATED 3,469 COLD WATER LAKES, 112 COLD WATER RESERVOIRS, AND OVER 200 RESERVOIRS WITH WARMWATER SPECIES. ACCORDING TO THE 2011 NATIONAL SURVEY OF FISHING, HUNTING, AND WILDLIFE-ASSOCIATED RECREATION (USDOI 2013) AN ESTIMATED 1.7 MILLION FRESHWATER ANGLERS ACCUMULATED OVER 23.8 MILLION ANGLING DAYS ON PONDS, LAKES, AND RESERVOIRS IN CALIFORNIA AND ANGLERS CONTRIBUTED OVER  2.3 BILLION TO THE STATE S ECONOMY FROM FISHING RELATED EXPENSES.ALTHOUGH SEEMINGLY HIGH, THE NUMBER OF ANGLERS IN CALIFORNIA HAS BEEN DECLINING FOR THE PAST DECADE. CONTRIBUTING FACTORS FOR THE DECLINING PARTICIPATION IN ANGLING HAS NOT BEEN WELL INVESTIGATED. IN 1988, FLETCHER AND KING (1988) REPORTED THAT, IN GENERAL, CALIFORNIA ANGLERS STOPPED FISHING DUE TO A LACK OF FREE TIME. HOWEVER, THE 18-24-YEAR-OLD AGE SUBGROUP CITED A LOSS OF INTEREST AS THE PRIMARY REASON FOR NO LONGER FISHING. LOSS OF INTEREST MAY RELATE TO POOR ANGLER SATISFACTION, WHICH WAS MOST NEGATIVELY IMPACTED BY NOT CATCHING ENOUGH FISH. IN A LATER STUDY OF 14 CALIFORNIA RESERVOIRS STOCKED WITH SALMONIDS, 78  OF ANGLERS CONTACTED WERE SATISFIED WITH THEIR OVERALL ANGLING EXPERIENCE, BUT APPROXIMATELY HALF OF ANGLERS CONTACTED WERE NOT SATISFIED WITH EITHER THE SIZE OR NUMBER OF FISH CAUGHT (LEE 2003). SATISFACTION METRICS DID NOT SHOW A STRONG TREND OVER TIME IN EITHER DIRECTION. HOWEVER, THE STAGNANT AND MEDIOCRE LEVELS OF SATISFACTION IN FISH SIZE AND CATCH RATE MAY HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO THE RECENT DECLINE IN ANGLING PARTICIPATION.LAKE AND RESERVOIR FISHERIES COMPRISE A LARGE PORTION OF THE RECREATIONAL FISHING EFFORT IN CALIFORNIA. BETWEEN THE YEARS OF 2010 AND 2019, THE SALE OF FISHING LICENSES IN CALIFORNIA HAS GENERATED BETWEEN  36,239,087 - 46,283,404 IN REVENUE. DURING THIS PERIOD, THE COST OF A SPORT-FISHING LICENSE HAS RISEN ANNUALLY EXCEPT FOR 2015 - 2017 WHEN IT REMAINED THE SAME. ONE COMMON COMPLAINT THAT WE CONTINUE TO ENCOUNTER FROM OUR STAKEHOLDERS IS THE LIMITED NUMBER AND TYPE OF GAME FISH AVAILABLE TO ANGLERS. THIS PERCEIVED ISSUE CAUSES A MAJOR PROBLEM IN PROVIDING SATISFACTORY FISHING OPPORTUNITIES FOR ANGLERS BY RECREATIONAL FISHING MANAGERS. NOT CATCHING ENOUGH FISH IS OFTEN THE GREATEST DETRACTOR FROM THE ENJOYMENT OF FISHING. FISHERY METHODS AND TECHNIQUES FOR IMPROVING ANGLER CATCHES ARE NUMEROUS AND LEE (1993) DESCRIBED VARIOUS LAKE AND RESERVOIR MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES COMMONLY USED IN CALIFORNIA. TO DETERMINE THE SUCCESS OF THESE STRATEGIES AND TO HELP DEVELOP NEW STRATEGIES, INFORMATION ON LAKE AND RESERVOIR PHYSICAL AND CHEMICAL PARAMETERS, FISH POPULATIONS, ANGLER SUCCESS AND CATCH, AND ANGLER ATTITUDES AND PREFERENCES ARE NEEDED.EVEN THOUGH LAKE AND RESERVOIR FISHERIES COMPRISE A LARGE PORTION OF THE RECREATIONAL FISHING EFFORT IN CALIFORNIA, THERE IS A LACK OF DATA ON FISH POPULATION DYNAMICS OF GAME FISHES IN MANY OF THE STATE S WATERS. INFORMATION ON SPORT FISH SPECIES ABUNDANCE, AGE, SIZE STRUCTURE, ANGLER SUCCESS AND HARVEST, AND THE SIZE OF NATURAL-SPAWNING POPULATIONS IS NECESSARY TO EFFECTIVELY MANAGE ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES.IN SOME WATERS THE INTRODUCTION OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES (AIS) CREATES THREATS TO DESIRABLE FISHERY RESOURCES. INFORMATION ON THE STATUS OF AIS SPECIES AND EFFECTIVE CONTROL METHODS ARE NEEDED TO DETERMINE APPROPRIATE MANAGEMENT RESPONSE TO AIS INTRODUCTIONS AND TO REDUCE THE IMPACT TO CALIFORNIA S SPORT FISHERIES.THE GOAL OF THE LAKE AND RESERVOIR FISHERY MANAGEMENT AND RESEARCH PROGRAM IS TO FURTHER OUR UNDERSTANDING OF SPORT FISH POPULATION DYNAMICS BY MAINTAINING AND IMPROVING RECREATIONAL FISHING OPPORTUNITIES IN CALIFORNIA LAKES AND RESERVOIRS, THUS INCREASING ANGLER SUCCESS AND SATISFACTION.

OVERVIEW: THIS GRANT AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) AND THE WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (DEPARTMENT) DEFINES HOW THE DEPARTMENT WILL ADMINISTER AND IMPLEMENT ITS SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM UNDER THE COMPREHENSIVE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (CMS) OPTION. THE CMS APPROACH REQUIRES THE DEPARTMENT TO ASSESS THE STATUS OF FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES, ESTABLISH FUTURE GOALS FOR THOSE RESOURCES, DEVELOP A FISH   WILDLIFE STRATEGIC PLAN, IMPLEMENT THAT PLAN THROUGH THE USE OF MANAGEMENT SYSTEM, AND EVALUATE PROGRESS IN IMPLEMENTING THAT PLAN.ACTION AREA: THIS GRANT INCLUDES ACTIVITIES ON STATE-OWNED FISHERY AREAS, BOAT RAMPS, AND FISHING PIERS THROUGHOUT WISCONSIN.GOALS   OBJECTIVES:  PROTECT, CONSERVE, AND MANAGE FISHERY RESOURCES ON OVER 1.8 MILLION ACRES OF PUBLIC LAND.  PROVIDE HIGH-QUALITY OPPORTUNITIES FOR ANGLERS.  MANAGE AND MAINTAIN DEPARTMENT-OWNED PROPERTIES.  ENHANCE, RESTORE, AND INCREASE PUBLIC APPRECIATION OF WISCONSIN S AQUATIC SPECIES AND ECOSYSTEMS.  PLAN FOR FUTURE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, RECREATIONAL USE, AND PUBLIC USE FACILITIES   PROVIDE PROFESSIONAL REAL ESTATE SERVICES TO THE DEPARTMENT   DESIGN RECREATIONAL AND EMPLOYEE SUPPORT FACILITIES   CONDUCT RESEARCH TO ACQUIRE ORIGINAL KNOWLEDGE AND ANALYZE INFORMATION TO INFORM POLICIES AND SUPPORT SCIENCE-BASED MANAGEMENT DECISIONS.  PROTECT, ENHANCE, AND PROMOTE PUBLIC SAFETY.  RECRUIT NEW ANGLERS, RETAIN EXISTING ANGLERS, AND REACTIVATE LAPSED ANGLERS.  DEVELOP AND MANAGE STATE-OWNED BOAT RAMPS AND FISHING PIERS  SUPPORT EXTERNAL PARTNERS IN ACHIEVING THESE SAME GOALS THROUGH SUB-AWARDS.OUTCOMES: MANAGEMENT AND ENHANCEMENT OF FISH POPULATIONS AND AQUATIC HABITATS  ENHANCED UNDERSTANDING OF FISHERY RESOURCES THROUGH RESEARCH  MANAGEMENT OF EMERGING FISH HEALTH ISSUES  AVAILABILITY OF HIGH-QUALITY PUBLIC OUTDOOR RECREATION OPPORTUNITIES  ENHANCED UNDERSTANDING OF FISH HEALTH THROUGH PUBLIC OUTREACH AND EDUCATION  ENHANCED PARTICIPATION IN ANGLING  AND EXCELLENCE IN PUBLIC SERVICE.

THE DEPARTMENT MAINTAINS NEARLY 200 FISHING ACCESS AREAS THAT ARE OPEN 24 7 FOR THE PUBLIC TO BOAT, FISH, HUNT, AND TRAP ON VERMONT WATERWAYS.  THESE SITES ARE HEAVILY USED YEAR-ROUND AND REQUIRE A SIGNIFICANT AMOUNT OF MAINTENANCE TO KEEP THEM OPERATIONAL AND SAFE FOR ALL USERS.  THIS GRANT FUNDS THE MANAGEMENT, OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE PROGRAM FOR VERMONTS FISHING ACCESS AREAS IN ORDER TO  ENSURE THESE FACILITIES ARE KEPT ACCESSIBLE, CLEAN, SAFE, AND FUNCTIONAL FOR THE PUBLIC. IN ADDITION, IT FUNDS LAND ADMINISTRATION, INSPECTIONS, MAINTENANCE, DESIGN, AND CONSTRUCTION OF DEPARTMENT FISHING ACCESS AREAS, BOTH CURRENT AND FUTURE LOCATIONS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO OPERATE AND MAINTAIN 135 EXISTING PUBLIC BOATING AND FISHING ACCESS FACILITIES OWNED OR CONTROLLED BY THE NEW HAMPSHIRE FISH AND GAME DEPARTMENT. ACTIVITIES PREFORMED INCLUDE OVERALL ADMINISTRATION OF THE NH STATEWIDE PUBLIC ACCESS PROGRAM, FIELD INSPECTIONS, OPERATION, MAINTENANCE, AND REPAIR OF EXISTING PUBLIC WATER ACCESS FACILITIES. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO TOWNS, DEVELOPMENT OF MATERIALS TO HELP THE PUBLIC LOCATE AND ENJOY FACILITIES, AND PUBLIC USE AND SATISFACTION SURVEYS ARE COMPLETED, AS NEEDED. THE EXPECTED OUTCOME IS A WELL-PLANNED AND EXECUTED OPERATION AND MANAGEMENT PROGRAM THAT HELPS TO KEEP PUBLIC BOAT ACCESS FACILITIES SAFE, ATTRACTIVE, AND FUNCTIONAL. IT IS EXPECTED THAT THE PROJECT WILL MAXIMIZE THE USEFUL LIFE OF THESE FACILITIES. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT ARE THE CITIZENS AND VISITORS OF THE STATE OF NEW HAMPSHIRE SEEKING AN OPPORTUNITY TO ENJOY THE STATE S WATER RESOURCES. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENTS PERFORMING WORK UNDER THIS PROJECT.
THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO ACQUIRE LAND FOR A BOAT LAUNCH SITE THAT WILL PROVIDE SAFE PUBLIC ACCESS TO THE WATERS OF PETTINGILL POND.

THIS GRANT IS A SUB-AWARD TO OKLAHOMA STATE UNIVERSITY. THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE MCCURTAIN COUNTY. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO FACILITATE THE CURRENT UNDERSTANDING OF ANGLER USE AND SATISFACTION OF THE LOWER MOUNTAIN FORK RIVER AS WELL AS ANGLERS ATTITUDES ON ALTERNATIVE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES, AND ANGLERS ECONOMIC INFLUENCE IN THE AREA. THIS STUDY WILL IMPLEMENT TWO SURVEYS OF ANGLERS, ONE TO ASSESS FISHING EFFORT AND CATCH, AND ANOTHER SURVEY WILL INCLUDE ADDITIONAL ECONOMICS AND HUMAN DIMENSIONS QUESTIONS. THE SECOND SURVEY WILL ALSO INCLUDE QUESTIONS ON THEIR TRIP EXPENDITURES. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION ON USE, CATCH, ECONOMIC VALUE, AND ANGLER PREFERENCES FOR TROUT FISHING AT THE LOWER MOUNTAIN FORK TROUT AREA, WHICH WILL PROVIDE INSIGHTS ON ALTERNATIVE MANAGEMENT MEASURES. DATA WILL BE PROVIDED AS AGREED UPON BY THE CONTRACT SPONSOR. OTHER DELIVERABLES OF THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE A FINAL REPORT AND COPIES OF PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS.

THIS GRANT WILL BE SUBAWARDED TO OKLAHOMA STATE UNIVERSITY. THE PROPOSED INTERDISCIPLINARY PROJECT WILL EVALUATE THE ECOSYSTEM EFFECTS AND ECONOMIC IMPACT OF ALTERNATIVE TROUT STOCKING SCENARIOS BY EXPLORING ANGLER OPINIONS ON ALTERNATIVE MANAGEMENT OPTIONS, ALONG WITH FOODWEB DYNAMICS TO EXPLORE HOW CHANGES IN WATER QUALITY QUANTITY COUPLED WITH SPECIES DISTRIBUTION WILL INFLUENCE FISH POPULATION AND ECONOMIC VALUE OF LOWER ILLINOIS RIVER FISHERY SITE, IN AN EFFORT TO BETTER INFORM NATURAL RESOURCES MANAGEMENT DECISIONS.
FUNDS FROM THIS GRANT AWARD WILL BE USED TO CONDUCT FRESHWATER FISHERY MANAGEMENT RESEARCH ACTIVITIES IN NORTH CAROLINA.

THE OROVILLE WILDLIFE AREA (OWA) IS AN 11,000-ACRE REGIONAL OPEN SPACE AREA AND REGIONAL ASSET LOCATED ALONG THEFEATHER RIVER IN BUTTE COUNTY, CALIFORNIA, APPROXIMATELY 70 MILES NORTH OF THE CITY OF SACRAMENTO. THE OWA IS APRIMITIVE WILDLIFE AREA THAT IS MANAGED FOR BOTH WILDLIFE HABITAT AS WELL AS RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES, ANDPROVIDES VISITORS FROM BUTTE, YUBA, SUTTER, COLUSA AND GLENN COUNTIES, AND IMMEDIATE COMMUNITIES, A REGIONALDESTINATION FOR OUTDOOR RECREATION, SUCH AS RIVER-ORIENTED FISHING AND BOATING, HIKING, WILDLIFE OBSERVATION ANDPHOTOGRAPHY. IT IS COMPRISED OF WILLOW- AND COTTONWOOD-LINED PONDS, ISLANDS, AND CHANNELS, INCLUDINGAPPROXIMATELY 10 MILES OF RIPARIAN WOODLAND HABITAT ALONG THE FEATHER RIVER AND EXTENSIVE GRASSLANDS AROUND THETHERMALITO AFTERBAY. WILDLIFE SPECIES OBSERVED IN THE AREA INCLUDE COYOTE, BADGER, FOX, BOBCAT, PORCUPINE,OSPREY, WHITE-TAILED KITE, EGRETS, WOODPECKERS, AND WARBLERS. THERE ARE GOOD POPULATIONS OF DEER, DOVE, QUAIL,AND WATERFOWL, AND FAIR POPULATIONS OF SQUIRREL AND RABBIT.THE OWA IS COOPERATIVELY MANAGED BY THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) AND THE CALIFORNIADEPARTMENT OF WATER RESOURCES (DWR). CDFW MANAGES THE OWA, BUT DWR HOLDS FEE TITLE TO MOST OF THE OWA LANDS. DWR RESERVES THE RIGHT TO USE THEIR LANDS FOR A NUMBER OF PURPOSES INCLUDING PROVIDING OPEN SPACE AND OUTDOOR RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES.THE PROPOSED OROVILLE WILDLIFE AREA THERMALITO AFTERBAY OUTLET PARK AND RECREATION AREA PROJECT ON APPROXIMATELY53 ACRES, IS LOCATED ON THE NORTHEAST SIDE OF THE THERMALITO AFTERBAY OUTFALL ALONG THE FEATHER RIVER ATAPPROXIMATELY RIVER MILE 59. IT IS OPEN TO THE PUBLIC 365 DAYS PER YEAR FROM 1 HOURS BEFORE SUNRISE TO 1 HOURAFTER SUNSET. PUBLIC ACCESS WITHIN THE OWA IS PROVIDED BY BOTH DEVELOPED AND PRIMITIVE ROADS, RECREATIONAL TRAILSAND WATERCRAFT. AUTHORIZED EXISTING USES INCLUDE MOTORIZED AND NON-MOTORIZED WATERCRAFT USE, RIVER-ORIENTEDFISHING FROM BOTH THE ADJACENT UPLAND AND FEATHER RIVER PROPER, BOATING, HIKING, LIMITED PRIMITIVE CAMPING ANDWILDLIFE OBSERVATION. IN OTHER PARTS OF THE OWA, THERE ARE OTHER RECREATIONAL SITES INCLUDING, A SHOOTING RANGE,DAY USE AREAS AND AUTHORIZED CAMPING AREAS. IN ADDITION TO THE MANY SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES, THE CLOSEST URBANAREA IS THE CITY OF OROVILLE WITH A POPULATION OF 21,000, APPROXIMATELY 7 MILES AWAY FROM THE PROPOSED PROJECT.

THE UTAH DIVISION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES WILL MAINTAIN ITS 13 HATCHERY FACILITIES IN A MANNER THAT WILL ALLOW THEM TO PRODUCE THE EGGS AND FISH NEEDED TO MEET STATE REGIONAL REQUEST. ALL QUOTAS ARE ESTABLISHED BASED ON CONSERVATION NEEDS OR SPORTFISH STOCKING TO MEET ANGLER DEMANDS. OUR MANTUA AND EGAN HATCHERIES PRODUCE VARIOUS SPECIES OF SALMONID EGGS FOR SPORTFISH NEED AND SHIPPED TO THE OTHER HATCHERIES TO RAISE. MAMMOTH CREEK HATCHERY HOLDS BROOD CUTTHROAT TROUT TO PRODUCE EGGS FOR CONSERVATION AND SPORTFISH NEEDS. LEE KAY HATCHERY HOLDS BROOD (MUSKELLUNGE AND NORTHERN PIKE) TO PRODUCE TIGER MUSKIE. THE REST OF THE HATCHERIES RECEIVE EGGS FROM ONE OF THESE HATCHERIES TO PRODUCE FISH FOR STOCKING. EIGHT WILD TRAPS ARE OPERATED BY HATCHERY STAFF TO COLLECT EGGS FOR CONSERVATION AND SPORTFISH NEEDS THEY ARE THEN RAISED AT PRODUCTION HATCHERIES AND STOCKED. THE STATE OF UTAH DOES NOT HAVE THE CAPABILITY TO RAISE ALL OF THE WARM COOL WATER FISH TO MEET THE NEEDS OF ANGLERS IN THE STATE. WHICH REQUIRES THE STATE TO BUY THEM OR OBTAIN THEM FROM OTHER STATES AFTER WHICH HATCHERY PERSONNEL DELIVER AND DISTRIBUTE THEM TO VARIOUS WATERS IN THE STATE.

THE ARIZONA GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT, SEEKS FUNDING FOR THE ENGINEERING DESIGN TO RENOVATE BIG LAKE BOAT RAMP. THESE IMPROVEMENTS INCLUDE: EXTENDING THE EXISTING BOAT RAMP INTO DEEPER WATER  REPLACING THE EXISTING COURTESY DOCK. THIS DESIGN WHEN IMPLEMENTED WOULD ALLOW FOR BOATS TO ACCESS THE WATERS AT BIG LAKE AT LOWER WATER LEVELS

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO OPERATE AND MAINTAIN 34 TIDAL BOATING AND FISHING ACCESS AREAS OWNED OR COOPERATIVELY MANAGED BY THE DELAWARE DNREC DIVISION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE ROUTINE INSPECTION AND MINOR REPAIRS OF ALL FACILITIES INCLUDING BOAT RAMPS, DOCKS, FISHING PIERS, PARKING AREAS AND ACCESS ROADS AS WELL AS GENERAL GROUNDS MAINTENANCE INCLUDING GRASS CUTTING, TRASH REMOVAL AND SIGN MAINTENANCE. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE KEEPING THESE AREAS OPEN AND SAFE FOR PUBLIC USERS PARTICIPATING IN BOATING AND FISHING ACTIVITIES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE ALL MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC WHO PARTAKE IN RECREATIONAL BOATING AND FISHING ACTIVITIES ON TIDAL WATERS THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF DELAWARE. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THIS GRANT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO OPERATE AND MAINTAIN SIX HATCHERY FACILITIES TO PRODUCE TROUT AND SALMON TO MEET FISHERIES MANAGEMENT NEEDS IN NEW HAMPSHIRE, AND SUPPORT ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES STATEWIDE. NEARLY A MILLION TROUT AND SALMON ARE STOCKED ANNUALLY TO MEET MANAGEMENT GOALS FOR SPECIFIED WATERS IN NEW HAMPSHIRE. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE ACQUISITION, PROPAGATION, AND CULTURE OF THE APPROPRIATE SPECIES, SIZE AND NUMBERS OF FISH SPECIFIED IN THE MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR CULTURED FISH, FISH HEALTH TESTING, STOCKING WATERBODIES ACCORDING TO PLAN, TRAINING OF HATCHERY STAFF, FACILITIES MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR, AND HATCHERY SYSTEM ADMINISTRATION EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE IMPROVED ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES FOR RESIDENTS AND VISITORS TO THE STATE BY SUPPLEMENTING FRESHWATER SPORT FISH RESOURCES THAT ARE DEPENDENT ON A HATCHERY PRODUCT, IMPROVED COST EFFECTIVENESS OF OPERATING THE FACILITIES, AND THE ABILITY TO MEET FEDERAL AND STATE STANDARDS REGULATING FISH CULTURE FACILITIES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE PUBLIC, WHICH WILL BENEFIT FROM APPROPRIATE MANAGEMENT OF STATE FISHERY RESOURCES, AND RECREATIONAL ANGERS IN PARTICULAR WHO WILL BENEFIT FROM ENHANCED OPPORTUNITY FOR CATCHABLE SIZE TROUT AND SALMON. THERE ARE NO ANTICIPATED SUBRECIPIENTS PREFORMING WORK UNDER THIS AWARD.

THE GEORGIA MARINE AQUATIC EDUCATION PROGRAM HAS FOUR OBJECTIVES: 1) TO ENHANCE STEWARDSHIP OF MARINE SPORT FISH POPULATIONS AND THEIR HABITATS  2) TO EDUCATE ANGLERS ABOUT THEIR ROLE AS MANAGERS OF MARINE RECREATIONAL FISHERIES  3) TO EDUCATE THE GENERAL PUBLIC AND ANGLERS ABOUT THE ECOLOGY OF FISH SPECIES POPULAR WITH GEORGIA S MARINE RECREATIONAL ANGLERS  AND 4) TO PROMOTE ETHICAL ANGLING AND INTEREST IN MARINE RECREATIONAL ANGLING.

THIS PROJECT IS BEING UNDERTAKEN FOR THE MAINTENANCE AND OPERATION OF 11 DAMS AND LAKES PROPERTIES LOCATED AROUND THE STATE AND ARE EITHER OWNED OR CONTROLLED BY THE STATE GAME COMMISSION. DAMS ON THESE PROPERTIES NEED TO BE MAINTAINED TO SUPPORT RECREATIONAL BOATING OR WATERFOWL MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES. DAMS ARE REQUIRED TO MEET STATE AND FEDERAL REGULATIONS RELATED TO WOODY VEGETATION REMOVAL, RODENT CONTROL, EROSION CONTROL AND SPECIFIC OPERATIONAL CONTROLS TO SAFEGUARD PUBLIC SAFETY WHICH DRIVESMOST OF THE MAINTENANCE AND OPERATIONAL COSTS.

BOATING ACCESS FUNDS PROVIDE OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF SPECIFIC MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES AT ABOUT 450 WDFW MANAGED WATER ACCESS AREAS, INCLUDING MAINTENANCE OF BOAT LAUNCHING RAMPS, VAULT TOILETS, PARKING AREAS, SIGNAGE, BOUNDARY FENCES, GATES, AND ACCESS ROADS  TOILET PUMPING  LITTER REMOVAL AND DUMP FEES  AND VEGETATION MANAGEMENT. WDFW MAY INCREASE MAINTENANCE CAPACITY THROUGH THE USE OF SEASONAL WORKERS AND OR SUPERVISED DEPARTMENT OF CORRECTIONS PRISON CREWS.

THE STATE OF NEVADA OPERATES AND MAINTAINS FOUR FISH CULTURAL FACILITIES LOCATED STRATEGICALLY AROUND THE STATE. TROUT PRODUCED AT THESE FACILITIES ARE AN INTEGRAL PART OF THE FISHERY MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS OF OVER 150 LAKES, RESERVOIRS, RIVERS AND STREAMS. MOST ANGLERS IN NEVADA FISH FOR HATCHERY PRODUCED RAINBOW, BROWN, CUTTHROAT, TIGER AND HYBRID TROUT. THE MOST HEAVILY FISHED WATERS IN NEVADA EITHER DO NOT PROVIDE CONDITIONS SUITABLE FOR NATURAL REPRODUCTION OR DO NOT PRODUCE TROUT POPULATIONS ADEQUATE TO MEET ANGLING DEMAND. TO MEET THIS DEMAND THE STATE MUST MAINTAIN A TROUT PRODUCTION AND STOCKING PROGRAM THAT WILL PROVIDE AT LEAST 900,000 HATCHERY REARED TROUT ON AN ANNUAL PRODUCTION CYCLE. TO ENSURE THAT EACH FACILITY IS BEING USED IN AN EFFICIENT MANNER CONSIDERING ITS LOCATION, ENVIRONMENT AND PHYSICAL CONSTRAINTS, IT IS NECESSARY TO MONITOR EACH FACILITY IN A VARIETY OF BENCHMARKS BOTH BIOLOGICAL AND ECONOMICAL. THESE BENCHMARKS ARE THEN USED TO CONTINUALLY MONITOR, ASSESS AND IMPROVE (IF NECESSARY) THE HATCHERY PROGRAM TO ENSURE THAT EACH FACILITY IS PERFORMING AT OPTIMAL EFFICIENCY AND TO SATISFY THE DEMAND OF LICENSED ANGLERS FOR A QUALITY FISHING EXPERIENCE.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES BY CREATING, PROTECTING, MAINTAINING,ENHANCING, AND CONSERVING SPORT FISHERIES AROUND THE STATE. THE STATE OF NEVADA RECOGNIZES THE VALUE OF WILDLIFEFOR AESTHETICS, RECREATIONAL, AND ECONOMIC ASPECTS AND GIVES THE DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AUTHORITY TO ADMINISTERLAWS FOR PRESERVATION, PROTECTION, MANAGEMENT, AND RESTORATION OF STATE WILDLIFE. THE FISHERIES DIVISION, UNDERTHE GUIDANCE OF COMMISSION POLICY P-33, HAS THE RESPONSIBILITY OF MANAGING SPORT FISHES AND NATIVE SPORT FISHESOF THE STATE UNDER THE PROVISIONS OF THE DINGELL-JOHNSON ACT (SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM). PROGRAMS AREDEVELOPED TO INCREASE TECHNICAL KNOWLEDGE FOR MAKING SPORT FISH MANAGEMENT DECISIONS, IMPROVING ANGLERSATISFACTION, AND ENSURING CONSERVATION NEEDS. THIS INVOLVES ASSESSING FISH STOCKS, HABITAT, AND ANGLER USE FROMPOSSIBLE CHANGES. RESEARCH AND MONITORING RESULTS ARE USED TO MAKE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS FOR ESCALATING ANGLERSUCCESS, SATISFACTION, AND USE, AND FOR CONSERVING FISH POPULATIONS AND AQUATIC HABITAT. SPECIFICALLY, THEMONITORING AND EVALUATION OF FISHERY POPULATIONS AND HABITATS ALLOW NDOW TO DEVELOP APPROPRIATE STOCKINGRECOMMENDATIONS, INFORM FISHING REGULATION CHANGES AND TAKE OTHER ACTIONS SUCH AS HABITAT RESTORATION TO ENHANCESPORT FISH OPPORTUNITIES. THE OVERALL PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS TO PROMOTE, SUSTAIN AND ENHANCE RECREATIONALSPORT FISH POPULATIONS AND PROVIDE INCREASED ANGLING SATISFACTION AND OPPORTUNITY. RECEIVING FEDERAL AID IN SPORTFISH RESTORATION ENABLES THE AGENCY TO FULFILL ITS MISSION TO PROTECT, CONSERVE, MANAGE, AND RESTORE WILDLIFE ANDITS HABITAT FOR AESTHETIC, SCIENTIFIC, EDUCATIONAL, RECREATIONAL, AND ECONOMIC BENEFITS TO CITIZENS OF THE STATEAND UNITED STATES.

THE CENTRAL CALIFORNIA COAST SPORT FISHERIES ASSESSMENT AND HABITAT ENHANCEMENT PROJECT IS PART OF THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) CENTRAL REGION S (REGION 4) COASTAL FISHERIES MANAGEMENT PROGRAM. IN 2021 THE PROJECT S NAME WAS UPDATED FROM  CENTRAL COAST FISH PASSAGE, STREAM AND LAKE HABITAT IMPROVEMENT  TO  CENTRAL CALIFORNIA COAST SPORT FISHERIES ASSESSMENT AND HABITAT ENHANCEMENT PROJECT  TO BETTER REFLECT THE WORK BEING IMPLEMENTED. THIS PROJECT IS COMPRISED OF ONE ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTIST AT 28  TIME TO MANAGE GRANT, DRAFT REPORTS, LEAD FIELD STAFF CONDUCTING SPORT FISH ASSESSMENTS AND ANGLER SURVEYS AND TWO FULL-TIME SCIENTIFIC AIDS TO ASSIST CDFW BIOLOGISTS WITH SPORT FISH POPULATION AND HABITAT ASSESSMENTS, SERVICING, AND MAINTENANCE OF ANGLER SURVEY BOXES (ASB), CONDUCTING CREEL SURVEYS ON SPORT FISH STREAMS IN SAN LUIS OBISPO, MONTEREY, AND SAN BENITO COUNTIES, CALIFORNIA. THE PRIMARY SPORT FISHING OPPORTUNITIES IN PROJECT AREA ARE FOR WARM WATER SPECIES IN RESERVOIRS, STOCKED TROUT IN RESERVOIRS AND ONE NON-ANADROMOUS STREAM (UPPER NACIMIENTO RIVER), AND SOUTH-CENTRAL CALIFORNIA COAST STEELHEAD (STEELHEAD, ONCORHYNCHUS MYKISS) ALONG COASTAL STREAMS WEST OF STATE ROUTE 1 AND A LIMITED NUMBER OF STREAMS WITH STEELHEAD ANGLING ACCESS EAST OF STATE ROUTE 1. HISTORICALLY, THIS GRANT HAS FOCUSED MUCH OF THE WORK ON WARM WATER HABITAT ENHANCEMENT BY CREATING AND MAINTAINING THOUSANDS OF HABITAT STRUCTURES IN PROJECT AREA RESERVOIRS THAT CONCENTRATE WARM WATER FISH TO INCREASE SUCCESSFUL ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES. BECAUSE THERE ALREADY EXISTS MANY WARM WATER SPORT FISHING OPPORTUNITIES IN THE PROJECT AREA, THIS GRANT IS SHIFTING FOCUS TO INVESTIGATING THE STEELHEAD RECREATIONAL SPORT FISHERY, INCLUDING ASSESSMENTS OF ANGLING, STEELHEAD POPULATION, AND HABITAT STATUS AND TRENDS. THIS WILL PROVIDE MUCH NEEDED INFORMATION TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE EXISTING STEELHEAD SPORT FISHERY AND TO POTENTIALLY DEVELOP NEW OPPORTUNITIES IN THE PROJECT AREA THAT WILL BENEFIT THE STEELHEAD SPORT FISHERY ANGLERS. THIS GRANT WILL ALSO MANAGE THE PROJECT AREAS ASB S ON THE SALINAS RIVER ESTUARY, CARMEL RIVER, BIG SUR RIVER, ARROYO DE LA CRUZ CREEK, SAN SIMEON CREEK DURING STEELHEAD SEASON AND THE UPPER CARMEL AND UPPER NACIMIENTO RIVERS DURING TROUT SEASON. THIS INFORMATION WILL BE USED TO ASSESS THE ANGLER SUCCESS RATE, CATCH PER UNIT EFFORT, AND ANGLER SATISFACTION TO HELP FISHERIES MANAGERS BETTER MANAGE THE SPORT FISHERY AND PROVIDE BETTER FISHING OPPORTUNITIES TO BENEFIT ANGLERS. HISTORICALLY, SEVERAL STREAMS IN PROJECT AREA SUPPORTED HEALTHY STEELHEAD RUNS AND A ROBUST STEELHEAD SPORT FISHERY. THESE ONCE-HEALTHY STEELHEAD POPULATIONS HAVE SIGNIFICANTLY DECLINED DUE TO CONSTRUCTION OF DAMS ON SOME OF THESE HISTORIC STEELHEAD STREAMS, URBANIZATION, SURFACE, AND GROUND WATER DIVERSIONS, AND SPAWNING AND REARING HABITAT DEGRADATION LOSS. IN 1997, NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) FISHERIES DESIGNATED THE SOUTH-CENTRAL CALIFORNIA COAST STEELHEAD DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENT AS A  THREATENED  SPECIES UNDER THE U.S. ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT OF 1973 (ESA) NATIONAL MARINE FISHERIES SERVICE (NMFS, 2013). CURRENTLY, THERE ARE LIMITED CATCH-AND-RELEASE SPORT FISHING OPPORTUNITIES ALONG THE PROJECT AREA COASTAL STREAMS WEST OF STATE ROUTE 1 WITH LIMITED STREAMS OPEN TO ANGLING UPSTREAM OF STATE ROUTE 1. THIS GRANT WILL PROVIDE THE NECESSARY FUNDING TO ASSESS AND MANAGE THE STEELHEAD SPORT FISHING RESOURCES IN PROJECT AREA.

WHITE SEABASS (ATRACTOSCION NOBILIS) HAS BEEN A POPULAR SPORT FISH IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA FOR OVER A CENTURY. DUE TO CONCERNS OVER THE DECLINE OF WHITE SEABASS LANDINGS IN THE MID-LATE 1900 S, THE CALIFORNIA LEGISLATURE ESTABLISHED THE OCEAN RESOURCES ENHANCEMENT AND HATCHERY PROGRAM (OREHP) IN 1983, UNDER CALIFORNIA FISH AND GAME CODE, SECTION 6590, ET. SEQ. THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THE OREHP WAS TO CONDUCT BASIC AND APPLIED RESEARCH INTO THE ARTIFICIAL PROPAGATION, REARING, AND STOCKING OF IMPORTANT MARINE FINFISH SPECIES OCCURRING IN OCEAN WATERS OFF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA. OVER THE YEARS, THE LEGISLATURE HAS AMENDED THE INTENT LANGUAGE OF THE PROGRAM. CURRENT LEGISLATION FOCUSES ON ADVANCING RESEARCH IN DETERMINING IF HATCHERY RELEASED FISH CAN ENHANCE IMPORTANT RECREATIONAL AND COMMERCIAL SPECIES THROUGH INCREASED PRODUCTION OF FISH AND INCREASED MONITORING OF FISHERIES TO ASSESS THE HATCHERY CONTRIBUTION. THE GOAL OF THE LEGISLATION IS TO ENHANCE POPULATIONS OF MARINE FINFISH SPECIES IMPORTANT TO CALIFORNIA FOR THEIR SPORT AND COMMERCIAL FISHING VALUE. WHITE SEABASS HAS BEEN THE FOCUS OF THIS RESEARCH SINCE 1990.THE DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) ADMINISTERS THE OREHP, WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF A 10-MEMBER OCEAN RESOURCES ENHANCEMENT ADVISORY PANEL (OREAP). THE OREAP CONSISTS OF ACADEMIC AND MANAGEMENT AGENCY SCIENTISTS, REPRESENTATIVES OF BOTH COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL FISHING GROUPS, THE AQUACULTURE INDUSTRY, AND NON-GOVERNMENT ORGANIZATION INTERESTS. CDFW ALSO EMPLOYS A RESEARCH SCIENTIST (FISH PATHOLOGIST) TO INVESTIGATE AND MANAGE DISEASE ISSUES WITH THE OREHP.CDFW S MAIN CONTRACTOR IS HUBBS-SEAWORLD RESEARCH INSTITUTE (HSWRI). HSWRI OWNS AND OPERATES THE MARINE FISH HATCHERY (LEON RAYMOND HUBBARD, JR., MARINE FISH HATCHERY). HSWRI HAS DEVELOPED THE CULTURE PROTOCOLS REQUIRED FOR THE PROGRAM AND ASSESSMENT TECHNIQUES REQUIRED TO EVALUATE THE IMPACT OF HATCHERY-REARED FISH ON THE WILD FISHERY. THE PRIMARY FUNCTION OF THE HATCHERY IS TO PROVIDE JUVENILE WHITE SEABASS TO GROWOUT FACILITIES OPERATED BY VOLUNTEER ORGANIZATIONS AND HSWRI. THE HATCHERY CAN PRODUCE SEVERAL MILLION JUVENILE WHITE SEABASS ANNUALLY  HOWEVER, CURRENT RELEASE GOALS ARE SET AT UP TO 350,000 JUVENILE WHITE SEABASS PER YEAR. SPECIFIC RELEASE GOALS ARE BASED ON THE NUMBER OF ADULT BROODSTOCK FISH AVAILABLE AND THE POTENTIAL GENETIC IMPACT OF HATCHERY RELEASES ON WILD WHITE SEABASS STOCKS.IN ADDITION TO HSWRI, THE OREHP RECEIVES CONSIDERABLE SUPPORT (5,000  HOURS PER YEAR) FROM VOLUNTEERS, PRIMARILY RECREATIONAL ANGLER AND EDUCATIONAL GROUPS, WHO OWN AND OPERATE ELEVEN GROWOUT FACILITIES IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA. THESE GROWOUT FACILITIES PROVIDE A COST-EFFECTIVE WAY TO INCREASE POST-RELEASE SURVIVAL RATE BY RELEASING LARGER WHITE SEABASS.IN 2017, CALIFORNIA SEA GRANT (CASG) COMPLETED A MULTI-YEAR EVALUATION OF THE OREHP TO DETERMINE IF THE PROGRAM HAS BEEN A SUCCESSFUL AND COST-EFFECTIVE TOOL FOR WHITE SEABASS ENHANCEMENT AND MANAGEMENT. WITH GUIDANCE FROM CDFW, CASG CREATED A 9-MEMBER SCIENCE ADVISORY COMMITTEE, COMPRISED OF SCIENTISTS FROM AROUND THE COUNTRY WHO WERE RESPONSIBLE FOR EVALUATING THE PROGRAM. THE EVALUATION REPORT (CASG 2017) CONCLUDED THAT WHILE THE OREHP HAS SIGNIFICANTLY CONTRIBUTED TO THE SCIENTIFIC UNDERSTANDING OF MARINE ENHANCEMENT SCIENCE, IT HAS NOT SUBSTANTIALLY INCREASED THE ABUNDANCE OF LEGAL-SIZED WHITE SEABASS, RESULTING IN LESS THAN ONE PERCENT CONTRIBUTION TO RECREATIONAL AND COMMERCIAL FISHERIES CATCHES.

BOATING PARTICIPATION CONTINUES TO EXPAND IN UTAH. IN ORDER TO KEEP UP WITH DEMAND, UTAH DIVISION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES HAS WORKED WITH THE WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION BOATER ACCESS PROGRAM AND STATE PARTNERS TO INVEST NEARLY  1.3 MILLION ANNUALLY TOWARD BOATING INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT AND MAINTENANCE EFFORTS OVER THE PAST 30 YEARS. PROVIDING SATISFYING BOATING EXPERIENCES AND HEADING OFF DEFERRED MAINTENANCE ARE CRITICAL STRATEGIC OBJECTIVES NECESSARY TO MAINTAINING OR AUGMENTING EXISTING BOATER PARTICIPATION RATES. IN ORDER TO PROVIDE BOATERS WITH SATISFYING EXPERIENCES, UDWR IS PROPOSING THE DEVELOPMENT OF A BOAT UTAH MOBILE APPLICATION AND DATABASE THAT (1) ALLOWS BOATERS TO PLAN TRIPS IN A MANNER THAT MEETS EXPECTATIONS AND (2) ALLOWS BOATERS TO SHARE THEIR SATISFACTION RATINGS WITH BOATING ACCESS DURING THEIR CURRENT TRIP PUBLICLY. ADDITIONALLY, UDWR IS PROPOSING THAT THIS TRIP PLANNER BE RELATED WITH A DEVELOPED INFRASTRUCTURE DATABASE WHERE UDWR AND PARTNER PERSONNEL CAN INVENTORY AND ASSESS CONDITION OF EXISTING BOATER ACCESS INFRASTRUCTURE ACROSS UTAH  ALLOWING FOR APPROPRIATE ANNUAL INVESTMENT IN BOATER INFRASTRUCTURE MAINTENANCE NEEDS AT A STATEWIDE SCALE.USERS OF THE MAP-DRIVEN MOBILE APPLICATION WILL BE ABLE TO QUERY POSSIBLE BOATING DESTINATIONS BY ACTIVITY, FACILITY, LOCATION AND VISITATION. BOATERS USING THE APPLICATION WILL BE ABLE TO UPLOAD REAL-TIME INFORMATION REGARDING CURRENT CONDITIONS AND BE ABLE TO VIEW OTHER REVIEWS TO AID THEM IN THEIR CHOICE OF DESTINATION. MANAGERS WILL ALSO POPULATE THE DATABASE WITH INFORMATION FOR INSTALLED COMPONENTS AT PARTICULAR SITES. FOR EXAMPLE, MANAGERS WILL BE CAPABLE OF CREATING NEW INFRASTRUCTURE ENTRIES AND IDENTIFYING THE DATE OF INSTALLATION AND ESTIMATED USEFUL LIFE FOR THE INSTALL. THESE INFRASTRUCTURE ENTRIES WILL POPULATE FACILITY DATA FOR BOATER QUERIES WHILE CREATING AN INVENTORY OF BOATER INFRASTRUCTURE ACROSS UTAH. THE INVENTORY, AND ASSOCIATED INSTALL DATE AND ESTIMATED USEFUL LIFE DATA, WILL BE USED TO DEVELOP A REPLACEMENT CALENDAR AND CALCULATE ESTIMATED ANNUAL MAINTENANCE REPLACEMENT COSTS. THESE COSTS WILL BE BALANCED WITH INSTALLATION OF NEW BOATER ACCESS INFRASTRUCTURE TO AVOID DEFERRED MAINTENANCE ISSUES.

THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO ESTIMATE PREVALENCE OF BACTERIAL DISEASE (MYCOBACTERIOSIS) IN THESTRIPED BASS MORONE SAXATILIS POPULATION RESIDENT TO CHESAPEAKE BAY, AND TO SUPPORT THEINVESTIGATION OF FISH HEALTH EVENTS IN MARYLAND WATERS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDEOPERATION OF A HOOK AND LINE SURVEY TO DIAGNOSE DISEASE IN STRIPED BASS BASED ON GROSS ANDHISTOPATHOLOGICAL EXAMINATION OF TISSUES, AND IMPLEMENT GENERAL DIAGNOSTIC PATHOLOGY SERVICES TOINVESTIGATE THE CAUSE OF FISH DISEASE OR MORTALITY EVENTS INVOLVING OTHER SPECIES. EXPECTEDOUTCOMES INCLUDE THE MAINTENANCE OF HEALTHY, SUSTAINABLE FISH POPULATIONS AND A MORE INFORMEDRESOURCE MANAGEMENT AND GENERAL PUBLIC ON NATURAL RESOURCE HEALTH ISSUES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIESARE THE GENERAL PUBLIC WHO USE AND APPRECIATE HEALTHY FISH POPULATIONS, AND MULTIPLE SEGMENTS OFTHE MARYLAND ECONOMY THAT DEPEND ON THE ECONOMIC BENEFITS OF A HEALTHY FISHERY. THERE ARE NOSUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

THE FOLLOWING PROPOSAL, CHESAPEAKE BAY FINFISH INVESTIGATIONS, F-61-R-19,2023  2024, IS A CONTINUATION OF WORK PROPOSED AND DESCRIBED IN THE CHESAPEAKE BAY FINFISHINVESTIGATIONS, F-61-R-18 PROPOSAL, 2022 - 2023. THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THE CHESAPEAKE BAYFINFISH INVESTIGATIONS SURVEY IS TO MONITOR AND BIOLOGICALLY CHARACTERIZE RESIDENT AND MIGRATORYFINFISH SPECIES IN THE MARYLAND PORTION OF THE CHESAPEAKE BAY. THIS SURVEY WILL CONTINUE TOPROVIDE INFORMATION REGARDING RELATIVE ABUNDANCE, AGE AND SIZE STRUCTURE, RECRUITMENT, GROWTH,MORTALITY, AND MIGRATION PATTERNS OF FINFISH POPULATIONS IN MARYLANDS CHESAPEAKE BAY. THE DATAGENERATED WILL BE UTILIZED IN BOTH INTRASTATE AND INTERSTATE MANAGEMENT PROCESSES AND PROVIDES AREFERENCE POINT FOR FUTURE FISHERIES MANAGEMENT CONSIDERATIONS. NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO PROMOTE SPORTFISHING, PROTECT FRESHWATER NATURAL RESOURCES, AND USE SCIENCE BASED METHODS TO MANAGE RECREATIONAL FISHERIES IN FRESHWATER IMPOUNDMENTS, RIVERS, AND STREAMS THROUGHOUT MARYLAND. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE FISH POPULATION MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT, HABITAT ASSESSMENT, ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW OF PROJECTS THAT MAY IMPACT AQUATIC RESOURCES, OUTREACH AND EDUCATION, AND INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE CONSERVING AQUATIC RESOURCES FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS, MAINTAINING STABLE AQUATIC HABITAT, PROVIDING DIVERSE FISHING EXPERIENCES FOR ANGLERS, AND PROTECTING RESIDENT FISH SPECIES FROM THE IMPACTS OF INVASIVE FISH SPECIES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC THAT PARTICIPATE IN FISHING ACTIVITIES AND ENJOY AQUATIC RESOURCES THROUGHOUT MARYLAND. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO RESTORE AMERICAN SHAD AND HICKORY SHAD IN THE CHOPTANK AND PATAPSCORIVERS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE USING HATCHERY STOCKING AT THE LARVAL AND JUVENILE LIFESTAGES TO PROVIDE ADULT SPAWNERS THAT WILL PRODUCE SELF-SUSTAINING POPULATIONS IN THE TARGETTRIBUTARIES. WE ASSESS BOTH THE JUVENILE AND ADULT POPULATIONS TO ESTIMATE CONTRIBUTION OF HATCHERYFISH, JUVENILE SURVIVAL AND MONITOR RECOVERY OF NATURALLY PRODUCED STOCKS. EXPECTED OUTCOMESINCLUDE HATCHERY INPUTS INTENDED TO PROVIDE ADULT SPAWNERS THAT WILL PRODUCE SELF-SUSTAININGPOPULATIONS IN THE TARGET TRIBUTARIES. THESE STOCKED FISH HAVE TREMENDOUS VALUE FOR STOCKASSESSMENT PURPOSES AT THE LARVAL, JUVENILE AND ADULT LIFE STAGES SINCE ALL STOCKED SHAD RECEIVE ANOXYTETRACYCLINE OTOLITH MARK. NATURAL SPAWN AND STRIP SPAWN CULTURE TECHNIQUES ALLOW FOR THEPRODUCTION OF LARGE NUMBERS OF LARVAL AND JUVENILE SHAD FOR STOCKING AND ASSESSMENT EFFORTS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE TO RESTORE SHAD STOCKS TO TRIBUTARIES THAT HISTORICALLY SUPPORTED RUNS THATWILL INCREASE FISHING OPPORTUNITIES FOR ANGLERS. RECREATIONAL FISHING THAT TARGETS HICKORY SHADOCCURS IN THE PATUXENT RIVER AND CHOPTANK RIVERS, AND THERE IS ANGLER INTEREST FOR RECREATIONALFISHING OPPORTUNITIES IN THE PATAPSCO RIVER AS WELL. AN INDIRECT BENEFIT OF RESTORING SHADPOPULATIONS TO SELF-SUSTAINABLE LEVELS IS THE INCREASED PREY AVAILABILITY PROVIDED BY BOTH ADULT ANDJUVENILE SHAD FOR LARGER, MORE ECONOMICALLY IMPORTANT RECREATIONAL SPECIES SUCH AS STRIPED BASS,BLUEFISH, AND RED DRUM. NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

LONG-TERM DATA COLLECTION ACTIVITIES ARE IMPORTANT FOR MONITORING FISH POPULATIONS AND ESTIMATING THE EFFECTS OF MANAGEMENT ACTIONS. THE ALABAMA DEPARTMENT OF CONSERVATION MARINE RESOURCES DIVISION (DCNR MRD) HAS USED AND PLANS TO USE IN THE FUTURE SPORT FISH RESTORATION FUNDS TO SAMPLE MARINE FINFISH POPULATIONS. THE DATA COLLECTED USING THESE SAMPLING GEARS SUPPORT STOCK ASSESSMENTS AND MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS WHICH HELP TO CONSERVE RECREATIONALLY IMPORTANT FINFISH STOCKS.HOWEVER, THE USE OF THESE GEARS MAY RESULT IN TAKES OF SPECIES PROTECTED UNDER THE MARINE MAMMALPROTECTION ACT (ACT). THE ACT REQUIRES A PERMIT FROM NOAA FISHERIES TO AUTHORIZE ACTIVITIES THAT MAY RESULT IN TAKES OF PROTECTED SPECIES IDENTIFIED IN THE ACT. DCNR MRD WILL EXECUTE A CONTRACT WITH A COMPANY THAT HAS DEMONSTRATED EXPERIENCE IN COMPLETING.NOAA FISHERIES INCIDENTAL TAKE APPLICATIONS. DCNR MRD STAFF WILL PROVIDE THE CONTRACTOR WITH SAMPLINGDATA PREVIOUSLY COLLECTED USING THE SFR-FUNDED SAMPLING GEARS. THE CONTRACTOR WILL USE THE DATA TO COMPLETE THE INCIDENTAL TAKE APPLICATION AND PROVIDE A DRAFT FOR DCNR MRD REVIEW. ONCE REVIEWED, DCNR MRD WILL SUBMIT THE APPLICATION TO NOAA FISHERIES. THE CONTRACTOR WILL ASSIST DCNR MRD WITH ANY FOLLOW-UP QUESTIONS AND OR DATA ANALYSIS REQUIRED BY NOAA FISHERIES DURING THEIR APPLICATIONREVIEW.

PROJECT 1: THIS PROJECT ASSESSES WATERSHED LAND USE EFFECTS ON RECREATIONALLY IMPORTANT FISHHABITATS AND POPULATIONS IN TIDAL TRIBUTARIES TO CHESAPEAKE BAY. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE DATA COLLECTION,RESEARCH, AND MONITORING OF RECREATIONALLY IMPORTANT SPECIES AND HABITATS. ANADROMOUS SPECIES(AMERICAN SHAD, ALEWIFE, BLUEBACK HERRING, STRIPED BASS) ESTUARINE SPECIES (WHITE PERCH,YELLOW PERCH, BAY ANCHOVY) AND MARINE MIGRANT SPECIES (ATLANTIC MENHADEN AND SPOT), ANDFRESH-TIDAL FORAGE SPECIES (SPOTTAIL SHINER, SILVERY MINNOW, GIZZARD SHAD) ARE TARGET SPECIES.MONITORING MAY TARGET HABITATS IMPORTANT TO EGGS, LARVAE, JUVENILES, OR ADULTS. EXPECTED OUTCOMESINCLUDE HABITAT TARGETS AND THRESHOLDS, RECREATIONAL FISHING STRATEGIES THAT ACCOUNT FOR LAND USE ANDHABITAT CHANGE, AND HABITAT INFORMATION FOR LOCAL AND STATE PLANNING, WATERSHED-BASED CITIZENGROUPS, AND FISHERIES MANAGEMENT NEEDS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE RECREATIONAL FISHERMEN,FISHERIES MANAGERS, LAND PLANNING AGENCIES, AND WATERSHED-BASED CITIZEN GROUPS.PROJECT 2: THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS MULTI-AGENCY HABITAT, MULTISPECIES, AND ECOSYSTEM-BASEDFISHERIES MANAGEMENT EFFORTS. THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS PARTICIPATION IN VARIOUS MULTI-AGENCYRESEARCH, MANAGEMENT, AND COMMUNICATION FORUMS SUPPORTING HABITAT, MULTISPECIES, ANDECOSYSTEM-BASED MANAGEMENT OF RECREATIONALLY IMPORTANT FINFISH SPECIES FOUND IN MARYLAND SCHESAPEAKE BAY AND ATLANTIC COAST. WE WILL WORK WITH RESEARCH INSTITUTIONS AND COUNTY, STATE,AND FEDERAL AGENCIES, STAKEHOLDERS, AND INDUSTRY GROUPS TO COMMUNICATE ABOUT AND MANAGEHABITAT, MULTISPECIES, AND ECOSYSTEM IMPACTS TO RECREATIONAL FISHING. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARERECREATIONAL FISHERMEN, FISHERIES MANAGERS, LAND PLANNING AGENCIES, AND WATERSHED-BASED CITIZENGROUPS.PROJECT 3: THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO DEVELOP SPATIAL DATA TO ASSIST IN CONSERVING PRIORITY FISHHABITAT. VISUALIZATION THROUGH GEOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS OF OVERLAP OF ECOLOGICALSTRESSORS OR THEIR INDICATORS WITH CRITICAL HABITATS AND RECREATIONAL FISHING AREAS IDENTIFY PRIORITYAREAS FOR CONSERVATION, ECOLOGICAL RE-ENGINEERING, AND EMERGING FISHERIES MANAGEMENT PROBLEMS.WE WILL DEVELOP CRITERIA TO DELINEATE CRITICAL FINFISH AND FORAGE HABITAT FOR KEY RECREATIONALSPECIES AND MAP THESE CRITERIA TO PRODUCE A SPATIAL TOOL FOR HABITAT AND FISHERIES MANAGEMENT.THIS INFORMATION WILL ENHANCE ONGOING LAND CONSERVATION EFFORTS BY PROVIDING INFORMATION ONCRITICAL HABITATS FOR RECREATIONAL FISH AND FISHERIES, HELPING TO STREAMLINE PERMIT REVIEWS BYALLOWING REVIEWERS TO USE MAPS TO UNDERSTAND CURRENT HABITAT STATUS SO AREAS WITH THE HIGHESTFISHERIES HABITAT VALUE. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE RECREATIONAL FISHERMEN, FISHERIES MANAGERS,LAND PLANNING AGENCIES, AND WATERSHED-BASED CITIZEN GROUPS.PROJECT 4: FISHERIES MANAGERS AND FISHERMEN WANT PRACTICAL GUIDANCE ON WHAT FORAGE ISIMPORTANT TO RESIDENT STRIPED BASS IN MARYLANDS PORTION OF CHESAPEAKE BAY, HOW ABUNDANT THISFORAGE IS, AND WHETHER IT IS ENOUGH. AN INDEX-BASED APPROACH PROVIDES A LOW COST MEANS TOINTEGRATE FORAGE INTO MARYLAND S RESIDENT STRIPED BASS MANAGEMENT THAT IS TRACTABLE FOR AVAILABLESTAFF. INFORMATION FROM ONGOING FISHING AND BOATING SERVICES MONITORING IS INTEGRATED TO DEVISEFORAGE INDICATORS. A FORAGE INDEX-TO-STRIPED BASS INDEX RATIO (FOR EACH OF FOUR MAJOR FORAGEITEMS) AND PERCENT OF EMPTY STOMACHS OR GRAMS OF ALL FORAGE CONSUMED PER GRAM OF STRIPED BASSIN FALL PROVIDE TRENDS IN SUPPLY RELATIVE TO DEMAND BASED ON RELATIVE ABUNDANCE INDICES AND DIETSAMPLING, RESPECTIVELY. THE PROPORTION OF RESIDENT STRIPED BASS WITHOUT VISIBLE BODY FAT (ACONDITION INDICATOR) AND TRENDS IN RELATIVE SURVIVAL OF SMALL STRIPED BASS DUE TO NATURAL MORTALITYPROVIDED INDICATORS OF WELL-BEING. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE RECREATIONAL FISHERMEN, FISHERIESMANAGERS, AND CITIZEN GROUPS.

VIRGINIA COASTAL WATERS AND THE CHESAPEAKE BAY PLAY A VERY CRITICAL ROLE IN ATLANTIC MARINE FISHERIES IN TERMS OF ECONOMIC,RECREATIONAL, ECOLOGICAL, AND EVEN GEOLOGICAL ASPECTS. MANY MARINE FISH SPECIES ARE NOT ONLY RESIDENTS BUT ALSO USE VIRGINIAAS THEIR WINTER NURSERY HABITATS AND MIGRATION ROUTES (SUCH AS STRIPED BASS (MORONE SAXATILIS), BLACK DRUM (POGONIASCROMIS), BLUEFISH (POMATOMUS SALTATRIX), TAUTOG (TAUTOGA ONITIS), COBIA (RACHYCENTRON CANADUM), ETC). A SOUND FISHERIESMANAGEMENT OF THOSE SPECIES BY THE VIRGINIA MARINE RESOURCES COMMISSION (VMRC) HAS ENHANCED VIRGINIA AND COASTWIDERECREATIONAL AND COMMERCIAL MARINE FISHERIES. STOCK ASSESSMENT MODELS REQUIRE EITHER LONG TIME SERIES OF AGE DATA(SUCH AGE-STRUCTURED MODEL), GROWTH INFORMATION (SUCH AS CATCH-BASED MODEL), OR BOTH. THE VMRC AGEING LAB HAS BEENPROVIDING AGE AND GROWTH INFORMATION OF 14 MARINE FINFISH SPECIES COLLECTED IN CHESAPEAKE BAY AND VIRGINIA WATERS OFATLANTIC TO THE STOCK ASSESSMENTS ALONG THE EAST COAST FOR MORE THAN TWO DECADES. MOREOVER, THE EXPERTISE AND SKILLSDEVELOPED BY THE AGEING LAB HAVE MADE IMPORTANT CONTRIBUTIONS TO COLLECTING, PROCESSING, AND AGEING CALCIFIED STRUCTURES(SUCH AS OTOLITHS AND SCALES) OF MARINE FINFISH SPECIES ALONG THE EAST COAST AND EVEN GULF OF MEXICO. CONTINUING PROVIDINGAGE AND GROWTH DATA COLLECTED IN VIRGINIA WILL CONTINUALLY SUPPORT RELIABLE STOCK ASSESSMENTS, AND FURTHER GREATLY ENHANCESCIENCE-BASED FISHERIES MANAGEMENTS BOTH IN VIRGINIA AND ALONG THE ATLANTIC COAST. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PUBLIC WHO USE THESE RESOURCES. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

PROJECT WILL PROVIDE FISHERY INDEPENDENT RELATIVE ABUNDANCE INDICES, BIOLOGICAL DATA, AND CATCH COMPOSITION DATA FROM MAJOR HARVEST SOURCES OF IMPORTANT RECREATIONAL FINFISH SPECIES IN NORTH CAROLINA. BIOLOGICAL AND ABUNDANCE DATA ARE USED TO EXAMINE LONG TERM POPULATION TRENDS, IMPROVE BYCATCH ESTIMATES, EVALUATE MANAGEMENT MEASURES, EVALUATE HABITAT USAGE, AND IMPROVE STOCK ASSESSMENTS. INCLUSION OF THE DATA IN STOCK ASSESSMENTS AND FISHERY MANAGEMENT PLANS (FMPS) PROVIDES FOR MORE EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF RECREATIONALLY IMPORTANT FINFISH SPECIES.

THE GEORGIA MARINE RECREATIONAL FISHERIES AND SURVEYS PROGRAM IS TASKED TO COLLECT, ANALYZE AND REPORT BIOLOGICAL AND FISHERIES INFORMATION TO DESCRIBE THE CONDITIONS OR HEALTH OF RECREATIONALLY IMPORTANT FINFISH POPULATIONS AND DEVELOP MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS THAT WOULD MAINTAIN OR RESTORE THE STOCKS.

THE CITY OF KODIAK (CITY) IS SITUATED ON THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF KODIAK ISLAND IN THE GULF OF ALASKA, SOUTH OF ANCHORAGE AND EAST OF THE ALASKA PENINSULA (FIGURE 1). THE KODIAK FISHING PORT IS THE LARGEST IN THE STATE AND RANKS AMONG THE TOP IN THE COUNTRY. KODIAK OFFERS A YEAR-ROUND ICE-FREE HARBOR AND AN OPPORTUNITY TO FISH FOR FIVE SPECIES OF PACIFIC SALMON, ESPECIALLY THE PRIZED KING SALMON, AS WELL AS HALIBUT, ROCKFISH, AND MANY OTHER MARINE FISH SPECIES.RECREATIONAL BOATERS CURRENTLY USE TWO BOAT RAMPS LOCATED IN THE CITY OF KODIAK TO LAUNCH AND RETRIEVE TRAILER-ABLE BOATS. ONE AT ST. PAUL BOAT HARBOR LOCATED IN DOWNTOWN AND ONE AT ST. HERMAN HARBOR LOCATED ON NEAR ISLAND. ST. PAUL IS A MUCH SMALLER FACILITY WITH LIMITED ACCESS DUE TO ACCESSIBILITY AT LOW TIDE. ST. HERMAN IS A BUSY HARBOR THAT CAN REQUIRE LONG WAITING PERIODS TO ACCESS THE BOAT RAMP DURING PEAK TIMES AS IT HAS TWO PAVED RAMPS WITH WIDER AND LONGER DOCK.DURING 2022, 1266 INDIVIDUAL BOAT LAUNCHES OCCURRED AT THE KODIAK ST. PAUL HARBOR RAMP. THE TOTAL NUMBER OF LAUNCHES TALLIED REPRESENTS A MINIMUM, AS IT DOES NOT INCLUDE BOATERS THAT ARE IN NONCOMPLIANCE WITH THE LAUNCH FEE SCHEDULE OR MULTIPLE LAUNCHES BY SEASON PASS HOLDERS EACH YEAR. THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME (ADF G) STATEWIDE HARVEST SURVEY DATA SUPPORTS THE FACT THAT SPORT ANGLERS CONTRIBUTE SIGNIFICANTLY TO THE MARINE FISHERY. FROM 2017-2021, SPORT ANGLERS FISHING SALTWATER NEAR KODIAK EXPENDED OVER 38,000 ANGLER DAYS OF EFFORT AND HARVESTED APPROXIMATELY 26,498 SALMON AND 47,027 HALIBUT AS WELL AS ROCKFISH AND LINGCOD.FOR MANY YEARS THE CITY HAD ONLY ONE BOAT LAUNCH, LOCATED IN DOWNTOWN KODIAK, THE DATE OF THE LAUNCH RAMP ORIGINAL CONSTRUCTION IS UNCLEAR. THE RAMP IS SHOWN ON EXISTING PROJECT DRAWINGS FOR THE RAMP FLOAT DATED 1979. THE RAMP IS COMPOSED OF PRECAST CONCRETE PLANKS BEARING ON TREATED TIMBERS. SOMETIME AFTER CONSTRUCTION THE JOINTS BETWEEN SEVERAL OF THE CONCRETE PLANKS WERE GROUTED WHICH HAS REDUCED THE FLEXIBILITY BETWEEN A FEW THE PLANKS AND POTENTIALLY LEAD TO INCREASE WEAR IN THE PLANKS DUE TO SETTLEMENT BELOW THE RAMP. THE DAMAGED PLANKS WERE PREVIOUSLY REPAIRED AND OR REPLACED IN 1998, BUT THE RAMP ITSELF IS NOW EXCEEDING ITS USEFUL LIFE EXPECTANCY.SITE INSPECTIONS IN DECEMBER 2020 AND MARCH 2021 DETERMINED THE MAJORITY OF THE CONCRETE PLANKS TO BE WORN AND NO LONGER PROVIDING A SAFE SURFACE FOR VEHICLES WHILE LAUNCHING VESSELS. DUE TO A COMBINATION OF UNDERMINING AT THE BOTTOM OF THE RAMP FROM DREDGING IN THE HARBOR AND THE FAILURE OF THE HOOK AND EYE SYSTEM LINKING THE PLANKS, SEVERAL OF THE BOTTOM PLANKS HAVE ALSO SEPARATED FROM EACH OTHER AND BECOME DISPLACED. THE SEPARATED PLANKS HAVE BECOME A HAZARD AND RESULTED IN MULTIPLE VEHICLES BECOMING STUCK ON THE RAMP DURING USAGE AT LOWER TIDES, THE ISSUE OF THE SEPARATED PLANKS HAS BEEN COMPOUNDED BY EFFECTIVE RAISING OF THE RAMP BY TECTONIC REBOUND THAT HAS CONTINUED FROM THE 1964 GREAT ALASKA EARTHQUAKE. THE ACCOMPANYING FLOAT, ALTHOUGH USABLE, IS WORN AND NARROWER THAN RECOMMENDED BY CURRENT DESIGN STANDARDS.BASED ON THE SITE INSPECTIONS IT WAS RECOMMENDED THAT THE LAUNCH RAMP BE REPLACED BY A NEW CONCRETE PANEL RAMP OF SIMILAR WIDTH (16 FEET WIDE) BUT BE EXTENDED TO IN LENGTH TO BETTER ACCOMMODATE LAUNCHINGS AT LOW TIDE. IT WAS ALSO RECOMMENDED THAT AT THE TIME OF THE RAMP REPLACEMENT THE PILE, ABUTMENTS, AND FLOAT ALSO BE REPLACED. THE FLOAT WOULD BE WIDENED TO 8 FEET WIDE AND WOULD BENEFIT FROM REPLACEMENT BY BEING BROUGHT UP TO AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT GUIDELINES AND IMPROVE USER EXPERIENCES.

MANY FACTORS HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO THE DECLINE OF SPORT FISH POPULATIONS AND FISHING OPPORTUNITIES IN CALIFORNIA. UNDERSTANDING THESE FACTORS AND IDENTIFYING WAYS TO IMPROVE MANAGEMENT OF BOTH RESIDENT AND ANADROMOUS SPORT FISH POPULATIONS IS A CENTRAL FOCUS FOR CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) FISHERIES BIOLOGISTS. THE NORTH CENTRAL REGION (NCR) HABITAT SHOP PROPOSES TO CONTINUE SUPPORTING NCR S FISHERIES PROGRAM IN PROMOTING SPORT FISHING OPPORTUNITIES AND MANAGEMENT OF SPORT FISH POPULATIONS IN THE REGION. HABITAT SHOP PERSONNEL ARE DEDICATED TO DESIGNING, FABRICATING, CREATING, INSTALLING, REPAIRING, AND MAINTAINING THE EQUIPMENT AND INFRASTRUCTURE THAT CDFW RELIES ON TO MONITOR AND MANAGE SPORT FISH POPULATIONS THROUGHOUT THE REGION AND MAINTAIN HABITATS AND HAVE THE UNIQUE SKILLS AND EQUIPMENT NECESSARY TO DO SO. THIS EQUIPMENT AND INFRASTRUCTURE REQUIRE ACTIVE AND ONGOING INSPECTIONS, MONITORING, MAINTENANCE, AND REPAIR.

CALIFORNIA COASTAL (CC) CHINOOK SALMON ARE PART OF AN EEL RIVER CATCH AND RELEASE SPORT FISHERY AND ARE ALSO A COMPONENT OF SEVERAL CHINOOK SALMON POPULATIONS AVAILABLE IN CALIFORNIA S RECREATIONAL OCEAN SALMON FISHERY. THE EEL RIVER S IN-RIVER FISHERY ATTRACTS NUMEROUS ANGLERS AND SUPPORTS VISITOR, TACKLE, AND GUIDE SERVICE INDUSTRIES  SIMILARLY, CALIFORNIA S RECREATIONAL OCEAN SALMON FISHERY IS CONDUCTED FROM PORTS THROUGHOUT THE STATE AND SIGNIFICANTLY CONTRIBUTES TO VISITOR, TACKLE, BOATING, AND CHARTER SERVICE INDUSTRIES. ACCESS TO THE IN-RIVER CHINOOK SALMON AND OCEAN SALMON FISHERY VARIES FROM EASY ACCESS CHARTER AND DRIFT BOATS, DRIVE TO BANK OR PIER ACCESS TO VARYING DEGREES OF REMOTE ACCESS TRAILS AND WADING. CALIFORNIA CHINOOK SALMON POPULATIONS HAVE EXPERIENCED NOTABLE DECLINES IN ABUNDANCE OVER THE LAST 50 YEARS. AS A RESULT OF THESE DECLINES THE CC CHINOOK SALMON EVOLUTIONARILY SIGNIFICANT UNIT (ESU) IS FEDERALLY LISTED AS THREATENED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA). THE CC CHINOOK SALMON ESU HAS A GEOGRAPHIC RANGE WHICH EXTENDS FROM RIVERS AND STREAMS SOUTH OF THE KLAMATH RIVER IN NORTHERN HUMBOLDT COUNTY TO AND INCLUDING THE RUSSIAN RIVER IN SONOMA COUNTY. CALIFORNIA S THIRD LARGEST WATERSHED, THE EEL RIVER, COMPOSES A SIGNIFICANT PROPORTION OF THE OVERALL CC CHINOOK SALMON ESU RANGE AND NATURAL PRODUCTION  HOWEVER, RECENT, AND HISTORICAL EEL RIVER CC CHINOOK SALMON POPULATION DATA ARE LIMITED. WHILE THIS SPECIES IS CAUGHT IN RECREATIONAL AND COMMERCIAL FISHERIES, THE LACK OF DATA HAS MADE IT DIFFICULT TO SUFFICIENTLY DETERMINE POPULATION STATUS AND TREND FOR THIS ESU AND SLOWED THE DEVELOPMENT OF DIRECT FISHERY ASSESSMENT AND ABUNDANCE-BASED FISHERY MANAGEMENT (ABM) (LACY ET AL. 2014). ACCURATE AND COST-EFFICIENT ANNUAL AND LONG-TERM MONITORING OF CC CHINOOK SALMON POPULATION STATUS IS REQUIRED FOR INFORMATION-BASED MANAGEMENT OF CHINOOK SALMON POPULATIONS AND IN-RIVER AND OCEAN RECREATIONAL FISHERIES. THIS PROJECT WILL OPERATE A DUAL FREQUENCY IDENTIFICATION HYDROACOUSTIC SONAR (DIDSON) CAMERA TO MONITOR AND ESTIMATE THE ESCAPEMENT OF EEL RIVER CALIFORNIA COASTAL (CC) CHINOOK SALMON (ONCORHYNCHUS TSHAWYTSCHA) DURING THE FALL AND WINTER OF 2023-2024. THIS PROJECT HAS DEMONSTRATED THAT EVEN IN THE HIGHLY VARIABLE FLOW CONDITIONS (DISCHARGE AND TURBIDITY) THAT CHARACTERIZE THE EEL RIVER DURING THE PERIOD OF SALMON MIGRATION, DIDSON CAMERAS ARE ABLE PROVIDE VALUABLE FISHERIES MOVEMENT AND POPULATION DATA. ENUMERATING THE RUN SIZE OF ADULT CHINOOK SALMON IS A CRITICAL MANAGEMENT COMPONENT FOR CHINOOK SALMON SPORT FISHERIES AND COMMERCIAL FISHERIES IN CALIFORNIA. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECT PROVIDES NEAR REAL-TIME DATA AND RUN SIZE ESTIMATES FOR NORTHERN CALIFORNIA (NC) STEELHEAD (0. MYKISS), AN IMPORTANT IN-RIVER FISHERY IN THE EEL RIVER.

THE IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME (DEPARTMENT) FISH HATCHERY PROGRAM HAS PROVIDED A DIVERSITY OF ANGLINGOPPORTUNITIES TO MEET THE STATES RECREATIONAL FISHERIES DEMANDS SINCE 1907. THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING FOR THECABINET GORGE STATE FISH HATCHERY TO CONTINUE TO HELP MEET THOSE NEEDS. APPROXIMATELY FORTY (40) PERCENT OFIDAHOS SURFACE WATER IS FORMED BY RESERVOIRS THAT LACK ADEQUATE SPAWNING HABITAT FOR NATIVE SPORT FISH. IN ADDITION,MANY OF THE NATURAL LAKES AND STREAMS HAVE REDUCED FISH SPAWNING AREAS DUE TO HABITAT ALTERATIONS. IN ORDER TO UTILIZE THE NATURAL PRODUCTIVITY OF THESE WATERS, AND TO PROVIDE RECREATIONAL FISHING OPPORTUNITIES FOR NEARLY 425,000 ANGLERS, THE STOCKING OF HATCHERY-PRODUCED FISH IS NECESSARY. ACCORDING TO A SURVEY TAKEN IN 2006, ANGLERS SPEND AN ESTIMATED4.4 MILLION DAYS PER YEAR ON WATERS LARGELY SUPPORTED BY IDAHOS FISH STOCKING PROGRAM. RETURNS TO THE ANGLER OF HATCHERY FISH ARE EXPECTED TO BE SIGNIFICANTLY GREATER THAN THE POUNDAGE STOCKED. THE SPECIES DIVERSITY AND FISHING OPPORTUNITY GENERATED BY THIS PROGRAM IS EXPECTED TO MAINTAIN ANGLER SATISFACTION AND PROVIDE MINIMUM CATCH RATES AS DESCRIBED IN THE IDAHO FISHERIES MANAGEMENT PLAN 2019-2024.

IDAHO CONTAINS NEARLY ONE-HALF MILLION ACRES OF LAKES AND RESERVOIRS AND OVER ONE HUNDRED THOUSAND ACRES OF RIVERS AND STREAMS STRETCHING NEARLY THIRTY THOUSAND MILES. THESE DIVERSE WATER RESOURCES PROVIDE IDAHO ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES FOR ABOUT 40 SPECIES OF GAME FISH WHICH ARE PURSUED BY OVER 530,000 LICENSED ANGLERS ANNUALLY. THE IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME FISHERIES PROGRAM IS OBLIGATED TO ENSURE THE STATE S FISHERIES RESOURCES ARE PRESERVED, PROTECTED, PERPETUATED AND MANAGED TO PROVIDE ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES AS APPROPRIATE BASED ON ANGLER PREFERENCES AND THE BIOLOGICAL CAPABILITIES OF THE HABITAT. IT IS ALSO COMMITTED TO CONTINUALLY IMPROVING THE PUBLICS AWARENESS OF SPORT FISHING OPPORTUNITIES AS WELL AS THEIR UNDERSTANDING OF AND INVOLVEMENT IN FISH MANAGEMENT. THIS GRANT PROVIDES THE FUNDING NECESSARY TO ACHIEVE THESE OBJECTIVES AND OBLIGATIONS.

THE IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME (DEPARTMENT) HAS STATE STATUTORY AUTHORITY TO MANAGE ANADROMOUS FISHERIES WITHIN THE STATE OF IDAHO. THIS AUTHORITY INCLUDES MANAGEMENT, RESEARCH, AND HATCHERY ACTIVITIES DESIGNED TO ENHANCE SALMON AND STEELHEAD SURVIVAL IN AND OUT OF STATE, TO PROVIDE SPORT-FISHING OPPORTUNITIES, AND TOCONSERVE ANADROMOUS RESOURCES TO ACHIEVE STATE AND FEDERAL OBJECTIVES.THE PROJECT PROVIDES MANAGEMENT DIRECTION AND COORDINATION FOR ANADROMOUS FISHING AND IMPLEMENTATION OFENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA) RECOVERY ACTIONS FOR SALMON AND STEELHEAD. THE PROJECT PROVIDES INPUT ON OUT OFBASIN ACTIVITIES THAT EFFECT IDAHO SALMON AND STEELHEAD AND COORDINATES AND MANAGES PROCEDURAL AND JURISDICTIONALCONSTRAINTS TO SALMON AND STEELHEAD FISHERIES, SUCH AS SUPERVISING ESA PERMIT IMPLEMENTATION AND COORDINATION FORIN-STATE AND OUT-OF-STATE TREATY AND NONTREATY FISHERIES. THESE COLLECTIVE EFFORTS ENSURE IDAHOS ABILITY TOPROVIDE FISHING OPPORTUNITIES ON HATCHERY FISH WHILE STAYING WITH ESA GUIDELINES RELEVANT TO WILD POPULATIONS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS FOR THE DELAWARE DIVISION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE TO STOCK DESIGNATED TROUT WATERS IN DELAWARE. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE MANAGING THE PURCHASE OF TROUT FROM PRIVATE HATCHERIES AND ORGANIZING THE STOCKINGS INTO DESIGNATED STREAMS AND PONDS. WITH NEW REGULATIONS IN PLACE FOR A YOUTH-ONLY OPENING DAY ON DELAWARE S TROUT PONDS AND STREAMS IN 2023, EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE RECRUITING YOUNG ANGLERS AND RETAINING ADULT TROUT ANGLERS. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THIS ACTION INCLUDE THE RECREATIONAL FISHING COMMUNITY.

VERMONT ANGLER RECRUITMENT, RETENTION AND REACTIVATIONTHIS GRANT FUNDS VERMONT FISH AND WILDLIFES EFFORTS TO INCREASE FISHING PARTICIPATION RATES IN STATE THROUGH RECRUITMENT, RETENTION AND REACTIVATION ACTIVITIES. THE OBJECTIVES OF THE GRANT INCLUDE, IN ADDITION OF INCREASED ANNUAL PARTICIPATION IN ANGLING AND DECREASING ANGLER CHURN RATE, INCREASING ANGLER KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS, IMPROVING ANGLER SUCCESS AND ENJOYMENT, INCREASING PUBLIC SUPPORT AND AWARENESS FOR FISHERIES MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO MAINTAIN AND SUPPLEMENT RECREATIONAL SPORT FISH POPULATIONS OF TROUT AND LANDLOCKED ATLANTIC SALMON TO PROVIDE ENHANCED FRESHWATER FISHING OPPORTUNITIES THROUGHOUT MASSACHUSETTS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDEHATCHERY OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE, FISH REARING, AND FISH STOCKING. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE THE IMPROVEMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF TROUT AND LANDLOCKED SALMON FISHERIES IN MASSACHUSETTS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PUBLIC WHO USE ANDAPPRECIATE THESE NATURAL RESOURCES. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FOR THE COMPLETION OF FISH POPULATION SURVEYS AND INVENTORIES, ANNUAL FISH POPULATION MONITORING, SPORT FISH MANAGEMENT INVESTIGATIONS(INCLUDING HARVEST AND STOCKING EVALUATIONS), HABITAT ENHANCEMENT AND CHEMICAL CONTAMINANT ASSESSMENTS ON THE RIVERS, RESERVOIRS, AND INLAND WATERS OF ILLINOIS. THESE SURVEYS AND INVENTORIES OF ILLINOIS  LAKES AND RIVER BASINS PROVIDE SCIENCE-BASED FISHERIES DATA USED TO INFORM AND SUPPORT RESOURCE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AND PRACTICES. THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES SPECIFIC NEEDS IDENTIFIED IN THE DIVISION OF FISHERIES  RIVERS AND INLAND WATERS SURVEYS AND INVENTORIES PORTION OF THE STRATEGIC PLAN FOR THE CONSERVATION OF ILLINOIS FISHERIES RESOURCES (ILLINOIS DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES). THE DATA COLLECTION AND FISHERIES MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES INCLUDED IN THIS PROJECT ARE NECESSARY TO PROVIDE QUALITY ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE PUBLIC. SPECIFICALLY, THESE ACTIVITIES MAINTAIN THE SUPPLY OF SPORT FISH AND SUSTAIN FISH POPULATIONS IN ILLINOIS  BIG RIVERS, RESERVOIRS, AND INLAND WATERS THAT INCLUDE 1,340 RIVERS AND CREEKS HAVING SUFFICIENT FLOW TO PROVIDE A SPORT FISHERY (APPROXIMATELY 281,800 ACRES) AND 1,300 MANAGED STATE AND PUBLIC IMPOUNDMENTS, INCLUDING THREE LARGE U.S. ARMY CORPS RESERVOIRS (176,000 ACRES). THIS PROJECT ALSO PROVIDES FOR TECHNICAL GUIDANCE AND ASSISTANCE TO STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES, MUNICIPALITIES AND LANDOWNERS REGARDING FISHERIES MANAGEMENT, HABITAT PROTECTION, HABITAT AND WATER QUALITY ENHANCEMENT MEASURES AND RIVER BASIN RESTORATIONS.
