F-10-38 SPORT FISHERIES INVESTIGATIONS IN ALASKA

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE S (CDFW) WILD TROUT PROGRAM, NOW THE HERITAGE AND WILD TROUTPROGRAM (HWTP) WAS ESTABLISHED BY THE CALIFORNIA FISH AND GAME COMMISSION (COMMISSION) IN 1971 TO PROTECT AND ENHANCE QUALITY TROUT FISHERIES SUSTAINED BY NATURAL REPRODUCTION. THE COMMISSION ADOPTED A WILD TROUT POLICY THAT PROVIDES FOR THE DESIGNATION OF  AESTHETICALLY PLEASING AND ENVIRONMENTALLY PRODUCTIVE  STREAMS AND LAKES TO BE MANAGED EXCLUSIVELY FOR WILD TROUT. THE COMMISSION DIRECTED THE CDFW TO STUDY AND IDENTIFY WATERS THAT WOULD PROVIDE QUALITY WILD TROUT ANGLING FOR DESIGNATION AS WILD TROUT WATERS. WILD TROUT POPULATIONS IN DESIGNATED WATERS ARE TO BE MANAGED WITH APPROPRIATE REGULATIONS TO BE  LARGELY UNAFFECTED BY THE ANGLING PROCESS. THE COMMISSION RECOGNIZED THE IMPORTANCE OF HIGH-QUALITY HABITAT FOR THE MAINTENANCE OF WILD TROUT POPULATIONSAND THE WILD TROUT POLICY STATES:  ALL NECESSARY ACTIONS, CONSISTENT WITH STATE LAW, SHALL BE TAKEN TO PREVENTADVERSE IMPACT BY LAND OR WATER DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS AFFECTING DESIGNATED WILD TROUT WATERS.  THE CDFW ISREQUIRED BY COMMISSION POLICY TO PREPARE AND PERIODICALLY UPDATE A MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR EACH WILD TROUT WATER.ADDITIONAL HWTP MANDATES ARE PROVIDED BY THE TROUT AND STEELHEAD CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT PLANNING ACT OF 1979 (SB 192) AND ITS ASSOCIATED UPDATES (SPECIFICALLY SENATE BILL 384). THE CDFW S HWTP CONDUCTS STATEWIDE RESOURCE ASSESSMENT WITH EMPHASIS ON SPECIAL MANAGEMENT WATERS. THESE WATERS INCLUDE RIVERS, STREAMS AND LAKES DESIGNATED AS  WILD TROUT MANAGEMENT AREAS  BY THE COMMISSION. NATURAL RECRUITMENT AND AESTHETIC SURROUNDINGS ARE EMPHASIZED AND NATURAL VALUES ARE PROTECTED.IN 1998, THE COMMISSION EXPANDED ITS WILD TROUT POLICY BY ESTABLISHING THE HERITAGE TROUT PROGRAM (NOWINCORPORATED INTO THE HWTP), SUCH THAT STREAMS OR LAKES FEATURING ONE OR MORE OF THE STATE S NATIVE TROUT, ANDMEETING OTHER SPECIFIC WILD TROUT WATER DESIGNATION CRITERIA, MAY BE DESIGNATED AS HERITAGE TROUT WATERS.HERITAGE TROUT WATERS ARE A SPECIAL SUBSET OF WILD TROUT WATERS TO BE MONITORED AND MANAGED BY THE HWTP. INADDITION, THE MANAGEMENT OF DESIGNATED HERITAGE TROUT WATERS WILL BE GUIDED BY APPROVED DEPARTMENT MANAGEMENT PLANS THAT IDENTIFY ACTIONS AND POLICIES NECESSARY TO PROTECT NATIVE TROUT HABITATS, AND MAINTAIN OR ENHANCE NATIVE TROUT POPULATIONS.SOME NATIVE TROUT POPULATIONS IN CALIFORNIA ARE STATE OR FEDERALLY LISTED AS THREATENED SPECIES OR STATE  SPECIESOF SPECIAL CONCERN  BUT THEY MAY STILL PROVIDE FISHING OPPORTUNITIES AND THE WATERS THEY INHABIT MAY BEDESIGNATED AS HERITAGE TROUT WATERS BY THE COMMISSION. INFORMATION ON THE STATUS OF THESE POPULATIONS IS NEEDED TO ADEQUATELY MANAGE AND RESTORE THESE POPULATIONS, WHILE MAINTAINING ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES WHERE BIOLOGICALLY JUSTIFIABLE.

ANADROMOUS FISH IN CALIFORNIA SUPPORT A MULTIMILLION-DOLLAR SPORT AND COMMERCIAL FISHING INDUSTRY. UNFORTUNATELY, SOME CENTRAL VALLEY (SACRAMENTO-SAN JOAQUIN DELTA AND ITS TRIBUTARIES) SALMON (ONCORHYNCHUS TSHAWYTSCHA), STEELHEAD (ONCORHYNCHUS MYKISS), AND STURGEON (ACIPENSER SPP.) POPULATIONS HAVE DECLINED TO PRECIPITOUSLY LOW LEVELS. POPULATION DECLINES HAVE BEEN LINKED TO VARIOUS FACTORS SUCH AS CONSTRUCTION OF DAMS, WATER DIVERSIONS, AND HABITAT DEGRADATION. SIGNIFICANT ALTERATIONS TO STREAM CHANNELS BEGAN WITH THE CALIFORNIA GOLD RUSH STARTING IN 1849. TODAY, URBAN EXPANSION, AGRICULTURAL AND INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT, AND WATER OPERATIONS CONTINUE TO NEGATIVELY AFFECT THESE POPULATIONS. THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW), AS THE TRUSTEE AGENCY FOR THE STATE S FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES, NOT ONLY MANAGES CATCHABLE STOCKS AND HARVEST OPPORTUNITY BUT ALSO HAS BEEN STEADILY WORKING TO REVERSE POPULATION DECLINES OBSERVED IN CALIFORNIA S ANADROMOUS FISHES. SINCE THE LATE 1980 S SEVERAL STATE AND FEDERAL LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS HAVE SIMILARLY FOCUSED ON REVERSING THESE DECLINES. THESE INCLUDE: THE STATE SALMON, STEELHEAD TROUT, AND ANADROMOUS FISHERIES PROGRAM ACT OF 1988, FEDERAL CENTRAL VALLEY PROJECT IMPROVEMENT ACT OF 1991, AND THE WATER RESOURCES AND DELTA RESTORATION ACT OF 1996. IN 1994, AND INCLUSIVE OF THE PRIOR LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS, THE BAY-DELTA ACCORD SET IN MOTION A MUCH BROADER PROCESS THAT WAS INTENDED TO BALANCE COMPETING DEMANDS AS WELL AS DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A LONG-TERM BAY-DELTA SOLUTION ENCOMPASSING FOUR SIGNIFICANT AREAS: ECOSYSTEM QUALITY, WATER QUALITY, WATER SUPPLY RELIABILITY AND LEVEE SYSTEM INTEGRITY. THE AUGUST 2000 CALFED BAY-DELTA PROGRAM RECORD OF DECISION DISPLAYED THE CONTINUED COMMITMENT TO IMPLEMENT THE CALFED ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION PROGRAM AND THE CALIFORNIA BAY-DELTA ACT OF 2003 ESTABLISHED THE CALIFORNIA BAY-DELTA AUTHORITY AS CALFED S GOVERNANCE STRUCTURE. SUBSEQUENTLY, THE DELTA REFORM ACT OF 2009 AUTHORIZED PLANNING EFFORTS TO ACHIEVE WATER SUPPLY RELIABILITY AND DELTA ECOSYSTEM HEALTH AND MODIFIED THE GOVERNANCE STRUCTURE PREVIOUSLY ESTABLISHED BY THE CALIFORNIA BAY-DELTA AUTHORITY AND CALFED SCIENCE PROGRAM. THERE HAVE ALSO BEEN SEVERAL HABITAT RESTORATION AND SPECIES RECOVERY DOCUMENTS DEVELOPED SINCE THE EARLY 1990S THAT HAVE PROVIDED DIRECTION FOR RESTORATION AND RECOVERY ACTIONS AND AID IN PRIORITIZING ACTIONS. THESE INCLUDE: -RESTORING CENTRAL VALLEY STREAMS: A PLAN FOR ACTION (CDFG 1993) -FINAL RESTORATION PLAN FOR THE ANADROMOUS FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS 1997) -CONSERVATION STRATEGY FOR RESTORATION OF THE SACRAMENTO-SAN JOAQUIN DELTA SACRAMENTO VALLEY AND SAN JOAQUIN VALLEY REGIONS (CDFW 2014) -RECOVERY PLAN FOR SACRAMENTO RIVER WINTER-RUN CHINOOK SALMON, CENTRAL VALLEY SPRING-RUN CHINOOK SALMON, AND CENTRAL VALLEY STEELHEAD NATIONAL MARINE FISHERIES SERVICE (NMFS 2014) -RECOVERY PLAN FOR THE SOUTHERN DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENT OF NORTH AMERICAN GREEN STURGEON (ACIPENSER MEDIROSTRIS) (NMFS 2018) THESE DOCUMENTS PROVIDE BROAD GUIDELINES FOR RESTORATION AND RECOVERY ACTIONS AND ARE CRUCIAL DRIVERS IN CENTRAL VALLEY ANADROMOUS FISHERIES MANAGEMENT IN AN ENVIRONMENT WHERE BOTH LISTED AND CATCHABLE STOCKS CO-OCCUR.

THERE IS A NEED TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT RECREATIONAL MARINE FISHERIES OUTREACH AND EDUCATION PROGRAMS TO HELPMAINTAIN AND ENHANCE THE QUALITY OF MARINE FISHERIES RESOURCES FOR CURRENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS. FLORIDASPOPULATION IS RAPIDLY GROWING AND EXPERIENCED A 1.9  INCREASE FROM 2021 TO 2022. AS MORE PEOPLE MOVE TO FLORIDA,THERE WILL BE INCREASED NUMBERS OF INDIVIDUALS INTERACTING AND IMPACTING MARINE FISHERIES RESOURCES, INCLUDINGANGLERS CAPTURING AND HARVESTING OR RELEASING MARINE FISH. UNLESS INNOVATIVE MARINE FISHERIES OUTREACH ANDEDUCATION STRATEGIES CONTINUE TO BE IMPLEMENTED, THE QUALITY OF MARINE RECREATIONAL FISHERIES AND THE HABITATSTHAT SUPPORT THEM COULD BE SIGNIFICANTLY COMPROMISED.

THE ILLINOIS DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (IDNR) DIVISION OF FISHERIES PROVIDES THE GUIDANCE, GOALS, AND OBJECTIVES TO DIRECT FISHERIES MANAGEMENT IN ILLINOIS INCLUDING THE OVERSIGHT OF 1.6 MILLION ACRES OF WATER. THE FISHERIES AND AQUATIC LIFE MANAGEMENT STATEWIDE OBJECTIVES INCLUDE PROVIDING A DIVERSITY OF QUALITY ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES THROUGH APPROPRIATE MANAGEMENT OF SELF-SUSTAINING FISH POPULATIONS SUPPLEMENTED BY THE JUDICIOUS USE OF HATCHERY-REARED FISH. THE ILLINOIS FISH HATCHERY SYSTEM, WHICH CONSISTS OF 3 HATCHERIES LOCATED STRATEGICALLY THROUGHOUT THE STATE, WAS DESIGNED AND IS OPERATED TO HELP MEET THIS OBJECTIVE. THE FUNCTION OF THE HATCHERY SYSTEM IS TO PRODUCE FISH STOCKS NECESSARY TO RESTORE, ESTABLISH, OR SUSTAIN SPORT FISH POPULATIONS IN LAKES AND RIVERS AND LAKE MICHIGAN IN ORDER TO DIVERSIFY SPORT FISHING OPPORTUNITIES THROUGH SUPPLEMENTAL PRODUCTION AND STOCKING OF HATCHERY REARED FISH. ANOTHER MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVE IS TO PRODUCE HEALTHY FRY AND FINGERLINGS THAT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE FISHERY AND TO PREVENT THE INTRODUCTION AMPLIFICATION, OR SPREAD OF FISH PATHOGENS THAT COULD NEGATIVELY AFFECT THE HEALTH OF BOTH HATCHERY AND NATURALLY REPRODUCING STOCKS. THE PURPOSE OF THE F-121-D GRANT IS TO ANNUALLY MAINTAIN THE ILLINOIS FISH HATCHERY SYSTEM AND ITS OPERATIONS IN ORDER TO PROVIDE FOR THE PROPAGATION AND REARING OF VARIOUS FISH SPECIES TO BE DISTRIBUTED STATEWIDE TO STATE AND PUBLIC WATERS OPEN TO PUBLIC ANGLING. FISH PRODUCED BY THE HATCHERY SYSTEM ARE UTILIZED IN STOCKING OF NEWLY IMPOUNDED OR CHEMICALLY REHABILITATED PUBLIC WATERS, SUPPLEMENTAL STOCKING OF EXISTING FISH POPULATIONS WITH POOR RECRUITMENT, AND ESTABLISHMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF SPORT FISHERIES IN EXISTING WATERS. THE PROJECT OBJECTIVE FOR F-121-D-033 GRANT IS THE PRODUCTION OF UP TO 19 DIFFERENT FISH SPECIES AND THE STOCKING OF OVER 13 MILLION FISH INTO OVER 400 ILLINOIS PUBLIC WATERS. THESE STOCKINGS WILL HELP PROVIDE QUALITY ANGLING DAYS FOR ILLINOIS FISHERMEN AND WOMEN AND ADDRESS THE MISSION OF THE DIVISION OF FISHERIES TO CONSERVE AND ENHANCE THE STATE S FISHERIES AND AQUATIC LIFE RESOURCES. INCREASED ILLINOIS FISHING LICENSE SALES OVER THE PAST SEVERAL YEARS INDICATES THAT THERE IS A CONTINUED NEED FOR THE HATCHERY SYSTEM TO PRODUCE FISH STOCKS TO SUPPLY QUALITY FISHING DAYS FOR THESE ANGLERS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO ENHANCE THE PUBLIC S UNDERSTANDING OF WATER RESOURCES, AQUATIC LIFE FORMS, SPORT FISHING, AND DEVELOP RESPONSIBLE ATTITUDES AND ETHICS TOWARD THE AQUATIC ENVIRONMENT IN SOUTH CAROLINA.

FUNDING FROM THIS GRANT IS USED TO EDUCATE THE PUBLIC REGARDING AQUATIC RESOURCES, TEACH INDIVIDUALS HOW TO FISH, AND INFORM THE PUBLIC ABOUT THE SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM AND SPECIFIC PROJECTS THROUGHOUT LOUISIANA.
THIS GRANT PROVIDES FUNDING FOR THE EVALUATION AND CONTROL OF AQUATIC NUISANCE VEGETATION TO MAINTAIN BOATING ACCESS ON PUBLIC WATERBODIES THROUGHOUT LOUISIANA.

THE EEL RIVER IS CALIFORNIA S THIRD LARGEST WATERSHED AND CONTAINS 398 MILES OF DESIGNATED WILD AND SCENIC RIVERREACHES, THE LARGEST NUMBER OF ALL CALIFORNIA RIVERS. THIS PROJECT PROVIDES CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH ANDWILDLIFE (CDFW) SPORT FISH MANAGEMENT AND POPULATION IMPROVEMENT INFORMATION THROUGH SURVEYS TARGETING THE EELRIVER S RESIDENT STEELHEAD TROUT HABITAT, STEELHEAD POPULATION ABUNDANCE, SPATIAL STRUCTURE AND DIVERSITY. THISMONITORING WORK IS SITUATED IN THE MOUNTAINOUS INTERIOR REGION OF THE EEL RIVER AND TRIBUTARIES. NOTABLE FOR ALACK OF URBANIZATION AND EXTENSIVE AGRICULTURAL CULTIVATION, THIS AREA INCLUDES SEVERAL DESIGNATED WILDERNESSAREAS, AND WILD AND SCENIC RIVER REACHES. THIS RUGGED AND REMOTE LANDSCAPE PROVIDES UNIQUE SPORTFISHINGOPPORTUNITY THROUGH A DIVERSITY OF LANDSCAPES PROVIDING BOTH ADVENTURE AND SOLITUDE. ADDITIONALLY, THE ABSENCEOF EXTENSIVE URBANIZATION AND INTENSIVE AGRICULTURE OFFERS INCREASED OPPORTUNITY TO RESTORE AND ENHANCE ECOSYSTEMPROCESSES CRITICAL TO SUPPORTING ROBUST SALMON AND STEELHEAD POPULATIONS. THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS CDFW SPORTFISHERY MANAGEMENT NEEDS INCLUDING EEL RIVER CATCH AND RELEASE ANADROMOUS STEELHEAD TROUT FISHERIES AND RESIDENTRAINBOW TROUT FISHERY. THE IN-RIVER BANK AND DRIFT BOAT STEELHEAD TROUT FISHERIES, AND THE AREAS LAKE AND STREAMTROUT FISHERIES, ATTRACT NUMEROUS ANGLERS AND SUPPORT VISITOR, TACKLE, AND GUIDE SERVICE INDUSTRIES.

ANADROMOUS FISH IN CALIFORNIA SUPPORT A MULTIMILLION-DOLLAR SPORT AND COMMERCIAL FISHING INDUSTRY THOUGH SOME CENTRAL VALLEY (SACRAMENTO-SAN JOAQUIN DELTA AND ITS TRIBUTARIES) SALMON (ONCORHYNCHUS TSHAWYTSCHA), STEELHEAD (ONCORHYNCHUS MYKISS), AND STURGEON (ACIPENSER SPP.) POPULATIONS HAVE DECLINED TO PRECIPITOUSLY LOW LEVELS. POPULATION DECLINES HAVE BEEN LINKED TO VARIOUS FACTORS SUCH AS CONSTRUCTION OF DAMS, WATER DIVERSIONS, AND HABITAT DEGRADATION. SIGNIFICANT ALTERATIONS TO STREAM CHANNELS BEGAN WITH THE CALIFORNIA GOLD RUSH STARTING IN 1849. TODAY URBAN EXPANSION, AGRICULTURAL AND INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT, AND WATER OPERATIONS CONTINUE TO NEGATIVELY AFFECT THESE POPULATIONS. THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW), AS TRUSTEE AGENCY FOR THE STATE S FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES, NOT ONLY MANAGES CATCHABLE STOCKS AND HARVEST OPPORTUNITY BUT ALSO HAS BEEN STEADILY WORKING TO REVERSE POPULATION DECLINES IN ANADROMOUS STOCKS. SINCE THE LATE 1980 S SEVERAL STATE AND FEDERAL LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS RECOGNIZED THESE DECLINES AND WERE TARGETED AT REVERSING THEM. THESE INCLUDE THE STATE SALMON, STEELHEAD TROUT, AND ANADROMOUS FISHERIES PROGRAM ACT OF 1988, FEDERAL CENTRAL VALLEY PROJECT IMPROVEMENT ACT OF 1991, AND THE WATER RESOURCES AND DELTA RESTORATION ACT OF 1996. PRIOR TO THE 1940 S, IT IS GENERALLY UNDERSTOOD THAT SPRING-RUN CHINOOK SALMON WERE THE DOMINANT SALMON RUN IN THE SAN JOAQUIN RIVER BASIN (SJRB). FROM THE 1940 S THRU THE 1980 S, MAJOR CHANGES IN WATER USE AND DELIVERY OCCURRED. THE CUMULATIVE RESULT OF THESE ACTIONS HAVE BEEN THE EXTIRPATION OF SELF-SUSTAINING STOCKS OF SPRINGRUN CHINOOK SALMON, THE NEAR EXTIRPATION OF STEELHEAD (A SPECIES LISTED AS THREATENED BY THE FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT), AND THE SUBSTANTIAL CURTAILMENT OF FALL-RUN CHINOOK SALMON PRODUCTION SINCE 2000 (I.E., CURRENTLY A CANDIDATE SPECIES FOR LISTING REVIEW UNDER THE FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT). TODAY FALL-RUN CHINOOK SALMON ARE THE DOMINATE RUN OF ANADROMOUS SALMONIDS REMAINING IN THE SJRB, AND THAT RUN IS A SHADOW OF ITS FORMER SELF. CONCURRENT WITH RECENT DECLINES IN BOTH THE SALMON AND STEELHEAD RUNS HAS BEEN THE REDUCTION OF ANGLING OPPORTUNITY AND SUCCESS, AS RESOURCE MANAGERS HAVE HAD TO CURTAIL SEASONS, EVENTUALLY REDUCING BAG LIMITS TO ZERO IN ORDER TO PROTECT THE REMAINING SALMON AND STEELHEAD STOCKS STILL PRESENT IN SAN JOAQUIN RIVER BASIN TRIBUTARIES (E.G., STANISLAUS, TUOLUMNE, AND MERCED RIVERS). IN RECENT TIMES, THE SACRAMENTO FALL-RUN HAS ALSO HAD SEVERE DECLINES AND OCEAN FISHING WAS CURTAILED ALMOST COMPLETELY. THE SJRB, IN RECENT HISTORY, IS CAPABLE OF PRODUCING TENS OF THOUSANDS OF ADULT SALMON. IT IS BELIEVED THAT GREATER, AND MORE FREQUENT PRODUCTION OF LARGE NUMBERS OF ADULT SALMON AND STEELHEAD IS POSSIBLE (I.E., PRODUCTION DEFINED AS ADULT SALMON AND STEELHEAD ESCAPING INTO THE TRIBUTARIES TO SPAWN). AS SALMON AND STEELHEAD PRODUCTION INCREASES, ANGLING SEASONS COULD BE REINSTATED AND AT LEAST SOME FISH COULD BE LEGALLY HARVESTED FROM THESE RIVERS.

GRANT FUNDING WILL SUPPORT COLORADO PARKS AND WILDLIFE S WATER SECTION WORK TO ACQUIRE NEW AND MANAGE EXISTING CPW WATER RIGHTS, CONSULT WITH OTHER LOCAL, STATE AND FEDERAL WATER AGENCIES ON WATER RIGHTS AND IN-STREAM FLOW ISSUES, AND PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO CPW HATCHERIES AND OTHER WATER USERS.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFES (CDFW) SOUTH COAST REGION (SCR) IS RESPONSIBLE FOR MONITORINGAND MANAGING MANY POPULATIONS OF WILD TROUT LOCATED THROUGHOUT THE SCR. THIS GRANT WILL FUND THE MONITORING,ASSESSMENT, AND MANAGEMENT OF THESE HERITAGE AND WILD TROUT POPULATIONS.

THE URBAN CATFISH PROGRAM WAS CREATED TO PROVIDE A SUSTAINABLE FISHERY IN URBAN COMMUNITIES THAT EXPERIENCE HIGH FISHING PRESSURE. THE STATE HATCHERY SYSTEM WOULD NOT BE ABLE TO SUPPLY THE NEEDED FISH AT PRESENT PRODUCTION LEVELS. TO PROVIDE A VALUABLE ANGLING EXPERIENCE THE DEPARTMENT PURCHASES CHANNEL CATFISH FROM COMMERCIAL PRODUCERS TO SUPPLY THOSE OF HARVESTABLE SIZE TO URBAN WATERS, MANY OF WHICH ARE PART OF OUR COMMUNITY FISHERIES ASSISTANCE PROGRAM. DUE TO THE EARLY SUCCESS OF THIS PROGRAM, IT WAS EXPANDED TO INCLUDE AREAS IN LESS POPULATED REGIONS OF THE STATE IN COUNTIES THAT FUNCTION AS  COMMUNITY FISHING HUBS . IN THIS GRANT APPROXIMATELY 133,862 CHANNEL CATFISH WILL BE STOCKED ACROSS THE STATE TO BEING FISHING OPPORTUNITIES TO THE GREATEST NUMBER OF ANGLERS.

TO INCREASE HARVEST OPPORTUNITY AND ALLEVIATE PRESSURE ON NATIVE FISH, HATCHERY-REARED CHINOOK AND COHOSALMON HAVE BEEN STOCKED IN NUMEROUS LOCATIONS IN SOUTHCENTRAL ALASKA. STOCKING SITES ARE SELECTED TOIMPROVE OR CREATE A SERIES OF TERMINAL SPORT FISHERIES. KEY COMPONENTS OF THE STOCKING PROGRAM INVOLVE:1) ESTIMATION AND ASSESSMENT OF THE CONTRIBUTION OF STOCKED FISH TO THE TERMINAL FISHERY  2) ESTIMATION OFSTOCK-SPECIFIC HARVESTS IN BOTH COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL FISHERIES  3) ESTIMATION OF SPAWNINGESCAPEMENT IN STOCKED STREAMS  4) ESTIMATION OF STRAYING OF RETURNING STOCKED FISH  AND 5) ASSESSMENT OFSPORT FISH EFFORT AND HARVEST AT TERMINAL LOCATIONS. THESE COMPONENTS WILL REQUIRE THAT ALL FISH IN EACHRELEASE GROUP OF STOCKED FISH BE MARKED WITH A THERMAL MARK, AND THAT SOME RELEASE GROUP CONTAIN FISHMARKED WITH AN ADIPOSE FIN CLIP.

F-40-15 RUTH BURNETT SPORT FISH HATCHERY OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE. OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCEOF THE RUTH BURNETT SPORT FISH HATCHERY IN FAIRBANKS, ALASKA. PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ENHANCERECREATIONAL SPORT FISH POPULATIONS AND PROVIDE INCREASED RECREATIONAL FISHING OPPORTUNITIES, WHILEPROTECTING WILD STOCKS THROUGHOUT INTERIOR ALASKA.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO INCREASE AQUATIC RESOURCES AWARENESS, ANGLING TECHNIQUES AND ANGLER PARTICIPATION STATEWIDE. TO FULFILL THIS PURPOSE, THE ARKANSAS GAME AND FISH COMMISSION WILL CONTINUE ITS AQUATIC RESOURCES EDUCATION (ARE) PROGRAM TO EQUIP ARKANSANS WITH THE KNOWLEDGE NEEDED TO BE SUCCESSFUL ANGLERS AND GOOD STEWARDS OF OUR AQUATIC RESOURCES. THIS PROGRAM HAS REACHED OVER 200,000 PEOPLE ANNUALLY FOR THE LAST 20 YEARS.

AQUATIC RESOURCES EDUCATION IS A PROGRAM DESIGNED TO EDUCATE THE PUBLIC ABOUT THE ABUNDANT RESOURCES OUR STATE HAS TO OFFER TOWARDS SPORT FISHING AND RESOURCES THAT ARE IN AND AROUND OUR NUMEROUS LAKES AND RIVERS. THIS PROGRAM WILL ALSO BE AN INTEGRAL PART IN RECRUITING, REACTIVATING, AND RETAINING ANGLERS IN THE THIS STATE. THIS GRANT HAS OBJECTIVES OF CONDUCTING FOUR INSTRUCTOR TRAININGS TO TEACH INSTRUCTORS HOW TO TEACH ABOUT THE AQUATIC RESOURCES EDUCATION, PRODUCE 265,000 PRINTED PRODUCTS TO INFORM THE PUBLIC OF THE AQUATIC RESOURCES DURING FISHING CLASSES, SCHOOLS, EDUCATIONAL EVENTS, TRAIN 4,000 NEW STUDENTS IN FISHING EDUCATION.

GEORGIA IS BLESSED WITH ABUNDANT AND DIVERS AQUATIC HABITATS AND FRESHWATER FISHERIES. AS THE POPULATION OF GEORGIA CONTINUES TO GROW AT A RAPID PACE, IT IS IMPORTANT TO PROMOTE PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING OF THE STATE S FISHERIES AND AQUATIC RESOURCES AND DEVELOP RESPONSIBLE ATTITUDES FOR THE WISE USE OF THESE RESOURCES TO ENSURE A HIGH QUALITY OF LIFE FOR THE PRESENT AND THE FUTURE.

SCDNR RECEIVES A SIGNIFICANT AMOUNT OF FUNDING FOR SPORTFISH MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES THROUGH THE SPORTFISH RESTORATION (SFR) GRANT PROGRAM. BECAUSE A PORTION OF THE MONIES THAT FUND SFR ARE DERIVED FROM EXCISE TAXES PAID BY MANUFACTURES, IT IS BENEFICIAL TO SCDNR FOR THEM TO UNDERSTAND AND APPRECIATE HOW THOSE FUNDS ARE BEING SPENT ON THE GROUND. SCDNR BELIEVES THAT SUCH UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION WILL FOSTER MORE SUPPORT FOR ONE ANOTHER IN TERMS OF FISHERIES MANAGEMENT FOR ANGLERS IN SOUTH CAROLINA. IN DISCUSSIONS WITH SOME MANUFACTURERS IN2015, IT BECAME APPARENT THAT THEY WERE VERY SUPPORTIVE OF OUR AGENCY EVEN THOUGH THEY DID NOT KNOW WHAT IT WAS EXACTLY THAT WE DID WITH THE MONEY. SCDNR FEELS THAT IT IS IMPERATIVE THAT WE WORK ON DEVELOPING RELATIONSHIPS WITH OUR INDUSTRY PARTNERS AND SUPPORT ONE ANOTHER IN THE CONSERVATION OF THE FISHERIES RESOURCES THAT WE BOTH VALUE. THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW US TO FACILITATE CONVERSATIONS ABOUT AND DEMONSTRATIONS OF HOW SFR FUNDS ARE USED IN SOUTH CAROLINA.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO OPERATE AND MAINTAIN PUBLIC LAKES AND ACCESS AREAS FOR USE BY ANGLERS AND BOATERS. THIS INCLUDES BOATING ACCESS SITES (BOAT RAMPS, PARKING AREAS, AND BOAT COURTESY DOCKS) AND BANK FISHING SITES (INCLUDING FISHING PIERS, BANK FISH SITES, AND BANK FISHING PARKING AREAS). A CURRENT LIST OF ACCESS AREAS, WHICH WILL BE MAINTAINED UNDER THIS GRANT AWARD, IS PROVIDED AS AN ATTACHMENT TO THE PROJECT STATEMENT.

THE PURPOSES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO: CONDUCT YOUTH FISHING EVENTS WHERE PARTICIPANTS LEARN ABOUT FISH, FISHING, AND OUR SHARED OUTDOOR ENVIRONMENT  OPERATE AND MAINTAIN 15 LARGE AQUARIA TO SHOWCASE MISSISSIPPI S FISH, AND TO PRODUCE AND DISTRIBUTE FISH, FISHING, AND AQUATIC ENVIRONMENT RELATED MATERIALS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT AWARD IS TO ENHANCE THE PUBLICS UNDERSTANDING OF WATER RESOURCES, AQUATIC LIFE FORMS, SPORT FISHING, AND DEVELOP RESPONSIBLE ATTITUDES AND ETHICS TOWARD THE AQUATIC ENVIRONMENT IN NORTH CAROLINA.

NEVADA PLAYS A PIVOTAL ROLE IN PREVENTING WIDESPREAD IMPACTS FROM SOME OF THE MOST DAMAGING AQUATIC INVASIVESPECIES (AIS) AFFECTING THE WESTERN UNITED STATES. AIS CAN HARM NEVADA S WATERS, DESTROY ECONOMIES, RESTRICTRECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES , RESULT IN LOSS OF PROPERTY VALUES AND THREATEN PUBLIC HEALTH . IF QUAGGA AND OR ZEBRAMUSSELS INVADE THE COLUMBIA RIVER , THEY COULD COST HYDROELECTRIC FACILITIES ALONE UP TO  250 - 300 MILLIONANNUALLY. IN 2007, WHEN QUAGGA MUSSELS WE R E DETECTED AT LAKE MEAD NATIONAL RECREATION AREA (LMNRA) AND THECOLORADO RIVER SYSTEM, WESTERN STATES REALIZED THEIR FRESHWATER RESOURCES WERE AT RISK. IN 2011, QUAGGA MUSSELVELIGERS WERE DETECTED IN RYE PATCH AND LAHONTAN RESERVOIRS IN NORTHERN NEVADA. ALTHOUGH UNSUCCESSFUL ATESTABLISHING POPULATIONS, THE PRESENCE OF VELIGERS AT THE TWO RESERVOIRS ILLUSTRATED THE NEED FOR QUAGGA MUSSELPREVENTION AND CONTAINMENT ACTIVITIES TO BE IMPLEMENTED. AN AGREEMENT WITH THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE (NPS) FUNDSFOUR PERMANENT WATERCRAFT INSPECTION AND DECONTAMINATION (WID) STATIONS THAT INSPECT AND DECONTAMINATE VESSELSLEAVING LMNRA.THROUGH THIS PROJECT THE NEVADA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE (NDOW) PROVIDES NO-CHARGE WID AT TWO HIGH USE RESERVOIRSIN NORTHERN NEVADA, RYE PATCH AND SOUTH FORK RESERVOIRS . A THIRD ROVER STATION PRIMARILY SERVICES TOPAZ LAKE BUTWILL ALSO BE PRESENT AT SPARKS MARINA FOR SPECIAL EVENTS . ADDITIONALLY, NDOW OPERATES TWO ROADSIDE WID STATIONS,ONE IN ALAMO, NEVADA ON U.S. HWY . 93 AND ONE NORTH OF ELKO, NEVADA AT THE INTERSECTION OF STATE ROUTE 225 ANDSTATE ROUTE 226. THE ROLE OF THE ROADSIDE WID STATIONS IS TO INTERCEPT ANY NORTHBOUND QUAGGA INFESTED VESSELSTHAT MAY HAVE BEEN MISSED BY WID STATIONS AT LMNRA. THE STATION NORTH OF ELKO ALSO INTERCEPTS VESSELS ON THEIRWAY TO WILDHORSE AND WILSON RESERVOIRS.ADDITIONAL STATIONS ARE PRESENT AT LAHONTAN RESERVOIR NEAR FALLON, NEVADA AND ON THE COLORADO RIVER NEARLAUGHLIN, NEVADA AND ARE FUNDING THROUGH AN AGREEMENT WITH BUREAU OF RECLAMATION (BOR).DURING EVERY BOATER CONTACT NDOW PERSONNEL DISTRIBUTE EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS AND EXPLAINS THE RISK OFAIS AND THE NEED FOR THE CLEAN, DRAIN, DRY (CDD) METHODOLOGY . THIS IS IN ADDITION TO ONGOING EDUCATIONALCAMPAIGNS THROUGHOUT THE STATE. THESE CAMPAIGNS INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TOO, ATTENDING BOATING, FISHING ANDOUTDOOR EVENTS TO COMMUNICATE WITH BOATERS AND OTHER OUTDOOR ENTHUSIAST TO SPREAD THE NEED TO PROTECT NEVADA SWATERWAYS FROM AIS.

THE OVERALL PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO ASSIST IN FUNDING NEVADA S AQUATIC ANGLER EDUCATION PROGRAM TO INFORM ANGLERS OF THE FISHING OPPORTUNITIES NEVADA HAS TO OFFER AND GIVE NEW AND EXISTING ANGLERS THE SKILLS NECESSARY TO MAKE THEIR FISHING OUTINGS SAFE, PRODUCTIVE AND MORE ENJOYABLE. ALL ANGLERS WILL BE EDUCATED TO BE MORE COURTEOUS AND SHOW GREATER RESPECT FOR LANDOWNERS, LAND MANAGERS, OTHER ANGLERS AND USERS OF PUBLIC LANDS AND AQUATIC RESOURCES.

PRIOR TO THE 1940S, SPRING-RUN CHINOOK SALMON WERE THE DOMINANT SALMON RUN IN THE SAN JOAQUIN RIVER (SJR) BASIN.FROM THE 1940S THRU THE 1980S, MAJOR CHANGES IN WATER USE AND DELIVERY OCCURRED. THE CUMULATIVE RESULT OF THESEACTIONS (E.G., WATER DIVERSIONS AND HABITAT DEGRADATION) HAVE BEEN THE EXTIRPATION OF SELF-SUSTAINING STOCKS OFSPRING-RUN CHINOOK SALMON AND THE NEAR EXTIRPATION OF STEELHEAD (NOW LISTED AS THREATENED BY THE FEDERALENDANGERED SPECIES ACT). THESE ACTIONS ALSO HAVE RESULTED IN SUBSTANTIAL CURTAILMENT OF FALL-RUN CHINOOK SALMONPRODUCTION DURING THE LATEST MULTI-YEAR DROUGHTS. ALONG WITH DECLINES IN BOTH THE SALMON AND STEELHEAD RUNS HASBEEN THE REDUCTION OF ANGLING OPPORTUNITY. RESOURCE MANAGERS HAVE HAD TO SHORTEN SEASONS AND REDUCE BAG LIMITS TO PROTECT SJR SALMON AND STEELHEAD STOCKS.SALMON AND STEELHEAD POPULATIONS IN THE SJR BASIN APPEAR TO RISE AND FALL IN CONNECTION WITH WET AND DRY YEARCYCLES. SINCE THE SJR BASIN, IN RECENT HISTORY, CAN PRODUCE TENS OF THOUSANDS OF ADULT SALMON, IT IS BELIEVEDTHAT GREATER, AND MORE FREQUENT, PRODUCTION OF LARGE NUMBERS OF ADULT SALMON AND STEELHEAD IS POSSIBLE.SUBSTANTIAL OPPORTUNITY FOR RESTORATION OF INLAND AND OCEAN SPORT FISHERIES EXISTS IF IN-STREAM HABITAT QUALITYAND QUANTITY CAN BE IMPROVED.DAM OPERATIONS ON THE SAN JOAQUIN, STANISLAUS, TUOLUMNE, AND MERCED RIVERS SINCE THE 1940S HAVE SIGNIFICANTLYALTERED HYDROLOGIC PATTERNS AND THE AMPLITUDE OF CHANNEL FORMING STREAM FLOW. CUMULATIVELY PRIVATE, STATE, ANDFEDERAL WATER DIVERSIONS ALONG THE RIVERS AND IN THE SACRAMENTO-SAN JOAQUIN ESTUARY INCREASE MORTALITY RATES FORVARIOUS SALMONID LIFE STAGES RESULTING IN LOWERED ADULT SALMON AND STEELHEAD PRODUCTION. THESE WATER PROJECTSALSO BLOCKED THE NATURAL DOWNSTREAM MOVEMENT OF SEDIMENT, WHICH FORM SPAWNING AND REARING HABITAT FOR ANADROMOUS FISHES (SALMON, STEELHEAD, LAMPREY AND STURGEON).FALL SPAWNING FLOWS ARE INADEQUATE TO MAINTAIN GOOD WATER QUALITY AND TO SAFELY GUIDE ADULTS UPSTREAM. SPRINGSTREAM FLOWS ARE INADEQUATE TO PROVIDE OPTIMUM REARING CONDITIONS AND OPTIMUM SURVIVAL LEVELS DURING OUTMIGRATIONPERIODS ON AN ANNUAL BASIS. IMPINGEMENT, ENTRAPMENT AND THE CONFUSION AND DELAY OF YOUNG SALMON DURING REARINGAND OUTMIGRATION FURTHER EXACERBATES MORTALITY RATES. ALSO, WATER QUALITY CHANGES ASSOCIATED WITH AGRICULTURALDRAINAGE WATER MAY FURTHER REDUCE JUVENILE SALMON PRODUCTION. IT IS BELIEVED THAT DRAMATIC INCREASES IN JUVENILEPRODUCTION, OUT MIGRATION SURVIVAL, AND EVENTUAL ADULT SALMON AND STEELHEAD ESCAPEMENT, ARE POSSIBLE THROUGH ACOMBINATION OF FLOW AND HABITAT IMPROVEMENTS.

THE NORTH CENTRAL COAST WATERSHED RESTORATION PROJECT IS PART OF THE BAY DELTA REGIONS (BDR) WATERSHED RESTORATION PROGRAM AND IS COMPRISED OF ONE SENIOR ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTIST SUPERVISOR AND THREE ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTISTS THAT OVERSEE SEASONAL FIELD STAFF THAT CONDUCT RESOURCE ASSESSMENT. TWO OF THE WATERSHED RESTORATION PROGRAM ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTISTS ARE PARTIALLY FUNDED THROUGH A PACIFIC COASTAL SALMON RECOVERY FUND (PCSRF) GRANT. THE BAY DELTA REGION (BDR) IS LOCATED IN THE CENTER OF THE CALIFORNIA COAST AND EXTENDS INLAND INTO THE SACRAMENTO-SAN JOAQUIN DELTA. THE NORTH COAST FISHERIES RESOURCE ASSESSMENT BIOLOGISTS ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE MANAGEMENT, CONSERVATION, RESTORATION, AND MONITORING OF FISHERIES AND AQUATIC RESOURCES WITHIN THE STREAMS OF THE NORTH CENTRAL COAST WITH SPECIAL EMPHASIS ON NATIVE SALMONIDS. THIS IS ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH CLOSE COORDINATION AND COMMUNICATION WITH OTHER DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (DFW) REGIONAL PROGRAMS AND VARIOUS FEDERAL, STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES AND INTERESTED STAKEHOLDERS. THIS GRANT WILL PARTIALLY FUND TWO ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTISTS AND SEASONAL FIELD STAFF TO COMPLETE THIS WORK.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE RELATED TO MARINE AND ANADROMOUS FISH AND THEIR AQUATIC HABITATS TO MAINTAIN OR IMPROVE RECREATIONAL FISHING IN DELAWARE TIDAL WATERS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE MONITORING MARINE AND ANADROMOUS FISH POPULATIONS TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR COOPERATIVE FISHERIES MANAGEMENT ENTITIES, ASSESSMENT AND REVIEW OF LAND AND WATER USE PLANS TO EVALUATE THE POTENTIAL IMPACTS TO FISH AND THEIR HABITAT, TO PROVIDE GUIDANCE TO SUPPORT SUSTAINABLE FISHING TO OTHER FISHERIES PROFESSIONAL, MANAGERS AND THE PUBLIC, AND TO INVESTIGATE AND PROVIDE AN APPROPRIATE RESPONSE TO ALL REPORTED FISH KILLS IN DELAWARE TIDAL WATERS. EXPECTED OUTCOME INCLUDE EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT OF MARINE AND ANADROMOUS GAMEFISH POPULATIONS THAT SUPPORT RECREATIONAL ANGLING, IMPROVED LAND AND WATER USE PRACTICES TO PROTECT WATER QUALITY AND AQUATIC HABITAT AND COORDINATED EFFECTIVE3 FISH KILL RESPONSE AIMED AT REDUCING THE NUMBER OF FISH KILLS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE RECREATIONAL ANGLERS AND FISHERIES BIOLOGISTS MANAGERS WORKING TO IMPROVE GAMEFISH POPULATIONS AND FISH HABITAT IN DELAWARE S TIDAL WATER BODIES. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THIS PROJECT.

THE SOUTH-CENTRAL COAST STEELHEAD RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT PROJECT IS PART OF THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) BAY DELTA REGIONS (BDR) FISHERIES MANAGEMENT PROGRAM AND IS COMPRISED OF ONE ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTIST THAT OVERSEES SEASONAL FIELD STAFF THAT CONDUCT STEELHEAD (ONCORHYNCHUS MYKISS) HABITAT AND POPULATION ASSESSMENT. BDR IS IN THE CENTER OF THE CALIFORNIA COAST AND EXTENDS INLAND INTO THE SACRAMENTO-SAN JOAQUIN DELTA. THE SOUTH-CENTRAL COAST STEELHEAD ASSESSMENT BIOLOGIST IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE MANAGEMENT, CONSERVATION, RESTORATION, AND MONITORING OF STEELHEAD WITHIN THE STREAMS OF THE SOUTH-CENTRAL COAST. THIS IS ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH COORDINATION AND COMMUNICATION WITH OTHER DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (DFW) REGIONAL PROGRAMS AND VARIOUS FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES, AND INTERESTED STAKEHOLDERS.  THIS GRANT WILL FULLY FUND ONE ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTIST AND SEASONAL FIELD STAFF TO COMPLETE THESE OBJECTIVES.

VERMONTS AQUATIC RESOURCE EDUCATION PROGRAM (ARE) BEGAN IN 1990 UNDER A FEDERAL AID GRANT FROM THE U. S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE.  VERMONTS ARE PROGRAM FOCUSES ON YOUTH AND ADULT EDUCATION IN A VARIETY OF CAPACITIES ALL WHILE FOLLOWING BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR NONFORMAL EDUCATION.  ARE YOUTH EDUCATION OCCURS AT THE DEPARTMENTS GREEN MOUNTAIN CONSERVATION CAMPS, SCHOOL PROGRAMS, AND EDUCATIONAL ORGANIZATION PROGRAMS.  ADULT EDUCATION OCCURS AT THE NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT FOR EDUCATORS AND OUTDOOR EDUCATION TECHNIQUES COURSE AS WELL AS THE PROJECT AQUATIC WILD CURRICULUM GUIDE AND TRAINING FOR EDUCATORS.  LASTLY, A COMBINATION OF ADULT AND YOUTH EDUCATION OCCURS IN THE LETS GO FISHING PROGRAM AS WELL AS INTERPRETATION THROUGH MOBILE EXHIBITS AND A STATE VISITORS CENTER AT A FISH CULTURE STATION (I.E. ED WEED FISH CULTURE STATION IN GRAND ISLE). THIS NEW FIVE-YEAR PLAN INTENDS TO BUILD UPON THE PREVIOUS ACCOMPLISHMENTS BY EXPLORING, IMPLEMENTING, AND EVALUATING NEW WAYS OF EDUCATOR TRAINING, REVISING, AND ENRICHING EDUCATIONAL CURRICULA, STREAMLINING THE PROCESS OF CERTIFYING VOLUNTEER INSTRUCTORS, IMPROVING VOLUNTEER INSTRUCTOR TRAINING, AND CREATING MORE EDUCATIONAL FISHING CLINICS FOR PEOPLE OF ALL AGES WITH A FOCUS ON UNDERSERVED AUDIENCES IN OUTDOOR ACTIVITIES, SPECIFICALLY FISHING.  DURING THIS NEXT FIVE-YEAR PLAN, AN EMPHASIS WILL BE PLACED ON ADVANCED AQUATIC EDUCATION CURRICULUM AND EVALUATION METHODS FOR THE LETS GO FISHING PROGRAM AS WELL AS REACHING UNDERSERVED AUDIENCES.  THIS NEW FIVE-YEAR GRANT WILL SUPPORT TOPIC PROGRAMMING AND EVALUATIONS FOR THE LGF PROGRAM THAT WILL HOPEFULLY LEAD TO RETENTION OF PARTICIPANTS IN THE PROGRAM, AS WELL AS THE REACTIVATION OF LAPSED ANGLERS.  ALL OF WHICH WILL LEAD TO A GREATER AWARENESS OF VERMONTS AQUATIC RESOURCES AND PARTICIPATION IN ANGLING.

NEW MEXICO HAS LIMITED WATERS AVAILABLE FOR RECREATIONAL BOATING. AN INCREASING POPULATION AND A GROWING DEMAND BY RECREATIONAL ANGLERS FOR BOATING OPPORTUNITIES WILL CONTINUE TO DIRECT THE NEW MEXICO DEPARTMENT OF GAME AND FISH (DEPARTMENT) TO UPGRADE AND MAINTAIN EXISTING FACILITIES.

THIS PROJECT WILL FUND THE NON-BOATING OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE BUDGETS FOR EACH OF THE THREE REGIONS IN ALASKA. THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THE SE ACCESS SITE MAINTENANCE PROJECT (NON-BOATING) IS TO MAINTAIN EXISTING NON-BOATING AND SHORELINE ANGLER ACCESS FACILITIES, PROVIDE SEASONAL FACILITIES AT ACCESS SITES (SUCH AS PORTA-POTTIES), AND DEVELOP OR MAKE MINOR IMPROVEMENTS TO EXISTING ACCESS SITES.THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THE SOUTHCENTRAL ACCESS MAINTENANCE PROJECT (NON-BOATING) IS TO MAINTAIN AND DEVELOP ANGLER ACCESS SITES, PROVIDE LAND AND EASEMENT RESEARCH, AND ACQUIRE EASEMENTS IN ORDER TO ACCOMMODATE THE RECREATIONAL SPORT ANGLING DEMAND IN SOUTHCENTRAL ALASKA. THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING FOR ANGLER ACCESS IMPROVEMENTS THAT COLLECTIVELY PROVIDE SIGNIFICANT SPORT FISHING OPPORTUNITIES TO SOUTHCENTRAL ALASKA S ANGLERS.THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THE REGION III ACCESS MAINTENANCE PROJECT (NON-BOATING) IS TO MAINTAIN EXISTING ANGLER ACCESS SITES, PROVIDE SIGNAGE AND REPAIRS, DIRECT THE SPORT ANGLING PUBLIC TO AVAILABLE OPPORTUNITIES, AND MAKE MINOR IMPROVEMENTS TO EXISTING ANGLER ACCESS SITES AND AMENITIES SUCH AS PARKING AREAS, SANITARY SERVICES, PUBLIC USE CABINS, ROADS, AND TRAILS.

THE RAMP AT LEAKESVILLE LANDING, LEAKESVILLE, MISSISSIPPI WAS BUILT IN THE EARLY 1960S AND IS IN NEED OR REPAIR. THE MS DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE, FISHERIES, AND PARKS WILL FUND A PROJECT TO RENOVATE THE BOAT RAMP, ACCESS ROAD, AND PARKING LOT USING SFR BOATING ACCESS MONEY.
THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE BOATING ACCESS ON THE BOUIE AND LEAF RIVERS, AND BLACK CREEK IN THE HATTIESBURG, MS, AREA.

THIS PROJECT COORDINATES THE PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION OF ENHANCEMENT PROJECTS CONDUCTED BY THE DIVISION OF SPORT FISH IN SOUTHEAST ALASKA TO INCREASE RECREATIONAL SPORT FISH POPULATIONS AND PROVIDE INCREASED RECREATIONAL FISHING OPPORTUNITIES.
THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO EXPLORE THE FEASIBILITY AND SUITABILITY OF ELECTROFISHING IN MISSISSIPPIS COASTAL WATERS AS A LONG-TERM FISHERY MONITORING PROGRAM.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INSPECT AND MAINTAIN MISSISSIPPI S EXISTING PUBLIC BOATING ACCESS FACILITIES, AS OPPOSED TO PRIVATELY OWNED FEE RAMPS. IN A SAFE AND FUNCTIONAL CONDITION. THIS ALLOWS THE ANGLING AND BOATING PUBLIC TO ACCESS THE STATE S RIVERS, LAKES AND RESERVOIRS FOR RECREATIONAL AND ANGLING PURPOSES. AS OPPORTUNITIES ARISE, THIS GRANT WILL BE AMENDED TO ALLOW FOR CONSTRUCTION OF NEW FACILITIES.

SCDNR HAS SEVERAL OCCURRENCES OF DISEASE, PARASITE INFESTATION, AND UNKNOWN MORTALITIES WITHIN OUR FRESHWATER FISH POPULATIONS. IT IS IMPERATIVE THAT WE HAVE A WAY TO DETERMINE BOTH THE CAUSES OF MORTALITIES INFECTION AND A PRESCRIPTIVE METHOD FOR ADDRESSING THESE ISSUES WHEN ONE EXISTS. THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW SCDNR TO HAVE ACCESS TO A PROFESSIONAL AND REPUTABLE LABORATORY WHERE FISH SAMPLES CAN BE SENT IMMEDIATELY FOR DISEASE AND PARASITE DIAGNOSIS AND TO CONTRIBUTE TO AN UNDERSTANDING OF FISH DISEASES AND PARASITES IN THE SOUTHEAST. FURTHER, WE WILL HAVE THE ABILITY TO PROVIDE FISH DISEASE TRAINING TO STAFF BY QUALIFIED INSTRUCTORS.

THE SOUTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES HAS A LONG HISTORY OF STRIPED BASS MANAGEMENT THROUGHOUT THE STATE, WITH STOCK ENHANCEMENT REPRESENTING A MAJOR COMPONENT. THE USE OF GENETIC TOOLS ALLOWS THE SCDNR HATCHERY PROGRAM TO BETTER DETERMINE STOCKING STRATEGIES. THESE EFFORTS ALLOW BETTER ACCOUNTABILITY TO STAKEHOLDER GROUPS AND MORE EFFICIENT USE OF DNR HATCHERY RESOURCES. THEY ALSO ALLOW THE DNR TO RESPONSIBLY DETERMINE THE GENETIC STRUCTURE OF THE POPULATION IN DIFFERENT DRAINAGES PRIOR TO STOCKING TO KEEP FROM IMPACTING EXISTING POPULATIONS BY STOCKING FISH THAT ARE GENETICALLY DIFFERENT. THE FY24 STRIPED BASS GENETICS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE THE GENETIC MANAGEMENT FOR ALL STRIPED BASS PRODUCTION AND STOCKING IN SOUTH CAROLINA. AS NATURAL POPULATIONS OF STRIPED BASS CONTINUE TO DECLINE WITHIN THE SOUTHERN PORTION OF ITS NATIVE RANGE, STOCK ENHANCEMENT HAS BECOME A CRITICAL PART OF THE SPECIES MANAGEMENT. IT IS IMPERATIVE THAT EFFICIENT AND EFFECTIVE STOCKING PROTOCOLS ARE INCORPORATED IN RESPONSIBLE APPROACH MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS  THE INCORPORATION OF GENETIC TOOLS FOR IDENTIFICATION OF HATCHERY FISH ALLOWS FOR IMPROVED OPTIMIZATION OF THOSE PROTOCOLS.

MAINTAIN 18 STATE-MANAGED LAKES (APPROXIMATELY L,415 ACRES) IN A MANNER THAT PROVIDES SATISFACTORY RECREATIONAL FISHING AND BOATING OPPORTUNITIES TO THE PUBLIC. PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR PUBLIC FISHING AND BOATING ON SCDNR OWNED AND LEASED LAKES THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA. THESE LAKES ALLOW FOR ANGLERS AND BOATERS TO FISH MORE LOCALLY TO THEIR HOMES AND TEND TO BE MORE AVAILABLE TO THOSE ANGLERS WITHOUT ACCESS TO BOATS AND OR THOSE THAT ARE UNABLE TO TRAVEL TOO FAR FROM HOME.

THIS PROJECT WILL FUND IMPROVEMENTS TO THE RANKIN LANDING BOATING ACCESS FACILITY BY REPLACING 3 BOAT RAMPS, INSTALLING 4 NEW FLOATING COURTESY PIERS, INSTALLING A 299-FT BREAKWATER, AND IMPROVING PARKING

SOUTH CAROLINA CONTAINS AN ABUNDANCE OF FRESHWATER IN LAKES, PONDS, RIVERS AND STREAMS. SCDNR IS CHARGED WITH THE MANAGEMENT OF THE FISHERIES RESOURCES WITHIN THESE WATERS. IN ORDER TO PROVIDE FOR THE MANAGEMENT, PROTECTION AND ENHANCEMENT OF THE STATE S FRESHWATER FISHERIES RESOURCES, SCDNR NEED TO ANNUALLY ASSESS THE CONDITION OF FISHES THROUGH A STATEWIDE RESEARCH AND SURVEY PROJECT. THIS PROJECT WILL ENSURE THAT MANAGEMENT MEASURES, SUCH AS CREEL AND SIZE LIMITS, PREDATOR INTRODUCTION AND FISH STOCKING SCHEDULES ARE BASED ON RELIABLE, UP-TO-DATE INFORMATION. THIS GRANT PROVIDES THE OPPORTUNITY TO CONDUCT AND COORDINATE ALL FRESHWATER FISHERIES MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES WITHIN SOUTH CAROLINA. THE FRESHWATER FISHERIES SECTION OF THE SOUTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES IS CHARGED WITH THE MANAGEMENT OF THE FISHERIES RESOURCES WITHIN THESE MAJOR DRAINAGE BASINS. MANAGEMENT OF FISHERIES RESOURCES INCLUDES, BUT IS NOT LIMITED TO: ANNUALLY ASSESSING THE CONDITION OF STATE FRESHWATER FISHERY RESOURCES IN SELECTED RIVERS, STREAMS, LAKES, AND RESERVOIRS WITHIN FOUR REGIONS AND TO ADDRESS RESOURCE ISSUES WHICH CROSS DISTRICT BOUNDARIES THROUGH A STATEWIDE RESEARCH AND SURVEY PROJECT IN ORDER TO ALLOW MANAGEMENT MEASURES SUCH AS CREEL AND SIZE LIMITS, PREDATOR INTRODUCTIONS, AND FISH STOCKING SCHEDULES ARE BASED ON RELIABLE, UP-TO-DATE INFORMATION. PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, TO INVESTIGATE FISH MORTALITIES AND TO REVIEW AND COMMENT ON ALL DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES WHICH MAY IMPACT THE STATE S AQUATIC RESOURCES. IMPROVING SPORTFISHING OPPORTUNITIES IN RESERVOIRS AND STREAMS BY PROVIDING WELL-MARKED, ACCESSIBLE AREAS THAT CONCENTRATE FISH AND IMPROVE HABITAT. PROVIDING IMPROVED ACCESS TO FISHERY RESOURCES IN IMPOUNDMENTS AND STREAMS FOR ANGLERS. INCREASING FISHING OPPORTUNITIES AND IMPROVE ANGLING SUCCESS.

FISH HATCHERIES PLAY AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN SOUTH CAROLINAS FISHERIES MANAGEMENT PROGRAM.PROVIDING FOR THE CONTINUAL OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF FRESHWATER FISH HATCHERIES IS ESSENTIALTO PROVIDING MANY OF THE SPORT FISHING OPPORTUNITIES IN SOUTH CAROLINA FOR 537,136 FRESHWATER ANGLERS. THE FISH PRODUCED AT SOUTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (SCDNR) HATCHERIES SIGNIFICANTLY CONTRIBUTE TO THE SUPPORT OF FRESHWATER SPORT FISHERIES IN SOUTH CAROLINA WHICH HAS AN ECONOMIC IMPACT EXCEEDING  897 MILLION. COLDWATER AND WARMWATER FISH HATCHERIES PRODUCE AND STOCK JUVENILE FISH TO SUPPORT RE-ESTABLISHMENT OF NATURALLY REPRODUCING STOCKS THAT, IN TURN, SUPPORT PUT, GROWN AND TAKE FISHERIES.PRODUCTION OF CATCHABLE AND FINGERLING TROUT, STRIPED BASS, HYBRID STRIPED BASS, LARGEMOUTH BASS,SMALLMOUTH BASS, WHITE BASS, SUNFISH, AMERICAN SHAD AND CHANNEL CATFISH SUPPORT POPULARREGIONAL FISHERIES. WITH CONTINUED POPULATION GROWTH AND INCREASED DEVELOPMENT IN SOUTHCAROLINA, IT IS LIKELY THE DEMANDS PLACED ON FISH HATCHERIES WILL CONTINUE TO INCREASE. PROVIDING FUNDING FOR THE OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE NEEDS FOR THESE FACILITIES WILL ENSURE CONTINUED SPORTFISHING OPPORTUNITIES ACROSS SOUTH CAROLINA. SCDNR WILL MAINTAIN, OPERATE, AND PRODUCE FISH AT THREE (3) FRESHWATER HATCHERY PRODUCTION LOCATIONS AND ONE (1) ASSOCIATED SATELLITE HATCHERY IN ORDER TO PRODUCE AND STOCK FRESHWATER SPORTFISH IN THE PUBLIC WATERS OF THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA.

WILDLIFE RESOURCES COMMISSION S (NCWRC) ACTIVITIES TO MANAGE AND MAINTAIN SPORTFISH POPULATIONS, THEIR HABITATS AND THEIR USERS IN NORTH CAROLINA S INLAND WATERS FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE ANGLINGPUBLIC. FISH HATCHERIES PLAY AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN NORTH CAROLINA S FISHERY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM. WILDLIFE RESOURCES COMMISSION S (NCWRC) HATCHERIES SIGNIFICANTLY CONTRIBUTE TO THE SUPPORT OF FRESHWATER SPORT FISHERIES IN NORTH CAROLINA. HATCHERY-SUPPORTED SPORT FISH ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES IN NORTH CAROLINA ARE DIVERSE AND INCREASING. PRODUCTION OF CATCHABLE AND FINGERLING TROUT, MUSKELLUNGE, WALLEYE, STRIPED BASS, HYBRID STRIPED BASS, LARGEMOUTH BASS, SMALLMOUTH BASS, WHITE BASS, SUNFISH, WHITE CATFISH AND CHANNEL CATFISH SUPPORT POPULAR REGIONAL FISHERIES. WITH CONTINUED POPULATION GROWTH AND INCREASED DEVELOPMENT IN NORTH CAROLINA, IT IS LIKELY THE DEMANDS PLACED ON FISH HATCHERIES WILL CONTINUE TO INCREASE. THE NCWRC MUST ROUTINELY MAINTAIN PUBLIC FISHING ACCESS AREAS YEAR-ROUND TO KEEP THE FACILITIES OPERATING IN A SAFE AND SERVICEABLE CONDITION FOR ANGLERS.IN ADDITION, IN ORDER TO MEET THE NEEDS OF THE ANGLING PUBLIC, NCWRC CONSTRUCTS NEW PUBLIC FISHING ACCESS AREAS IN LOCATIONS WHICH HAVE LIMITED ACCESS FOR BANK FISHING.

THE MAGEE S CREEK BOATING ACCESS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE A PUBLIC BOAT RAMP ON PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAY FOR THE LARGE NUMBER OF BOATERS (SMALL WATER CRAFT LIKE KAYAKS, CANOES AND SMALL JOHN BOATS) THAT FREQUENT THE CREEK.

THIS ANNUAL GRANT PROVIDES CRUCIAL FUNDING FOR THE MAINTENANCE OF BOATING RAMPS AND BANK FISHING SITES THROUGHOUT KENTUCKY. OVER 160 RAMPS ARE MAINTAINED THROUGHOUT THE STATE, AND OVER 30 FISHING ACCESS SITES ARE MAINTAINED, ALL BY OUR ENGINEERING DIVISION. ACTIVITIES RANGE FROM SIMPLE MOWING AND TRASH CLEANUP TO PAVING AND ADDING GRAVEL TO EXISTING RAMPS FACILITIES. THIS FUNDING ENSURES CLEAN, QUALITY ACCESS FOR BOATERS AND FISHERMEN IN KENTUCKY.

THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE FUNDS TO ASSIST IN CONSTRUCTING THE SOUTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF NATURALRESOURCES (SCDNR) YORK OFFICE, A PORTION OF WHICH IS INTENDED TO HOUSE REGION 2 FRESHWATERFISHERIES PROGRAM STAFF. THIS PROGRAM IS FUNDED THROUGH A SPORTFISH RESTORATION GRANT AND ISRESPONSIBLE FOR MANAGING THE FISHERIES RESOURCES THROUGHOUT ONE QUARTER OF THE STATE, INCLUDING RESERVOIRS, RIVERS, AND STATE FISHING LAKES. IN ORDER TO MEET THE DEMAND FOR OFFICE SPACE IN REGION2, THIS PROJECT PROPOSES CONSTRUCTION OF A MULTI-USE OFFICE BUILDING TO ACCOMMODATE REGION 2FRESHWATER FISHERIES STAFF, REGION 2 LAW ENFORCEMENT STAFF AND A SCDNR LICENSE SALES OFFICE.THE PROPOSED FACILITY WILL PROVIDE OFFICE AND STORAGE SPACE FOR THE EXISTING REGION 2 FRESHWATER FISHERIES OPERATIONS. BY MERGING OFFICE SPACE WITH LAW ENFORCEMENT AND LICENSING, SCDNR WILL BE ABLE TO PROVIDE A MORE COST-EFFECTIVE SOLUTION TO THE NEEDS OF ALL THREE PROGRAMS. BEING HOUSEDTOGETHER WILL LOWER UTILITY COSTS FOR ALL THREE PROGRAMS AND REDUCE THE COST OF UPKEEP AND MAINTENANCE TO THE FACILITY. FURTHER, THE OFFICE WILL ALLOW FOR THE COMMUNITY TO BETTER INTERACT WITHSCDNR STAFF IN ONE CONVENIENT LOCATION. ADDITIONALLY, BECAUSE SCDNR CURRENTLY OWNS THEPROPERTY, THE FRESHWATER FISHERIES PROGRAM WILL NOT NEED TO FIND THE FUNDING TO PURCHASE ADDITIONALPROPERTY.

THE SOUTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES HAS A LONG HISTORY OF BLACK BASSMANAGEMENT THROUGHOUT THE STATE, WITH STOCK ENHANCEMENT REPRESENTING A MAJOR COMPONENT. OVER THE YEARS, BLACK BASS SPECIES HAVE BEEN MOVED AROUND BY ANGLERS ANDSPOTTED ALABAMA BASS HAVE BEEN INTRODUCED BY WELL-MEANING FISHERMEN. THE USE OF GENETIC TOOLSALLOWS THE SCDNR TO BETTER DETERMINE DEGREES OF HYBRIDIZATION WITHIN THE BLACK BASS COMPLEX AND DISTRIBUTION OF ALL THE BLACK BASS SPECIES IN THE STATE. THESE EFFORTS ALLOW BETTERACCOUNTABILITY TO STAKEHOLDER GROUPS AND A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF BLACK BASS DISTRIBUTION FOR REGIONAL MANAGEMENT. THEY ALSO ALLOW THE DNR TO RESPONSIBLY DETERMINE THE GENETIC STRUCTURE OFTHE POPULATION IN DIFFERENT DRAINAGES SO THAT SCDNR CAN REDUCE ANY IMPACTS TO EXISTING POPULATIONS BY STOCKING FISH THAT ARE GENETICALLY DIFFERENT.

THE GRANT WILL PROVIDE FUNDS TO THE SUBRECIPIENT, SABINE RIVER AUTHORITY (SRA), FOR THE CONSTRUCTION OF NEW AMENITIES AT THE VAN ZANDT COUNTY RECREATION AREA BOAT RAMP FACILITIES, AT LAKE TAWAKONI, WILLIS POINT, VAN ZANDT COUNTY, TEXAS. GRANT FUNDS WILL BE USED FOR THE CONSTRUCTION AND INSTALLATION OF A COURTESY DOCK, WAVE BREAK JETTY, SHORELINE STABILIZATION, DREDGING, LIGHTING, RESTROOM, AND UTILITIES.

SPORT FISHING IN THE BAY DELTA REGION (BDR) OF CALIFORNIA PROVIDES A WIDE VARIETY OF OUTDOOR RECREATION AND ADVENTURE. THE ABILITY TO MONITOR, MANAGE AND ENHANCE SPORT FISH OPPORTUNITIES IS ESSENTIAL TO MAINTAIN ANGLER OPPORTUNITIES AND SATISFACTION.  THE BAY DELTA REGION CENTRAL COAST STEELHEAD TROUT CONSERVATION AND ENHANCEMENT PROJECT IS PART OF THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFES (CDFW) BDR FISHERIES MANAGEMENT PROGRAM AND IS COMPRISED OF THREE ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTISTS THAT OVERSEE THREE DISTRICTS: NORTH BAY (MARIN, SONOMA, NAPA, AND SOLANO COUNTIES), INNER SOUTH BAY (CONTRA COSTA, ALAMEDA, AND SANTA CLARA COUNTIES), AND THE SOUTH COAST (SAN FRANCISCO, SAN MATEO, AND SANTA CRUZ COUNTIES). THESE ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTISTS ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE MANAGEMENT, CONSERVATION, RESTORATION, AND MONITORING OF FISHERIES AND AQUATIC RESOURCES WITHIN THE LAKES AND STREAMS OF THEIR RESPECTIVE DISTRICTS WITH SPECIAL EMPHASIS ON NATIVE SALMONIDS AND FUNCTION AS DISTRICT FISHERIES BIOLOGISTS.  THIS GRANT WILL PROVIDE THE FUNDING NECESSARY TO PARTIALLY SUPPORT THREE DISTRICT BIOLOGISTS AND SEASONAL FIELD STAFF TO ASSESS AND MANAGE THE SPORT FISH RESOURCES IN THE TEN COUNTIES LOCATED WITHIN THE BAY DELTA REGION. THEY ACCOMPLISH THIS THROUGH CLOSE COORDINATION AND COMMUNICATION WITH OTHER CDFW REGIONAL PROGRAMS AND VARIOUS FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES AND INTERESTED STAKEHOLDERS.
THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS STUDY IS TO EVALUATE WHETHER DAYTIME AND NIGHTIME PRIVATE ACCESS POINT ANGLERS HAVE DIFFERENT CATCH RATES COMPARED TO PUBLIC ACCESS POINT ANGLERS.
THIS GRANT WILL FUND THE OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF 68 MARINE BOATING ACCESS AREA FACILITIES IN NORTH CAROLINA FOR THE PUBLIC BENEFIT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS ANNUAL GRANT IS TO INTRODUCE KENTUCKY S RESIDENTS TO SPORT FISHING AND THE TECHNICAL AND PHYSICAL SKILLS ASSOCIATED WITH IT. SEVERAL COMMUNITY-BASED EVENTS, AQUATIC EDUCATION BASED VIDEOS ARE JUST A FEW OF THE ACTIVITIES THIS GRANT SUPPORTS. CHILDREN AND ADULTS THROUGHOUT KENTUCKY HAVE BENEFITED FROM THE EDUCATION PROVIDED AT THE IN-PERSON EVENTS AS WELL AS THE VIDEOS GENERATED AND POSTED ONLINE.

THIS PROJECTS COLLECTS DATA ON FISH POPULATIONS, HEALTH AND TRENDLINES THROUGH FISH SURVEYS ON HUNDREDS OF COLORADO STREAMS AND LAKES. THE GRANT ALSO FUNDS A SMALL NUMBER OF ANGLER CREEL SURVEYS FOR INFORMATION ON ANGLER SUCCESS RATES.

HABITAT ENHANCEMENT ACTIVITIES WILL RESULT IN INCREASED SPAWNING AND NURSERY SITES, AREAS OF PROTECTIVE COVER, AND AREAS OF FOOD PRODUCTION. AS A RESULT, FISH POPULATIONS SHOULD EXHIBIT IMPROVED FISH DENSITY AND SIZE. THE OPERATION   MAINTENANCE OF DESTRATIFICATION UNITS WILL BE CONSIDERED WHERE NEEDED TO INCREASE THE AMOUNT OF PRODUCTIVE WATER IN LAKES THAT BECOME STRATIFIED. AS A RESULT, THE INCREASE IN SPACE AND NATURAL FOOD ITEMS WILL TRANSLATE INTO INCREASED FISH NUMBERS AND FISH SIZES. THE REHABILITATION OF UNBALANCED FISH POPULATIONS AND OR SUPPLEMENTAL STOCKING OF FISH WILL RESULT IN BETTER-BALANCED FISH POPULATIONS WITH IMPROVED FISH DENSITY AND SIZE. FISH FEEDING PROGRAMS WILL INCREASE THE GROWTH AND DENSITY OF BLUEGILL, CHANNEL CATFISH AND OTHER SPECIES ADAPTED TO FEEDING ON PELLETED FEED. THROUGH PROVEN MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES KDWP HOPES TO INCREASE ANGLER USE AND ENJOYMENT OF THESE WATERS FOR YEARS TO COME.

TO PROTECT, CONSERVE, AND ENHANCE KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AND PARKS PUBLIC LANDS FISHERIES USING SCIENCE BASED AND BUSINESS INTELLIGENCE INFORMATION, AND TO PROVIDE FISHING AND COMPATIBLE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR CURRENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS. TO OPERATE AND MAINTAIN 29,139 ACRES OF LAND AND WATER ON 44 PUBLIC LOCATIONS AND MAINTAIN AND IMPROVE ACCESS AREAS FOR SPORT FISHING. TO IMPROVE SPORT FISH AND POPULATIONS BY IMPROVING AQUATIC HABITATS AND SUPPLEMENTAL STOCKINGS. TO MEET THE DIVERSE DEMAND FOR PUBLIC FISHING. THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF MISSISSIPPI S FRESHWATER AQUATIC RESOURCES, PROVIDES TECHNICAL GUIDANCE TO MISSISSIPPI PRIVATE POND OWNERS, AND IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF MDWFP S STATE FISHING LAKES. FUNDING UNDER THIS GRANT WILL ALSO SUPPORT THE CONSTRUCTION OF A SMALL EQUIPMENT BUILDING AT LAKE CLAUDE BENNETT.

MAD RIVER HATCHERY, OPERATED BY CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW), BEGAN REARING STEELHEAD IN 1971 TO PROVIDE A VIABLE FISHERY FOR THE MAD RIVER. MAD RIVER HATCHERY IS THE ONLY SALMON AND STEELHEAD HATCHERY CONSTRUCTED AND OPERATED BY CDFW EXCLUSIVELY FOR ENHANCEMENT PURPOSES. SINCE INITIAL OPERATIONS BEGAN, MAD RIVER HATCHERY HAS, AND CONTINUES, TO PLAY A KEY ROLE IN RESTORATION EFFORTS ALONG THE CENTRAL AND NORTH COAST. MAD RIVER HATCHERY WILL TRAP AND SPAWN NATURAL ORIGIN (NOR) FISH FROM THE MAD RIVER, CROSSED WITH HATCHERY ORIGIN FISH (HOR) IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE HATCHERY GENETICS AND MANAGEMENT PLAN (HGMP). MAD RIVER HATCHERY IS LOCATED 12.2 RIVER MILES (20 KILOMETERS) UPSTREAM OF THE PACIFIC OCEAN AND 63.4 RIVER MILES (101 KILOMETERS) DOWNSTREAM OF THE ROBERT L. MATTHEWS DAM IN TRINITY COUNTY (ATTACHMENT A).   MAD RIVER HATCHERY WILL COLLECT APPROXIMATELY 250,000 WINTER STEELHEAD EGGS FROM 250 ADULTS WINTER STEELHEAD ANNUALLY, USING METHODS AND SPAWNING PROTOCOLS AS CITED IN THE APPROVED HGMP, AND REAR 150,000 YEARLING WINTER STEELHEAD FOR STOCKING AT APPROXIMATELY 5 LB IN THE MAD RIVER DURING MARCH AND APRIL OF THE FOLLOWING YEAR. THE HATCHERY WILL ALSO PROVIDE 1,500 STEELHEAD EGGS FOR THE CALIFORNIA AQUARIUM EDUCATION PROJECT.  IN 2000, NATIONAL MARINE FISHERIES SERVICE (NMFS) FUNDED MAD RIVER STEELHEAD STUDIES, PURSUANT TO THEIR NORTH COAST STEELHEAD MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT (MOA) WITH CDFW. MONITORING IS NECESSARY TO PROVIDE A GREATER UNDERSTANDING OF SALMONID AQUATIC ECOLOGY, POPULATION ABUNDANCE, AS WELL AS A MEANS TO EVALUATE INTERACTION BETWEEN HATCHERY-PRODUCED AND NATURALLY SPAWNING SALMON AND STEELHEAD STOCKS IN MAD RIVER. THE RESULTS OF THESE STUDIES INDICATE THAT HATCHERY FISH MAKE UP OVER 90  OF THE STEELHEAD POPULATION IN MAD RIVER. PREVIOUS STEELHEAD REPORT CARD INFORMATION ALSO INDICATED THAT 79.4  OF ALL STEELHEAD OBSERVED WERE ADIPOSE FIN-CLIPPED. ALL STEELHEAD RELEASED ARE 100  ADIPOSE FIN-CLIPPED. THE HATCHERY OPERATES UNDER THE HGMP PROTOCOLS TO ACHIEVE A 50  TO 100  USE OF NOR ADULTS SPAWNED TO INCREASE THE PROPORTIONATE NATURAL INFLUENCE (PNI) WITHIN THE RIVER SPAWNING POPULATION. THIS EFFORT INCLUDES TRAPPING AT THE HATCHERY, IN RIVER COLLECTION, AND TAKES MORE PERSONNEL, TIME AND SORTING OF FISH TO ACHIEVE THE NOR X HOR SPAWNING CROSSES. EACH YEAR THE HATCHERY STRIVES TO INCREASE THE NOR FISH NUMBERS FOR SPAWNING TO ACHIEVE THE IN-RIVER NATURAL ORIGIN BROOD (NOB) AND INCREASE THE PNI TO A MORE BALANCED STATE BETWEEN HATCHERY AND NATURAL ORIGIN BROODSTOCK. COLLECTION OF ADULTS AT THE HATCHERY TRAPS ALSO ALLOWS ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTISTS AND RESEARCHERS ADDITIONAL OPPORTUNITY FOR DATA COLLECTION, I.E. MALE AND FEMALE RATIOS, SIZE, SCALE SAMPLES, GENETIC COLLECTION, ABILITY TO TAG ADULTS FOR IN-RIVER STUDIES, ETC.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE S (CDFW) NORTHERN REGION IS HEADQUARTERED IN REDDING, CALIFORNIA,AND INCLUDES THE FOLLOWING COUNTIES: DEL NORTE, HUMBOLDT, LASSEN, MENDOCINO, MODOC, SHASTA, SISKIYOU, TEHAMA, AND TRINITY. THIS REGION CONTAINS THOUSANDS OF MILES OF RIVERS AND STREAMS INCLUDING ALL OR PORTIONS OF THESACRAMENTO, SMITH, KLAMATH, TRINITY AND EEL RIVERS. LAKES AND RESERVOIRS ARE LOCATED THROUGHOUT THE REGIONINCLUDING SHASTA AND TRINITY LAKES. THESE WATERS HAVE HISTORICALLY PROVIDED RICH AND DIVERSE SPORT FISHINGOPPORTUNITIES FOR COLD AND WARM WATER FISH SPECIES (E.G., SMALLMOUTH AND LARGEMOUTH BASS, BLUEGILL, CRAPPIE,GREEN SUNFISH AND KOKANEE). STREAMS ALSO PROVIDE SPAWNING AND REARING HABITAT FOR ANADROMOUS SPECIES HELPING TOSUSTAIN COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL OCEAN SPORT FISHERIES, IN-RIVER SPORT FISHERIES AND TRIBAL QUOTAS (E.G.,CHINOOK AND COHO SALMON, STEELHEAD, LAMPREY).

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS GRANT APPLICATION IS TO OPERATE AND MAINTAIN FOUR STATE FISH HATCHERIES AND A SATELLITE FISH-REARING POND FOR A ONE YEAR PERIOD FOR STATE FISCAL YEAR 2024. IN ADDITION, THIS GRANT APPLICATION WILL ALSO PROVIDE FUNDING FOR WILD STOCK BROODFISH AND STATEWIDE EGG COLLECTIONS.

THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS THE STATE OF KANSAS SPORT FISH SAMPLING AND DATA COLLECTION EFFORTS ACROSS 40 STATEFISHING LAKES THAT TOTAL 4,300 ACRES, AND 25 FEDERAL FLOOD CONTROL RESERVOIRS COVERING APPROXIMATELY 166,000ACRES. IN ADDITION, THE DEPARTMENT PROVIDES TECHNICAL ADVICE TO 212 CITY AND COUNTY GOVERNMENT AGENCIES ACROSSTHE STATE WHICH OWN 14,000 ACRES OF COMMUNITY-BASED IMPOUNDMENTS. EACH OF THESE PROPERTIES REQUIRES PRECISE,EXPERT ADVICE AND INTENSIVE MANAGEMENT TO ALLOW FOR THE BEST POSSIBLE ANGLING OPPORTUNITY FOR THE PUBLIC WHILEALSO BENEFITTING THE RESOURCE.

THIS GRANT FUNDS THE OUTREACH AND EDUCATION AIMING TO DEVELOP AN ANGLING PUBLIC THAT UNDERSTANDS AND IS INVOLVED IN THE MANAGEMENT ALASKA SPORT FISHERIES WHILE CULTIVATING AN ATTITUDE OF SUSTAINABLE USE AND STEWARDSHIP OF ALASKAS FISHERY RESOURCE AND THEIR HABITAT.

ANNUAL ASSESSMENTS OF SPORT AND PREY FISH POPULATIONS ARE NECESSARY FOR EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT, PROTECTION AND ENHANCEMENT OF FISHERIES. IN THIS PROJECT, WE PROPOSE A SERIES OF ANNUAL ASSESSMENT SURVEYS TARGETING IMPORTANT SPORT AND PREY FISH POPULATIONS IN THE ILLINOIS PORTION OF LAKE MICHIGAN (976,640 ACRES). SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL ASSESS THE RELATIVE ABUNDANCE AND CONDITION OF LAKE TROUT, YELLOW PERCH, STOCKED SALMON AND TROUT, VARIOUS PREY FISH STOCKS, AND THE NON-SALMONINE NEARSHORE FISH COMMUNITY (E.G., LARGEMOUTH BASS, SMALLMOUTH BASS, ROCK BASS AND OTHER SUNFISHES). THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES SPECIFIC NEEDS IDENTIFIED IN THE LAKE MICHIGAN MANAGEMENT PORTION OF THE STRATEGIC PLAN FOR THE CONSERVATION OF ILLINOIS FISHERIES RESOURCES (ILLINOIS DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES) AND WILL PROVIDE MANAGERS WITH TIMELY INFORMATION ON THE STATUS OF IMPORTANT SPORT AND PREY FISH POPULATIONS IN THE ILLINOIS PORTION OF LAKE MICHIGAN. THIS INFORMATION WILL BE SHARED WITH OTHER AGENCY PARTNERS AND USED TO MONITOR TRENDS AND CHANGES OF ABUNDANCE OR CONDITION OF FISH STOCKS. DEPARTMENT FISHERIES MANAGERS WILL BE BETTER ABLE TO INSTITUTE EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AND ACTIONS FOR THE BETTERMENT OF THE ANGLING PUBLIC REGARDING STOCKING LEVELS, SPORT HARVEST REGULATIONS AND PREDATOR-PREY RELATIONSHIPS.

THE PROJECT RESULTS IN A GEOGRAPHICALLY EXTENSIVE AND ANNUAL ASSESSMENT OF SPORTFISH POPULATIONS AND ASSEMBLAGES IN ILLINOIS LARGE RIVERS. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A REACH SPECIFIC STOCK ASSESSMENT AND STRUCTURE OF IMPORTANT ILLINOIS RECREATIONAL AND COMMERCIALLY VALUABLE SPORTFISH THAT CAN BE USED TO GUIDE THEIR MANAGEMENT AND INFORM REGULATIONS FOR HARVEST. EXTENSIVE MARK RECAPTURE AND POPULATION ASSESSMENT OF ROCK RIVER STURGEON WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION NEEDED TO BETTER MANAGE THIS IMPORTANT, BUT POORLY UNDERSTOOD SPORTFISH COMMUNITY. FINALLY, THE IDENTIFICATION OF ONE UNIFIED ELECTROFISHING APPROACH THAT BEST FITS THE IDNR GOALS WILL INCREASE THE EFFICIENCY OF DATA COLLECTION, PRECISION AND ACCURACY OF ABUNDANCE ESTIMATES, AND STANDARDIZATION OF DATA TO INFORM MORE RELIABLE AND MEANINGFUL MANAGEMENT DECISIONS OVER TIME.
