SURVEYS AND INVESTIGATIONS FOR SPORTFISH MANAGEMENT IN LAKES AND RIVERS IN ILLINOIS, F-185-R-12

THE FISHERY CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ACT OF 1976 (ACT) DECLARED A FISHERY CONSERVATION ZONE IN OCEAN WATERS SURROUNDING THE UNITED STATES FROM 3 TO 200 MILES OFFSHORE. UNDER THIS ACT THE PACIFIC FISHERIES MANAGEMENT COUNCIL (PFMC) WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1976. IN 1977, THE PFMC RECOGNIZED THE NEED FOR SALMON RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AND IMPLEMENTED THE FISHERY MANAGEMENT PLAN (FMP) FOR COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL SALMON FISHERIES OFF THE COASTS OF WASHINGTON, OREGON, AND CALIFORNIA. THIS FMP HAS BEEN REVISED MULTIPLE TIMES SINCE 1977 AND THIS PLANNING DOCUMENT WAS UPDATED THROUGH AMENDMENT 21 IN SEPTEMBER OF 2021. THE KLAMATH RIVER IS REGARDED AS ONE OF THE MORE IMPORTANT PRODUCERS OF FALL-RUN CHINOOK SALMON (KRFC) TO CALIFORNIA AND SOUTHERN OREGON COMMERCIAL AND SPORT FISHERIES. KRFC CONSIST LARGELY OF NATURALLY PRODUCED (NATIVE SPORTFISH) STOCKS AS WELL AS HATCHERY PRODUCED STOCKS. PFMC MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOCUS ON HARVEST OPPORTUNITIES WHEN STOCKS CAN SUPPORT HARVEST AND PROVIDE A FRAMEWORK FOR HARVEST RESTRICTIONS WHEN ABUNDANCE IS FORECASTED TO BE LOW. THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA, WITH MANAGEMENT JURISDICTION OF FISHERIES IN COASTAL WATERS WITHIN THREE MILES OF SHORE AND INLAND SPORT FISHERIES, IMPLEMENTS KRFC MANAGEMENT PRACTICES AND REGULATIONS CONFORMING TO PFMC OBJECTIVES. THEREFORE, KRFC RUN-SIZE DATA IS A CRITICAL MANAGEMENT COMPONENT FOR CHINOOK SALMON SPORT FISHERIES AND COMMERCIAL FISHERIES CONDUCTED IN CALIFORNIA AND OREGON. IN ADDITION TO THE HARVESTABLE STOCK OF KRFC, OTHER IMPORTANT ANADROMOUS SALMONIDS OCCUR IN THE KLAMATH RIVER INCLUDING SPRING RUN CHINOOK SALMON, COHO SALMON AND STEELHEAD TROUT. WITH THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE COHO SALMON HARVEST CONTROL RULE IN 2022 (NATIONAL MARINE FISHERIES SERVICE (NMFS) 2022) AS DETAILED IN THE SOUTHERN OREGON NORTHERN CALIFORNIA COAST (SONCC) COHO SALMON BIOLOGICAL OPINION THE NEED FOR STATUS AND TREND DATA FROM THIS PORTION OF THE EVOLUTIONARILY SIGNIFICANT UNIT (ESU) IS REQUIRED TO MANAGE THIS EMERGING FISHERY.

THE SMITH RIVER IS CALIFORNIA S LARGEST FREE-FLOWING RIVER AND PROVIDES A FLAGSHIP FISHING DESTINATION FOR THOUSANDS OF ANGLERS ANNUALLY FISHING FOR STEELHEAD TROUT, RESIDENT RAINBOW TROUT, COASTAL CUTTHROAT TROUT, AND CHINOOK SALMON. MOST OF THE BASIN IS WITHIN THE SMITH RIVER NATIONAL RECREATION AREA WITH DOZENS OF DEVELOPED RIVER ACCESS POINTS USED FOR FISHING AND OTHER RECREATION ACTIVITIES. THERE ARE A TOTAL OF SEVEN INDIVIDUAL FISHERY REGULATION ZONES AND 18 INDIVIDUAL SPECIES  ZONE-SPECIFIC REGULATIONS RESULTING IN 25 UNIQUE FISHERIES THROUGHOUT THE BASIN  SECTION 180  2018 CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) REGULATIONS . MANAGEMENT OF THESE IN-RIVER FISHERIES AS WELL AS THE EVALUATION OF OCEAN FISHERIES HARVEST RATES RELIES UPON INFORMATION REGARDING THE ROBUSTNESS OF INDIVIDUAL STOCKS AND THE FRESHWATER HABITATS UPON WHICH THEY DEPEND. THE NATIONAL MARINE FISHERIES SERVICE S (NMFS) ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA) SECTION 7(A) (2) CURRENT BIOLOGICAL OPINION ANTICIPATES INCIDENTAL TAKE OF ESA-LISTED SOUTHERN OREGON   NORTHERN CALIFORNIA COAST (SONCC) COHO SALMON TO OCCUR EACH YEAR IN SALMON FISHERIES. UNDER THE PROPOSED ACTION, THE PACIFIC FISHERIES MANAGEMENT COUNCIL SHALL CONSTRAIN TOTAL EXPLOITATION RATE OF SONCC COHO AT 15.0 PERCENT FOR EACH OF THE INDIVIDUAL POPULATIONS WITHIN THE ESU EFFECTIVELY LIMITING FISHERIES FOR OTHER SPECIES. NMFS, IN COLLABORATION WITH THE COUNCIL, INDICATES STATES SHOULD CONTINUE TO INVESTIGATE INCREASES IN MONITORING INCLUDING EXPANSION OF SPAWNING GROUND SURVEYS TO AID THE COMANAGERS  ABILITY TO ASSESS IMPACTS TO WILD SONCC COHO SALMON, REDUCING SOME OF THE UNCERTAINTY REFLECTED IN THE RISK ASSESSMENT. ESTIMATING ANNUAL CHINOOK SALMON AND STEELHEAD TROUT ESCAPEMENT AND IDENTIFYING CRITICAL AREAS FOR JUVENILE REARING WILL AID IN DEFINING FUTURE SALMONID HABITAT RESTORATION PRIORITIES AND FISHERIES MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. FISHERIES ASSESSMENT AND MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS PRODUCED IN TECHNICAL REPORTS ASSOCIATED WITH THIS SPORT FISH RESTORATION ACT (SFRA) PROJECT ARE THE PRIMARY CATALYST FOR IDENTIFYING RESTORATION ACTIONS TARGETED AT INCREASING SPORTFISH POPULATION NUMBERS AND EVALUATING FISHERIES MANAGEMENT. AN EFFECTIVE MEANS TO ESTIMATE SPAWNING ESCAPEMENT IN LARGER RIVER SYSTEMS IS THROUGH THE USE OF SOUND NAVIGATION AND RANGING (SONAR) TECHNOLOGY. IN ORDER TO ESTIMATE SPAWNING ESCAPEMENT OF ANADROMOUS SALMONID SPECIES IN THE SMITH RIVER BASIN USING SONAR, TWO KEY STUDY COMPONENTS ARE NEEDED. THE FIRST COMPONENT IS OPERATION OF THE SONAR UNIT TO ENUMERATE FISH AS THEY MIGRATE UPSTREAM. THE SECOND COMPONENT PARTITIONS THIS COUNT INTO UNIQUE SPECIES BY ESTIMATING THE SPECIES COMPOSITION OF FISH USING AUXILIARY SAMPLING TECHNIQUES. THE JUVENILE SNORKEL SURVEYS WILL INVESTIGATE HOW POPULATIONS ARE DISTRIBUTED WITHIN THE BASIN. INFORMATION REGARDING THE DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF SALMONID SPECIES REARING WITHIN THE BASIN IS NECESSARY TO EVALUATE BOTH IN-RIVER FISHERIES ASSOCIATED WITH CDFW HERITAGE TROUT WATERS AND TRENDS IN SALMONID SPECIES DISTRIBUTION AND OCCUPANCY PATTERNS THROUGHOUT THE BASIN OVER TIME. THE SPAWNING GROUND SURVEY COMPONENT OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TARGETED AT EVALUATION OF CHINOOK SALMON, COHO SALMON AND STEELHEAD SUB-POPULATIONS IN MILL CREEK WITHIN THE SMITH RIVER. BECAUSE POPULATIONS OF COHO SALMON ARE SMALL RELATIVE TO CHINOOK SALMON AND STEELHEAD, SONAR COUNTS PARTITIONED TO SPECIES ARE EXPECTED TO BE IMPRECISE FOR COHO SALMON. MILL CREEK IS KNOWN TO SUPPORT THE MAJORITY OF SPAWNING COHO SALMON ADULTS IN THE SMITH RIVER. WE THEREFOR TAKE A MORE APPROPRIATE, SPAWNING GROUND SURVEY APPROACH TO MONITORING TRENDS FOR THIS STOCK IN THE MILL CREEK SUB-BASIN. ADDITIONALLY, COLLECTION OF SCALES FROM CHINOOK SALMON TAKEN DURING THIS EFFORT CAN BE USED TO ADD AGE STRUCTURE TO ESTIMATES OF ABUNDANCE DERIVED FROM THE SONAR COUNTS.

THIS PROJECT INCLUDES THE ADMINISTRATION OF THE STATE OF UTAH S BOATING ACCESS PROGRAM, WHICH PROVIDES FOR IMPROVEMENTS MADE TO ENHANCE THE EXPERIENCES OF RECREATIONAL BOATERS AND BOATING ANGLERS IN UTAH. PROPOSALS FOR NEW PROJECTS, SUCH AS NEW BOAT RAMPS, COURTESY DOCKS, RESTROOMS, AND FISH CLEANING STATIONS, AMONG OTHER AMENITIES, ARE SUBMITTED ANNUALLY FOR FUNDING CONSIDERATION. LIKEWISE, PROPOSALS ARE SUBMITTED TO MAINTAIN EXISTING BOATING FACILITIES. PROJECTS APPROVED FOR FUNDING REQUIRE ADMINISTRATION AND OVERSIGHT, INCLUDING THE DRAFTING AND SUBMISSION OF FEDERAL GRANT PROPOSALS, MONITORING OF CONTRACTS AND AGREEMENTS, BILLING, PAYMENT, REPORTING, AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF OUTREACH MATERIAL TO HIGHLIGHT PROJECTS. IN ADDITION, PROJECT FUNDING PROVIDES FOR THE MAINTENANCE OF UTAH DIVISION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES-OWNED BOATING ACCESS FACILITIES.

UTAHS AQUATIC ANIMAL HEALTH AND RESEARCH CENTER, FORMERLY KNOWN AS THE FISHERIES EXPERIMENT STATION (FES) IS DESIGNED TO PROVIDE ADMINISTRATIVE, RESEARCH AND AQUATIC ANIMAL HEALTH SERVICES FOR THE UTAH DIVISION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES (UDWR). MUCH OF THIS WORK IS DIRECTED TOWARD IDENTIFYING AND IMPLEMENTING BROAD SCALE PRIORITIES TO HELP PROTECT, CONSERVE AND MANAGE AQUATIC SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS IN ACCORDANCE WITH REGIONAL AND STATEWIDE OBJECTIVES.THE CENTERS RESEARCH PROGRAM HAS BEEN ACTIVELY INVOLVED IN FISHERIES RESEARCH SINCE 1986, ALTHOUGH INFORMAL RESEARCH HAS BEEN CONDUCTED AT THE LOCATION SINCE THE EARLY 1960S. CURRENTLY THE PROGRAM PROVIDES APPLIED RESEARCH METHODS TO ADDRESS NEEDS ASSOCIATED WITH UTAHS SPORTFISH AND NATIVE RECOVERY PROGRAMS. THE CENTERS ANIMAL HEALTH PROGRAM PLAYS AN EXTENSIVE ROLE IN ADDRESSING AQUATIC ANIMAL HEALTH ISSUES FOR BOTH STATE FISH CULTURE FACILITIES AND MANAGED WATERS. THIS SECTION INCLUDES DIAGNOSTIC AND INSPECTION SERVICES GEARED TOWARD STATEWIDE MONITORING, QUICK RESPONSE, TIMELY REPORTING AND MANAGEMENT OF FISH PATHOGENS WITHIN BIOLOGICAL AND LEGAL REQUIREMENTS FOR ALL SPORTFISH AND CONSERVATION SPECIES NEEDS.RESULTS AND BENEFITS FROM THIS WORK INCLUDE DATA DRIVEN RECOMMENDATIONS FOR REGIONAL AND STATEWIDE AQUATIC SECTION BIOLOGIST TO MEET MANAGEMENT GOALS, PROMOTE HEALTHY FISH POPULATIONS, ENHANCE SPORT FISHERIES AND IMPROVE CONSERVATION EFFORTS THROUGHOUT UTAH.
THIS PROJECT IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE COORDINATION AND ADMINISTRATION OF MISSISSIPPI WILDLIFE, FISHERIES, AND PARKS SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROJECTS FOR MS FISCAL YEAR 2024.
CONSERVATION AND ECOLOGY OF ILLINOIS SPORTFISH, F-202-R-4

RED SNAPPER (LUTJANUS CAMPECHANUS) IS A HIGHLY PRIZED FINFISH IN RECREATIONAL FISHERIES AND IS PARTICULARLY IMPORTANT TO MISSISSIPPI GIVEN ITS ECONOMIC AND CULTURAL IMPACTS. HOWEVER, TRADITIONAL FISHERY-INDEPENDENT MONITORING METHODS POORLY REFLECT THE RELATIVE ABUNDANCE OF THIS SPECIES. ACCORDINGLY, WE PROPOSE THE DEVELOPMENT OF A CAMERA-BASED MONITORING METHOD, WHICH HAS SHOWN SUCCESS IN OTHER GULF STATES, AND WAS SUCCESSFULLY USED DURING THE RECENT GREAT RED SNAPPER COUNT. THE PROPOSED METHOD REPRESENTS A MORE EFFICIENT AND POTENTIALLY MORE EFFECTIVE MANNER OF SAMPLING THAT WILL POSITIVELY BENEFIT FEDERAL STOCK ASSESSMENT AND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS FOR THE STATE OF MISSISSIPPI. WE ENVISION THIS MONITORING PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE VALUABLE INSIGHT FOR MISSISSIPPI FISHERY MANAGERS AND ANGLERS ALIKE, WHILE ENSURING THE CONTINUED SUSTAINABILITY OF THIS IMPORTANT NATURAL RESOURCE. THIS PROJECT INCLUDES THE DEVELOPMENT OF A CAMERA-BASED MONITORING SURVEY FOR REEF FISHES IN OFFSHORE MISSISSIPPI, WHICH ARE OF UTMOST RECREATIONAL IMPORTANCE. THE PROPOSED METHOD REPRESENTS A MORE EFFICIENT AND POTENTIALLY EFFECTIVE MANNER OF SAMPLING THAT WILL POSITIVELY BENEFIT FEDERAL STOCK ASSESSMENT AND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS FOR THE STATE OF MISSISSIPPI. THIS ASPECT, COMBINED WITH THE ALREADY SUCCESSFUL FISHERY DEPENDENT MONITORING PROGRAM, WILL PROVIDE A COMPREHENSIVE UNDERSTANDING OF MISSISSIPPI S OFFSHORE REEF FISH POPULATIONS AND AID IN THEIR SUSTAINABILITY THROUGHOUT THE FUTURE.

THROUGH SURVEYS AND INVENTORIES OF FISH POPULATIONS AND THEIR HABITATS, RESOURCE MANAGERS AND ADMINISTRATORS CAN GAUGE THE CONDITION OF IMPORTANT NATURAL AQUATIC RESOURCES. THIS INFORMATION INFORMS THE MEASURES TAKEN TO ENSURE THEIR CONTINUED PROTECTION, MANAGEMENT, AND DEVELOPMENT OF RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES IN GEORGIA.

CONTINUED STANDARDIZED SAMPLING OF OHIO RIVER FISH POPULATIONS IS NEEDED TO DETERMINE THE STATUS OF SPORT FISH POPULATIONS AND INFORM MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR THESE SPECIES  IN CONJUNCTION WITH LONG-TERM ELECTROFISHING SAMPLING ON THE ILLINOIS, WABASH, AND MISSISSIPPI RIVERS, CONTINUED SAMPLING OF OHIO RIVER FISH POPULATIONS WILL PROVIDE A UNIQUE ASSESSMENT OF TRENDS IN RIVERINE FISH COMMUNITIES OVER A LARGE GEOGRAPHIC SCALE. ASSESSMENTS OF SEVERAL SPORT FISH POPULATIONS IN THE ILLINOIS SECTION OF THE OHIO RIVER HAVE RECENTLY BEEN CONDUCTED, BUT CURRENT INFORMATION ON ANGLING EFFORT, CATCH AND HARVEST, AND ANGLER DEMOGRAPHICS AND OPINIONS REGARDING OHIO RIVER SPORT FISHERIES ARE LACKING. IN ADDITION, ASSESSMENT OF THE EFFECTS OF HARVEST REGULATIONS ON SPORT FISH POPULATIONS IS OFTEN CHALLENGING BECAUSE MEAN VALUES OF POPULATION VITAL RATES DO NOT ALWAYS RESPOND TO MODIFIED REGULATIONS. STOCK ASSESSMENT MODELS THAT ARE EASILY USED, GENERALIZABLE, AND ACCOUNT FOR VARIABILITY IN DEMOGRAPHIC RATES AND COHORT SIZE STRUCTURE ARE NEEDED. THUS, THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO: 1) CONDUCT STANDARDIZED FIXED-SITE AND RANDOM-SITE SAMPLING ON THE ILLINOIS PORTION OF THE OHIO RIVER DURING JULY-OCTOBER 2023 AND COMPARE SPECIES COMPOSITION, RELATIVE ABUNDANCE, AND SIZE STRUCTURE TO DATA FROM PRIOR YEARS TO ASSESS INTER-ANNUAL TRENDS IN FISH POPULATION CHARACTERISTICS AND THEIR POTENTIAL CAUSES  2) COMPLETE AN ACCESS POINT CREEL AND ANGLER SURVEY ON THE ILLINOIS PORTION OF THE OHIO RIVER DURING JULY 2023-MARCH 2024 (CONTINUING THE SURVEY STARTED IN F-187-R-11) TO QUANTIFY ANGLING EFFORT, CATCH, AND HARVEST OF SPORT FISHES, AND COLLECT INFORMATION ON ANGLER OPINIONS REGARDING OHIO RIVER FISHERIES  AND 3) DEVELOP, APPLY, AND TEST AN INDIVIDUAL-BASED MODEL AND DATA ANALYSIS TOOL OF COHORT-SPECIFIC GROWTH AND SURVIVAL FOR SPORT FISH POPULATIONS IN ILLINOIS LAKES AND RIVERS. PROJECT OBJECTIVES 1 AND 2 WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION ON POPULATION STATUS, HARVEST, AND ANGLING EFFORT FOR OHIO RIVER SPORT FISHES TO INFORM FISHERIES MANAGEMENT. THE INDIVIDUAL-BASED MODEL AND DATA ANALYSIS TOOL WILL WILL ALLOW MANAGERS TO ASSESS THE IMPACT OF REGULATIONS ON DISTRIBUTIONS OF LENGTHS AND AGES IN FISH POPULATIONS RATHER THAN MEAN RESPONSES.
F-13-C-33 RECREATIONAL BOATING AND SPORT FISHING ACCESS COORDINATION BOATING ACCESS

THIS PROJECT WILL FUND THE BOATING OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE BUDGETS FOR EACH OF THE THREE REGIONS IN ALASKA. THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THE SE ACCESS MAINTENANCE PROJECT (BOATING) IS TO MAINTAIN EXISTING BOATING ACCESS FACILITIES, PROVIDE TEMPORARY FACILITIES AT ACCESS SITES (SUCH AS SANITATION FACILITIES), DEVELOP OR MAKE MINOR IMPROVEMENTS TO EXISTING BOATING ACCESS SITES, AND COORDINATE CONSTRUCTION AND RENOVATION OF CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT PROJECT (CIP) BOATING ACCESS FACILITIES.THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THE SOUTHCENTRAL ACCESS MAINTENANCE PROJECT (BOATING) IS TO MAINTAIN AND DEVELOP BOATING ACCESS SITES, PROVIDE LAND AND EASEMENT RESEARCH, AND ACQUIRE EASEMENTS IN ORDER TO ACCOMMODATE THE RECREATIONAL BOATING AND SPORT ANGLING DEMAND IN SOUTHCENTRAL ALASKA. THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING FOR BOATING ACCESS IMPROVEMENTS AND MAINTENANCE ACTIVITIES THAT COLLECTIVELY PROVIDE SIGNIFICANT SPORT FISHING OPPORTUNITIES TO SOUTHCENTRAL ALASKA S ANGLERS.THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THE REGION III ACCESS MAINTENANCE PROJECT (BOATING) IS TO MAINTAIN EXISTING BOATING ACCESS FACILITIES, PROVIDE SIGNAGE AND REPAIRS, AND MAKE MINOR IMPROVEMENTS TO EXISTING BOATING ACCESS SITES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO RESEARCH, MODEL, STOCK, AND EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF YY MALE BROOK TROUT IN REMOVING BROOK TROUT FROM HABITATS CURRENTLY OR FORMERLY OCCUPIED BY RIO GRANDE CUTTHROAT OR GILA TROUT. AS WELL AS TO EXPLORE THE POTENTIAL FOR YY BROWN TROUT PROJECTS AND ADVANCE THE DEVELOPMENT OF A BROODSTOCK FOR THE SPECIES. THESE ACTIONS WILL ULTIMATELY HELP TO IMPROVE ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES FOR AND IMPROVE THE CONSERVATION STATUS OF NATIVE TROUT.

LOCATED IN SHASTA COUNTY, READING ISLAND BOAT LAUNCH (RIBL) SITS AT A SITE THAT IS CURRENTLY POPULAR FOR FISHING, WITH A PICNIC AREA, VAULT TOILETS, POTABLE WATER AND A GROUP CAMP SITE. HOWEVER, THE BOAT LAUNCH IS CLOSED BECAUSE IT IS DETERIORATED, BLOCKED BY INVASIVE AQUATIC VEGETATION AND SILTED IN. IT ALSO DOES NOT HAVE FACILITIES SUCH AS FLOATING DOCK OR A SEPARATE NON-MOTORIZED ACCESS. THIS GRANT WILL FUND THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE PLANNING, ENGINEERING, AND PERMITTING FOR THE EVENTUAL CONSTRUCTION OF THE LAUNCH FACILITY.

SPORT FISHING IN THE INLAND PORTION OF THE NORTHERN REGION OF THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) PROVIDES A HIGH LEVEL OF OUTDOOR RECREATION AND ADVENTURE. THE ABILITY TO MONITOR, MANAGE, AND ENHANCE SPORT FISH OPPORTUNITIES IS ESSENTIAL TO MAINTAIN A HIGH LEVEL OF ANGLER OPPORTUNITIES, SATISFACTION AND NATURAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION AND PROTECTION. IN THE NORTHERN REGION THE ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTISTS SERVING AS THE DISTRICT BIOLOGIST, ASSISTED BY SCIENTIFIC AIDES (TEMPORARY HELP) PLAY A MAJOR ROLE IN DEVELOPMENT AND MANAGEMENT OF SPORT FISH OPPORTUNITIES. THIS GRANT WILL PROVIDE THE FUNDING NECESSARY FOR ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTISTS TO ASSESS AND MANAGE PRIORITY SPORT FISH RESOURCES WITHIN THE NORTHERN REGION.

THE PRIMARY FUNCTION OF THIS GRANT IS TO MANAGE GEORGIA S DIVERSE FISHERY RESOURCES WHICH INCLUDE MORE THAN 4,000 MILES OF TROUT STREAMS, 12,000 MILES OF WARM WATER STREAMS, AND 500,000 ACRES OF IMPOUNDMENTS THROUGH POPULATION MONITORING, PRODUCTION OF SPORTFISH, HABITAT MANAGEMENT, TECHNICAL GUIDANCE, AND OPERATION OF PUBLIC FISHING AREAS.
FUNDING FROM THIS GRANT IS USED TO MONITOR, MANAGE, AND CONSERVE MARINE FISHERIES THROUGHOUT COASTAL LOUISIANA.
THIS GRANT PROVIDES FUNDING TO STOCK COMMUNITY FISHING PONDS THROUGHOUT LOUISIANA.

SOUTH CAROLINAS ESTUARIES REPRESENT A VALUABLE RESOURCE FOR RESIDENTS AND VISITORS DUE INLARGE PART TO THE IMPORTANCE OF THESE SYSTEMS AS NURSERY HABITAT FOR MANY INSHORE FISHERY SPECIES.THE COASTAL ZONE IS A MAJOR TOURISM DESTINATION THAT CONTRIBUTES SUBSTANTIALLY TO THE STATES  14 BILLION TRAVEL AND TOURISM INDUSTRY (WORLD TRAVEL AND TOURISM COUNCIL 2001), AND THE ECONOMIC IMPACT OF THE STATES SALTWATER RECREATIONAL AND COMMERCIAL FISHERIES ALONE EXCEEDS  650 MILLION (SCDNR UNPUBLISHED DATA). THE SOUTHEAST US HAS SEEN THE FASTEST POPULATION GROWTH RATES OF ALL US COASTAL AREAS (CROSSETT 2005). POPULATION GROWTH IN THE COASTAL COUNTIES OF SOUTH CAROLINA HAS BEEN RAPIDLY INCREASING IN RECENT YEARS, WITH OVER ONE MILLION RESIDENTS LIVING IN THE STATESEIGHT COASTAL COUNTIES IN 2004 AND AN ADDITIONAL 300,000 RESIDENTS EXPECTED BY 2025 (SC BUDGETAND CONTROL BOARD 2005). THE ASSOCIATED DEVELOPMENT, COMBINED WITH INCREASED RECREATIONALUTILIZATION OF OUR COASTAL WATERS, WILL RESULT IN AN ESCALATING POTENTIAL FOR SERIOUS IMPACTS TO SOUTHCAROLINAS COASTAL HABITATS AND FISHERIES.THE COASTAL LOWCOUNTRY OF SOUTH CAROLINA HOSTS MORE SALT MARSH HABITAT THAN ANY OTHER ATLANTIC COAST STATE (SAMFC 1998). THIS HABITAT IS DISSECTED BY EXTENSIVE TIDAL CREEK SYSTEMSTHAT DRAIN SURROUNDING UPLAND AREAS (DAME ET AL. 2000) AND PROVIDE NURSERY HABITAT TO MANY ECONOMICALLY IMPORTANT FISHERY SPECIES (OGBURN 1988  SAMFC 1998  ROSS 2003). INCREASING HUMAN POPULATION GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT OF OUR COASTLINE CAN PLACE STRESS ON FISHERY SPECIESAND ESTUARINE HABITATS THROUGH BOTH INCREASING FISHING PRESSURE AND HABITAT DEGRADATION (HOLLANDET AL. 2004). HABITAT DEGRADATION RELATED TO HUMAN LAND USE PRACTICES CAN RESULT FROM CHANGES INWATER QUALITY (NUTRIENT ENRICHMENT, CHANGING FRESHWATER RUNOFF, REDUCED OXYGEN CONCENTRATIONS,ETC.), SEDIMENT QUALITY (SUCH AS INCREASED SEDIMENT CONTAMINATION), AND FOOD RESOURCES (SUCH ASBENTHIC INFAUNAL PREY) (SANGER ET AL. 1999A  SANGER ET AL. 1999B  LERBERG ET AL. 2000). HABITATDEGRADATION CAN ALSO IMPAIR HUMAN USE OF FISHERY RESOURCES BY CONTAMINATING FISH TISSUES WITHFECAL COLIFORM BACTERIA AND VARIOUS POLLUTANTS SUCH AS HYDROCARBONS, POLYCHLORINATED BIPHENYLS,AND METALS (E.G., VAN DOLAH ET AL. 2006).THE SOUTH CAROLINA ESTUARINE AND COASTAL ASSESSMENT PROGRAM (SCECAP HTTP:  WWW.DNR.STATE.SC.US MARINE SCECAP) WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1999 TO ASSESS THE OVERALL HEALTH(WATER QUALITY, SEDIMENT QUALITY, AND BIOLOGICAL INTEGRITY) OF THE STATES ESTUARINE HABITATS ON A PERIODIC BASIS. SCECAP PROVIDES THE MOST COMPREHENSIVE DATA ON HABITAT QUALITY AVAILABLE FORSOUTH CAROLINAS COASTAL AND ESTUARINE ENVIRONMENTS (VAN DOLAH ET AL. 2013). SINCE ITSINCEPTION, SCECAP HAS PROVIDED A SOURCE OF FISHERIES-INDEPENDENT MONITORING FOR SEVERALRECREATIONALLY IMPORTANT SPECIES FOR WHICH LITTLE OR NO OTHER SUCH MONITORING INFRASTRUCTURE EXISTS. THE PROJECT PROPOSED HERE WOULD CONTINUE SCECAP MONITORING EFFORTS, TARGETING RECREATIONALLY-IMPORTANT FISHERY SPECIES UTILIZING ESTUARIES AS NURSERY HABITATS DURING THE SUMMER(PARTICULARLY SPOT, WEAKFISH, AND CROAKER). THE SUMMER PERIOD REPRESENTS A SEASON WHENJUVENILES ARE PRESENT IN BOTH TIDAL CREEK AND OPEN WATER HABITATS, AND WHEN WATER QUALITY CONDITIONS (TEMPERATURE AND DISSOLVED OXYGEN) ARE MOST LIMITING. THE QUALITY OF ESTUARINE HABITATS FOR THESE SPECIES WILL ALSO BE EVALUATED BY MEASURING OVERALL FINFISH AND CRUSTACEAN DIVERSITY AND ABUNDANCE, QUALITY OF BENTHIC INVERTEBRATE FOOD SOURCES, AND OTHER ENVIRONMENTALQUALITY MEASURES.

THIS GRANT PROVIDES FUNDING TO PROCESS AGE, GROWTH, REPRODUCTIVE AND MORTALITY DATA, EVALUATE MANAGEMENT OPTIONS, DEVELOP RECOMMENDATIONS, AND DEVELOP STOCK ASSESSMENTS AND MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR RECREATIONALLY IMPORTANT SPORT FISHES.
THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO OPERATE AND MAINTAIN MS DEPT OF WILDLIFE, FISHERIES, AND PARKS, FISHERIES BUREAU, LAKE JEFF DAVIS FOR THE BOATERS AND ANGLERS OF MISSISSIPPI.

STREAMS AND RIVERS IN ILLINOIS OFFER GREAT FISHING AND RECREATION OPPORTUNITIES TO THE PUBLIC AND SUPPORT HIGH DIVERSITY OF AQUATIC LIFE. OUR RESEARCH TEAM IN THE ILLINOIS NATURAL HISTORY SURVEY HAS CONDUCTED MULTIPLE-YEAR FISHERIES MONITORING IN SEVERAL MAJOR TRIBUTARIES OF THE ILLINOIS RIVER, INCLUDING THE MACKINAW, VERMILION, AND KANKAKEE RIVER TO SUPPORT THE MANAGEMENT AND DECISION-MAKING PROCESSES OF ILLINOIS DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (IDNR), FISHERIES DIVISION. THIS PARTICULAR PROJECT CONTINUES OUR EFFORT TO INVESTIGATE THE POSSIBLE CAUSES OF THE SMALLMOUTH BASS POPULATION DECLINE AND POOR SUCCESS OF STOCKING IN THE MACKINAW RIVER. OUR APPROACH IS TO COMPARE THE POPULATIONS AND HABITATS OF THE SPECIES IN DIFFERENT RIVERS, PARTICULARLY THE MACKINAW AND VERMILION RIVER, WHICH ARE SIMILAR IN MANY WAYS (E.G., SIZE AND STOCKING). WE SHALL CONDUCT FISH SAMPLING WITH BOAT AND TOW-BARGE SHOCKING, NESTING SURVEYS DURING SPAWNING, AND ASSESS FORAGING HABITAT QUALITY BETWEEN RIVERS. THE DATA COLLECTED FROM THESE EFFORTS SHALL BE ANALYZED AND SYNTHESIZED TO ASSESS THE POTENTIAL LIMITING FACTORS FOR THE SMALLMOUTH BASS POPULATION IN THE MACKINAW RIVER. THE INFORMATION THEN CAN BE USED TO SUPPORT MANAGEMENT DECISIONS BY IDNR AND HELP US TO BETTER UNDERSTAND HOW THIS POPULAR SPORTFISH SPECIES INTERACTS WITH ITS ENVIRONMENT.

IN RECENT YEARS, AQUATIC INVASIVE PLANT INFESTATIONS (E.G., WATER HYACINTH) HAVE BECOME INCREASINGLY PROBLEMATIC THROUGHOUT THE SACRAMENTO-SAN JOAQUIN DELTA (DELTA) AND ITS TRIBUTARIES, PARTICULARLY IN THE SAN JOAQUIN AND MERCED RIVERS. THE RAPID GROWTH RATES AND EXCESSIVE ACCUMULATION OF PLANT BIOMASS HAVE RESULTED IN A WIDE VARIETY OF RECREATIONAL AND ECOLOGICAL IMPACTS, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO: BANK TO BANK VEGETATION DAMS IN NUMEROUS PLACES ALONG THE MAINSTEM SAN JOAQUIN AND MERCED RIVERS, CREATING A COMPLETE IMPASSE FOR BOATERS  AND PRECLUDED ACCESS TO LAUNCH RAMPS AND NAVIGABILITY OF WATERWAYS ON CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) WILDLIFE AREAS, RESULTING IN CLOSURE OF ACCESS POINTS AND RECREATION AREAS TO THE PUBLIC. THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION  DIVISION OF BOATING AND WATERWAYS  (DBW) (CONTRACTOR) IS THE LEAD STATE AGENCY FOR CONTROLLING INVASIVE AQUATIC PLANTS IN THE DELTA, SUISUN MARSH, AND ITS TRIBUTARIES  HAS THE AUTHORITY MANDATE TO CONTROL AUTHORIZED SPECIES OF AQUATIC INVASIVE PLANTS (AIP) TO MAINTAIN ACCESS AND NAVIGABILITY OF THE WATERWAYS UNDER ITS JURISDICTION  AND MAINTAINS THE NECESSARY BIOLOGICAL OPINIONS, PERMITS, AND APPLICATOR LICENSES TO IMPLEMENT ITS AQUATIC INVASIVE PLANT CONTROL PROGRAM (AIPCP) FOR BOTH FLOATING  EMERGENT (FAV) AND SUBMERSED AQUATIC VEGETATION (SAV). IN ADDITION TO THE CHEMICAL TREATMENTS CONDUCTED BY THE AIPCP, DBW ALSO UTILIZES EXTERNAL CONTRACTORS (SUBCONTRACTORS) TO PERFORM PHYSICAL AND MECHANICAL REMOVAL TREATMENTS THROUGHOUT THEIR JURISDICTION, AS WELL FOR CHEMICAL TREATMENTS (AND OTHER CONTROL METHODS) IN AREAS WHERE DBW LACKS THE CAPACITY TO PERFORM THE WORK. AIP INFESTATIONS THROUGHOUT THE DELTA AND ITS TRIBUTARIES HAVE RAPIDLY WORSENED IN THE LAST TWO TO THREE YEARS DUE TO A COMBINATION OF FACTORS THAT INCLUDES EXACERBATION BY EXCEPTIONAL DROUGHT CONDITIONS, AIPCP CAPACITY AND RESOURCE LIMITATIONS, AND LAPSED TREATMENTS IN CRITICAL AREAS AND CONVEYANCE SYSTEMS. AT THE CURRENT EXTENT OF THE AIP INFESTATIONS, THE AIPCP, WITHOUT RESOURCE AUGMENTATION, IS UNABLE TO IMPLEMENT CONTROL EFFORTS WITH THE SCOPE, SCALE, AND INTENSITY NECESSARY TO MAINTAIN ACCESS AND NAVIGABILITY OF THE WATERWAYS IN THE SAN JOAQUIN VALLEY.

CONSTRUCTION OF THE LITTLE SUSITNA PUBLIC USE FACILITY (LSPUF), LOCATED ON THE LITTLE SUSITNA RIVER NEAR RIVER MILE (RM) 29, WAS COMPLETED IN 1990 USING FEDERAL AID IN SPORT FISH RESTORATION FUNDS UNDER PROJECT F-13-D-6. FACILITY CONSTRUCTION ALLOWED FOR EXCELLENT BOATING ACCESS TO UPPER AND LOWER SECTIONS OF THE RIVER IN THE POINT MACKENZIE AREA SOUTHWEST OF THE COMMUNITY OF WASILLA. THE FACILITY IS OWNED BY THE STATE OF ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME (ADF G) DIVISION OF SPORT FISH (DSF) AND IS LOCATED WITHIN THE SUSITNA FLATS STATE GAME REFUGE. OVER THE YEARS, NUMEROUS FEDERAL AID PROJECTS HAVE IMPROVED AND MAINTAINED THE FUNCTION OF THE FACILITY, INCLUDING: LSPUF BOAT LAUNCH RAMP REPLACEMENT, PROJECT F-13-D-53  LITTLE SUSITNA RIVER TRAIL DEVELOPMENT, PROJECT F-13-D-68  LSPUF REMOTE CAMPSITE DEVELOPMENT, PROJECT F-13-D-75  AND LSPUF VAULT LATRINE REPLACEMENT, PROJECT F-13-D-138.THE LSPUF IS A HIGH USE SITE THAT PROVIDES ACCESS AND RECREATIONAL USE FOR SPORT ANGLERS, CAMPERS, AND RECREATIONAL BOATERS. THE FACILITY IS LOCATED AT AN END-OF-THE ROAD LOCATION THAT SEASONALLY REQUIRES AN ON-SITE PRESENCE TO ENSURE PROPER SITE MANAGEMENT, MAINTENANCE, AND SECURITY. THESE SERVICES ARE PROVIDED BY THE DEPARTMENT AND A VOLUNTEER CAMPGROUND HOST. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE FUNDS TO ENSURE THAT THE FACILITY IS BEING PROPERLY OPERATED AND MAINTAINED IN A SAFE AND SECURE MANNER FOR PUBLIC USE.

SUSITNA LANDING IS THE LARGEST ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH   GAME (ADF G), DIVISION OF SPORT FISH (DSF) OWNED BOATING ACCESS FACILITY IN THE STATE AND ONE OF THE PRIMARY BOAT LAUNCH SITES IN THE SUSITNA RIVER DRAINAGE. NUMEROUS SITE IMPROVEMENTS HAVE PROVIDED SERVICES THAT FEW BOAT LAUNCH FACILITIES IN SOUTHCENTRAL ALASKA CAN MATCH. THE CONTRACT FOR A STATE-HIRED CONTRACTOR RESPONSIBLE FOR THE DAY-TO-DAY OPERATIONS OF THE FACILITY WAS NOT RENEWED BY ADF G AND THE CONTRACT TERMINATED OCTOBER 31, 2022. ADF G DSF STAFF TOOK OVER DAY-TO-DAY MANAGEMENT OF THE SUSITNA LANDING FACILITY NOVEMBER 1, 2022, AND WILL CONTINUE TO MANAGE THE SITE THROUGH JUNE 30, 2024.REQUIRED ROUTINE OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE (O M) TASKS OVERSEEN BY DSF STAFF INCLUDE: YEARLY DREDGING OF THE BOAT LAUNCH AND BOAT MOORING AREA  ROAD AND PARKING LOT GRADING  VAULT LATRINE AND SHOWER BUILDING CLEANING  SNOW AND TRASH REMOVAL  COLLECTION OF FEES  AND, GENERAL MAINTENANCE OF BOARDING FLOAT, BUILDINGS, FISH CLEANING TABLES, CAMPSITES, AND OTHER AMENITIES. ANNUAL CONTRACTS FOR REFUSE CONTAINER SERVICES, PORTABLE TOILET RENTAL, WINTER SNOW PLOWING, AND VAULT LATRINE CLEANING, AS WELL AS LARGER MAINTENANCE TASKS AND CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS WILL BE CONTRACTED SEPARATELY BY DSF THROUGH THE STATE S COMPETITIVE BIDDING PROCESS. FEES COLLECTED FOR FACILITY USE HELP PAY FOR THE VOLUNTEER CAMPGROUND HOST SUBSISTENCE STIPEND, STAFFING HOURS, AND O M COSTS. PUBLIC USE AND REVENUE GENERATED ARE LARGELY DEPENDENT ON SEASONAL SPORT FISHERY SUCCESS, WEATHER AND WATER CONDITIONS, AND TOURISM. HISTORICALLY, THE ANNUAL AMOUNT OF REVENUE GENERATED THROUGH FEE COLLECTION HAS ONLY PROVIDED A PORTION OF THE COSTS REQUIRED TO MANAGE AND MAINTAIN THE FACILITY.SUSITNA LANDING IS LOCATED AT THE END OF A ONE-MILE GRAVEL ROAD (SUSITNA LANDING ROAD) OFF THE PARKS HIGHWAY, APPROXIMATELY 84 MILES NORTH OF ANCHORAGE. WITH A LACK OF LAW ENFORCEMENT PERSONNEL AT THE SITE (OR ANYWHERE NEARBY), DSF STAFF WILL MAKE ROUTINE VISITS, AND A SUMMER VOLUNTEER CAMPGROUND HOST WILL HELP PREVENT THEFT AND VANDALISM FROM OCCURRING AND PROVIDE A SECURITY PRESENCE FOR THE PUBLIC UTILIZING THE SITE. OTHER MEASURES THAT DSF HAS TAKEN TO PROVIDE A SAFE SITE ARE THE ADDITION OF MOTION DETECTORS TO MONITOR TRAFFIC INTO AND OUT OF THE FACILITY, AND ADDITIONAL SECURITY CAMERAS WHICH WERE INSTALLED IN JANUARY 2023.FACILITY IMPROVEMENTS INCLUDE ACCESSIBLE SHOWERS AND VAULT TOILETS, ELECTRIC AND NON-ELECTRIC RV CAMPING SITES, BOAT LAUNCH AND DOCK, AND ENHANCEMENTS TO PARKING AND TRAFFIC FLOW. THESE IMPROVEMENTS, ALONG WITH WEATHER CONDITIONS DURING THE WINTER MONTHS, COMPOUND THE MAINTENANCE NEEDS OF THE FACILITY WHERE TEMPERATURES CAN DROP BELOW MINUS-FORTY DEGREES FAHRENHEIT. REGULAR INSPECTION AND MAINTENANCE OF ON-SITE BUILDINGS AND AMENITIES IS REQUIRED TO HELP PREVENT COSTLY REPAIRS.THE DSF HAS INVESTED A SIGNIFICANT AMOUNT OF TIME AND FUNDING INTO SUSITNA LANDING TO PROVIDE RECREATIONAL BOATERS AND SPORT ANGLERS WITH UP-TO-DATE AMENITIES AND IMPROVEMENTS TO MAKE THEIR RECREATIONAL EXPERIENCES MORE PLEASURABLE AND ACCOMMODATING. DSF NOT ONLY HAS AN OBLIGATION TO THE FEDERAL AID IN SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM TO MAINTAIN THE SITE, BUT MUST CONTINUE TO PROVIDE SAFE, RESPONSIBLE, AND SECURE MANAGEMENT OF THE FACILITY FOR THE RECREATING ANGLERS.

WANTING TO PROVIDE A UNIQUE FISHING EXPERIENCE DURING THE WINTER MONTHS KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AND PARKS STARTED ITS TROUT PROGRAM IN 1995. THROUGH THE COMMERCIAL PURCHASE OF HARVESTABLE - SIZED RAINBOW TROUT KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AND PARKS CAN PROVIDE A UNIQUE FISHING EXPERIENCE THAT WOULD NOT BE POSSIBLE WITH THESE EFFORTS. KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AND PARKS SUPPLIES TROUT TO 16 LOCATIONS LOCATED THROUGHOUT THE STATE SO THAT KANSAN CAN ENJOY A DIFFERENT FISHING EXPERIENCE DURING THE WINTER MONTHS. A  14.50 ANNUAL PERMIT FEE IS REQUIRED TO FOR ADULTS AND A  7.00 FOR YOUTH 15 AND UNDER ARE USED TO OFFSET THE COST OF PURCHASING TROUT. WITH THE SUMMER WATER TEMPERATURE BEING LETHAL TO TROUT, THE SEASON RUNS FOR NOVEMBER 1 TO APRIL 15 WHEN WATER TEMPERATURES ARE BELOW LETHAL RANGE FOR TROUT. THE GOAL OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO PROVIDE A DIFFERENT OPPORTUNITY FOR ANGLERS.

SDGFP CURRENTLY MAINTAINS AND OPERATES THREE FULL PRODUCTION HATCHERIES, TWO SPAWNING STATIONS, SEVEN REARING PONDS, AND NUMEROUS NATURAL REARING AREAS. HIGH DEMANDS FOR FISH CULTURE PRODUCTS  CONTINUE AS MANAGERS WORK TO FULFILL OPERATIONAL PLANS. INCREASED PRECIPITATION IN RECENT YEARS  HAVE CREATED NEW AND EXPANDED OPPORTUNITIES FOR FISHERIES. THE AMOUNT OF COLDWATER HABITAT IN  STREAMS IN THE BLACK HILLS HAS INCREASED, AND MANY EASTERN SOUTH DAKOTA LAKES ARE GREATLY EXPANDED IN SIZE. HATCHERY FISH ARE FREQUENTLY USED TO QUICKLY DEVELOP FISHERIES IN THESE SITUATIONS. IN ADDITION, SDGFP HAS RECENTLY PLACED CONSIDERABLE EMPHASIS ON URBAN FISHERIES. THESE PONDS AND SMALL  LAKES FREQUENTLY DO NOT HAVE THE HABITAT NEEDED FOR FISH REPRODUCTION, GROWTH, AND LONG-TERM SURVIVAL. HATCHERY-REARED FISH ARE FREQUENTLY USED TO PROVIDE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITY IN THESE WATERS LOCATED WITHIN OR IN CLOSE-PROXIMITY TO RELATIVELY LARGE CONCENTRATIONS OF PEOPLE.THE PROCEDURES AND FISH CULTURE PRACTICES AT HATCHERIES OWNED AND OPERATED BY SDGFP ARE CONTINUALLY EVALUATED AND IMPROVED AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE TO MAXIMIZE FISH REARING EFFICIENCIES AND THE POST-STOCKING SURVIVAL OF HATCHERY- REARED FISH. THE HATCHERY SYSTEM IS ALSO CONTINUALLY CHALLENGED TO MEET THE PRODUCTION REQUESTS FROM FISHERIES MANAGERS, WHO ARE IN TURN CHALLENGED TO MEET THE EXPECTATIONS OF THE LICENSED ANGLERS IN SOUTH DAKOTA. STABLE FUNDING SOURCES DIRECTED TO SPAWNING OPERATIONS, FISH CULTURE, DISEASE PREVENTION, ENERGY USE, POND HARVESTING, WATER TREATMENT, TRANSPORTATION OF FISH FOR STOCKING, AND OTHER HATCHERY ACTIVITIES IS ESSENTIAL TO THE SUCCESS OF SDGFP FISHERIES MANAGEMENT EFFORTS. A BALANCED APPROACH TO FISHERIES MANAGEMENT, INCLUDING OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF FISH CULTURE FACILITIES, IS CRITICAL TO THE FUTURE OF RECREATIONAL FISHING IN SOUTH DAKOTA.

THE NEW MEXICO DEPARTMENT OF GAME AND FISHS FISHERIES MANAGEMENT DIVISION (FMD) HAS HISTORICALLY COLLECTED ALL MONITORING DATA ON PHYSICAL DATASHEETS AND MAINTAINED THAT DATA IN MULTIPLE DATABASES. CONTINUED CHANGES IN TECHNOLOGY AND PERSONNEL, AS WELL AS THE EVER-GOWNING VOLUME OF HISTORICAL AND CURRENT MONITORING DATA HAS INCREASED THE NEED FOR FMD TO DEVELOP A SINGLE COMPREHENSIVE DATABASE FOR HOUSING DATA THAT CAN BE EASILY ACCESSED AND USED BY BIOLOGISTS. DEVELOPMENT OF DIGITAL DATA COLLECTION APPLICATIONS WILL ALSO STREAMLINE WORKFLOWS, DECREASE DATA ENTRY AND CLEANING EFFORTS, AND INCREASE TIME AVAILABLE FOR ANALYSIS.

THE CITY OF GREEN RIVER IS ENGAGING IN A MULTIFACETED PROJECT TO ENHANCE THE USE OF THE RIPARIAN CORRIDOR OF THE GREEN RIVER WHERE IT BISECTS THE CITY AND ENHANCE BOATER ACCESS OPPORTUNITIES FOR RAFTERS AND PADDLERS USING GREEN RIVER. THE FIRST PHASE OF THIS PROJECT CREATED A BOATING ACCESS PUT-IN AND TAKE-OUT RAMP ADJACENT TO THE JOHN WESLEY POWELL RIVER HISTORY MUSEUM (MUSEUM). THIS PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO CONSTRUCT A CONCRETE ADA-ACCESSIBLE ACCESS TRAIL FROM THE BOATER PARKING AREA DOWN TO THE NEWLY CONSTRUCTED RAMP. THE CURRENT STATE OF THE SITE PROPOSED FOR TRAIL CONSTRUCTION CAN BE CATEGORIZED AS A PREVIOUSLY DISTURBED STEEP BANK. THE PREVIOUSLY DISTURBED AREA IS LOCATED WITHIN THE HISTORICAL RIPARIAN CORRIDOR OF THE GREEN RIVER AND PRIMARILY VEGETATED WITH INVASIVE TAMARISK AND RUSSIAN OLIVE. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE PADDLERS AND RAFTERS ON THE GREEN RIVER WITH UNIVERSAL ACCESS TO THE IMPROVED RETRIEVAL AND LAUNCHING AREA IN THE TOWN OF GREEN RIVER  ENHANCING BOATER ACCESS ON ALONG THE GREEN RIVER CORRIDOR. ADDITIONALLY, PREVIOUSLY DISTURBED AREAS ADJACENT TO THE RAMP HAVE BEEN REHABILITATED USING NATIVE SEED MIXES AND WILLOW PLANTINGS TO REPLACE REMOVED STANDS OF INVASIVE TAMARISK AND RUSSIAN OLIVE. TO COMPLETE THE ADA-ACCESS TRAIL PROJECT, THE CITY OF GREEN RIVER, UTAH PLANS TO CONSTRUCT A 6 FOOT WIDE AND 856 FOOT LONG CONCRETE ACCESS PATH BETWEEN THE PARKING AREA AND RAMP ADJACENT TO THE MUSEUM.

THE NORTH CENTRAL REGION (NCR) OF THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) PROPOSES TO CONDUCT STUDIES OF FISH POPULATION STRUCTURE, POPULATION DYNAMICS, FISH SPECIES COMPOSITION, AND ANGLER UTILIZATION AND PREFERENCE TO ASSESS RECREATIONAL FISHERIES ACROSS THE REGION. THIS INFORMATION WILL BE UTILIZED TO MANAGE SPORT FISHERIES INCLUDING WILD AND SELF-SUSTAINING FISHERIES AND HATCHERY-BASED SPORT FISHERIES. STUDIES WILL BE CONDUCTED ON COLD WATER (SALMONID SPECIES) AND WARM WATER (CENTRARCHID AND ICTALURID SPECIES) SPORT FISH THAT OCCUR IN LAKES, RESERVOIRS, STREAMS, AND RIVERS THROUGHOUT THE REGION. DATA WILL BE COLLECTED USING ELECTROFISHING, SEINING, SNORKEL, MARK RECAPTURE, GILL NET, CREEL SURVEY TECHNIQUES, AND ONLINE ANGLER SURVEYS. THESE METHODS ARE APPLICABLE TO COMPLETING GENERAL FISH SURVEYS (GFS) AND FISHERY ASSESSMENTS.

IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA, MANY SPECIES HAVE SHOWN CONSIDERABLE DECLINES IN ABUNDANCE OVER THE PAST 10-20 YEARS. MANY OF THESE SPECIES ARE SUBJECTS OF IMPORTANT SPORT FISHERIES, INCLUDING BARRED SAND BASS, CALIFORNIA HALIBUT, AND PACIFIC BARRACUDA. IN ORDER TO UNDERSTAND THESE DECLINES AND MANAGE THESE FISHERIES SUSTAINABLY, ESSENTIAL FISHERY INFORMATION (EFI) IS NEEDED TO ASSESS THEIR POPULATIONS. EFI INCLUDES DATA ON AGE AND GROWTH, REPRODUCTION, AND OTHER LIFE HISTORY CHARACTERISTICS THAT ARE IMPORTANT FOR MANAGING A SUSTAINABLE FISHERY. THESE DATA FORM THE BASIS FOR STOCK ASSESSMENTS AND MODELS THAT PROVIDE BETTER INFORMATION ON THE HISTORY, CURRENT STATUS, AND FUTURE DIRECTION OF THESE IMPORTANT SPORT FISHERIES AND ENABLE THEIR BETTER MANAGEMENT.A MASTER PLAN PER THE MARINE LIFE MANAGEMENT ACT (MLMA: SECTION 7050 FISH AND GAME CODE) WAS UPDATED AND IMPLEMENTED IN JUNE 2018 TO REFLECT NEW PRIORITIES AND MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES FOR STATE MARINE FISHERIES. THE MLMA MASTER PLAN INCLUDES A FRAMEWORK FOR MLMA-BASED MANAGEMENT THAT USES A PRIORITIZATION APPROACH FOLLOWED BY THE APPROPRIATE MANAGEMENT SCALING FOR THAT FISHERY. PRIORITIZATION INTEGRATES A PRODUCTIVITY AND SUSCEPTIBILITY ANALYSIS (PSA) THAT LOOKS AT RISKS TO STOCKS WITH AN ECOLOGICAL RISK ASSESSMENT (ERA) THAT EVALUATES ECOLOGICAL RISKS. ONCE A PRIORITIZED LIST OF FISHERIES IS GENERATED, A SCALED MANAGEMENT STRATEGY APPROPRIATE TO THAT FISHERY IS APPLIED. THIS RANGES FROM ENHANCED STATUS REPORTS (ESRS) FOR THOSE FISHERIES WITH LOWER PRIORITY AND COMPLEXITY TO FISHERY MANAGEMENT PLANS (FMPS) FOR THE HIGHER PRIORITY AND MORE COMPLEX ONES. THE MLMA MASTER PLAN CALLS FOR FMPS AND ESRS TO BE DEVELOPED FOR FISHERIES TO SYSTEMATICALLY ADDRESS OBJECTIVES AND REQUIREMENTS OF THE MLMA. RECOGNIZING THAT FMPS ARE COSTLY, RESOURCE-INTENSIVE, AND CAN TAKE YEARS TO COMPLETE, ESRS PROVIDE A SCALED APPROACH THAT CAN BE APPLIED TO MORE FISHERIES ON A MORE IMMEDIATE BASIS. ESRS CONTAIN MANY COMPONENTS OF AN FMP INCLUDING SPECIES DESCRIPTIONS, LANDINGS INFORMATION, MONITORING EFFORTS, AND IDENTIFICATION OF INFORMATION AND MANAGEMENT NEEDS. AN ADVANTAGE OF ESRS IS THAT THEY CAN BE MADE READILY AVAILABLE AND UPDATED ANNUALLY TO PROVIDE CURRENT INFORMATION TO THE STAKEHOLDERS. ESRS HAVE BEEN DEVELOPED FOR THE ABOVE FISHERIES WHICH IDENTIFIED CONCERNS AND EFI THAT SHOULD BE ADDRESSED TO BETTER MANAGE THESE FISHERIES. THIS GRANT SPECIFICALLY ADDRESSES THESE ITEMS.

THE PURPOSES OF THE MISSOURI FISHERIES MANAGEMENT PROGRAM GRANT IS TO:1. GATHER THE FISH POPULATION, AQUATIC HABITAT AND ANGLER USE INFORMATION NEEDED TO EFFECTIVELY MANAGE THE STATE S STREAMS AND PUBLIC LAKES IN ORDER TO ENHANCE RECREATIONAL FISHING OPPORTUNITIES THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF MISSOURI. THIS PROJECT PROVIDES INFORMATION ABOUT THE RESULTS OF PAST MANAGEMENT ACTIONS (I.E., STOCKING, REGULATIONS, HABITAT IMPROVEMENT) SO THAT THE DEPARTMENT CAN REFINE TECHNIQUES, ADJUST MANAGEMENT PLANS, TAKE APPROPRIATE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS ON OTHER WATERS, AND DEVELOP PROGRAMS THAT ARE POPULAR AND EFFECTIVE. 2. INSTALL AND MAINTAIN HABITAT IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS ON THE STATE S STREAMS AND PUBLIC LAKES IN ORDER TO ENHANCE RECREATIONAL SPORT FISH POPULATIONS AND PROVIDE INCREASED RECREATIONAL FISHING OPPORTUNITIES THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF MISSOURI. THE DEPARTMENT HAS MADE A CONCERTED EFFORT TO ENSURE THE ENSURE AREAS IT MANAGES HAVE THE KIND OF HABITAT THAT SUPPORTS HEALTHY AQUATIC COMMUNITIES AND QUALITY SPORT FISHING. THE DEPARTMENT ALSO ENSURES THAT IN-LAKE HABITAT IS BOTH PRODUCTIVE AND FISHABLE. 3. PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO PUBLIC AGENCIES TO IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING OF THE EFFECTS OF HUMAN ACTIVITIES ON THE AQUATIC ENVIRONMENT AND TO SUPPORT UPDATING AND IMPROVING ENVIRONMENTAL REGULATIONS IN THE STATE OF MISSOURI. THE DEPARTMENT HAS AS AN IMPORTANT, IF NOT MANDATED, STAKEHOLDER, PARTNER AND PROVIDER OF TECHNICAL INFORMATION AND SUPPORT IN MATTERS PERTAINING TO AQUATIC HABITAT, AQUATIC COMMUNITIES, FISHERIES AND ANGLING. 4. PROVIDE TECHNICAL GUIDANCE TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS TO EFFECTIVELY MANAGE AND CONSERVE THE STATE OF MISSOURI S FISHERIES AND AQUATIC RESOURCES AND MEET THE NEEDS AND EXPECTATIONS OF ANGLERS. IF THE DEPARTMENT IS TO EFFECTIVELY MANAGE AND CONSERVE FISHERIES IN THE STATE, THEIR PROFESSIONAL TECHNICAL GUIDANCE MUST INCLUDE PRIVATELY OWNED LANDS IN ORDER TO HAVE LANDSCAPE-LEVEL EFFECTS. 5. CONDUCT FISHERIES AND AQUATIC RESOURCES MANAGEMENT PLANNING IN ORDER TO ENHANCE RECREATIONAL SPORT FISH POPULATIONS AND PROVIDE INCREASED RECREATIONAL FISHING OPPORTUNITIES THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF MISSOURI. THROUGH THE PLANNING PROCESS, THE DEPARTMENT IS ABLE TO IDENTIFY AND INVOLVE PARTNERS AND STAKE HOLDERS  IDENTIFY ISSUES, PROBLEMS AND OPPORTUNITIES  GATHER AND ORGANIZE INFORMATION  EVALUATE THE RESULTS OF PAST EFFORTS, ESTABLISH GOALS AND OBJECTIVES  DEVELOP STRATEGIES AND WORK SCHEDULES. COMMUNICATE NEEDS AND INTENTIONS  AND MONITOR PROGRESS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO OPERATE AND MAINTAIN FACILITIES AND PROVIDE STAFF, INCLUDING A LICENSED VESSEL CAPTAIN AND CREW, TO MAINTAIN THE OPERATIONAL READINESS OF THE RESEARCH VESSEL  R V FIRST STATE , THE PRIMARY RESEARCH AND MONITORING PLATFORM FOR THE DELAWARE DIVISION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE THE SAFE AND RELIABLE OPERATION OF THE R V FIRST STATE TO ENSURE DELAWARE S FISHERY-INDEPENDENT DATA COLLECTION EFFORTS ARE MAINTAINED. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF SECURE DOCKAGE, FUEL, MAINTENANCE, AND PERSONNEL FOR THE SAFE STORAGE AND OPERATION OF THE PRIMARY RESEARCH PLATFORM TO MEET THE DIVISION S FINFISH MONITORING REQUIREMENTS IN THE DELAWARE ESTUARY AND ATLANTIC OCEAN. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE RECREATIONAL FISHING PUBLIC OF DELAWARE BECAUSE THE ACTIVITIES PERFORMED BY THE R V FIRST STATE ARE NECESSARY TO MAINTAIN DELAWARE S COMPLIANCE WITH INTERSTATE FISHERIES MANAGEMENT PLANS. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENTS.
THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO DETERMINE THE GENETIC COMPOSITION OF LARGEMOUTH BASS COLLECTED FROM PUBLIC WATERS THAT HAVE BEEN STOCKED WITH FLORIDA LARGEMOUTH BASS THROUGHOUT LOUISIANA.

FUNDING FROM THIS GRANT SUPPORTS ADMINISTRATIVE TASKS ASSOCIATED WITH CARRYING OUT THE OBJECTIVES OF ALL SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROJECTS. TASKS INCLUDE GRANT APPLICATION AND MANAGEMENT, TRAINING ACTIVITIES, BUDGET MANAGEMENT, AND OTHER COORDINATION ACTIVITIES.
THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO MONITOR, MANAGE AND CONSERVE FRESHWATER FISHERIES THROUGHOUT LOUISIANA.

THIS GRANT WILL  RECRUIT NEW ANGLERS, RETAIN ACTIVE ANGLERS, AND PROMOTE OUTDOORS ETHICS BY INCREASING THE PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING OF THE WATER RESOURCES AND ASSOCIATED AQUATIC LIFE FORMS IN PUERTO RICO. TO ACHIEVE THIS PURPOSE, THE PROGRAM OFFERS FISHING ACTIVITIES AND DEVELOPS EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS IN THE FOLLOWING FORMS: IN ADDITION, WITH PRASP THE DNER WILL TARGET PUBLIC AND PRIVATE SCHOOLS TO INTRODUCE ARCHERY AS A SPORT TO THEIR PHYSICAL EDUCATION CURRICULUM THROUGHOUT THE ISLAND. FINALLY, THE PUERTO RICO HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM PORTION OF THE GRANT WILL EDUCATE HUNTERS ON THE SKILLS AND ATTITUDES NECESSARY TO PRACTICE THE SPORT RESPONSIBLY BY PROVIDING TRAINING ON HUNTING AND SHOOTING EQUIPMENT SAFETY, HUNTER RESPONSIBILITIES AND KNOWLEDGE OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES. THE PROGRAM ALSO PRODUCES AND DISTRIBUTES INFORMATION REGARDING HUNTING AND SHOOTING SPORTS.

ANGLER USE AND ANGLING SUCCESS IS CURRENTLY BEING EVALUATED ON MOSSBACK FISH CITY HABITAT  STRUCTURES IN CENTRAL SOUTH DAKOTA IMPOUNDMENTS. THIS RESEARCH FOCUSES ON THE USE OF THESE  STRUCTURES BY ANGLERS AND SEEKS TO DESCRIBE CHANGES IN ANGLER EFFORT AND FISHING SUCCESS ASSOCIATED  WITH THE PLACEMENT OF ARTIFICIAL HABITAT STRUCTURES. WE WOULD LIKE TO EXPAND ON THIS WORK TO  DETERMINE TO WHAT DEGREE SPORTFISH USE DIFFERENT ARTIFICIAL FISH HABITAT STRUCTURES AND DETERMINE FISH SELECTION BETWEEN TWO TYPES OF INTRODUCED HABITAT TYPES AS WELL AS NATURAL FISH HABITAT. THERE ARE SEVERAL ARTIFICIAL FISH HABITAT STRUCTURES ON THE MARKET, AND ALL ARE EXPENSIVE, CAN TAKE CONSIDERABLE TIME TO ASSEMBLE AND PLACE IN THE SYSTEMS, AND ALL CLAIM SIMILAR RESULTS AS FAR AS SPORTFISH USE. HOWEVER, SPECIFIC USE OF THESE STRUCTURES BY COMMON SOUTH DAKOTA SPORTFISH HAS NOT BEEN ASSESSED AND BIOLOGISTS QUESTION TO WHAT DEGREE THESE STRUCTURES EFFECTIVELY ATTRACT SPORTFISH AND IF FISH USE OF THESE ARTIFICIAL HABITAT STRUCTURES DIFFER SEASONALLY OR BETWEEN SPECIFIC HABITAT TYPES AND OR SPECIES.WE ARE REQUESTING DJ FUNDING FOR A RESEARCH PROJECT THAT WOULD USE ACOUSTIC TELEMETRY ARRAYS TO EVALUATE HABITAT USE BY COMMON SOUTH DAKOTA SPORTFISH OVER MULTIPLE SEASONS. THE MANAGEMENT GOALS OF THIS STUDY WOULD BE TO DETERMINE SEASONAL USE OF VARIOUS ARTIFICIAL AND NATURAL HABITAT TYPES AND MAKE RECOMMENDATIONS TO FISH MANAGERS ON WHICH HABITAT TYPES ARE MOST USED BY COMMON SPORTFISH IN SOUTH DAKOTA WATERS.
THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO ENHANCE RECREATIONAL SPORT FISH POPULATIONS AND PROVIDE INCREASED RECREATIONAL FISHING OPPORTUNITIES THROUGHOUT LOUISIANA.

THE DIVISION OF AQUATIC RESOURCES EDUCATION PROGRAM IS DESIGNED TO ENHANCE PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING OF HAWAIISAQUATIC ENVIRONMENTS, DEVELOP RESPONSIBLE ATTITUDES AND A SENSE OF STEWARDSHIP TOWARD HAWAIIS AQUATICRESOURCES, ENCOURAGE PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT IN CONSERVATION ISSUES, AND PROMOTE SAFE AND ETHICAL AQUATIC RESOURCEBASEDRECREATION. THIS IS ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH FISHING EDUCATION CLASSES EMPHASIZING CONSERVATION  IN-SERVICETRAINING FOR TEACHERS  CLASSROOM PRESENTATIONS  PARTICIPATION IN OUTREACH EVENTS  PRESENTATIONS TO COMMUNITYGROUPS  AND OUTREACH THROUGH VARIOUS TYPES OF MEDIA INCLUDING WEBSITES, TELEVISION SPOTS, AND PRINTED MATERIALS.THE GOAL IS TO PROVIDE RESIDENTS AND VISITORS WITH INFORMATION THAT WILL HELP THEM MAKE WISE DECISIONS REGARDINGUSE OF OUR AQUATIC RESOURCES.

THE STATEWIDE FRESHWATER TECHNICAL GUIDANCE PROJECT PROVIDES PROFESSIONAL AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO PRIVATELANDOWNERS, GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, PUBLIC ENTITIES, LAND MANAGERS, AND NON-GOVERNMENT ORGANIZATIONS DURING PROJECTPLANNING AND PERMIT REVIEW PROCESSES TO PREVENT AND OR REDUCE NEGATIVE IMPACTS TO FRESHWATER HABITATS ANDRESOURCES FROM HUMAN DEVELOPMENT AND ACTIVITIES. PROVIDING EXPERT ADVICE AND INFORMATION ON FISH ASSESSMENTS,RESEARCH TECHNIQUES, SPECIES AND OR HABITAT MANAGEMENT HELPS THESE ENTITIES BETTER UNDERSTAND THE IMPACTS THEIRPROPOSED PROJECTS (I.E., STREAM DE-WATERING, DAMMING, OR CHANNELIZING  HIGHWAY BRIDGE CONSTRUCTION  HOUSING ANDOTHER LAND DEVELOPMENTS  HYDROPOWER DEVELOPMENT  INTRODUCTION OF EXOTIC ORGANISMS  PESTICIDE USAGE  WASTEDISPOSAL  AND WATERSHED MANIPULATION) MAY HAVE ON FRESHWATER FISH AND THEIR HABITAT RESOURCES

THE MARINE GAME FISH TAGGING PROGRAM IS AN ASMFC-CERTIFIED ANGLER-BASED PROJECT THAT UTILIZES RECREATIONAL ANGLERS FOR DEPLOYING EXTERNAL FISH TAGS IN MARINE GAME FISH. THE PROGRAM PROVIDES DATA ON MOVEMENT AND MIGRATORY PATTERNS, LENGTH FREQUENCY CHARACTERIZATION FOR RELEASED FISH, HABITAT UTILIZATION, AND MORTALITY ESTIMATES. THIS EFFORT SUPPLEMENTS BOTH FISHERY DEPENDENT AND INDEPENDENT DATA COLLECTION AND ALLOWS FOR MORE INFORMED MANAGEMENT DECISIONS IN SOUTH CAROLINA.

IN SOUTH CAROLINAS ESTUARINE AND OFFSHORE WATERS, PRIMARY FISH HABITAT IS USUALLY FOUND IN AREASWHERE THE OCEAN BOTTOM CONSISTS OF HARD SUBSTRATE SUCH AS ROCK OR SHELL WHICH BECOMES ENCRUSTEDWITH MARINE ORGANISMS TO FORM A LIVE BOTTOM REEF COMMUNITY. NATURALLY OCCURRING REEF AREASARE LIMITED OFF THE SOUTHEAST COAST AND, BECAUSE OF THIS LIMITED AVAILABILITY, OFTEN OVERFISHED. INAREAS WHERE HARD SUBSTRATE IS LACKING, MANMADE OR ARTIFICIAL REEFS CAN BE CREATED BY PROVIDING THIS HARD SUBSTRATE AND ALLOWING NATURAL COLONIZATION TO OCCUR. OYSTER REEFS ARE WELL DOCUMENTEDPRIMARY FISH HABITAT WITHIN ESTUARINE ENVIRONMENTS FOR INSHORE SPECIES AND JUVENILE OFFSHORE SPECIES. FISHERIES RESOURCES ARE THEREBY ENHANCED BY INCREASING THE AMOUNT AND AVAILABILITY OFOFFSHORE HARD BOTTOM HABITATS AND ESTUARINE OYSTER REEFS.

BETWEEN 2 JULY 2023 AND 1 JULY 2024, WE WILL MAINTAIN AN ARRAY OF 74 ACOUSTIC RECEIVERS OFF THE COAST OF SOUTH CAROLINA WHICH ENCOMPASS STATE AND FEDERAL WATERS. SEVENTEEN OF THESE RECEIVERS ARE LOCATED BETWEEN WINYAH BAY, SC AND THE SC NC BORDER, 37 OCCUR OFFSHORE OF CHARLESTON, AND 20 OCCUR BETWEEN TWO LARGE SOUND SYSTEMS (ST. HELENA AND PORT ROYAL) IN THE SOUTHERN PART OF THE STATE. FIVE ADDITIONAL RECEIVERS FUNDED BY THE USACE (MITIGATION REEF) ARE LOCATED OFF CHARLESTON, SC. ACROSS RECEIVERS THREE GENERAL HABITAT TYPES ARE REPRESENTED: SHIPPING CHANNELS (37 ), ARTIFICIAL REEFS (33 ), AND PREDOMINANTLY SANDY BOTTOM (30 ) REPRESENTATIVE OF BORROW AREAS FOR BEACH RE-NOURISHMENT AND SEDIMENT DISPOSAL AREAS. AS SUCH, THIS TYPE OF CONTINUOUS MONITORING IS INCREDIBLY BENEFICIAL FOR REFINING ASSESSMENT OF SPECIES VULNERABILITIES TO ANTHROPOGENIC DISTURBANCES AND, IN TURN, IMPROVING MITIGATION STRATEGIES FOR SAID THREAT EXPOSURES.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT REPRESENTS A SIGNIFICANT ENHANCEMENT TO OUR COBIA STOCK RESTORATION AND APPLIED FISHERIES RESEARCH PROGRAMS INCLUDING INCREASED CAPACITY FOR BROODSTOCK COLLECTION, MAINTENANCE, AND LARVAL PRODUCTION, AS WELL AS INCREASING ANGLER OUTREACH AND COLLABORATION FOR BIOLOGICAL SAMPLE COLLECTION AND THE IMPLEMENTATION OF NOVEL TECHNIQUES AND TOOLS IN STOCK ENHANCEMENT TO HELP ASSESS A UNIQUE DPS UNDER STRICT FISHING REGULATION.

THE PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE RECREATIONAL AND ECONOMIC BENEFITS FOR PUERTO RICAN (AND INTERNATIONAL) RECREATIONAL ANGLERS. IT WILL FACILITATE RECREATIONAL FISHING OPPORTUNITIES IN PUERTO RICO AND HELP PERPETUATE TRADITIONAL FISHING ACTIVITIES BY INCREASING THEIR CATCH AND REDUCING TIME AND FUEL SPENT SEARCHING FOR FISH SCHOOLS. WE AIM TO DEPLOY ADDITIONAL SUBMERGED FADS AND CONTINUE THE RESEARCH AROUND THESE STRUCTURES THAT HAS ALLOWED US TO EVALUATE THEIR EFFECTIVENESS, USE BY STAKEHOLDERS AND EFFECT ON RESOURCES (FISH DYNAMIC).

UNDERSTANDING KEY DEMOGRAPHIC PARAMETERS OF WILD, INTERTIDAL OYSTERS IN SOUTH CAROLINA IS KEY TOUNDERSTANDING AND MONITORING THE HEALTH OF THE HABITAT UPON WHICH MANY RECREATIONAL FINFISH SPECIESDEPEND. PARAMETERS SUCH AS NATURAL MORTALITY, RECRUITMENT, AND GROWTH OF WILD OYSTERS ARE EXPECTED TOVARY BY GEOGRAPHIC REGION AND AS A RESULT OF EPISODIC ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES. IN FY2024, AT LEAST 34LOCATIONS ACROSS THE COAST OF SOUTH CAROLINA WILL BE SAMPLED, WITH THREE REPLICATES COLLECTED PER SITE.THESE SAMPLES WILL BE PROCESSED IN THE MRRI SHELLFISH LABORATORY TO ESTIMATE REGIONALLY-EXPLICIT RATES OFNATURAL OYSTER MORTALITY AND OTHER APPROPRIATE POPULATION DEMOGRAPHIC PARAMETERS. THESE DATA WILL BEUSED TO ASSESS IMPACTS AND TO IDENTIFY AREAS OF CONCERN. THE VALUE OF THIS INFORMATION IS EXPECTED TO INCREASE WITH THE CONTINUED ANNUAL COLLECTION OF THESE DATA TO GENERATE A MULTI-YEAR DATASET.OVER THE PAST FIVE FISCAL YEARS, SMALL UNMANNED AERIAL SYSTEMS (SUAS) APPROACHES HAVE BEEN DEVELOPEDTO CONTINUE THE PROGRAM OF USING AERIAL PLATFORMS TO ACCURATELY MAP THE LOCATION OF INTERTIDAL OYSTER REEFS,AND HAVE GREATLY IMPROVED THE ABILITY TO MONITOR CHANGES IN THE COVERAGE OF INTERTIDAL OYSTERS IN SOUTHCAROLINA. SUCH SUAS METHODS HAVE GENERATED GEOREFERENCED IMAGERY PRODUCTS SUITABLE FOR HEADS-UPDIGITIZING OR AUTOMATED CLASSIFICATION. THESE METHODS WILL CONTINUE TO BE APPLIED AND REFINED IN FY2024.UNMANNED AIRCRAFT WILL BE USED TO COLLECT IMAGERY FROM KEY AREAS OF IMPORTANCE TO MANAGERS DURINGFY2024.A CRAB TRAP-BASED OYSTER REEF RESTORATION PROJECT WILL BE COMPLETED IN THE INTERTIDAL ZONE ALONG THE COASTOF SOUTH CAROLINA TO CREATE ESSENTIAL FISH HABITAT (EFH) AND PROTECT ADJACENT SALTMARSH HABITAT FROMEROSION DUE TO BOAT WAKES AND OR CURRENTS, WAVES, AND STORMS. THE MRRI SHELLFISH RESEARCH SECTION HASAN ESTABLISHED PROGRAM THAT COLLECTS ABANDONED AND DONATED CRAB TRAPS TO BE RE-PURPOSED AS OYSTER REEFSUBSTRATE TO CREATE NEW OYSTER REEFS. THESE TRAPS ARE REPAIRED, ALL VENTS CLOSED SO THAT THEY NO LONGERGHOST FISH, AND COATED IN A THIN LAYER OF CEMENT TO ATTRACT OYSTER LARVAE THAT ARE READY TO SETTLE AND ATTACHTO HARD SUBSTRATE. IN ADDITION, THE SHELLFISH RESEARCH SECTION HAS DEVELOPED A TECHNIQUE FOR PREFABRICATINGMANUFACTURED WIRE REEFS COMPRISING SIMILAR MATERIALS THAT CAN BE MADE TO ORDER BY MEMBERS OF THE SRSIN ORDER TO EXPAND THE FOOTPRINTS OF REEF-BUILDING SUBSTRATE THAT CAN BE DEPLOYED ON INTERTIDAL, ESTUARINESHORELINES. THESE REEF MATERIALS ARE ANCHORED WITH REBAR SO THAT THEY REMAIN IN PLACE AND THE REEFS WILLHAVE EDUCATIONAL SIGNS POSITIONED ON THE EDGES OF THE REEF TO INFORM RECREATIONAL FISHERMEN AND BOATERSBOTH AS TO THEIR PRESENCE AND THEIR ECOLOGICAL VALUE.FOR OVER 10 YEARS, THE SHELLFISH RESEARCH SECTION HAS ANNUALLY INSTALLED MULTIPLE WIRE-BASED INTERTIDALOYSTER REEFS IN SOUTH CAROLINA ESTUARINE SYSTEMS TO PROVIDE FISH HABITAT AND TO PROTECT ADJACENTSHORELINES. IN FY2024, THE SRS WILL MONITOR AND, IF NECESSARY, PROVIDE MINOR SITE MAINTENANCE FOR AT LEASTSIX OF THESE INSTALLATIONS THAT ARE NOT OTHERWISE MONITORED USING OTHER FUNDING SOURCES. BETTERUNDERSTANDING THE PERFORMANCE OF THESE REEFS AS THEY MATURE WILL INFORM MANAGERS ABOUT BESTINSTALLATION PRACTICES, FURTHER IMPROVING THE SUCCESS OF THIS ESTABLISHED PROGRAM. MONITORING PARAMETERSWILL INCLUDE QUADRAT-BASED ESTIMATES OF OYSTER COVERAGE, SUAS IMAGERY ANALYSES, AND HIGH-ACCURACYGLOBAL NAVIGATION SATELLITE SYSTEM (GNSS) POSITION MEASUREMENTS. MAINTENANCE WILL INCLUDE THEREPLACEMENT OF LOST OR DAMAGED INFORMATIONAL SIGNAGE AND THE RE-POSITIONING OF WIRE MATERIALS, ASNEEDED.

1. NEED: EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT OF MARINE RECREATIONAL FISHERIES IS VITAL TO THE ECONOMY OF SOUTH CAROLINA. FISHERIES BIOLOGISTS FROM THE MARINE RESOURCES DIVISION (MRD) REPRESENT SOUTH CAROLINA DURING STOCK ASSESSMENTS OF SEVERAL SPECIES THAT ARE STUDIED AND PROVIDE THE DATA COLLECTED ALONG WITH RECOMMENDATIONS TO THE SOUTH ATLANTIC FISHERIES MANAGEMENT COUNCIL (WWW.SAFMC.NET ), THE ATLANTIC STATES MARINE FISHERIES COMMISSION (WWW.ASMFC.ORG ) AND NOAA FISHERIES (WWW.FISHERIES.NOAA.GOV). TO EFFECTIVELY MANAGE SC SALTWATER RECREATIONAL FISHERIES, FISHERY DEPENDENT DATA ARE NEEDED. THIS PROGRAM COLLECTS INFORMATION FROM ANGLERS ON THEIR ACTIVITIES, THEIR OPINIONS, AND THE FISH THEY CATCH (FISHERY-DEPENDENT DATA). THIS DATA IS USED TO DETERMINE THE EFFORT AND BEHAVIOR OF RECREATIONAL ANGLERS AND EVALUATE FINFISH STOCKS (SPECIES, SIZE, AGE, ETC.) THAT ARE TARGETED.2. PURPOSE: THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THE RECREATIONAL FISHERY STATISTICS PROGRAM IS TO COLLECT SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION ON THE MAJOR FINFISH SPECIES THAT ARE CAUGHT BY RECREATIONAL ANGLERS IN SOUTH CAROLINA, AS WELL AS INFORMATION ON THE FISHING ACTIVITIES OF THOSE ANGLERS. THESE DATA ARE USED BY BIOLOGISTS TO ASSESS THE STATUS AND HEALTH OF THE FISH POPULATIONS AND ARE VITAL FOR MAKING MANAGEMENT DECISIONS THAT AFFECT THE LONG-TERM SUSTAINABILITY OF THESE FISHERIES. THE TARGET SPECIES FOR THE PROJECT ARE THE MOST POPULAR SPORTFISH IN SOUTH CAROLINA: FLOUNDER, SPOTTED SEATROUT, RED DRUM, AND THE SNAPPER GROUPER COMPLEX. THIS GRANT WILL HELP FUND TWO FISHERY DEPENDENT DATA COLLECTION PROGRAMS: ACCESS POINT ANGLER INTERCEPT SURVEY AND CHARTER BOAT LOGBOOK PROGRAM.

YEAR 5 (F-55-D-22) OF MARYLAND S FIVE YEAR PROJECT COORDINATION GRANT WHICH FUNDS AN AGENCY GRANTS SPECIALIST POSITION THAT ASSISTS WITH THE COORDINATION AND ADMINISTRATION OF FEDERAL SPORT FISH RESTORATION - BOATING ACCESS FUNDS AND MISC. OPERATING EXPENSES SUCH AS TRAINING TRAVEL SUPPLIES ETC.

THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO CONSERVE, RESTORE AND ENHANCE THE FISHERIES RESOURCES OF CONNECTICUT THROUGH IMPROVED MANAGEMENT AND RESTORATION OF ESTUARINE AND FRESHWATER HABITATS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE REVIEWING PROPOSED PROJECTS THAT MAY IMPACT FISHERIES RESOURCES, REVIEW OF RE-LICENSING OF FEDERAL ENERGY REGULATORY COMMISSION (FERC) PROJECTS, REVIEW APPLICATIONS FOR THE RELEASE OF GRASS CARP INTO PONDS, AND FISH KILL INVESTIGATIONS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE MAINTAINING HEALTHY AND SUSTAINABLE POPULATIONS OF FISHERIES RESOURCES WITHIN BIOLOGICAL AND CULTURAL LIMITS, WHICH SUPPORTS THE BUREAU OF NATURAL RESOURCES  MISSION OF CONSERVATION. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PUBLIC WHO USE AND APPRECIATE THESE NATURAL RESOURCES.

THIS PROJECT PROVIDES CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) MANAGEMENT DATA AND REPORTING NEEDS FOR FOUR SPORT FISHERIES INCLUDING EEL RIVER CATCH AND RELEASE CHINOOK SALMON FISHERY (CALIFORNIA S ONLY IN-RIVER CALIFORNIA COASTAL CHINOOK SALMON CATCH AND RELEASE FISHERY), CATCH AND RELEASE STEELHEAD TROUT FISHERY, AND STATE AND FEDERAL OCEAN SALMON FISHERIES SOUTH OF CAPE FALCON, OREGON. THE INLAND AND COASTAL WATERS OF SOUTHERN HUMBOLDT AND MENDOCINO COUNTY PROVIDE EXCELLENT SPORT FISHING OPPORTUNITIES FOR CHINOOK SALMON AND STEELHEAD TROUT. FISHERIES CONDUCTED IN THE EEL RIVER AND MENDOCINO COASTAL RIVERS ATTRACT NUMEROUS ANGLERS AND SUPPORT VISITOR, TACKLE, AND GUIDE SERVICE INDUSTRIES. STATE AND FEDERAL RECREATIONAL OCEAN SALMON FISHERIES CONDUCTED FROM PORTS THROUGHOUT THE STATES OF OREGON AND CALIFORNIA SIGNIFICANTLY CONTRIBUTE TO TOURISM, TACKLE, BOATING, AND CHARTER SERVICE INDUSTRIES. THE NORTHERN REGION FISHERIES ASSESSMENT PROJECT CONTRIBUTES TO QUALITY FISHING OPPORTUNITIES BY CONDUCTING AND COORDINATING THE FISHERIES SCIENCE NEEDED TO IMPROVE SALMONID POPULATIONS, AND SUCCESSFULLY MANAGE THAT FISHERY. DATA GATHERED BY THIS PROJECT ARE USED TO ASSESS, PLAN, AND IMPLEMENT RESTORATION WORK IN SOUTHERN HUMBOLDT AND MENDOCINO COUNTY WHICH SUPPORTS BOTH LISTED SPECIES AND TARGETED RECREATIONAL STOCKS. A CLEAR UNDERSTANDING OF SALMONID POPULATION AND HABITAT STATUSES ARE ESSENTIAL COMPONENTS TO PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTING CHINOOK SALMON AND STEELHEAD TROUT RECOVERY ACTIONS FOR SUSTAINED IN-RIVER AND OCEAN RECREATIONAL FISHERIES.

THIS GRANT WILL BE USED TO OPERATE MAINTAIN 9 STATE FISH HATCHERIES, WHICH ARE EXPECTED TO PRODUCE APPROXIMATELY 50 MILLION SPORT FISH HATCHLINGS TO BE RELEASED INTO APPROXIMATELY 866 LAKES AND RESERVOIRS AND 22 RIVERS OR STREAMS THROUGHOUT MONTANA DURING THE 2023-2024 FIELD SEASONS. THESE RELEASES WILL PROVIDE OR AUGMENT POPULATIONS TO OFFER FISHING OPPORTUNITIES AND TO HELP RESTORE NATIVE POPULATIONS.
THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO ENHANCE STATEWIDE FISHING OPPORTUNITIES FOR ARKANSAS ANGLERS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO PROVIDE FUNDING FOR THE BOATING ACCESS PROGRAM MANAGER AND AUTHORIZED PERSONNELTO COORDINATE MULTIPLE BOATING ACCESS PROJECTS THAT IMPROVE EXISTING FACILITIES AND OR CONSTRUCT NEWINFRASTRUCTURE FOR THE RECREATIONAL BOATING PUBLIC. THE DEVELOPMENT AND COORDINATION OF SUCH PROJECTS ISNECESSARY TO FULFILL THE NEVADA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE S OBLIGATION TO PROVIDE PUBLIC BOATING ACCESS, AND TOMAINTAIN OUR ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS FOR THE WILDLIFE AND SPORTFISH RESTORATION PROGRAM.

THE CITY OF REDDING (CITY) OPERATES THREE MOTORIZED BOAT RAMP FACILITIES AND THREE NON-MOTORIZED FACILITIES ALONG THE SACRAMENTO RIVER. THE SACRAMENTO RIVER THROUGH THE CITY IS A DESIGNATED BY THE CALIFORNIA FISH AND GAME COMMISSION AS A WILD TROUT WATER AND OFFERS SOME OF THE MOST PRISTINE FISHERIES IN THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA AND THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA. MANY RESIDENTS USE THESE ACCESS POINTS REGULARLY AS DO OUR MANY PROFESSIONAL FISHING GUIDES AND THEIR CUSTOMERS, AS WELL AS A LARGE NUMBER OF RECREATIONAL ANGLERS BOTH ON FOOT AND VIA WATERCRAFT.

A WELL-ROUNDED INVENTORY PROGRAM PROVIDED A VIEW OF THE OVERALL HEALTH AND WELL-BEING OF THE STATES FISHERIES, WHICH ALLOWS FWP TO MANAGE AND PROTECT THE RESOURCE FOR PUBLIC USE AND ENJOYMENT OVER A LONG PERIOD OF TIME. THE DATA ACQUIRED IS USED FOR MAKING MANAGEMENT DECISIONS INCLUDING ABOUT FISHING REGULATIONS, FOR MAKING RECOMMENDATIONS TO OTHER AGENCIES AND INDIVIDUALS AND FOR SOLVING FISHERIES PROBLEMS, BOTH BIOLOGICAL AND SOCIAL.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT FISH AND WILDLIFE THROUGH THE REVIEW OF FEDERALLY FUNDED, PERMITTED, AND OR LICENSED ACTIVITIES THROUGHOUT ARKANSAS. DURING THE GRANT PERIOD, THE ENVIRONMENTAL COORDINATION DIVISION WILL REVIEW PROJECT PROPOSALS FOR THE POTENTIAL TO AFFECT FISH AND WILDLIFE AND WORK TO MINIMIZE IMPACTS ON THESE RESOURCES.

THE MORTON SLOUGH ACCESS SITE IS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 12 MILES SOUTHWEST OF SANDPOINT, IDAHO IN BONNER COUNTY. THE SITE PROVIDES FISHING AND BOATING ACCESS TO THE PEND OREILLE RIVER. ALBENI FALLS DAM IS LOCATED ABOUT 15MILES DOWNSTREAM AND REGULATES WATER LEVEL IN THE RIVER, WHICH INFLUENCES BOAT RAMP AND DOCK USABILITY. THE PROPERTY IS OWNED BY THE U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS (CORPS) AND MANAGED BY THE IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME (IDFG), BY LICENSE, WITHIN THE PEND OREILLE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA. FACILITIES AT MORTON SLOUGH INCLUDE A BOAT RAMP, FLOATING BOAT DOCK, PAVED PARKING LOT, AND VAULT TOILET AND IS POPULAR YEAR-ROUND WITH ANGLERS, WATERFOWL HUNTERS AND OUTDOOR RECREATIONISTS. A MAJOR SITE RENOVATION WAS COMPLETED IN 2011 AND STANDARD O M HAS OCCURRED SINCE, INCLUDING PARKING LOT SEAL COATING AND STRIPING IN 2021. THIS PROJECT WILL RE-DESIGN AND EXPAND THE PARKING LOT TO ALLOW FOR SAFER, MORE FUNCTIONAL USE AND INCREASE PARKING CAPACITY. THE PROJECT WILL BE IMPLEMENTED BY IDFG IN COORDINATION WITH THE CORPS.

THIS GRANT IS INTENDED TO PROVIDE ADMINISTRATIVE OVERSIGHT ON THE SC MARINE SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM AND EDUCATE THE ADMINISTRATIVE STAFF AND PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS ON THE ADMINISTRATIVE REQUIREMENTS IN 50 CFR 80 AND 2 CFR 200 AS REQUIRED FOR THE MARINE SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROJECTS.
THIS GRANT WILL OPERATE AND MAINTAIN 223 INLAND BOATING ACCESS AREA FACILITIES IN NORTH CAROLINA FOR THE PUBLIC BENEFIT.

THE DISTRIBUTION OF THE GULF STRAIN WALLEYE IS LIMITED TO THE MOBILE RIVER BASIN IN MISSISSIPPI AND ALABAMA AND THE PEARL RIVER IN MISSISSIPPI. WILD STOCKS OF WALLEYE HAVE DECLINED DUE TO HABITAT DEGRADATION. TO OFFSET THESE LOSSES A CAPTIVE BREEDING PROGRAM WAS DEVELOPED BY THE MISSISSIPPI DEPT OF WILDLIFE, FISHERIES, AND PARKS. BROOD STOCK COLLECTION HAS BEEN LIMITED TO A FEW STREAMS POTENTIALLY LEADING TO DEGRADATION OF GENETIC DIVERSITY. RECENT REPORTS OF ANGLERS CATCHING WALLEYE OUTSIDE OF ITS KNOWN RANGE. ENVIRONMENTAL DNA (EDNA) SAMPLING MAY INCREASE THE NUMBER OF STREAMS WITH VIABLE POPULATIONS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO BENEFIT STRUCTURE-ORIENTED FISH POPULATIONS BY DEPLOYMENT OF DURABLE, STABLE NON-TOXIC MATERIALS TO ENHANCE FISH HABITAT AND TO IMPROVE RECREATIONAL FISHING OPPORTUNITIES. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE THE CONTINUED DEPLOYMENT OF DURABLE, STABLE AND NON-TOXIC MATERIALS AND VESSELS ON DELAWARE S PERMITTED ARTIFICIAL REEF SITE, PHYSICAL AND BIOLOGICAL MONITORING OR ARTIFICIAL REEF STRUCTURES AND ASSOCIATED BIOTA, CONTINUED ASSESSMENT OF ANGLER UTILIZATION OF ARTIFICIAL REEF SITES, AND THE CREATION OF DIGITAL ARTIFICIAL REEF SITE CHARTS AND DISTRIBUTION OF UPDATED INFORMATION ON ARTIFICIAL REEF SITE MATERIAL DEPLOYMENTS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE THE CREATIN OF ADDITIONAL HABITAT FOR STRUCTURE-ORIENTED FISHES, INCREASED RECREATIONAL FISHING OPPORTUNITIES, AN ASSESSMENT OF ARTIFICIAL REEF SITE PHYSICAL STRUCTURE AND BIOLOGICAL PRODUCTIVITY, INFORMATION ON ARTIFICIAL REEF SITE ANGLER EFFORT AND THE ECONOMIC BENEFITS TO COASTAL ECONOMIES, AND IMPROVED COMMUNICATION WITH THE RECREATIONAL FISHING COMMUNITY PERTAINING TO ARTIFICIAL REEF SITE DEPLOYMENTS, LOCATIONS AND FISHING OPPORTUNITIES. INFORMATION FROM THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO BENEFIT THE STRUCTURE-ORIENTED FISH COMMUNITY OFF THE DELAWARE COAST BY PROVIDING IMPORTANT HABITAT FOR ALL LIFE HISTORY PHASES, AND THE RECREATIONAL FISHERS FROM DELAWARE AND BEYOND BY IMPROVING AND EXPANDING FISHING OPPORTUNITIES IN THE DELAWARE BAY AND ATLANTIC OCEAN. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE COMPREHENSIVE MAPPING OF ARTIFICIAL REEF SITES 10, 11 AND 13 IN THE ATLANTIC OCEAN USING HIGH DEFINITION MULTI BEAM ECHOSOUNDER (MRES).

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO CONSERVE, PROTECT, AND ENHANCE FISH POPULATIONS, THEIR HABITATS, AND THE PUBLICS OPPORTUNITY TO ENJOY THEM BY RESTORING, MAINTAINING, AND PROTECTING NATIVE SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS  PROACTIVELY MANAGE FISH AND WILDLIFE POPULATIONS IN A TRANSPARENT AND SCIENCE-BASED MANNER  MANAGING GAME SPECIES IN A WAY THAT PROVIDES RECREATIONAL AND SUSTAINABLE HARVEST OPPORTUNITIES WHILE MINIMIZING CONFLICTS  IMPROVING AND PROTECTING HABITAT SO THAT HIGH-PRIORITY AREAS ARE CONSERVED AND CONNECTED AT A LANDSCAPE LEVEL  AND USE RESEARCH, MONITORING, AND EMERGING TECHNOLOGY SO THAT MANAGEMENT DECISIONS ARE WELL INFORMED.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) FISH HEALTH LABORATORY (FHL) PERFORMS DISEASE DIAGNOSIS AND TREATMENT OF HATCHERY FISH AND SCREENING OF WILD BROODSTOCKS. THE CDFW FHL ALSO ENGAGES IN RESEARCH OF FISH PATHOGENS AND RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT OF DIAGNOSTIC TESTS AND TREATMENTS FOR THOSE PATHOGENS. EARLY AND ONGOING DISEASE DETECTION ENSURES OPTIMAL PERFORMANCE AND SURVIVAL OF FISH PRODUCED BY HATCHERIES AND HELPS MINIMIZE THE RISK TO WILD FISHES. FISH DISEASES THAT OCCUR AT HATCHERIES ARE DETRIMENTAL TO HATCHERY PRODUCED FISH, CAUSING DECREASED GROWTH RATES, DISFIGUREMENT, AND MORTALITY. IN ADDITION TO SALMONID FISHES, THE DEPARTMENT S FISH PATHOLOGIST RESEARCH SCIENTISTS ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR HEALTH MONITORING FOR ALL SPORT FISH, DOMESTIC OR WILD, WHICH MAY ADVERSELY IMPACT THE FISHERY RESOURCES OF THE STATE DUE TO DISEASE. THESE SPECIES INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO, STRIPED BASS, BLACK BASS, CATFISH, SUNFISHES, ETC. TO HELP MINIMIZE STATEWIDE FISH HEALTH ISSUES, FISH PATHOLOGIST RESEARCH SCIENTISTS ARE NEEDED TO STAFF AND OPERATE THE DEPARTMENT S FISH HEALTH LABORATORY. THE FISH HEALTH LABORATORY EXISTS TO MINIMIZE FISH MORTALITIES DURING FISH PRODUCTION AT HATCHERIES AND TO INVESTIGATE HEALTH CONCERNS OF WILD FISH POPULATIONS. THIS IS DONE THROUGH DIAGNOSTIC VISITS WHEN HATCHERIES ARE EXPERIENCING INCREASED LOSSES, THOUGH FISH HEALTH INSPECTIONS AND CERTIFICATIONS IN HATCHERIES AND SURVEILLANCE OF DISEASE IN BOTH DOMESTIC AND WILD FISH. FISH HEALTH LAB FISH PATHOLOGIST RESEARCH SCIENTISTS ALSO INVESTIGATE NEW AND ESTABLISHED FISH PATHOGENS AND PARTICIPATE IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW TREATMENTS AND DETECTION TECHNIQUES FOR FISH PATHOGENS AND DISEASES.

THIS GRANT AND SUBSEQUENT AMENDMENTS OBLIGATE 15  OF WYOMING S SPORT FISH RESTORATION APPORTIONMENTS FORIMPLEMENTATION AND OPERATION OF IT S COMPREHENSIVE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM AS DEFINED IN 50 CFR 80.2 AND 50 CFR80.81. THIS GRANT IS SPECIFIC TO BOATING ACCESS PROJECTS. WYOMINGS LAKES AND RESERVOIRS NEED NEW, UPDATED ANDPROPERLY MAINTAINED MOTORBOAT ACCESS RAMPS, DOCKS, PARKING AREAS, CONVENIENCE STATIONS, AND SAFETY FEATURES ASWELL AS OTHER ITEMS TO MAXIMIZE THE ACCESS AND SAFE USE OF THESE FACILITIES BY BOATING ENTHUSIASTS. ALL OFWYOMINGS BOATING ACCESS FACILITIES REQUIRE CONTINUED MAINTENANCE TO ENSURE THEIR SAFE OPERATION FORRECREATIONAL USERS.
IOWA FY24 FISH CULTURE

FISH RESEARCH FINDINGS WILL ASSIST MANAGEMENT PERSONNEL IN MORE FULLY UNDERSTANDING THE ECOLOGY OF AQUATICSPECIES. METHODS TO IMPROVE FISHERIES HABITATS AND INCREASE SPECIES DIVERSITY AND ABUNDANCE WILL ALSO BEIDENTIFIED THOUGH RESEARCH EFFORTS. IMPLEMENTATION OF NEW AND IMPROVED TECHNIQUES WILL AID MANAGEMENT BYIMPROVING MONITORING OF FISH POPULATIONS AND THEREFORE, ALLOW SOUND MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS TO BE MADE.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INCREASE OPPORTUNITIES FOR SPORT FISHING AND RECREATIONAL BOATING ON BIG INDIAN POND THROUGH THE RECONSTRUCTION OF THE WATER ACCESS FACILITY ON PROPERTY OWNED BY THE TOWN OF ST. ALBANS WITH AN EASEMENT HELD BY MAINE DEPARTMENT OF INLAND FISHERIES AND WILDLIFE. THE FACILITY WILL INCLUDE AN ACCESS ROAD, PAVED PARKING AREA, CONCRETE PLANK RAMP, AND FLOAT SYSTEM.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE SAFE PUBLIC ACCESS TO A LARGE BOATING POOL ON THE WEST BRANCH OF THE SUSQUEHANNA RIVER THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT A NEW LAUNCH RAMP AND ACCESS POINT DOWNSTREAM OF THE EXISTING MUNCY BOAT ACCESS SITE, WHICH HAS BEEN PERMANENTLY CLOSED FOR PUBLIC SAFETY DUE TO SILTATION ISSUES AT THE SITE. THE NEW ACCESS SITE WILL INCLUDE A LAUNCH RAMP, AN ENTRANCE EXIT LANE BETWEEN THE EXISTING PARKING LOT AT THE CLOSED FACILITY AND THE NEW LAUNCH RAMP, AND ADA COMPLIANT PARKING AND ACCESS TO THE BOAT LAUNCH. USE OF THE PROJECT AREA AFTER COMPLETION WILL BE ON A NON-FEE BASIS AND CONTROLLED BY STANDARD RULES AND REGULATIONS ESTABLISHED BY THE PFBC. POWERED AND NON-POWERED BOATERS WHO WISH TO ACCESS THE WEST BRANCH OF THE SUSQUEHANNA RIVER IN THE AREA OF MUNCY, LYCOMING COUNTY WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS PROJECT. THIS PROJECT HAS NO SUBRECIPIENTS.

PROJECT 1: DAR S SURVEY OF FISH AND HABITAT PROJECT WAS ESTABLISHED TO MONITOR THE HEALTH AND QUALITY OF HAWAIIS MARINE RECREATIONAL FISHERIES STOCKS AND THEIR HABITAT. SURVEYS ARE CONDUCTED TO DETERMINE THE IMPACT OF FISHING PRESSURE AND MANAGEMENT ACTIONS ON SPORT FINFISH AND THEIR ASSOCIATED HABITATS.PROJECT 2: TO FACILITATE PROACTIVE FISHERIES MANAGEMENT, THE HAWAII MARINE RECREATIONAL FISHING SURVEY (HMRFS) WAS INITIATED IN 2001 AS A STATEWIDE MARINE CREEL SURVEY THAT COLLECTS NON-COMMERCIAL FISHING CATCH AND EFFORT INFORMATION FROM BOTH SHORELINE AND PRIVATE BOAT FISHERS.PROJECT 3: THE INVESTIGATION OF HAWAIIAN ESTUARIES PROJECT ADDRESSES THE NEED TO MANAGE AND CONSERVE SPORT FISH POPULATIONS BY IMPROVING OUR MANAGEMENT OF JUVENILE FISH HABITAT IN HAWAIIAN ESTUARIES TO CONTINUE TO MEET EXPECTATIONS OF THE ISLANDS FISHING COMMUNITY NOW AND IN THE FUTURE. THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO TRANSLATE RESULTS FROM RESEARCH AND SURVEYING STUDIES UNDERTAKEN IN HAWAIIAN ESTUARIES INTO MANAGEMENT ACTIONS FOCUSED ON IMPROVING GROWTH AND SURVIVAL OF JUVENILE FISH TO ENHANCE SPORT FISHING OPPORTUNITIES.PROJECT 4: THE DATABASE (DARDATA) PROJECT SERVES TO IMPROVE AND MAINTAIN A CENTRALIZED DATABASE THAT HOUSES DATA PRODUCED BY MANY DAR PROJECTS ASSOCIATED WITH FISH, AQUATIC HABITATS, AND RECREATIONAL FISHING IN HAWAII. PROJECT 5: THE LIFE HISTORIES OF MARINE FISHERIES PROJECT WAS ESTABLISHED TO PROVIDE BASIC LIFE HISTORY INFORMATION (I.E., RECRUITMENT, GROWTH, MIGRATION, SEASONALITY, ETC.) FOR MARINE FISH SPECIES COMMONLY TARGETED BY HAWAIIS RECREATIONAL AND NON-COMMERCIAL FISHERS.

HAWAIIS DIVISION OF AQUATIC RESOURCES (DAR), STATEWIDE MARINE FISHERIES TECHNICAL GUIDANCE PROJECT WORKSCOLLABORATIVELY WITH BOTH PUBLIC AND PRIVATE ENTITIES TO BEST MANAGE AND CONSERVE THE MARINE FISHERIES RESOURCESOF THE STATE AND TO MEET THE NEEDS AND EXPECTATIONS OF FISHERMEN AND OCEAN USERS. IN ORDER TO PREVENT ADVERSEECOLOGICAL DISTURBANCES, THIS PROJECT PROVIDES TECHNICAL GUIDANCE AND ASSISTANCE TO PRIVATE INDIVIDUALS, FIRMS,AND FEDERAL, STATE AND COUNTY AGENCIES THROUGH THE PROCESS OF ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW OF PROPOSED OCEAN RELATEDPROJECTS THAT MAY AFFECT FISHING AND MARINE RESOURCES. THESE PROPOSED PROJECTS MAY INCLUDE, BUT NOT LIMITED TO,SHORELINE REPLENISHMENT OR DEVELOPMENT AND MARINE CONSTRUCTION, RENEWABLE ENERGY PROJECTS, RESEARCH ACTIVITIESAND MILITARY TESTING AND TRAINING. EXAMPLES OF REVIEWS CONDUCTED INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO REVIEW OFENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENTS (EA), ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT STATEMENTS (EIS), MARINE RESEARCH OR SURVEY PROPOSALS ANDREPORTS. IN ADDITION, THE DAR RESPONDS TO AND CONDUCTS INVESTIGATIONS OF FISH OR INVERTEBRATE KILLS, OIL SPILLSAND OTHER POLLUTION INCIDENTS, DOCUMENTING IMPACTS TO MARINE AND ESTUARINE RESOURCES. INFORMATION COLLECTED FROMSPORT FISH RESTORATION STUDIES SUCH AS MARINE RESEARCH OR SURVEYS, ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEWS AND FISH OR INVERTEBRATEKILLS WILL BE USED IN THE EVALUATION AND PREPARATION OF COMMENTS AND RECOMMENDATIONS TO MINIMIZE IMPACT, ORREQUIRED DOCUMENTATION FOR THESE TYPES OF PROJECTS, AND ALLOWS THE STATE TO BETTER MANAGE AND CONSERVE MARINE ANDESTUARINE FISHES AND THEIR HABITATS.

THE STATEWIDE FRESHWATER RESEARCH AND SURVEYS PROJECT WAS ESTABLISHED TO MAINTAIN AND PROVIDE NEW OPPORTUNITIES FOR FRESHWATER SPORT FISHING IN HAWAII. THE WAHIAWA RESERVOIR PUBLIC FISHING AREA (PFA) ON THE ISLAND OF OAHU PROVIDES ONE OF THE FEW AREAS FOR FRESHWATER SPORT FISHING. THEREFORE, MONITORING AND MAINTAINING THIS AREA IS CRITICAL TO ACHIEVING THIS OBJECTIVE. WAHIAWA PFA HOSTS AN ENTIRELY EXOTIC FISHERY COMPOSED OF SPECIES FOUND INCOMBINATION NOWHERE ELSE IN THE WORLD SUCH AS PEACOCK BASS, LARGEMOUTH BASS, SMALLMOUTH BASS, CHANNEL CATFISH AND BLUEGILL. CREEL SURVEYS ARE CONDUCTED TO MONITOR FISH POPULATIONS AND TO DETERMINE IF HATCHERY CULTUREDLARGEMOUTH BASS ARE MAKING AN IMPACT ON THE EXISTING LARGEMOUTH BASS POPULATIONS IN THE RESERVOIR. IN ADDITION,VISUAL AND ELECTROFISHING SURVEYS AND EDNA SAMPLING ARE CONDUCTED TO MONITOR ANY NEW AND EXOTIC INTRODUCTIONS(FLORA AND FAUNA). MITIGATION MEASURES ARE ALSO TAKEN TO AVOID FISH POPULATION IMBALANCES, OUTBREAKS OF FISHDISEASE, FISH KILLS OR THE ESTABLISHMENT OF INVASIVE SPECIES. OXYGEN READINGS ARE TAKEN THROUGHOUT THE RESERVOIRDURING LOW WATER LEVELS DURING THE LATE SUMMER MONTHS AND A PORTABLE EMERGENCY AERATION SYSTEM CAN BE OPERATEDAND MAINTAINED IN THE EVENT LOW DISSOLVED OXYGEN LEVELS ARE PRESENT TO MITIGATE ANY POTENTIAL FISH KILLS DUE TOANOXIA.

THE HAWAII DEPARTMENT OF LAND AND NATURAL RESOURCES, DIVISION OF AQUATIC RESOURCES, SUPPORTS 13 PROJECTS UNDEREIGHT GRANTS WHICH ARE FUNDED BY THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFES SPORT FISH RESTORATION (WSFR) PROGRAM ON AN ANNUALBASIS. HAWAIIS STATEWIDE SPORT FISH RESTORATION COORDINATION PROGRAM WAS ESTABLISHED TO PROVIDE EFFECTIVE GRANTMANAGEMENT AND OVERSIGHT CONTROLS TO ENSURE THAT THE ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS OF THE PROGRAM ARE MAINTAINED. USEOF PROGRAM FUNDS REQUIRES CONSIDERABLE ADMINISTRATION, SUPERVISION AND COORDINATION FROM THE APPLICATION PROCESSTHROUGH POST-CLOSEOUT  AND STAFF MUST ENSURE GRANTS PROJECTS COMPLY WITH ALL STATE AND FEDERAL LAWS ANDREGULATIONS. STATEWIDE SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM COORDINATION, INVOLVING FRESHWATER, ESTUARINE AND MARINEDEVELOPMENT AND OPERATION PROJECTS, TECHNICAL GUIDANCE, RESEARCH, SURVEYS AND INVENTORIES, AQUATIC RESOURCESEDUCATION, AND RECREATIONAL BOATING ACCESS, IS VITAL IN VIEW OF THE SIZE, DIVERSITY AND SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION OFALL ACTIVITIES INVOLVED. IN ADDITION, LIAISON WITH EXTERNAL ENTITIES SUCH AS THE REGIONAL AND AREA FISH ANDWILDLIFE SERVICE OFFICES, OTHER FEDERAL, STATE AND MUNICIPAL AGENCIES, COUNCILS, PRIVATE AND PUBLICORGANIZATIONS, IS NECESSARY, AS IS MONITORING OF LEGISLATION THAT MAY POTENTIALLY IMPACT THE SPORT FISHRESTORATION PROGRAM.

PROJECT 1: THE STATE OF HAWAII ARTIFICIAL REEF FISH HABITAT ENHANCEMENT PROJECT STARTED IN 1961 WITH THEESTABLISHMENT OF THE MAUNALUA BAY ARTIFICIAL REEF OFF THE SOUTH SHORE OF OAHU. IT WAS THE FIRST OF FIVEARTIFICIAL REEFS, WITH THE OTHERS BEING THE WAIANAE, KEAWAKAPU, KUALOA AND EWA DEEPWATER, THAT THE STATEESTABLISHED FOR ADDITIONAL RECREATIONAL FISHING OPPORTUNITIES. THE HAWAIIAN ISLANDS HAVE A NARROW BAND OF NATURALCORAL REEFS CONFINING RECREATIONAL FISHING OPPORTUNITIES IN THE NEARSHORE AREA. MUCH OF THE NEARSHORE AREA ISBARREN IN APPEARANCE. ARTIFICIAL REEFS PLACED IN THESE AREAS PROVIDE THE NECESSARY SHELTER FOR A VARIETY OF FISHSPECIES. SOME OF THE BENEFITS FROM THIS PROJECT ARE INCREASED FISH PRODUCTIVITY, INCREASED FISHING OPPORTUNITIES,AND MOVING FISHING PRESSURE AWAY FROM NATURAL REEFS. THE STATE PLANS TO OBTAIN THE NECESSARY PERMITS ANDCERTIFICATIONS TO ADD MATERIAL TO EXISTING ARTIFICIAL REEFS AND POSSIBLY TO ESTABLISH NEW ARTIFICIAL REEFS.UNDERWATER VISUAL SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED TO DETERMINE PRODUCTIVITY OF THE ARTIFICIAL REEFS AND DETECT ANYCHANGES OVER TIME. THIS SURVEY DATA WILL BE USED TO ASSESS THE STATUS OF REEF FISH AND HABITATS AROUND EXISTINGARTIFICIAL REEFS AND TO AID IN PLANNING FOR FUTURE ARTIFICIAL REEF ENHANCEMENTS (ADDING MORE MODULES).PROJECT 2: THE FISH AGGREGATING DEVICES DEVELOPMENT AND OPERATION PROGRAM MAINTAINS A NETWORK OF 55 ANCHORED FISH AGGREGATING DEVICES (FADS) AROUND THE MAIN HAWAIIAN ISLANDS AT VARYING DISTANCES FROM SHORE. ANCHORED FADSCAPITALIZE ON THE FACT THAT PELAGIC FISHES SUCH AS TUNA, MAHIMAHI AND MARLIN ARE ATTRACTED TO FLOATING OBJECTS.BECAUSE OF THIS, ANCHORED FADS ALLOW SPORT FISHERS TO MAXIMIZE THEIR FISHING SUCCESS WHILE REDUCING THE AMOUNT OFTIME NEEDED TO SEARCH FOR FISH. FADS ALSO REDIRECT FISHING EFFORT AWAY FROM NEAR SHORE AREAS WHERE RESOURCES AREEASILY DEPLETED TO OFFSHORE AREAS WHERE THE RESOURCE IS MUCH LARGER AND MORE RESILIENT. FADS CAN ALSO SERVE TOFACILITATE RESEARCH IN TO THE BIOLOGY OF PELAGIC FISHES THEREBY CONTRIBUTING TO BETTER MANAGEMENT ANDCONSERVATION. THE FAD PROGRAMS OUTREACH COMPONENT CONSISTS OF A HOT LINE FOR PROVIDING INFORMATION TO FISHERSAND RECEIVING PUBLIC COMMENT AND A DEDICATED WEB SITE DESCRIBING THE PROGRAMS MISSION, THE LOCATION OF THE FADSAND WHETHER OR NOT THEY ARE CURRENTLY ON STATION.

THE DEPARTMENT OF LAND AND NATURAL RESOURCES  DIVISION OF AQUATIC RESOURCES (DLNR DAR) STATEWIDE FRESHWATERFISHERIES DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM MAINTAINS AND ENHANCES FRESHWATER SPORT FISH POPULATIONS AND PROVIDES QUALITYFRESHWATER RECREATIONAL FISHING OPPORTUNITIES IN HAWAII. NOT ONLY DOES THIS INCREASE CATCH AND SATISFACTIONRATES, BUT ALSO BENEFITS THE LOCAL ECONOMY THROUGH THE SALE OF FISHING SUPPLIES AND EQUIPMENT, ALONG WITH FOODAND LODGING FROM TRAVELING ANGLERS.EFFORTS ARE FOCUSED ON THE STOCKING OF RAINBOW TROUT IN PUU LUA RESERVOIR ON KAUAI, AND LARGEMOUTH BASS IN LAKEWILSON ON OAHU, TWO POPULAR AREAS FOR THE FRESHWATER RECREATIONAL FISHING COMMUNITY.EYED RAINBOW TROUT EGGS ARE IMPORTED FROM MT. SHASTA HATCHERY IN CALIFORNIA AND GROWN AT HAWAIIS DLNR DARANUENUE FISHERY RESEARCH CENTERS TROUT HATCHERY. A TARGET AMOUNT OF 20,000 TO 40,000 TROUT FINGERLINGS ARESHIPPED TO KAUAIS PUU LUA RESERVOIR, KOKEE PUBLIC FISHING AREA. THIS IS WHERE THOUSANDS OF ANGLERS, BOTH LOCALAND VISITING, ENJOY THE ANNUAL TROUT FISHING OPEN.THE WAHIAWA MIDDLE SCHOOL FISH HATCHERY IS OPERATED BY THE SCHOOL STAFF AND VOLUNTEERS. DLNR DAR HELPS MAINTAIN THE FISH HATCHERY BY PROVIDING FEED, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND ASSISTING WITH MAINTENANCE. THE HATCHERY RAISES LARGEMOUTH BASS AND BLUEGILL FROM EGGS OBTAINED FROM BROOD STOCK RAISED IN THE HATCHERY. JUVENILE BASS ANDBLUEGILL ARE THEN STOCKED IN LAKE WILSON, WAHIAWA PUBLIC FISHING AREA. STOCKING SUPPLEMENTS THE POPULATION OFLARGEMOUTH BASS (INTRODUCED IN 1911) AND BLUEGILL (INTRODUCED IN THE LATE 1940S) IN LAKE WILSON. ALTHOUGH BOTHSPECIES ARE REPRODUCING NATURALLY, REPRODUCTION IS NOT SUBSTANTIAL ENOUGH TO SUSTAIN A VIABLE RECREATIONAL SPORTFISHING PROGRAM.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS THE COORDINATION AND ADMINISTRATION OF NC  SPORT FISH RESTORATION GRANT MANAGEMENT PROCESSES AND MAINTENANCE OF THE COMMISSION S PROGRAM ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS

PROGRAM LEADERS FOR SPORT FISH RESTORATION (SFR) PROJECTS ARE LOCATED IN HARRISON AND JACKSON COUNTIES WITHPROJECTS OCCURRING IN ALL THREE MISSISSIPPI COASTAL COUNTIES (HANCOCK, HARRISON, AND JACKSON). WITH A NUMBER OFACTIVITIES AND ACCESS CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS OCCURRING THROUGHOUT THE STATE MARINE WATERS, CLOSE COORDINATION OFPERSONNEL AND EQUIPMENT IS NECESSARY TO SUCCESSFULLY MANAGE SFR ACTIVITIES. ADDITIONAL TRAINING IN THE MANAGEMENT OF FEDERAL GRANTS WILL AID IN CARRYING OUT THESE ACTIVITIES MORE EFFICIENTLY. A DIRECTOR AND A PROGRAMCOORDINATOR FROM BOTH THE OFFICE OF MARINE FISHERIES AND THE OFFICE OF COASTAL RESTORATION AND RESILIENCY WITHINTHE MISSISSIPPI DEPARTMENT OF MARINE RESOURCES (MDMR) WILL SERVE AS PROJECT LEADERS, THUS EXPEDITING THEDECISION-MAKING PROCESS REGARDING EQUIPMENT AND MANPOWER ASSIGNMENTS.
