THE KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AND PARKS OWNS OR HAS LICENSE TO 144 PUBLIC FISHING WATER WITH A TOTAL OF 166,004 ACRES  UNFORTUNATELY, NOT ALL OF THESE WATERS PROVIDE THE QUALITY OF FISHING, DEFINED IN TERMS OF NUMBER AND SIZE OF FISH, THAT ANGLERS MOST PREFER  THE SE OF PROVEN FISHERIES MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES PROVIDE AVENUES FOR FISHERIES MANAGERS TO MANIPULATE FISH POPULATIONS AND ADDRESS THOSE PREFERENCES  HABITAT ENHANCEMENT ACTIVITIES WILL RESULT IN INCREASED SPAWNING AND NURSERY SITES, AREAS OF PROTECTIVE COVER, AND AREAS OF FOOD PRODUCTION  THE REHABILITATION OF UNBALANCED FISH POPULATIONS AND OR SUPPLEMENTAL STOCKING OF FISH WILL RESULT IN BETTER BALANCED FISH POPULATIONS WITH IMPROVED DENSITY AND SIZE  THROUGH PROVEN MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES, KDWP INTENDS TO INCREASE ANGLER USE AND ENJOYMENT  THROUGH THE RESULTING RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES, THE AGENCY ALSO INTENDS TO ENHANCE THE QUALITY OF LIFE FOR THE SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES AND THE STATE

THE FISHERY MANAGEMENT PROCESS THAT PROVIDES THE OPPORTUNITY FOR ANGLERS TO FISH FOR ANADROMOUS SPECIES IN CALIFORNIAS CENTRAL VALLEY IS DEPENDENT UPON BASE MONITORING ACTIVITIES THAT ASSESS BOTH THE RESOURCES SUPPORTING THE FISHERIES, AND PERFORMANCE OF THE FISHERIES THEMSELVES. CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) MANAGERS ARE DEPENDENT UPON THE INFORMATION GENERATED FROM MONITORING TO MAKE SOUND DECISIONS FOR SETTING SEASONS BY TIME AND PLACE, ESTABLISHING DAILY BAG AND POSSESSION LIMITS, IMPOSING GEAR RESTRICTIONS, AND MAKING OVERALL ALLOCATIONS OF FISHERY RESOURCES.  THE FISHERIES ARE DIVERSE. THEY INCLUDE MULTI MILLION DOLLAR PER YEAR FISHERIES ON NATIVE SPECIES SUCH AS CHINOOK SALMON, STEELHEAD RAINBOW TROUT, AND WHITE STURGEON. THE INTRODUCED STRIPED BASS FISHERY IS TYPICALLY THE LARGEST FISHERY IN TERMS OF TOTAL ANGLER EFFORT. THE FISHERIES SUPPORTED BY INTRODUCED SUNFISHES RANGE FROM CONSUMPTIVE PANFISH FISHERIES FOR SPECIES SUCH AS BLUEGILL, TO NATIONALLY RECOGNIZED LARGEMOUTH BASS TOURNAMENT FISHERIES. THERE ARE ALSO MORE LOCALIZED NICHE FISHERIES SUCH AS THAT FOR SACRAMENTO SPLITTAIL, A CALIFORNIA NATIVE SPECIES OF SPECIAL CONCERN. EFFECTIVE MONITORING OF THE FISHERIES REQUIRES ANGLER SURVEYS THAT ARE STATISTICALLY ROBUST BY BEING COMPREHENSIVE IN COVERAGE BOTH SPATIALLY AND TEMPORALLY. ANGLER SURVEYS YIELD ESSENTIAL INFORMATION ABOUT FISHERY PERFORMANCE, INCLUDING ESTIMATES OF ANGLING EFFORT, CATCH, AND HARVEST, ALL ON A SPECIES-SPECIFIC BASIS. THIS INFORMATION IS USED TO ASSESS FISHERY TRENDS OVER TIME AND SPACE, BOTH WITHIN AND ACROSS FISHING SEASONS. IT CAN ALSO BE USED FOR DESIGNING REGULATIONS THAT BALANCE UTILIZATION WITH CONSERVATION, INCLUDING THROUGH THE USE OF IN SEASON CLOSURES. MONITORING OF THESE FISHERIES HAS OCCURRED TO VARYING DEGREES AND USING VARIOUS APPROACHES OVER TIME. EARLY MONITORING FOCUSED ON COMMERCIAL FISHERIES IN THE BAY AND DELTA PORTIONS OF THE SYSTEM (CLARK 1929). MONITORING OF RIVER SPORT FISHERIES IN THE SACRAMENTO RIVER SYSTEM DID NOT OCCUR UNTIL THE LATE 1940S WITH FOCUS ON THE UPPER BASIN FOLLOWING THE CONSTRUCTION OF SHASTA DAM (SMITH 1950). A MORE COMPREHENSIVE ANGLER SURVEY WAS CONDUCTED BY THE CDFW DURING THE MID 1960S (VAN WOERT 1965, 1966, 1968), AND THEN AGAIN DURING THE LATE 1980S TOEARLY 1990S (WIXOM ET AL. 1995) AND LATE 1990S-EARLY 2000S (E.G. MURPHY ET AL. 1999; MASSA AND SHROYER 2003). THE CDFW RESUMED THE ANGLER SURVEY IN 2006 AS A SPORT FISH RESTORATION ACT (SFRA) FUNDED PROJECT (TITUS 2007) THAT CONTINUES TODAY AS THE CENTRAL VALLEY ANGLER SURVEY (TITUS ET AL. 2012). IN CALIFORNIA, AS THROUGHOUT THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST, ANADROMOUS FISHERY RESOURCES ARE MANAGED IN PART THROUGH THE IMPLEMENTATION OF BROADSCALE MARKING AND TAGGING PROGRAMS. THESE PROGRAMS FACILITATE STOCK MANAGEMENT, ALLOW FOR SELECTIVE HARVEST, AND PROVIDE THE BASIS FOR ASSESSING VARIOUS ATTRIBUTES OF THE EXPLOITED RESOURCE, INCLUDING AGE AND GROWTH, FISHERY IMPACTS ON POPULATION STRUCTURE, AND HOMING FIDELITY RELATIVE TO MANAGEMENT OF GENETIC RESOURCES. IN THE CENTRAL VALLEY, MARKING AND TAGGING PROGRAMS ARE FOCUSED ON HATCHERY PRODUCED CHINOOK SALMON AND STEELHEAD RAINBOW TROUT, AND INCLUDE THE CONSTANT FRACTIONAL MARKING PROGRAM IN WHICH 25% (8 MILLION) OF ANNUAL FALL RUN CHINOOK SALMON HATCHERY PRODUCTION IS ADIPOSE FIN CLIPPED AND CODED WIRE TAGGED. CALIFORNIAS CODED WIRE TAG PROGRAM IS COORDINATED ON A STATEWIDE BASIS. MONITORING ADULT ABUNDANCE OF TARGET SPECIES IS ALSO AN ESSENTIAL FISHERY MANAGEMENT ELEMENT IN CENTRAL VALLEY RIVERS AND STREAMS. MAINTAINING A PULSE ON ABUNDANCE OF KEY SPECIES, SUCH AS CHINOOK SALMON AND STEELHEAD, IS NECESSARY FOR OPTIMIZING ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES AND FOR REGULATING HARVEST OF THESE SPECIES. MONITORING ADULT.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) - CENTRAL REGION (SAN JOAQUIN VALLEY INCLUDING SAN JOAQUINRIVER AND TRIBUTARIES, SIERRA NEVADA FOOTHILL RESERVOIRS, AND COASTAL [MONTEREY AND SAN LUIS OBISPO COUNTIES]STREAMS AND RESERVOIRS) PROVIDES HABITATS AND SPORT FISHES SUITABLE FOR ABUNDANT SPORT FISHING OPPORTUNITIES.HOWEVER, DUE TO THE VARIOUS DEMANDS PLACED ON THE REGION'S LIMITED WATER SUPPLIES ALONG WITH THE NEEDS FORPROTECTION FROM FLOOD EVENTS, THESE HABITATS ARE REGULARLY MINIMIZED BY DIVERSIONS AND FLOOD CONTROL OPERATIONSAND THREATEN THE SURVIVAL OF THE VARIOUS SPORT FISH SPECIES. CONSEQUENTLY, RECREATIONAL FISHERY ENHANCEMENT ANDHABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS ARE CONDUCTED ANNUALLY, WORKING TO IMPROVE INSTREAM FLOWS AND TEMPERATURES,RESERVOIR CONDITIONS (E.G., HABITAT AND COLD-WATER POOL STORAGE), HABITAT CONDITIONS, FISH PASSAGE AND BARRIERPROJECTS, FISH STOCKING ANALYSIS, AND FISH PRODUCTION. THIS GRANT WILL FUND ENGINEERING SUPPORT REQUIRED TOASSIST WITH THE DESIGN AND REVIEW OF THE VARIOUS ANTICIPATED ENHANCEMENT PROJECTS OCCURRING WITHIN THE CENTRALREGION.

THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS THE STATE OF KANSAS  SPORT FISH SAMPLING AND DATA COLLECTION EFFORTS ACROSS FORTY STATE FISHING LAKES THAT TOTAL 4,300 ACRE AND 25 FEDERAL FLOOD CONTROL RESERVOIRS COVERING APPROXIMATELY 166,000 ACRES  IN ADDITION, THE DEPARTMENT PROVIDES TECHNICAL ADVISE TO 212 ITY AND COUNTY GOVERNMENT AGENCIES ACROSS THE STATE WHICH OWN 14,000 ACRES OF COMMUNITY BASED IMPOUNDMENTS  EACH OF THESE PROPERTIES REQUIRES PRECISE, EXPERT ADVICE AND INTENSIVE MANAGEMENT TO ALLOW FOR THE BEST POSSIBLE ANGLING OPPORTUNITY FOR THE PUBLIC WHILE ALSO BENEFITING THE RESOURCE,THE PROJECT INCLUDES SAMPLING PLANS FOR EACH OF THESE WATERS ACROSS THE STATE  DATA COLLECTED FROM THESE SAMPLES ARE CRITICAL TO THE APPROPRIATE MANAGEMENT AT EACH IMPOUNDMENT  THE STATEWIDE DATABASE IS USED AS A VALUABLE REFERENCE WHEN RESEARCHING HISTORICAL DATA TRENDS ANGLER USE AND INTERESTS OF THE FISHERIES RESOURCE VARY ACROSS THE STATE AND MUST BE CONSIDERED WHEN COORDINATING AN ANNUAL MANAGEMENT PLAN  THESE DATA ARE COLLECTED WITH 8 MONTH LONG ROVING CREEL SURVEYS CONDUCTED AT RANDOM INTERVALS IN SELECT IMPOUNDMENTS  THESE DATA ARE USEFUL TO PROVIDE THE INFORMATION NECESSARY TO MAKE REGULATION AND STOCKING RECOMMENDATIONS AND TO INFORM THE PUBLIC ABOUT THE SPORT FISHING OPPORTUNITIES AVAILABLE TO THEM,

THE MISSION OF THE AQUATIC EDUCATION PROGRAM AND THIS GRANT IS TO FOSTER AN AWARENESS AND APPRECIATION INCHILDREN AND ADULTS FOR THE STATE S AQUATIC RESOURCES, FOCUSING UPON THE SPORT OF FISHING TO INTRODUCE THEOUTDOORS IN AN ENJOYABLE, SAFE AND RESPONSIBLE MANNER

THIS PROJECTS COLLECTS DATA ON FISH POPULATIONS, HEALTH AND TRENDLINES THROUGH FISH SURVEYS ON HUNDREDS OF COLORADO STREAMS AND LAKES. THE GRANT ALSO FUNDS A SMALL NUMBER OF ANGLER CREEL SURVEYS FOR INFORMATION ON ANGLER SUCCESS RATES.

VIRGINIA COASTAL WATERS AND THE CHESAPEAKE BAY PLAY A VERY CRITICAL ROLE IN ATLANTIC MARINE FISHERIES IN TERMS OF ECONOMIC, RECREATIONAL, ECOLOGICAL, AND EVEN GEOLOGICAL ASPECTS. MANY MARINE FISH SPECIES ARE NOT ONLY RESIDENTS BUT ALSO USE VIRGINIA AS THEIR WINTER/NURSERY HABITATS AND MIGRATION ROUTES (SUCH AS STRIPED BASS (MORONE SAXATILIS), BLACK DRUM (POGONIAS CROMIS), BLUEFISH (POMATOMUS SALTATRIX), TAUTOG (TAUTOGA ONITIS), COBIA (RACHYCENTRON CANADUM), ETC). A SOUND FISHERIES MANAGEMENT OF THOSE SPECIES BY THE VIRGINIA MARINE RESOURCES COMMISSION (VMRC) HAS ENHANCED VIRGINIA AND COAST-WIDE RECREATIONAL AND COMMERCIAL MARINE FISHERIES. STOCK ASSESSMENT MODELS REQUIRE EITHER LONG TIME SERIES OF AGE DATA (SUCH AGE-STRUCTURED MODEL), GROWTH INFORMATION (SUCH AS CATCH-BASED MODEL), OR BOTH. THE VMRC AGEING LAB HAS BEEN PROVIDING AGE AND GROWTH INFORMATION OF 14 MARINE FINFISH SPECIES COLLECTED IN CHESAPEAKE BAY AND VIRGINIA WATERS OF ATLANTIC TO THE STOCK ASSESSMENTS ALONG THE EAST COAST FOR MORE THAN TWO DECADES. MOREOVER, THE EXPERTISE AND SKILLS DEVELOPED BY THE AGEING LAB HAVE MADE IMPORTANT CONTRIBUTIONS TO COLLECTING, PROCESSING, AND AGEING CALCIFIED STRUCTURES (SUCH AS OTOLITHS AND SCALES) OF MARINE FINFISH SPECIES ALONG THE EAST COAST AND EVEN GULF OF MEXICO. CONTINUING PROVIDING AGE AND GROWTH DATA COLLECTED IN VIRGINIA WILL CONTINUALLY SUPPORT RELIABLE STOCK ASSESSMENTS, AND FURTHER GREATLY ENHANCE SCIENCE-BASED FISHERIES MANAGEMENTS BOTH IN VIRGINIA AND ALONG THE ATLANTIC COAST.
IN FW-21-D-53 PUBLIC ACCESS PROGRAM (FISHING AND BOATING)

THE STATE OF NEVADA OPERATES AND MAINTAINS FOUR FISH CULTURAL FACILITIES LOCATED STRATEGICALLY AROUND THE STATE. TROUT PRODUCED AT THESE FACILITIES ARE AN INTEGRAL PART OF THE FISHERY MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS OF OVER 150 LAKES, RESERVOIRS, RIVERS AND STREAMS. MOST ANGLERS IN NEVADA FISH FOR HATCHERY PRODUCED RAINBOW, BROWN, CUTTHROAT, TIGER AND HYBRID TROUT. THE MOST HEAVILY FISHED WATERS IN NEVADA EITHER DO NOT PROVIDE CONDITIONS SUITABLE FOR NATURAL REPRODUCTION OR DO NOT PRODUCE TROUT POPULATIONS ADEQUATE TO MEET ANGLING DEMAND. TO MEET THIS DEMAND THE STATE MUST MAINTAIN A TROUT PRODUCTION AND STOCKING PROGRAM THAT WILL PROVIDE AT LEAST 900,000 HATCHERY REARED TROUT ON AN ANNUAL PRODUCTION CYCLE.TO ENSURE THAT EACH FACILITY IS BEING USED IN AN EFFICIENT MANNER CONSIDERING ITS LOCATION, ENVIRONMENT AND PHYSICAL CONSTRAINTS, IT IS NECESSARY TO MONITOR EACH FACILITY IN A VARIETY OF BENCHMARKS BOTH BIOLOGICAL AND ECONOMICAL. THESE BENCHMARKS ARE THEN USED TO CONTINUALLY MONITOR, ASSESS AND IMPROVE (IF NECESSARY) THE HATCHERY PROGRAM TO ENSURE THAT EACH FACILITY IS PERFORMING AT OPTIMAL EFFICIENCY AND TO SATISFY THE DEMAND OF LICENSED ANGLERS FOR A QUALITY FISHING EXPERIENCE.

THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO SUPPORT ECOLOGICALLY SOUND, SCIENCE-BASED FINFISH CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE DATA COLLECTION, RESEARCH AND MONITORING ON THE HEALTH, ABUNDANCE, AND DISTRIBUTION OF CHESAPEAKE BAY FISHES FOCUSING ON THE VIRGINIA PORTION OF THE ESTUARY. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE MAINTAINING HEALTHY AND SUSTAINABLE POPULATIONS OF FISHES WITHIN BIOLOGICAL AND CULTURAL LIMITS, WHICH SUPPORTS THE GOALS OF THE U. S. FISH & WILDLIFE, SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PUBLIC WHO USE AND APPRECIATE THESE NATURAL RESOURCES. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

PROJECT PURPOSE: TO PROTECT, CONSERVE, AND ENHANCE KDWP PUBLIC LANDS FISHERIES USING SCIENCE BASED AND BUSINESS INTELLIGENCE INFORMATION, AND TO PROVIDE FISHING AND COMPATIBLE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR CURRENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS. ACTIVITIES PERFORMED: TO OPERATE AND MAINTAIN 29,139 ACRES OF LAND AND WATER ON FORTY-FOUR PUBLIC LOCATIONS AND TO MAINTAIN AND IMPROVE ACCESS AREAS FOR SPORT FISHING. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: TO IMPROVE SPORT FISH AND POPULATIONS BY IMPROVING AQUATIC HABITATS AND SUPPLEMENTAL STOCKINGS. TO MEET THE DIVERSE DEMAND FOR PUBLIC FISHING. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF OUR PUBLIC FISHING LAKES WILL BENEFIT THE OVERALL FISHERIES. THE FISHING PUBLIC WILL BE GIVEN THE OPPORTUNITY TO ENJOY OUR FISHING LAKES AND FACILITIES.

ALABAMA AQUATIC RESOURCES ARE AS DIVERSE AS THE FRESHWATER FISH SPECIES THAT INHABIT THEM. CULTIVATING ANGLING SKILLS AND EDUCATIONAL STRATEGIES WILL SUSTAIN PARTICIPATION AND APPRECIATION IN ALABAMA'S AQUATIC RESOURCES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES BY CREATING, PROTECTING, MAINTAINING, ENHANCING, AND CONSERVING SPORT FISHERIES AROUND THE STATE. THE STATE OF NEVADA RECOGNIZES THE VALUE OF WILDLIFE FOR AESTHETICS, RECREATIONAL, AND ECONOMIC ASPECTS AND GIVES THE DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AUTHORITY TO ADMINISTER LAWS FOR PRESERVATION, PROTECTION, MANAGEMENT, AND RESTORATION OF STATE WILDLIFE. THE FISHERIES DIVISION, UNDER THE GUIDANCE OF COMMISSION POLICY P-33, HAS THE RESPONSIBILITY OF MANAGING SPORT FISHES AND NATIVE SPORT FISHES OF THE STATE UNDER THE PROVISIONS OF THE DINGELL-JOHNSON ACT (SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM). PROGRAMS ARE DEVELOPED TO INCREASE TECHNICAL KNOWLEDGE FOR MAKING SPORT FISH MANAGEMENT DECISIONS, IMPROVING ANGLER SATISFACTION, AND ENSURING CONSERVATION NEEDS. THIS INVOLVES ASSESSING FISH STOCKS, HABITAT, AND ANGLER USE FROM POSSIBLE CHANGES. RESEARCH AND MONITORING RESULTS ARE USED TO MAKE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS FOR ESCALATING ANGLER SUCCESS, SATISFACTION, AND USE, AND FOR CONSERVING FISH POPULATIONS AND AQUATIC HABITAT. SPECIFICALLY, THE MONITORING AND EVALUATION OF FISHERY POPULATIONS AND HABITATS ALLOW NDOW TO DEVELOP APPROPRIATE STOCKING RECOMMENDATIONS, INFORM FISHING REGULATION CHANGES AND TAKE OTHER ACTIONS SUCH AS HABITAT RESTORATION TO ENHANCE SPORT FISH OPPORTUNITIES. THE OVERALL PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS TO PROMOTE, SUSTAIN AND ENHANCE RECREATIONAL SPORT FISH POPULATIONS AND PROVIDE INCREASED ANGLING SATISFACTION AND OPPORTUNITY. RECEIVING FEDERAL AID IN SPORT FISH RESTORATION ENABLES THE AGENCY TO FULFILL ITS MISSION TO PROTECT, CONSERVE, MANAGE, AND RESTORE WILDLIFE AND ITS HABITAT FOR AESTHETIC, SCIENTIFIC, EDUCATIONAL, RECREATIONAL, AND ECONOMIC BENEFITS TO CITIZENS OF THE STATE AND UNITED STATES.

THE ATTACHED GRANT SUPPORTS VERMONT FISH AND WILDLIFE'S WORK COMPLETING SURVEYS AND INVENTORIES OF VERMONT'S FISH POPULATIONS IN INLAND LAKES, RIVERS AND STREAMS. UNDER THIS GRANT, WORK WILL BE COMPLETED RELATED TO SALMONID INVENTORY AND MANAGEMENT, BASS INVENTORY AND MANAGEMENT, WALLEYE MANAGEMENT, AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES, ANGLER AND CREEL SURVEYS, FISHERIES PLANNING, FISH COMMUNITY MONITORING, ESOCID MANAGEMENT, CONNECTICUT RIVER DIADROMOUS FISH STUDIES AND AQUATIC HABITAT CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION.EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE MAINTAINING HEALTHY AND SUSTAINABLE POPULATIONS OF SPORT FISH. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PUBLIC WHO USE AND APPRECIATE THESE NATURAL RESOURCES. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

THE ATTACHED GRANT SUPPORTS VERMONT FISH AND WILDLIFE'S WORK COMPLETING SURVEYS AND INVENTORIES OF VERMONT'S FISHPOPULATIONS IN LAKE CHAMPLAIN. UNDER THIS GRANT, ACTIVITIES WILL BE COMPLETED RELATED TO WALLEYE MANAGEMENT, FORAGE FISHMONITORING, FISH COMMUNITY MONITORING, SALMONID MANAGMENT, RESTORATION OF LAKE STURGEON, LAKE CHAMPLAIN CREEL SURVEYSAND SEA LAMPREY CONTROL IN LAKE CHAMPLAIN. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE MAINTAINING HEALTHY AND SUSTAINABLE POPULATIONS OFSPORT FISH. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PUBLIC WHO USE AND APPRECIATE THESE NATURAL RESOURCES. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENTACTIVITIES.

IN 1978, THE MASSACHUSETTS DIVISION OF MARINE FISHERIES, MA DMF, BEGAN A PROGRAM TO MONITOR ABUNDANCE OF FINFISH, WHICH ARE OF MAJOR IMPORTANCE TO RECREATIONAL AND COMMERCIAL FISHERMEN OF MASSACHUSETTS. THE CORNERSTONE OF THIS EFFORT IS A SEMIANNUAL COASTWIDE BOTTOM TRAWL SURVEY, WHICH HAS CONTINUED FOR 40 CONSECUTIVE YEARS. A SECONDARY ONGOING INVESTIGATION IS A SUMMER SEINE SURVEY (42 YEARS) TO MEASURE RELATIVE YEAR-CLASS STRENGTH OF WINTER FLOUNDER. LONG-TERM MONITORING OF ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION OF FISHERY RESOURCES USING A CONSISTENT STANDARDIZED PROTOCOL IS OF HIGH IMPORTANCE TO RESOURCE MANAGERS. THE PRIMARY SAMPLING GEAR USED ON THE MASSACHUSETTS SURVEY HAS BEEN OF THE SAME DESIGN FOR THE ENTIRE 40-YEAR TIME SERIES AND THE SAME RESEARCH VESSEL HAS BEEN USED SINCE 1982. WHILE FISHERY DEPENDENT DATA MAY BE DIFFICULT TO INTERPRET OVER TIME DUE TO TECHNOLOGICAL ADVANCES THAT COMMERCIAL FISHERMEN HAVE USED TO GREAT EFFECT, THE CONSISTENCY OF THE MASSACHUSETTS SURVEY ALLOWS FOR COMPARISONS IN FISHERY INDEPENDENT CATCH OBSERVATIONS OVER TIME. THIS IS ONE OF THE LONGEST RUNNING INSHORE TRAWL SURVEYS IN THE UNITED STATES AND WITH EACH ADDITIONAL YEAR'S OBSERVATION, THE DATA RECORD ADDS TO ITS VALUE.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO RESTORE AMERICAN SHAD AND HICKORY SHAD IN THE CHOPTANK AND PATAPSCO RIVERS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDED USING HATCHERY STOCKING AT THE LARVAL AND JUVENILE LIFE STAGES TO PROVIDE ADULT SPAWNERS THAT WILL PRODUCE SELF-SUSTAINING POPULATIONS IN THE TARGET TRIBUTARIES. WE ASSESS BOTH THE JUVENILE AND ADULT POPULATIONS TO ESTIMATE CONTRIBUTION OF HATCHERY FISH, JUVENILE SURVIVAL AND MONITOR RECOVERY OF NATURALLY PRODUCED STOCKS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE HATCHERY INPUTS INTENDED TO PROVIDE ADULT SPAWNERS THAT WILL PROVIDE ADULT SPAWNERS THAT WILL PRODUCE SELF-SUSTAINING POPULATIONS IN THE TARGET TRIBUTARIES. THESE STOCKED FISH HAVE TREMENDOUS VALUE FOR STOCK ASSESSMENT PURPOSES AT THE LARVAL, JUVENILE AND ADULT LIFE STAGES SINCE ALL STOCKED SHAT RECEIVE AN OXYTETRACYCLINE OTOLITH MARK. NATURAL SPAWN AND STRIP SPAWN CULTURE TECHNIQUES ALLOW FOR THE PRODUCTION OF LARGE NUMBERS OF LARVAL AND JUVENILE SHAD FOR STOCKING AND ASSESSMENT EFFORTS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE RECREATIONAL PUBLIC ANGLERS BY PROVIDING INCREASED FISHING OPPORTUNITIES IN HISTORICALLY SUPPORTED RUNS IN THE PATAPSCO AND CHOPTANK RIVERS. AN INDIRECT BENEFIT OF RESTORING SHAD POPULATIONS TO SELF-SUSTAINABLE LEVELS IS THE INCREASED PREY AVAILABILITY PROVIDED BY BOTH JUVENILE AND ADULT SHAD FOR LARGER, MORE ECONOMICALLY IMPORTANT RECREATIONAL SPECIES SUCH AS STRIPED BASS, BLUE FISH AND RED DRUM.
IN FF-31-D-02 COMPREHENSIVE FISH HATCHERY AND FISH MANAGEMENT

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO MAINTAIN AND OPERATE 135 PUBLIC BOATING AND FISHING WATER ACCESS FACILITIES ACROSS THE STATE OF NEW HAMPSHIRE OWNED OR CONTROLLED BY NH FISH AND GAME DEPARTMENT ON FRESHWATER RIVERS, LAKES AND PONDS, AS WELL AS COASTAL WATERS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE OVERALL ADMINISTRATION OF NEW HAMPSHIRE'S STATEWIDE PUBLIC ACCESS PROGRAM TO ENSURE EFFECTIVE PLANNING, DEVELOPMENT, AND OPERATION OF ALL DEPARTMENT-CONTROLLED PUBLIC ACCESS FACILITIES; FIELD INSPECTION, OPERATION, MAINTENANCE, AND REPAIR OF EXISTING, AND ANY NEWLY-DEVELOPED PUBLIC WATER ACCESS FACILITIES; TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO TOWNS TO INCREASE PUBLIC WATER ACCESS OPPORTUNITIES FOR FISHING AND BOATING; DEVELOPMENT OF MATERIALS THAT HELP THE PUBLIC LOCATE AND ENJOY FACILITIES; PUBLIC USE AND SATISFACTION SURVEYS AS NEEDED; PROVISION OF INFORMATION THAT EDUCATES THE PUBLIC REGARDING THE RESPONSIBLE USE OF DEPARTMENT SITES, SUCH AS INVASIVE SPECIES INFORMATION AND POWER-LOADING PREVENTION; AND THE CONSTRUCTION OF UNIVERSAL DOCKS AND/OR PIERS AT EXISTING FACILITIES, WHERE FEASIBLE. THE EXPECTED OUTCOME IS A WELL-PLANNED AND EXECUTED OPERATION AND MANAGEMENT PROGRAM THAT HELPS TO KEEP PUBLIC BOAT ACCESS FACILITIES SAFE, ATTRACTIVE, FUNCTIONAL, AND USER-FRIENDLY. IT IS EXPECTED THAT THE RESULTS AND BENEFITS OF CARRYING OUT THE PROVISIONS OF THIS GRANT WILL MEET PUBLIC EXPECTATIONS AND WILL MAXIMIZE THE USEFUL LIFE OF FEDERALLY-FUNDED CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS. IN ADDITION, PERIODIC INSPECTIONS WILL ENABLE THE DEPARTMENT TO ADDRESS MINOR MAINTENANCE PROBLEMS EARLY, BEFORE THEY REQUIRE A COSTLY MAJOR REPAIR. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT ARE RESIDENT AND NON-RESIDENT RECREATIONAL BOATERS AND ANGLERS SEEKING ACCESS TO STATE WATERS. PAST SURVEYS HAVE DETERMINED THE PUBLIC FEELS THAT THE STATE HAS AN OBLIGATION TO PROVIDE FACILITIES TO ACCESS PUBLIC WATERS, AND ONCE ESTABLISHED, THE STATE HAS A RESPONSIBILITY TO ENSURE THAT THEY ARE SAFE, ATTRACTIVE, FUNCTIONAL, AND USER-FRIENDLY. THERE ARE NO SUB-RECIPIENTS PERFORMING WORK UNDER THIS AWARD.

THE GEORGIA MARINE AQUATIC EDUCATION PROGRAM HAS FOUR OBJECTIVES:1) TO ENHANCE STEWARDSHIP OF MARINE SPORT FISH POPULATIONS AND THEIR HABITATS; 2) TO EDUCATE ANGLERS ABOUT THEIR ROLE AS MANAGERS OF MARINE RECREATIONAL FISHERIES; 3) TO EDUCATE THE GENERAL PUBLIC AND ANGLERS ABOUT THE ECOLOGY OF FISH SPECIES POPULAR WITH GEORGIA'S MARINE RECREATIONAL ANGLERS; AND 4) TO PROMOTE ETHICAL ANGLING AND INTEREST IN MARINE RECREATIONAL ANGLING.

THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THE CHESAPEAKE BAY FINFISH INVESTIGATIONS SURVEY IS TO MONITOR AND BIOLOGICALLY CHARACTERIZE RESIDENT AND MIGRATORY FINFISH SPECIES IN THE MARYLAND PORTION OF THE CHESAPEAKE BAY. THIS SURVEY WILL CONTINUE TO PROVIDE INFORMATION REGARDING RELATIVE ABUNDANCE, AGE AND SIZE STRUCTURE, RECRUITMENT , GROWTH, MORTALITY AND MIGRATION PATTERNS OF FINFISH POPULATIONS IN THE BAY. THE DATA GENERATED WILL BE UTILIZED IN BOTH INTER-AND INTRASTATE MANAGEMENT PROCESSES AND PROVIDES A REFERENCE POINT FOR FUTURE FISHERIES MANAGEMENT CONSIDERATIONS.

THE PURPOSES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO ASSESS WATERSHED LAND USE EFFECTS ON RECREATIONALLY IMPORTANT FISH HABITATS AND POPULATIONS IN TIDAL TRIBUTARIES TO THE CHESAPEAKE BAY, PARTICIPATE IN VARIOUS MULTI-AGENCY RESEARCH, MANAGEMENT AND COMMUNICATIONS FORUMS SUPPORTING HABITAT, MULTISPECIES, AND ECOSYSTEM BASED MANAGEMENT OF RECREATIONALLY IMPORTANT FINFISH SPECIES FOUND IN MARYLAND'S CHESAPEAKE BAY AND ATLANTIC COAST, DEVELOP SPATIAL DATA TO ASSIST IN CONSERVING PRIORITY FISH HABITAT AND TO TAKE AN INDEX BASED APPROACH TO PROVIDE LOW COST MEANS TO INTEGRATE FORAGE INTO MARYLAND'S RESIDENT STRIPED BASS MANAGEMENT THAT IS TRACTABLE FOR AVAILABLE STAFF. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE DATA COLLECTION, RESEARCH AND MONITORING OF RECREATIONALLY IMPORTANT SPECIES AND HABITATS, WORKING WITH RESEARCH INSTITUTIONS AND COUNTY STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES, STAKEHOLDERS AND INDUSTRY GROUPS TO COMMUNICATE ABOUT AND MANAGE HABITAT, MULTI-SPECIES AND ECOSYSTEM IMPACTS TO RECREATIONAL FISHING, USING GEOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS TO VISUALIZE OVERLAP OF ECOLOGICAL STRESSORS OR THEIR INDICATORS TO IDENTIFY PRIORITY AREAS FOR CONSERVATION AND INDEXING INFORMATION COLLECTED FROM MONITORING TO ADDRESS QUESTIONS AND CONCERNS ABOUT RESIDENT STRIPED BASS FORAGE FISH AND STRIPED BASS WELLBEING IN MARYLAND'S PORTION OF THE CHESAPEAKE BAY. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE RECREATIONAL FISHERMAN, FISHERIES MANAGERS AND CITIZEN GROUPS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ESTIMATE THE PREVALENCE OF BACTERIAL DISEASE (MYCOBACTERIOSIS) IN THE STRIPED BASS MORONE SAXATILIS POPULATION RESIDENT TO THE CHESAPEAKE BAY, AND TO SUPPORT THE INVESTIGATION OF FISH HEALTH EVENTS IN MARYLAND WATERS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE OPERATION OF A HOOK AND LINE SURVEY TO DIAGNOSE DISEASE IN STRIPED BASS BASED ON GROSS AND HISTOPATHOLOGICAL EXAMINATION OF TISSUES, AND IMPLEMENT GENERAL DIAGNOSTIC PATHOLOGY SERVICES TO INVESTIGATE THE CAUSE OF FISH DISEASE OR MORTALITY EVENTS INVOLVING OTHER SPECIES. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE THE MAINTENANCE OF HEALTHY, SUSTAINABLE FISH POPULATIONS AND A MORE INFORMED RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AND GENERAL PUBLIC ON NATURAL RESOURCE HEALTH ISSUES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE GENERAL PUBLIC WHO USE AND APPRECIATE HEALTHY FISH POPULATIONS, AND MULTIPLE SEGMENTS OF THE MARYLAND ECONOMY THAT DEPEND ON THE ECONOMIC BENEFITS OF A HEALTHY FISHERY. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO MAINTAIN AND SUPPLEMENT RECREATIONAL SPORT FISH POPULATIONS OF TROUT AND LANDLOCKED ATLANTIC SALMON TO PROVIDE ENHANCED FRESHWATER FISHING OPPORTUNITIES THROUGHOUT MASSACHUSETTS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE HATCHERY OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE, FISH REARING, AND FISH STOCKING. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE THE IMPROVEMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF TROUT AND LANDLOCKED SALMON FISHERIES IN MASSACHUSETTS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PUBLIC WHO USE AND APPRECIATE THESE NATURAL RESOURCES. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) PROJECT STAFF MONITOR AND ASSESS FISHERIES AND FISH STOCKS AND PROVIDE SCIENCE-BASED RECOMMENDATIONS TO INFORM FISHERIES MANAGEMENT DECISIONS UNDER MIXED STATE AND FEDERAL JURISDICTION. FEDERAL SUPPORT OCCURS BY STAFF PERFORMING THE ANALYTICAL WORK OF ADVISORY BODIES FOR THE PACIFIC FISHERY MANAGEMENT COUNCIL (PFMC). SIMILARLY, PRODUCTS AND CONTENT PRODUCED UNDER THIS GRANT ARE USED BY THE CALIFORNIA FISH AND GAME COMMISSION (COMMISSION) IN ITS PROCESSES. WORK FOCUSES ON EFFORTS TO DEVELOP, ADOPT, AMEND AND/OR IMPLEMENT FISHERY MANAGEMENT PLANS (FMPS) FOR THE PFMC AND THE COMMISSION. THIS PROJECT ALSO PARTICIPATES IN STOCK ASSESSMENTS TO INFORM MANAGERS ON THE STATUS OF FISHED POPULATIONS, INCLUDING THE LEVEL OF FISHERY REMOVALS THAT CAN BE SAFELY SUPPORTED WHILE MAXIMIZING FISHING OPPORTUNITIES. IN ADDITION, CDFW COLLABORATES WITH RESEARCHERS ON TOPICS OF BIOLOGICAL OR MANAGEMENT INTEREST.A KEY FOCAL AREA OF WORK UNDER THIS AGREEMENT SURROUNDS OUTREACH EFFORTS AND PRODUCTS TO ASSIST THE RECREATIONAL FISHING COMMUNITY WITH INFORMATION TO AID WITH COMPLIANCE AND UNDERSTANDING OF CURRENT MANAGEMENT. ACTIVITIES RANGE FROM: DEVELOPMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF WEB CONTENT; ATTENDANCE AT CONFERENCES, PUBLIC EVENTS, AND FISHERY SEASON OPENERS; DEVELOPMENT OF INFORMATIVE HANDOUT MATERIALS; AND HOLDING PUBLIC MEETINGS.TO ACTIVELY MANAGE MIXED JURISDICTION FISHERIES IN A SUSTAINABLE, BALANCED, COLLABORATIVE, AND TIMELY MANNER, CDFW MUST BE FULLY ENGAGED IN FEDERAL AND STATE MANAGEMENT PROCESSES TO ENSURE CONSISTENCY IN ANALYSES AND PLAN DEVELOPMENT. CDFW INVOLVEMENT IS IMPERATIVE TO INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS FOR A VARIETY OF SPECIES OF INTEREST TO THE MARINE RECREATIONAL FISHING COMMUNITY AND THE CALIFORNIA CURRENT ECOSYSTEM (CCE). KEY RECREATIONAL FISHERIES MANAGED UNDER THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE OCEAN SALMON, GROUNDFISH (E.G., ROCKFISH, LINGCOD, FLATFISH), PACIFIC HALIBUT AND HIGHLY MIGRATORY SPECIES (HMS; E.G., TUNAS, DORADO, SOME SHARKS AND BILLFISHES). ALSO INCLUDED ARE COASTAL PELAGIC SPECIES (CPS) WHICH FORM A MAJOR COMPONENT OF RECREATIONAL FISHERIES BAIT AND ARE CRITICAL TO SUCCESSFUL ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES. AS STATE AND FEDERAL MANAGEMENT DEVELOP A MORE ECOSYSTEM-BASED APPROACH, PFMC WORK ALSO INCLUDES ACTIVITIES DIRECTED TO CONNECTIONS BETWEEN THESE FISHED SPECIES AND THE GREATER CCE (E.G., PREDATORS, PREY, ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS AND INDICATORS).SUPPORTING CDFW INVOLVEMENT IN THESE PROCESSES USING SPORT FISH RESTORATION ACT (SFRA) FUNDS IS JUSTIFIED BASED ON THE HIGH PROPORTION OF RECREATIONAL ANGLERS PARTICIPATING IN THESE FISHERIES, THE HIGH PROPORTION OF FISHERY MORTALITY OF KEY NEARSHORE AND SHELF ROCKFISH AND LINGCOD STOCKS BY CALIFORNIA'S RECREATIONAL FISHERY, AND IN RECOGNITION THAT ECOSYSTEM-LEVEL INFORMATION IS NEEDED TO ENSURE THE CONTINUED AVAILABILITY OF HARVESTABLE RESOURCES THAT ARE OF HIGH INTEREST TO RECREATIONAL USERS. THIS WORK PROVIDES THE SCIENTIFIC FOUNDATION FOR SUSTAINABLE USE OF OCEAN SALMON, GROUNDFISH, PACIFIC HALIBUT, HMS, AND CPS RESOURCES AND UNDERSTANDING OF THEIR CONNECTIONS TO THE ECOSYSTEM; CONTINUATION OF THIS WORK IS ESSENTIAL FOR EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT OF THESE IMPORTANT FISHERIES.
IN F-24-E-20 AQUATIC RESOURCES EDUCATION

WHITE SEABASS (ATRACTOSCION NOBILIS) HAS BEEN A POPULAR SPORT FISH IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA FOR OVER A CENTURY. DUETO CONCERNS OVER THE DECLINE OF WHITE SEABASS LANDINGS IN THE MID-LATE 1900'S, THE CALIFORNIA LEGISLATUREESTABLISHED THE OCEAN RESOURCES ENHANCEMENT AND HATCHERY PROGRAM (OREHP) IN 1983, UNDER CALIFORNIA FISH AND GAMECODE, SECTION 6590, ET. SEQ. THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THE OREHP WAS TO CONDUCT BASIC AND APPLIED RESEARCH INTO THEARTIFICIAL PROPAGATION, REARING, AND STOCKING OF IMPORTANT MARINE FINFISH SPECIES OCCURRING IN OCEAN WATERS OFFSOUTHERN CALIFORNIA. OVER THE YEARS, THE LEGISLATURE HAS AMENDED THE INTENT LANGUAGE OF THE PROGRAM. CURRENTLEGISLATION FOCUSES ON ADVANCING RESEARCH IN DETERMINING IF HATCHERY RELEASED FISH CAN ENHANCE IMPORTANTRECREATIONAL AND COMMERCIAL SPECIES THROUGH INCREASED PRODUCTION OF FISH AND INCREASED MONITORING OF FISHERIES TOASSESS THE HATCHERY CONTRIBUTION. THE GOAL OF THE LEGISLATION IS TO ENHANCE POPULATIONS OF MARINE FINFISH SPECIESIMPORTANT TO CALIFORNIA FOR THEIR SPORT AND COMMERCIAL FISHING VALUE. WHITE SEABASS HAS BEEN THE FOCUS OF THISRESEARCH SINCE 1990.THE DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) ADMINISTERS THE OREHP, WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF A 10-MEMBER OCEANRESOURCES ENHANCEMENT ADVISORY PANEL (OREAP). THE OREAP CONSISTS OF ACADEMIC AND MANAGEMENT AGENCY SCIENTISTS,REPRESENTATIVES OF BOTH COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL FISHING GROUPS, THE AQUACULTURE INDUSTRY, AND NON-GOVERNMENTORGANIZATION INTERESTS. CDFW ALSO EMPLOYS A RESEARCH SCIENTIST (FISH PATHOLOGIST) TO INVESTIGATE AND MANAGEDISEASE ISSUES WITH THE OREHP.CDFW'S MAIN CONTRACTOR IS HUBBS-SEAWORLD RESEARCH INSTITUTE (HSWRI). HSWRI OWNS AND OPERATES THE MARINE FISHHATCHERY (LEON RAYMOND HUBBARD, JR., MARINE FISH HATCHERY). HSWRI HAS DEVELOPED THE CULTURE PROTOCOLS REQUIREDFOR THE PROGRAM AND ASSESSMENT TECHNIQUES REQUIRED TO EVALUATE THE IMPACT OF HATCHERY-REARED FISH ON THE WILDFISHERY. THE PRIMARY FUNCTION OF THE HATCHERY IS TO PROVIDE JUVENILE WHITE SEABASS TO GROWOUT FACILITIES OPERATEDBY VOLUNTEER ORGANIZATIONS AND HSWRI. THE HATCHERY CAN PRODUCE SEVERAL MILLION JUVENILE WHITE SEABASS ANNUALLY;HOWEVER, CURRENT RELEASE GOALS ARE SET AT UP TO 350,000 JUVENILE WHITE SEABASS PER YEAR. SPECIFIC RELEASE GOALSARE BASED ON THE NUMBER OF ADULT BROODSTOCK FISH AVAILABLE AND THE POTENTIAL GENETIC IMPACT OF HATCHERY RELEASESON WILD WHITE SEABASS STOCKS.IN ADDITION TO HSWRI, THE OREHP RECEIVES CONSIDERABLE SUPPORT (5,000+ HOURS PER YEAR) FROM VOLUNTEERS, PRIMARILYRECREATIONAL ANGLER AND EDUCATIONAL GROUPS, WHO OWN AND OPERATE ELEVEN GROWOUT FACILITIES IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA.THESE GROWOUT FACILITIES PROVIDE A COST-EFFECTIVE WAY TO INCREASE POST-RELEASE SURVIVAL RATE BY RELEASING LARGERWHITE SEABASS.IN 2017, CALIFORNIA SEA GRANT (CASG) COMPLETED A MULTI-YEAR EVALUATION OF THE OREHP TO DETERMINE IF THE PROGRAMHAS BEEN A SUCCESSFUL AND COST-EFFECTIVE TOOL FOR WHITE SEABASS ENHANCEMENT AND MANAGEMENT. WITH GUIDANCE FROMCDFW, CASG CREATED A 9-MEMBER SCIENCE ADVISORY COMMITTEE, COMPRISED OF SCIENTISTS FROM AROUND THE COUNTRY WHOWERE RESPONSIBLE FOR EVALUATING THE PROGRAM. THE EVALUATION REPORT (CASG 2017) CONCLUDED THAT WHILE THE OREHP HASSIGNIFICANTLY CONTRIBUTED TO THE SCIENTIFIC UNDERSTANDING OF MARINE ENHANCEMENT SCIENCE, IT HAS NOT SUBSTANTIALLYINCREASED THE ABUNDANCE OF LEGAL-SIZED WHITE SEABASS, RESULTING IN LESS THAN ONE PERCENT CONTRIBUTION TORECREATIONAL AND COMMERCIAL FISHERIES CATCHES. THE EVALUATION REPORT DID NOT MAKE A RECOMMENDATION AS TO WHETHERTHE OREHP SHOULD CONTINUE; HOWEVER, IT DOES INCLUDE OBJECTIVE-SPECIFIC AND PROGRAM-WIDE RECOMMENDATIONS SHOULDTHE OREHP CONTINUE WITH EITHER WHITE SEABASS OR ANOTHER MARINE SPECIES, AS WELL AS RECOMMENDATIONS ON HOW TODISCONTINUE THE OREHP. THE INFORMATION GENERATED BY THE PROGRAM, TO DATE, CAN BE USED AS A LEARNING EXPERIENCEFOR ENHANCEMENT OF WILD POPULATIONS, WHETHER FOCUSING ON WHITE SEABASS OR OTHER SPECIES.

CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) PROJECT STAFF COLLECT AND MANAGE FISHERY DEPENDENT MARINE SPORT FISHING DATA THAT IS ESSENTIAL FOR EFFECTIVE FISHERIES MANAGEMENT WITH THE INTENT TO MAXIMIZE FISHING OPPORTUNITIES WHILE PROTECTING THE FISHERY RESOURCES. THIS INFORMATION IS NECESSARY TO MEET THE MANDATES OF THE MARINE LIFE MANAGEMENT ACT, THE MAGNUSON-STEVENS FISHERY CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ACT AND THE MODERNIZING MARINE RECREATIONAL FISHERIES ACT. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE CONDUCTING MARINE RECREATIONAL FISHERIES SURVEYS, ENTERING, AND MANAGING SURVEY DATA, MANAGEMENT OF COMMERCIAL PASSENGER FISHING VESSEL (CPFV ALSO KNOWN AS PARTY OR CHARTER BOATS) LOGBOOKS, AND PROVIDING TECHNICAL SUPPORT OF SURVEY DESIGNS FOR SPORT FISHERY STUDIES AND DATA ANALYSIS.  WORK CONDUCTED UNDER THIS PROJECT ALIGNS WITH CDFWS SEVEN STRATEGIC INITIATIVES, THE MARINE REGION STRATEGIC PLAN AND THE DATA AND ESTIMATES ARE VITAL COMPONENTS OF THE MARINE LIFE MANAGEMENT ACT MASTER PLAN.  MARINE FISH PROVIDE SPORT FISHING OPPORTUNITIES IN THREE INTERLINKED ECOSYSTEMS - BAYS AND ESTUARIES, NEAR SHORE OCEAN WATERS, AND OFFSHORE WATERS ALONG CALIFORNIAS 1100 MILE COASTLINE. THE FISH ARE DIVERSE, EXTENSIVE, AND COMPRISE ONE OF THE NATIONS LARGEST AND MOST HEAVILY USED FISHERY RESOURCES WITH ANGLERS TAKING APPROXIMATELY 3.4 MILLION FISHING TRIPS ANNUALLY. CALIFORNIAS MARINE ENVIRONMENT SUPPORTS 16 MAJOR RECREATIONAL FISHERIES: CALIFORNIA AND PACIFIC HALIBUT, CALIFORNIA SCORPIONFISH, CHINOOK SALMON, FLATFISHES FLOUNDERS AND SOLES, LINGCOD, PACIFIC MACKEREL, ROCKFISH, SHARKS, STRIPED BASS, SURFPERCHES, TRUE SEA BASSES -KELP BASS, BARRED AND SPOTTED SAND BASSES, TUNAS AND PELAGIC SPECIES, WHITE SEABASS, WHITE STURGEON, YELLOWTAIL -JACK AND NUMEROUS NICHE FISHERIES: EG, GRUNION, PACIFIC HERRING, NIGHT SMELT. IN 2017 MARINE RECREATIONAL ANGLERS SPENT $2.5 BILLION ON FISHING ACTIVITIES, ADDING A TOTAL OF $1.6 BILLION OF ECONOMIC VALUE AND SUPPORTED APPROXIMATELY 20,000 FULL AND PART-TIME JOBS IN CALIFORNIA - FISHERIES ECONOMICS OF THE UNITED STATES INTERACTIVE TOOL. MANAGEMENT PROCESSES DESIGNED TO HELP SUSTAIN LONG TERM USE OF MARINE FISH OF SPORT INTEREST HAVE, AT THEIR CORE, DATA GATHERING AND ANALYTICAL COMPONENTS. THE FISHERY DEPENDENT DATA AND ESTIMATES PROVIDED BY THIS PROJECT ARE ESSENTIAL FOR TRACKING HARVEST IN SEASON, DEVELOPING HARVEST LIMITS, CONDUCTING STOCK ASSESSMENTS, AND EVALUATING THE EFFECTIVENESS OF FISHERY MANAGEMENT POLICIES. IF CRFS DATA AND ESTIMATES ARE NOT PROVIDED, FISHERIES MANAGEMENT DECISIONS WILL NEED TO BE BASED ON PROXIES OF EFFORT AND CATCH RESULTING IN CONSERVATIVE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES THAT REDUCE OR ELIMINATE RECREATIONAL FISHING OPPORTUNITIES. THE REFERENCE SECTION PROVIDES A PARTIAL LIST OF STOCK ASSESSMENTS AND MANAGEMENT PLANS THAT USE FISHERY DEPENDENT INFORMATION OBTAINED THROUGH THIS GRANT.

IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA, MANY SPECIES HAVE SHOWN CONSIDERABLE DECLINES IN ABUNDANCE OVER THE PAST 10-20 YEARS. MANY OF THESE SPECIES ARE SUBJECTS OF IMPORTANT SPORT FISHERIES, INCLUDING BARRED SAND BASS, CALIFORNIA HALIBUT, AND PACIFIC BARRACUDA. IN ORDER TO UNDERSTAND THESE DECLINES AND MANAGE THESE FISHERIES SUSTAINABLY, ESSENTIAL FISHERY INFORMATION (EFI) IS NEEDED TO ASSESS THEIR POPULATIONS. EFI INCLUDES DATA ON AGE AND GROWTH, REPRODUCTION, AND OTHER LIFE HISTORY CHARACTERISTICS THAT ARE IMPORTANT FOR MANAGING A SUSTAINABLE FISHERY. THESE DATA FORM THE BASIS FOR STOCK ASSESSMENTS AND MODELS THAT PROVIDE BETTER INFORMATION ON THE HISTORY, CURRENT STATUS, AND FUTURE DIRECTION OF THESE IMPORTANT SPORT FISHERIES AND ENABLE THEIR BETTER MANAGEMENT.A MASTER PLAN PER THE MARINE LIFE MANAGEMENT ACT (MLMA SECTION 7050 FISH AND GAME CODE) WAS UPDATED AND IMPLEMENTED IN JUNE 2018 TO REFLECT NEW PRIORITIES AND MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES FOR STATE MARINE FISHERIES. THE MLMA MASTER PLAN INCLUDES A FRAMEWORK FOR MLMA-BASED MANAGEMENT THAT USES A PRIORITIZATION APPROACH FOLLOWED BY THE APPROPRIATE MANAGEMENT SCALING FOR THAT FISHERY. PRIORITIZATION INTEGRATES A PRODUCTIVITY AND SUSCEPTIBILITY ANALYSIS (PSA) THAT LOOKS AT RISKS TO STOCKS WITH AN ECOLOGICAL RISK ASSESSMENT (ERA) THAT EVALUATES ECOLOGICAL RISKS. ONCE A PRIORITIZED LIST OF FISHERIES IS GENERATED, A SCALED MANAGEMENT STRATEGY APPROPRIATE TO THAT FISHERY IS APPLIED. THIS RANGES FROM ENHANCED STATUS REPORTS (ESRS) FOR THOSE FISHERIES WITH LOWER PRIORITY AND COMPLEXITY TO FISHERY MANAGEMENT PLANS (FMPS) FOR THE HIGHER PRIORITY AND MORE COMPLEX ONES. THE MLMA MASTER PLAN CALLS FOR FMPS AND ESRS TO BE DEVELOPED FOR FISHERIES TO SYSTEMATICALLY ADDRESS OBJECTIVES AND REQUIREMENTS OF THE MLMA. RECOGNIZING THAT FMPS ARE COSTLY, RESOURCE-INTENSIVE, AND CAN TAKE YEARS TO COMPLETE, ESRS PROVIDE A SCALED APPROACH THAT CAN BE APPLIED TO MORE FISHERIES ON A MORE IMMEDIATE BASIS. ESRS CONTAIN MANY COMPONENTS OF AN FMP INCLUDING SPECIES DESCRIPTIONS, LANDINGS INFORMATION, MONITORING EFFORTS, AND IDENTIFICATION OF INFORMATION AND MANAGEMENT NEEDS. AN ADVANTAGE OF ESRS IS THAT THEY CAN BE MADE READILY AVAILABLE AND UPDATED ANNUALLY TO PROVIDE CURRENT INFORMATION TO THE STAKEHOLDERS. ESRS HAVE BEEN DEVELOPED FOR THE ABOVE FISHERIES WHICH IDENTIFIED CONCERNS AND EFI THAT SHOULD BE ADDRESSED TO BETTER MANAGE THESE FISHERIES. THIS GRANT SPECIFICALLY ADDRESSES THESE ITEMS.

THE MARINE LIFE MANAGEMENT ACT (MLMA) IS CALIFORNIA'S PRIMARY FISHERIES MANAGEMENT LAW. IT DIRECTS THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) TO DEVELOP A MASTER PLAN. THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF THE MASTER PLAN IS TO PROVIDE GUIDANCE FOR THE SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT OF FISH STOCKS AND FISHERIES USING THE BEST AVAILABLE SCIENCE. AMONG THE MANY AREAS OF GUIDANCE ARE: 1) PRIORITIZATION OF MANAGEMENT EFFORTS; 2) MEETING STOCK SUSTAINABILITY OBJECTIVES; 3) MEETING ECOSYSTEM OBJECTIVES (INCLUDING MINIMIZING IMPACT TO HABITAT AND BYCATCH SPECIES FROM THE NORMAL PROMULGATION OF FISHERIES, 4) ADAPTING TO CLIMATE CHANGE; 5) DATA COLLECTION TO ANALYZE TRENDS IN FISHERIES; AND 6) PROVIDING THE PUBLIC WITH RELEVANT SCIENTIFIC DATA SUMMARIES AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR ENGAGEMENT. AS PART OF THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE MLMA, CDFW COMPLETED A FISHERY PRIORITIZATION EXERCISE FOR STATE-MANAGED FINFISH SPECIES.  THOSE FISHERIES WITH HIGHEST OVERALL VULNERABILITY ARE CONSIDERED THE HIGHEST CANDIDATES FOR FUTURE ATTENTION AND MANAGEMENT ACTION, USING A SCALED MANAGEMENT APPROACH. THIS APPROACH INCLUDES THE FOLLOWING OPTIONS: ADDITIONAL DATA COLLECTION; MANAGEMENT STRATEGY EVALUATION (MSE); DEVELOPMENT AND UPDATES OF ENHANCED STATUS REPORTS (ESR); AND A COMBINATION OF AN ESR AND A SCALED MANAGEMENT APPROACH, WHICH MAY INCLUDE A FISHERY MANAGEMENT PLAN.   THE PRIORITIZATION PROCESS IDENTIFIED THE FOLLOWING SIX FINFISH SPECIES FOR WHICH THE PROJECT HAS MANAGEMENT RESPONSIBILITY TO FOCUS EFFORTS: BARRED SURFPERCH (AMPHISTICUS ARGENTEUS), REDTAIL SURFPERCH (A RHODOTERUS), CALIFORNIA HALIBUT (HALIBUT) (PARALICHTHYS CALIFORNICUS), NIGHT SMELT (SPIRINCHUS STARKSI), SURF SMELT (HYPOMESUS PRETIOSUS), AND WHITE SEABASS (ATRACTOSCION NOBILIS).  ESSENTIAL FISHERY INFORMATION (EFI) COLLECTED BY FISHERY SCIENTISTS IS NEEDED TO ASSESS AND MANAGE THESE IMPORTANT SPORT FISHERIES. FISH AND GAME CODE SECTION 93 DEFINES EFI AS INFORMATION ABOUT FISH LIFE HISTORY AND HABITAT REQUIREMENTS; THE STATUS AND TRENDS OF FISH POPULATIONS, FISHING EFFORT, AND CATCH LEVELS; FISHERY EFFECTS ON AGE STRUCTURE AND ON OTHER MARINE LIVING RESOURCES AND USERS, AND ANY OTHER INFORMATION RELATED TO THE BIOLOGY OF A FISH SPECIES OR TO TAKING IN THE FISHERY THAT IS NECESSARY TO PERMIT FISHERIES TO BE MANAGED ACCORDING TO THE REQUIREMENTS OF THIS CODE. THE PRIMARY TYPES OF EFI COLLECTED OR DETERMINED BY OUR STATE FINFISH RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT PROJECT (PROJECT) USING SFRA FUNDS ARE AGE AND GROWTH, REPRODUCTION, AND OTHER LIFE HISTORY PARAMETERS THAT ARE IMPORTANT FOR MANAGING A SUSTAINABLE FISHERY. CDFW ALSO COLLECTS FISHERY DEPENDENT DATA ON FISHING EFFORT AND CATCH LEVELS. A KEY COMPONENT OF THE ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT MANDATED BY THE MLMA IS A PROCESS TO USE THE DATA COLLECTED TO UNDERSTAND HOW THE SYSTEM IS RESPONDING TO MANAGEMENT. MSE IS THE GENERIC TERM USED FOR A CLASS OF ANALYSES THAT TEST POTENTIAL MANAGEMENT PROCEDURES AND EXPLICITLY ADDRESS THE TRADE-OFFS AND LEVELS OF UNCERTAINTY ASSOCIATED WITH THEM. IN MSE, THE ENTIRE FISHERY MANAGEMENT CYCLE IS SIMULATED OVER A SPECIFIED TIME PERIOD TO UNDERSTAND HOW EACH ASPECT OF THE MANAGEMENT PROCEDURE IS LIKELY TO PERFORM IN BOTH THE SHORT AND LONG TERM. MSE REPRESENTS AN EXCELLENT OPPORTUNITY TO PARTNER WITH STAKEHOLDERS, ACADEMICS, AND OTHER OUTSIDE EXPERTS TO ACCURATELY AND COMPREHENSIVELY CHARACTERIZE THE FISHERY AND ITS MANAGEMENT GOALS. MSES HAVE BEEN COMPLETED OR ARE BEING COMPLETED FOR HALIBUT AND SURFPERCH BY NON-SFRA FUNDED CDFW STAFF AND HAVE INFORMED DISCUSSIONS ABOUT MANAGEMENT AND SUSTAINABILITY. THE GOAL OF ESRS IS TO PROVIDE AN OVERVIEW OF THE SPECIES, FISHERY, CURRENT MANAGEMENT AND MONITORING EFFORTS, AND FUTURE MANAGEMENT NEEDS, AND PROVIDE TRANSPARENCY AROUND DATA AND INFORMATION THAT IS UNAVAILABLE OR UNKNOWN.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE'S (CDFW) WILD TROUT PROGRAM, NOW THE HERITAGE AND WILD TROUTPROGRAM (HWTP) WAS ESTABLISHED BY THE CALIFORNIA FISH AND GAME COMMISSION (COMMISSION) IN 1971 TO PROTECT ANDENHANCE QUALITY TROUT FISHERIES SUSTAINED BY NATURAL REPRODUCTION. THE COMMISSION ADOPTED A WILD TROUT POLICY(POLICY) THAT PROVIDES FOR THE DESIGNATION OF "AESTHETICALLY PLEASING AND ENVIRONMENTALLY PRODUCTIVE" STREAMS ANDLAKES TO BE MANAGED EXCLUSIVELY FOR WILD TROUT. THE COMMISSION DIRECTED THE CDFW TO STUDY AND IDENTIFY WATERSTHAT WOULD PROVIDE QUALITY WILD TROUT ANGLING FOR DESIGNATION AS WILD TROUT WATERS. WILD TROUT POPULATIONS INDESIGNATED WATERS ARE TO BE MANAGED WITH APPROPRIATE REGULATIONS TO BE "LARGELY UNAFFECTED BY THE ANGLINGPROCESS."THE COMMISSION RECOGNIZED THE IMPORTANCE OF HIGH QUALITY HABITAT FOR THE MAINTENANCE OF WILD TROUT POPULATIONSAND THE POLICY STATES: "ALL NECESSARY ACTIONS, CONSISTENT WITH STATE LAW, SHALL BE TAKEN TO PREVENT ADVERSEIMPACT BY LAND OR WATER DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS AFFECTING DESIGNATED WILD TROUT WATERS." THE CDFW IS REQUIRED BYCOMMISSION POLICY TO PREPARE AND PERIODICALLY UPDATE A MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR EACH WILD TROUT WATER.ADDITIONAL HWTP MANDATES ARE PROVIDED BY THE TROUT AND STEELHEAD CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT PLANNING ACT OF 1979(SB 192) AND ITS ASSOCIATED UPDATES (SPECIFICALLY SENATE BILL 384).THE CDFW'S HWTP CONDUCTS STATEWIDE RESOURCE ASSESSMENT WITH EMPHASIS ON SPECIAL MANAGEMENT WATERS. THESE WATERSINCLUDE RIVERS, STREAMS AND LAKES DESIGNATED AS "WILD TROUT MANAGEMENT AREAS" BY THE COMMISSION. NATURALRECRUITMENT AND AESTHETIC SURROUNDINGS ARE EMPHASIZED AND NATURAL VALUES ARE PROTECTED.IN 1998, THE COMMISSION EXPANDED ITS WILD TROUT POLICY BY ESTABLISHING THE HERITAGE TROUT PROGRAM (NOWINCORPORATED INTO THE HWTP), SUCH THAT STREAMS OR LAKES FEATURING ONE OR MORE OF THE STATE'S NATIVE TROUT, ANDMEETING OTHER SPECIFIC WILD TROUT WATER DESIGNATION CRITERIA, MAY BE DESIGNATED AS HERITAGE TROUT WATERS.HERITAGE TROUT WATERS ARE A SPECIAL SUBSET OF WILD TROUT WATERS TO BE MONITORED AND MANAGED BY THE HWTP. INADDITION, THE MANAGEMENT OF DESIGNATED HERITAGE TROUT WATERS WILL BE GUIDED BY APPROVED DEPARTMENT MANAGEMENTPLANS THAT IDENTIFY ACTIONS AND POLICIES NECESSARY TO PROTECT NATIVE TROUT HABITATS, AND MAINTAIN OR ENHANCENATIVE TROUT POPULATIONS.SOME NATIVE TROUT POPULATIONS IN CALIFORNIA ARE STATE OR FEDERALLY LISTED AS THREATENED SPECIES OR STATE "SPECIESOF SPECIAL CONCERN" BUT THEY MAY STILL PROVIDE FISHING OPPORTUNITIES AND THE WATERS THEY INHABIT MAY BEDESIGNATED AS HERITAGE TROUT WATERS BY THE COMMISSION. INFORMATION ON THE STATUS OF THESE POPULATIONS IS NEEDEDTO ADEQUATELY MANAGE AND RESTORE THESE POPULATIONS, WHILE MAINTAINING ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES WHERE BIOLOGICALLYJUSTIFIABLE.

ANADROMOUS FISH IN CALIFORNIA SUPPORT A MULTIMILLION-DOLLAR SPORT AND COMMERCIAL FISHING INDUSTRY THOUGH SOMECENTRAL VALLEY (SACRAMENTO-SAN JOAQUIN DELTA AND ITS TRIBUTARIES) SALMON (ONCORHYNCHUS TSHAWYTSCHA), STEELHEAD(ONCORHYNCHUS MYKISS), AND STURGEON (ACIPENSER SPP.) POPULATIONS HAVE DECLINED TO PRECIPITOUSLY LOW LEVELS.POPULATION DECLINES HAVE BEEN LINKED TO VARIOUS FACTORS SUCH AS CONSTRUCTION OF DAMS, WATER DIVERSIONS, ANDHABITAT DEGRADATION. SIGNIFICANT ALTERATIONS TO STREAM CHANNELS BEGAN WITH THE CALIFORNIA GOLD RUSH STARTING IN1849. TODAY, URBAN EXPANSION, AGRICULTURAL AND INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT, AND WATER OPERATIONS CONTINUE TONEGATIVELY AFFECT THESE POPULATIONS.THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW), AS THE TRUSTEE AGENCY FOR THE STATE'S FISH AND WILDLIFERESOURCES, NOT ONLY MANAGES CATCHABLE STOCKS AND HARVEST OPPORTUNITY BUT ALSO HAS BEEN STEADILY WORKING TOREVERSE POPULATION DECLINES OBSERVED IN CALIFORNIA'S ANADROMOUS FISH. SINCE THE LATE 1980'S SEVERAL STATE ANDFEDERAL LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS HAVE SIMILARLY FOCUSED ON REVERSING THESE DECLINES. THESE INCLUDE: THE STATE SALMON,STEELHEAD TROUT, AND ANADROMOUS FISHERIES PROGRAM ACT OF 1988, FEDERAL CENTRAL VALLEY PROJECT IMPROVEMENT ACT OF1991, AND THE WATER RESOURCES AND DELTA RESTORATION ACT OF 1996. IN 1994, AND INCLUSIVE OF THE PRIOR LEGISLATIVEACTIONS, THE BAY-DELTA ACCORD SET IN MOTION A MUCH BROADER PROCESS THAT WAS INTENDED TO BALANCE COMPETING DEMANDSAS WELL AS DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A LONG-TERM BAY-DELTA SOLUTION ENCOMPASSING FOUR SIGNIFICANT AREAS: ECOSYSTEMQUALITY, WATER QUALITY, WATER SUPPLY RELIABILITY AND LEVEE SYSTEM INTEGRITY. THE AUGUST 2000 CALFED BAY-DELTAPROGRAM RECORD OF DECISION DISPLAYED THE CONTINUED COMMITMENT TO IMPLEMENT THE CALFED ECOSYSTEM RESTORATIONPROGRAM AND THE CALIFORNIA BAY-DELTA ACT OF 2003 ESTABLISHED THE CALIFORNIA BAY-DELTA AUTHORITY AS CALFED'SGOVERNANCE STRUCTURE. SUBSEQUENTLY, THE DELTA REFORM ACT OF 2009 AUTHORIZED PLANNING EFFORTS TO ACHIEVE WATERSUPPLY RELIABILITY AND DELTA ECOSYSTEM HEALTH AND MODIFIED THE GOVERNANCE STRUCTURE PREVIOUSLY ESTABLISHED BY THECALIFORNIA BAY-DELTA AUTHORITY AND CALFED SCIENCE PROGRAM.THERE HAVE ALSO BEEN SEVERAL HABITAT RESTORATION AND SPECIES RECOVERY DOCUMENTS DEVELOPED SINCE THE EARLY 1990STHAT HAVE PROVIDED DIRECTION FOR RESTORATION AND RECOVERY ACTIONS AND AID IN PRIORITIZING ACTIONS. THESE INCLUDE:- RESTORING CENTRAL VALLEY STREAMS: A PLAN FOR ACTION (CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME (CDFG 1993))- FINAL RESTORATION PLAN FOR THE ANADROMOUS FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM (UNITED STATES FISH & WILDLIFE SERVICES(USFWS 1997))- CONSERVATION STRATEGY FOR RESTORATION OF THE SACRAMENTO-SAN JOAQUIN DELTA SACRAMENTO VALLEY AND SANJOAQUIN VALLEY REGIONS (CDFW 2014)- RECOVERY PLAN FOR SACRAMENTO RIVER WINTER-RUN CHINOOK SALMON, CENTRAL VALLEY SPRING-RUN CHINOOK SALMON,AND CENTRAL VALLEY STEELHEAD (NATIONAL MARINE FISHERIES SERVICE (NMFS 2014))- RECOVERY PLAN FOR THE SOUTHERN DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENT OF NORTH AMERICAN GREEN STURGEON (ACIPENSERMEDIROSTRIS) (NMFS 2018)THESE DOCUMENTS PROVIDE BROAD GUIDELINES FOR RESTORATION AND RECOVERY ACTIONS AND ARE CRUCIAL DRIVERS IN CENTRALVALLEY ANADROMOUS FISHERIES MANAGEMENT IN AN ENVIRONMENT WHERE BOTH LISTED AND CATCHABLE STOCKS CO-OCCUR.

CALIFORNIA HAS AN ESTIMATED 3,469 COLD WATER LAKES, 112 COLD WATER RESERVOIRS, AND OVER 200 RESERVOIRS WITH WARMWATER SPECIES. ACCORDING TO THE 2011 NATIONAL SURVEY OF FISHING, HUNTING, AND WILDLIFE-ASSOCIATED RECREATION (USDOI 2013) AN ESTIMATED 1.7 MILLION FRESHWATER ANGLERS ACCUMULATED OVER 23.8 MILLION ANGLING DAYS ON PONDS, LAKES, AND RESERVOIRS IN CALIFORNIA AND ANGLERS CONTRIBUTED OVER $2.3 BILLION TO THE STATE'S ECONOMY FROM FISHING RELATED EXPENSES.ALTHOUGH SEEMINGLY HIGH, THE NUMBER OF ANGLERS IN CALIFORNIA HAS BEEN DECLINING FOR THE PAST DECADE. CONTRIBUTING FACTORS FOR THE DECLINING PARTICIPATION IN ANGLING HAS NOT BEEN WELL INVESTIGATED. IN 1988, FLETCHER AND KING(1988) REPORTED THAT, IN GENERAL, CALIFORNIA ANGLERS STOPPED FISHING DUE TO A LACK OF FREE TIME. HOWEVER, THE 18-24-YEAR-OLD AGE SUBGROUP CITED A LOSS OF INTEREST AS THE PRIMARY REASON FOR NO LONGER FISHING. LOSS OF INTEREST MAY RELATE TO POOR ANGLER SATISFACTION, WHICH WAS MOST NEGATIVELY IMPACTED BY NOT CATCHING ENOUGH FISH. IN A LATER STUDY OF 14 CALIFORNIA RESERVOIRS STOCKED WITH SALMONIDS, 78% OF ANGLERS CONTACTED WERE SATISFIED WITH THEIR OVERALL ANGLING EXPERIENCE, BUT APPROXIMATELY HALF OF ANGLERS CONTACTED WERE NOT SATISFIED WITH EITHER THE SIZE OR NUMBER OF FISH CAUGHT (LEE 2003). SATISFACTION METRICS DID NOT SHOW A STRONG TREND OVER TIME IN EITHER DIRECTION. HOWEVER, THE STAGNANT AND MEDIOCRE LEVELS OF SATISFACTION IN FISH SIZE AND CATCH RATE MAY HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO THE RECENT DECLINE IN ANGLING PARTICIPATION.A MAJOR PROBLEM FACING RECREATIONAL FISHING MANAGERS IS PROVIDING SATISFACTORY FISHING OPPORTUNITIES FOR ANGLERS. NOT CATCHING ENOUGH FISH IS OFTEN THE GREATEST DETRACTOR FROM THE ENJOYMENT OF FISHING. ONE FACTOR THAT CAN LIMIT THE ANGLER USE AND SATISFACTION IS THE NUMBER AND TYPE OF GAME FISH AVAILABLE TO ANGLERS. FISHERY METHODS AND TECHNIQUES FOR IMPROVING ANGLER CATCHES ARE NUMEROUS AND LEE (1993) DESCRIBED VARIOUS LAKE AND RESERVOIR MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES COMMONLY USED IN CALIFORNIA. TO DETERMINE THE SUCCESS OF THESE STRATEGIES AND TO HELP DEVELOP NEW STRATEGIES, INFORMATION ON LAKE AND RESERVOIR PHYSICAL AND CHEMICAL PARAMETERS, FISH POPULATIONS, ANGLER SUCCESS AND CATCH, AND ANGLER ATTITUDES AND PREFERENCES ARE NEEDED.EVEN THOUGH LAKE AND RESERVOIR FISHERIES COMPRISE A LARGE PORTION OF THE RECREATIONAL FISHING EFFORT IN CALIFORNIA, THERE IS A LACK OF DATA ON FISH POPULATION DYNAMICS OF GAME FISHES IN MANY OF THE STATE'S WATERS. INFORMATION ON SPORT FISH SPECIES ABUNDANCE, AGE, SIZE STRUCTURE, ANGLER SUCCESS AND HARVEST, AND THE SIZE OF NATURAL-SPAWNING POPULATIONS IS NECESSARY TO EFFECTIVELY MANAGE ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES.IN SOME WATERS THE INTRODUCTION OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES (AIS) CREATES THREATS TO DESIRABLE FISHERY RESOURCES. INFORMATION ON THE STATUS OF AIS SPECIES AND EFFECTIVE CONTROL METHODS ARE NEEDED IN ORDER TO DETERMINE APPROPRIATE MANAGEMENT RESPONSE TO AIS INTRODUCTIONS AND TO REDUCE THE IMPACT TO CALIFORNIA'S SPORT FISHERIES.THE GOAL OF THE LAKE AND RESERVOIR FISHERY MANAGEMENT AND RESEARCH PROGRAM IS TO FURTHER OUR UNDERSTANDING OF SPORT FISH POPULATION DYNAMICS BY MAINTAINING AND IMPROVING RECREATIONAL FISHING OPPORTUNITIES IN CALIFORNIA LAKES AND RESERVOIRS, THUS INCREASING ANGLER SUCCESS AND SATISFACTION.

INLAND SPORTFISHING REGULATIONS FOR TROUT IN CALIFORNIA HAVE FOR MANY DECADES BEEN LARGELY STRUCTURED AROUND A "SUMMER" TROUT SEASON, RUNNING FROM THE LAST SATURDAY IN APRIL THROUGH NOVEMBER 15. THIS BASIC SEASON STRUCTURE FOCUSES FISHING OPPORTUNITY IN MID-TO-HIGH ELEVATION WATERS TO THE TIME OF YEAR WHEN THESE WATERS ARE MOST ACCESSIBLE, GIVEN SEVERE COLD-WEATHER CONDITIONS WITH SNOW AND ICE IN WINTER AND HIGH FLOW CONDITIONS FROM RUNOFF OF SNOWMELT IN SPRING. ADDITIONALLY, THIS SEASON STRUCTURE PROVIDES DE FACTO PROTECTIONS TO BOTH FALL SPAWNING AND SPRING SPAWNING SPECIES OF TROUT (E.G., BROWN TROUT AND RAINBOW TROUT, RESPECTIVELY) IN THESE WATERS. IN THESE RESPECTS, THE LOGIC BEHIND THIS BASIC SEASON STRUCTURE IS VERY COMPELLING AND HAS EVEN RESULTED IN THE EVOLUTION OF FISHING TRADITIONS THAT REVOLVE AROUND THIS ANNUAL CYCLE.OVER TIME, HOWEVER, MANY EXCEPTIONS TO THIS BASIC SEASON STRUCTURE HAVE BEEN IMPLEMENTED RESULTING IN A LONG LIST OF WATERS WITH SPECIAL FISHING REGULATIONS REPRESENTING WIDELY VARYING OPEN SEASONS, GEAR RESTRICTIONS, BOTH MINIMUM AND MAXIMUM SIZE LIMITS, AND VARYING DAILY BAG LIMITS. WITH THIS VARIATION IN FISHING REGULATIONS HAS EVOLVED A CERTAIN LEVEL OF CONFUSION AND DISCOURAGEMENT AMONG THE ANGLING PUBLIC, SUCH THAT THE UNCERTAINTY OF WHERE THEY CAN AND CANNOT FISH, AND WHEN, HAS LIKELY BECOME A DETERRENT TO ENGAGING IN TROUT FISHING AT ALL.CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) RECENTLY DEVELOPED A STATEWIDE SIMPLIFICATION OF INLAND SPORTFISHING REGULATIONS, WHICH ADDRESSES THE COMPLEXITY OF THE CURRENT REGULATIONS BY APPLYING A YEAR-ROUND OPEN SEASON TO TROUT WATERS THROUGHOUT THE STATE, GENERALLY WITH HARVEST ALLOWED DURING THE TRADITIONAL SUMMER TROUT SEASON, AND GEAR RESTRICTIONS AND ZERO HARVEST APPLIED DURING THE NEW WINTER FISHING SEASON. VARIATIONS TO THIS NEW BASIC SEASON STRUCTURE STILL APPLY, BUT TO A MUCH LESSER EXTENT THAN PREVIOUSLY. THE CALIFORNIA FISH AND GAME COMMISSION ADOPTED THIS REGULATORY PACKAGE IN DECEMBER 2020, WITH AN EFFECTIVE DATE OF MARCH 1, 2021.EVALUATING THE SUCCESS OF CALIFORNIA'S NEW INLAND SPORTFISHING REGULATIONS WILL REQUIRE A MONITORING PROGRAM. SUCH A PROGRAM WILL MONITOR FOR MEASURABLE RESPONSES IN PERFORMANCE METRICS OF THE SPORT FISHERY, THE SUPPORTING FISH POPULATIONS, AND IN ANGLER SATISFACTION WITH THE CHANGES IN ANGLING OPPORTUNITY. THE PROJECT PROPOSED BELOW WILL PROVIDE THE START TO THAT MONITORING.THE MISSION OF THE HERITAGE AND WILD TROUT PROGRAM (HWTP) IS TO PROTECT AND ENHANCE CALIFORNIA'S HERITAGE AND WILD TROUT RESOURCES, WHILE PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR HIGH-QUALITY WILD TROUT ANGLING. THE HWTP ACHIEVES THIS MISSION IN PART BY ADMINISTERING THE HERITAGE TROUT CHALLENGE (CHALLENGE) WHICH EXHIBITS THE ECOLOGICAL AND AESTHETIC VALUES OF NATIVE TROUT NATIVE TO CALIFORNIA WHILE ENCOURAGING ANGLERS TO CATCH THEM WITHIN THEIR HISTORIC DRAINAGES. THE CHALLENGE HAS GARNERED NATIONAL RECOGNITION AND HAS BEEN EMULATED BY OTHER WESTERN STATES. A HANDBOOK WAS CREATED AS A GUIDE TO THE CHALLENGE TO PROVIDE ANGLERS WITH DETAILED INFORMATION ON HOW AND WHERE TO CATCH THESE FISH AS WELL AS DESCRIBE THEIR UNIQUE ATTRIBUTES. AN INITIAL PRODUCTION OF THE GUIDE WAS WILDLY SUCCESSFUL AND THERE IS AN EMINENT NEED FOR AN ADDITIONAL PRODUCTION RUN.

MANY FACTORS HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO THE DECLINE OF SPORT FISH POPULATIONS AND FISHING OPPORTUNITIES IN CALIFORNIA.UNDERSTANDING THESE FACTORS AND IDENTIFYING WAYS TO IMPROVE MANAGEMENT OF BOTH RESIDENT AND ANADROMOUS SPORT FISHPOPULATIONS IS A CENTRAL FOCUS FOR CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) FISHERIES BIOLOGISTS. THENORTH CENTRAL REGION (NCR) HABITAT SHOP PROPOSES TO CONTINUE SUPPORTING NCR'S FISHERIES PROGRAM IN PROMOTINGSPORT FISHING OPPORTUNITIES AND MANAGEMENT OF SPORT FISH POPULATIONS IN THE REGION. HABITAT SHOP PERSONNEL AREDEDICATED TO DESIGNING, FABRICATING, CREATING, INSTALLING, REPAIRING, AND MAINTAINING THE EQUIPMENT ANDINFRASTRUCTURE THAT CDFW RELIES ON TO MONITOR AND MANAGE SPORT FISH POPULATIONS THROUGHOUT THE REGION ANDMAINTAIN HABITATS AND HAVE THE UNIQUE SKILLS AND EQUIPMENT NECESSARY TO DO SO. THIS EQUIPMENT AND INFRASTRUCTUREREQUIRE ACTIVE AND ONGOING INSPECTIONS, MONITORING, MAINTENANCE, AND REPAIR.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS, ENVIRONMENTAL CONSULTANTS, PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, BUSINESSES, LOCAL MUNICIPALITIES, FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES, AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS IN CONSULTATION FOR HIGHWAY, BRIDGE, OTHER PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION PROJECTS, ENERGY PROJECTS, ALTERATIONS OF FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITATS, AND OTHER DEVELOPMENTAL PROJECTS TO AVOID, MINIMIZE, AND/OR MITIGATE IMPACTS OR LOSS OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS IN NEW HAMPSHIRE. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE WILL ALSO BE PROVIDED FOR PROJECTS DIRECTLY INVOLVED WITH THE PRESERVATION, RESTORATION, AND ENHANCEMENT OF AQUATIC RIPARIAN HABITATS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE REVIEW OF PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION AND ENERGY PROJECTS AND OTHER PROJECTS POTENTIALLY IMPACTING FISH AND WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS AND PARTICIPATION ON RELATED TECHNICAL COMMITTEES. PERSONNEL WILL ATTEND MEETINGS, REVIEW PROPOSED PROJECTS, CONDUCT SITE VISITS, MAKE TELEPHONE CALLS, WRITE CORRESPONDENCE, AND PREPARE SCIENTIFIC SUMMARIES TO PROVIDE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR ALTERNATIVES OR MODIFICATIONS TO PROJECTS OR TO PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION METHODS TO MINIMIZE ADVERSE IMPACTS TO FISH AND WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS, OR TO ENHANCE THE SUCCESS OF HABITAT RESTORATION EFFORTS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE THE AVOIDANCE, MINIMIZATION, AND MITIGATION OF ADVERSE IMPACTS TO FISH AND WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS. IN ADDITION, NEW HAMPSHIRE'S FISHERIES HABITATS WILL EXHIBIT SELF-SUSTAINING NATURAL PROCESSES AND LINKAGES AMONG ITS TERRESTRIAL, RIPARIAN, AND AQUATIC COMPONENTS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE LAND USE PLANNERS AND DECISION-MAKERS WHOSE ACTIVITIES CAN AFFECT THE HEALTH OF THE STATE'S FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES, AS WELL AS THOSE GROUPS WHO ARE IN A POSITION TO PROTECT, CONSERVE, OR ENHANCE THESE RESOURCES. THE PUBLIC WILL BENEFIT FROM APPROPRIATE CONSERVATION OF THE STATE'S FISH AND WILDLIFE. THERE ARE NO ANTICIPATED SUBRECIPIENTS PERFORMING WORK UNDER THIS AWARD.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT ECOLOGICALLY SOUND, SCIENCE BASED CONSERVATION AND FISHERIES MANAGEMENT OF RECREATIONALLY IMPORTANT SPECIES. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE FISHERIES SURVEYS TO COLLECT DATA, OBTAIN BIOLOGICAL SAMPLES, AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE CHARACTERIZATION OF FISHES IN THE MARYLAND COASTAL BAYS; CONTRIBUTIONS TO SUPPORT HEALTHY AND SUSTAINABLE POPULATIONS OF FISHES, FORAGE SPECIES, AND HABITAT; AND TECHNICAL EXPERTISE. THESE OUTCOMES SUPPORT THE DEPARTMENTS MISSION AS WELL AS THE ATLANTIC STATES MARINE FISHERIES COMMISSION, THE MID-ATLANTIC FISHERY MANAGEMENT COUNCIL, AND THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION FISHERIES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE RECREATIONAL FISHING PUBLIC WHO USE AND APPRECIATE THESE NATURAL RESOURCES. THERE ARE NO SUB-RECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO MAINTAIN ELIGIBILITY STANDARDS AND REQUIREMENTS FOR PARTICIPATION IN THE SFR PROGRAM, BY ESTABLISHING AND MAINTAINING MANAGEMENT CONTROL SYSTEMS AND COMPLYING WITH APPLICABLE FEDERAL LAWS AND REGULATIONS.

THE FISHERY CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ACT OF 1976 (ACT) DECLARED A FISHERY CONSERVATION ZONE IN OCEAN WATERSSURROUNDING THE UNITED STATES FROM 3 TO 200 MILES OFFSHORE. UNDER THIS ACT THE PACIFIC FISHERIES MANAGEMENTCOUNCIL (PFMC) WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1976. IN 1977, THE PFMC RECOGNIZED THE NEED FOR SALMON RESOURCE MANAGEMENT ANDIMPLEMENTED THE FISHERY MANAGEMENT PLAN (FMP) FOR COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL SALMON FISHERIES OFF THE COASTS OFWASHINGTON, OREGON, AND CALIFORNIA. THIS FMP HAS BEEN REVISED MULTIPLE TIMES SINCE 1977 AND THIS PLANNINGDOCUMENT WAS UPDATED THROUGH AMENDMENT 19 IN MARCH OF 2016. THE KLAMATH RIVER IS REGARDED AS ONE OF THE MOREIMPORTANT PRODUCERS OF FALL-RUN CHINOOK SALMON (KRFC) TO CALIFORNIA AND SOUTHERN OREGON COMMERCIAL AND SPORTFISHERIES. KRFC CONSIST LARGELY OF NATURALLY PRODUCED (NATIVE SPORTFISH) STOCKS AS WELL AS HATCHERY PRODUCEDSTOCKS. PFMC MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOCUS ON HARVEST OPPORTUNITIES WHEN STOCKS CAN SUPPORT HARVEST AND PROVIDE AFRAMEWORK FOR HARVEST RESTRICTIONS WHEN ABUNDANCE IS FORECASTED TO BE LOW. THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA, WITHMANAGEMENT JURISDICTION OF FISHERIES IN COASTAL WATERS WITHIN THREE MILES OF SHORE AND INLAND SPORT FISHERIES,IMPLEMENTS KRFC MANAGEMENT PRACTICES AND REGULATIONS CONFORMING TO PFMC OBJECTIVES. THEREFORE, KRFC RUN-SIZE DATAIS A CRITICAL MANAGEMENT COMPONENT FOR CHINOOK SALMON SPORT FISHERIES AND COMMERCIAL FISHERIES CONDUCTED INCALIFORNIA AND OREGON. IN ADDITION TO THE HARVESTABLE STOCK OF KRFC, OTHER IMPORTANT ANADROMOUS SALMONIDS OCCURIN THE KLAMATH RIVER INCLUDING SPRING RUN CHINOOK SALMON, COHO SALMON AND STEELHEAD TROUT.

TO MAINTAIN 196 FISHING ACCESS AREAS, AS WELL AS ANY FUTURE DEVELOPED SITES, FOR THE PUBLIC TO ACCESS PUBLIC WATERS FOR THE PURPOSES OF BOATING, FISHING, HUNTING AND TRAPPING.VT FISH AND WILDLIFE WILL ACCOMPLISH THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS GRANT THROUGH:PROGRAM SUPPORTGROUNDS MAINTENANCEFACILITIES MAINTENANCE ANDFACILITIES REPAIR

RHE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO OPERATE AND MAINTAIN LAKE JEFF DAVIS TO PROVIDE QUALITY PUBLIC FISHING AND WATER ASSOCIATED RECREATION. THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY: ROUTINE MAINTENANCE OF 7 FACILITY BUILDINGS, GROUNDS MAINTENANCE: LITTER CONTROL ON 115 LAND ACRES, MOWING OF 20 ACRES, MAINTAINING 5 FISHING PIERS (WOODEN AND EARTHEN), 1 BOAT RAMP, 13 CAMPSITES, PURCHASE OF SUPPLIES, AND MAINTENANCE OF PROJECT EQUIPMENT. THE LAKE'S CAMPGROUND WILL BE MAINTAINED USING PROGRAM INCOME GENERATED THROUGH LAKE/FACILITY USER PERMITS.

THE NORTH CENTRAL COAST WATERSHED RESTORATION PROJECT IS PART OF THE BAY DELTA REGION'S (BDR) WATERSHEDRESTORATION PROGRAM AND IS COMPRISED OF ONE SENIOR ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTIST SUPERVISOR AND THREE ENVIRONMENTALSCIENTISTS THAT OVERSEES SEASONAL FIELD STAFF THAT CONDUCT RESOURCE ASSESSMENT. TWO OF THE WATERSHED RESTORATIONPROGRAM ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTISTS ARE PARTIALLY FUNDED THROUGH A PACIFIC COASTAL SALMON RECOVERY FUND (PCSRF)GRANT. THE BAY DELTA REGION (BDR) IS LOCATED IN THE CENTER OF THE CALIFORNIA COAST AND EXTENDS IN-LAND INTO THESACRAMENTO-SAN JOAQUIN DELTA. THE NORTH COAST FISHERIES RESOURCE ASSESSMENT BIOLOGISTS ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR THEMANAGEMENT, CONSERVATION, RESTORATION, AND MONITORING OF FISHERIES AND AQUATIC RESOURCES WITHIN THE STREAMS OFTHE NORTH CENTRAL COAST WITH SPECIAL EMPHASIS ON NATIVE SALMONIDS. THIS IS ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH CLOSECOORDINATION AND COMMUNICATION WITH OTHER DFW REGIONAL PROGRAMS AND VARIOUS FEDERAL, STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTALAGENCIES AND INTERESTED STAKEHOLDERS.

THE DEVELOPMENT OF GEORGIA'S ESTUARINE AND MARINE HABITATS INVOLVES THE DEVELOPMENT OF LONG-TERM SPORT FISHERIES HABITAT THROUGH THE RESTORATION OF OYSTER REEFS AND THE ENHANCEMENT OF INSHORE AND OFFSHORE ARTIFICIAL REEFS TO INCREASE RECREATIONAL FISHING OPPORTUNITIES.

THE SOUTH-CENTRAL COAST STEELHEAD RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT PROJECT IS PART OF THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OFFISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) BAY DELTA REGION'S (BDR) FISHERIES MANAGEMENT PROGRAM AND IS COMPRISED OF ONEENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTIST (SPECIALIST) THAT OVERSEES SEASONAL FIELD STAFF THAT CONDUCT STEELHEAD HABITAT ANDPOPULATION ASSESSMENT. BDR IS IN THE CENTER OF THE CALIFORNIA COAST AND EXTENDS INLAND INTO THE SACRAMENTO-SANJOAQUIN DELTA. THE SOUTH-CENTRAL COAST STEELHEAD ASSESSMENT BIOLOGIST IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE MANAGEMENT,CONSERVATION, RESTORATION, AND MONITORING OF STEELHEAD WITHIN THE STREAMS OF THE SOUTH-CENTRAL COAST. THIS ISACCOMPLISHED THROUGH COORDINATION AND COMMUNICATION WITH OTHER DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (DFW) REGIONALPROGRAMS AND VARIOUS FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES, AND INTERESTED STAKEHOLDERS.

THE SMITH RIVER IS CALIFORNIA'S LARGEST FREE-FLOWING RIVER AND PROVIDES A FLAGSHIP FISHING DESTINATION FORTHOUSANDS OF ANGLERS ANNUALLY FISHING FOR STEELHEAD TROUT, RESIDENT RAINBOW TROUT, COASTAL CUTTHROAT TROUT, ANDCHINOOK SALMON. THERE ARE A TOTAL OF SEVEN INDIVIDUAL FISHERY REGULATION ZONES AND 18 INDIVIDUAL SPECIES/ ZONESPECIFICREGULATIONS RESULTING IN 25 UNIQUE FISHERIES THROUGHOUT THE BASIN [SECTION 180; 2018 CALIFORNIADEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) REGULATIONS]. MOST OF THE BASIN IS WITHIN THE SMITH RIVER NATIONALRECREATION AREA WITH DOZENS OF DEVELOPED RIVER ACCESS POINTS USED FOR FISHING AND OTHER RECREATION ACTIVITIES.PRIOR TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF THIS SPORT FISH RESTORATION ACT (SFRA) PROJECT, LITTLE WAS KNOWN ABOUT THE SMITHRIVER CATCHABLE SALMONID POPULATIONS DESPITE THE RIVER BEING ONE OF THE MOST POPULAR SALMONID SPORT FISHERIES INCALIFORNIA WITH OVER 300 MILES OF ANADROMOUS WATERS OPEN TO SPORT FISHING.ESTIMATING ANNUAL CHINOOK SALMON AND STEELHEAD TROUT ESCAPEMENT AND IDENTIFYING CRITICAL AREAS FOR JUVENILEREARING WILL AID IN DEFINING FUTURE SALMONID HABITAT RESTORATION PRIORITIES AND FISHERIES MANAGEMENT DECISIONS.FISHERIES ASSESSMENT AND MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS PRODUCED IN TECHNICAL REPORTS ASSOCIATED WITH THIS SFRAPROJECT ARE THE PRIMARY CATALYST FOR RESTORATION ACTIONS TARGETED AT INCREASING SPORTFISH POPULATION NUMBERS.THESE DATA ARE NECESSARY AS THE BASIS TO INFORM AND EVALUATE FISHERIES EXPLOITATION AND MANAGEMENT. LASTLY, STAFFASSOCIATED WITH THIS SFRA PROJECT REGULARLY PARTICIPATE WITH SMITH RIVER STAKEHOLDER GROUPS, INCLUDING THE MILLCREEK ADVISORY GROUP AND SMITH RIVER ADVISORY COUNCIL, TO COMMUNICATE MONITORING ASSESSMENTS, MAINTAIN ACOORDINATED SALMONID MONITORING STRATEGY, AND INFORM SPORT FISH RESTORATION IN THE SMITH RIVER BASIN.THE SCALE ARCHIVE COMPONENT OF THIS PROJECT HAS INVENTORIED ADULT ANADROMOUS SALMONID SCALES SAMPLED DURING THECOURSE OF ITS OWN AND OTHER CDFW STUDIES IN THE KLAMATH-TRINITY BASIN SINCE 1984. IN 1993, WE BEGAN CATALOGINGAND INVENTORYING SOME 50,000+ SCALE SAMPLES COLLECTED THROUGHOUT NORTHERN AND CENTRAL CALIFORNIA FROM 1913THROUGH 1933. BOTH THE CURRENT AND HISTORIC COLLECTIONS ARE VALUABLE REFERENCE MATERIAL FOR RESOURCE ASSESSMENTAND RESEARCH WHICH SHOULD BE ADDED TO AND MAINTAINED FROM YEAR TO YEAR. GENETICISTS WORKING WITH UNIVERSITY OFCALIFORNIA DAVIS, HUMBOLDT STATE UNIVERSITY, THE NATIONAL MARINE FISHERIES SERVICE, AND SEVERAL GRADUATE STUDENTSHAVE REQUESTED SCALES FOR THEIR STUDIES.

SPORT FISHERIES FOR EEL RIVER CHINOOK, AND EEL AND MENDOCINO COASTAL RIVERS STEELHEAD AND RAINBOW TROUT RELY UPONHABITAT CONDITION AND PRODUCTIVITY FOR NATURAL FISH PRODUCTION. THESE FISHING OPPORTUNITIES CAN ONLY BE PROVIDEDAND MANAGED FOR THROUGH FIELD STUDY OF THE WILD FISH POPULATIONS. THIS PROJECT PROVIDES CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OFFISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) SPORT FISH MANAGEMENT AND POPULATION IMPROVEMENT INFORMATION VIA STEELHEAD POPULATIONSPATIAL STRUCTURE AND DIVERSITY ASSESSMENT, AND CHINOOK SALMON, STEELHEAD TROUT, AND TROUT HABITAT SURVEY ANDRECOMMENDATIONS. WITHIN THE NORTH CENTRAL DISTRICT, THERE IS AN ESTIMATED 447 MILES OF CHINOOK SALMON HABITAT,3,179 MILES OF STEELHEAD TROUT HABITAT, AND 1,537 MILES OF TROUT HABITAT. THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS CDFW SPORTFISHERY MANAGEMENT NEEDS INCLUDING EEL RIVER CATCH AND RELEASE CHINOOK SALMON AND STEELHEAD TROUT FISHERIES,MENDOCINO COASTAL RIVERS CATCH AND RELEASE STEELHEAD TROUT FISHERY, RESIDENT TROUT FISHERY, AND CALIFORNIA'SOCEAN SALMON FISHERY. THE IN-RIVER BANK AND DRIFT BOAT CHINOOK SALMON AND STEELHEAD TROUT FISHERIES, AND THEAREAS LAKE AND STREAM TROUT FISHERIES, ATTRACT NUMEROUS ANGLERS AND SUPPORT VISITOR, TACKLE, AND GUIDE SERVICEINDUSTRIES. CALIFORNIA'S RECREATIONAL OCEAN SALMON FISHERY IS CONDUCTED FROM PORTS THROUGHOUT THE STATE ANDSIGNIFICANTLY CONTRIBUTES TO VISITOR, TACKLE, BOATING, AND CHARTER SERVICE INDUSTRIES.

THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO PROMOTE SPORTFISHING, PROTECT FRESHWATER NATURAL RESOURCES, AND USE SCIENCE BASED METHODS TO MANAGE RECREATIONAL FISHERIES IN FRESHWATER IMPOUNDMENTS, RIVERS, AND STREAMS THROUGHOUT MARYLAND. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE FISH POPULATION MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT, HABITAT ASSESSMENT, ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW OF PROJECTS THAT MAY IMPACT AQUATIC RESOURCES, OUTREACH AND EDUCATION, AND INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE CONSERVING AQUATIC RESOURCES FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS, MAINTAINING STABLE AQUATIC HABITAT, PROVIDING DIVERSE FISHING EXPERIENCES FOR ANGLERS, AND PROTECTING RESIDENT FISH SPECIES FROM THE IMPACTS OF INVASIVE FISH SPECIES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC THAT PARTICIPATE IN FISHING ACTIVITIES AND ENJOY AQUATIC RESOURCES THROUGHOUT MARYLAND. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO OPERATE AND MAINTAIN FACILITIES, HATCHERIES, PUBLIC FISHING AREAS AND LABORATORY FACILITIES; PRODUCE COLD WATER AND WARM WATER FISH SPECIES FOR RECREATIONAL, MAINTENANCE AND FISH RODEO STOCKING; AND FISH HEALTH TESTING AND MONITORING. ACTIVITIES PERFORMED INCLUDE DAILY OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF FISH HATCHERIES, OFFICES, AND LABORATORIES, STATE OWNED FISHERY MANAGEMENT AREAS, AND PROVIDES GUIDANCE AND SOME ASSISTANCE (E.G., AQUATIC VEGETATION CONTROL) TO LOCAL PUBLIC ACCESS FISHING AREAS THAT ARE NOT OWNED BY THE DEPARTMENT. FISH PRODUCTION FOR RECREATION AND MAINTENANCE AND FISH RODEO STOCKING. FISH HEALTH TESTING AND MONITORING WILL HELP TO ENSURE THAT FISH STOCKED FOR RECREATIONAL OR RESTORATION PURPOSES INTO MARYLAND WATERS CARRY NO PATHOGENS AND WILL NOT POSE A THREAT TO ANY RECEIVING WATERS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE STOCKING FISH FOR RECREATIONAL SPORT FISHING AND STOCKING TO MAINTAIN HEALTHY AND SUSTAINABLE POPULATIONS OF FISH WITHIN BIOLOGICAL LIMITS, WHICH SUPPORTS THE MARYLAND DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES' MISSION. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PUBLIC WHO USE THESE RESOURCES. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO OPERATE AND MAINTAIN SIX HATCHERY FACILITIES TO PRODUCE TROUT AND SALMON TO MEET FISHERIES MANAGEMENT NEEDS IN NEW HAMPSHIRE, AND SUPPORT ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES STATEWIDE  NEARLY A MILLION TROUT AND SALMON ARE STOCKED ANNUALLY TO MEET MANAGEMENT GOALS FOR SPECIFIED WATERS IN NEW HAMPSHIRE  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE ACQUISITION, PROPAGATION, AND CULTURE OF THE APPROPRIATE SPECIES, SIZE, AND NUMBERS OF FISH SPECIFIED IN THE MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR CULTURED FISH  FISH HEALTH TESTING  STOCKING WATERBODIES ACCORDING TO PLAN  TRAINING OF HATCHERY STAFF  FACILITIES MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR  AND HATCHERY SYSTEM ADMINISTRATION  EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE IMPROVED ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES FOR RESIDENTS AND VISITORS TO THE STATE BY SUPPLEMENTING FRESHWATER SPORT FISH RESOURCES THAT ARE DEPENDENT ON A HATCHERY PRODUCT, IMPROVED COST EFFECTIVENESS OF OPERATING THE FACILITIES, AND THE ABILITY TO MEET FEDERAL AND STATE STANDARDS REGULATING FISH CULTURE FACILITIES  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE PUBLIC, WHICH WILL BENEFIT FROM APPROPRIATE MANAGEMENT OF STATE FISHERY RESOURCES, AND RECREATIONAL ANGLERS IN PARTICULAR WHO WILL BENEFIT FROM ENHANCED OPPORTUNITY FOR CATCHABLE SIZE TROUT AND SALMON  THERE ARE NO ANTICIPATED SUBRECIPIENTS PERFORMING WORK UNDER THIS AWARD

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO MONITOR AND ASSESS THE STATUS OF NEW HAMPSHIRE'S FRESHWATER AND ANADROMOUS FISHERIES RESOURCES THROUGH A PLANNED SCIENTIFIC APPROACH, AND TO DEVELOP, IMPLEMENT, AND EVALUATE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES THAT ARE CONSISTENT WITH RESOURCE CAPABILITIES. ACTIVITIES TO BE PREFORMED INCLUDE FISH HABITAT SURVEYS, FISH POPULATION ASSESSMENTS, ANADROMOUS FISH RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION, ANGLER SURVEYS AND HUMAN DIMENSIONS RESEARCH, OPERATIONAL PLANNING, PUBLIC OUTREACH, PROFESSIONAL TRAINING, AND PROJECT COORDINATION. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE IMPROVED MANAGEMENT OF NEW HAMPSHIRE'S INLAND FISHERIES RESOURCES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE PUBLIC WHICH WILL BENEFIT FROM MORE EFFECTIVE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AND RECREATIONAL ANGLERS WHO BENEFIT FROM IMPROVED FISHERIES.. THE FISHERY RESOURCES WILL ALSO ULTIMATELY BENEFIT. THERE ARE NO ANTICIPATED SUBRECIPIENTS PREFORMING WORK FOR THIS PROJECT.

THE GEORGIA MARINE RECREATIONAL FISHERIES AND SURVEYS PROGRAM IS TASKED TO COLLECT, ANALYZE AND REPORT BIOLOGICAL AND FISHERIES INFORMATION TO DESCRIBE THE CONDITIONS OR HEALTH OF RECREATIONALLY IMPORTANT FINFISH POPULATIONS AND DEVELOP MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS THAT WOULD MAINTAIN OR RESTORE THE STOCKS.

THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL SUPPORT FOR THE NCDMF BIOLOGICAL DATABASE (BDB) AND GEOSPATIAL DATABASE TO BENEFIT MANAGEMENT OF RECREATIONAL SPECIES AND THEIR CRITICAL HABITATS. THESE INITIATIVES ARE COORDINATED BY THE BIOLOGICAL USERS GROUP (BUG) AND MAPPING ADVISORY TEAM (MAT). THE BUG IS ALSO RESPONSIBLE, WITH THE INPUT OF FIMSS USERS, TO IDENTIFY ISSUES AND NEEDS, WHILE NORTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY (DEQ IT) ROLE IS TO ADDRESSES THOSE ISSUES AND DEVELOP SOLUTIONS. THIS GRANT SUPPORTS THOSE ACTIVITIES. NORTH CAROLINA IS A MAJOR HARVESTER OF MANY COASTAL STOCKS AND THE ESTUARINE WATERS OF THE STATE SERVE AS CRITICAL HABITAT FOR AT LEAST ONE LIFE STAGE FOR NUMEROUS RECREATIONAL SPECIES. MARINE RECREATIONAL FISHING IS AN EXTREMELY IMPORTANT ECONOMIC ACTIVITY IN COASTAL NORTH CAROLINA. MANY NORTH CAROLINA FISH STOCKS ARE IMPORTANT TO LOCAL RECREATIONAL ANGLERS AND INCLUDE SPECIES SUCH AS WEAKFISH, BLUEFISH, BLACK DRUM, RED DRUM, SPANISH MACKEREL, KING MACKEREL, SPOT, SPOTTED SEATROUT, AND ATLANTIC CROAKER. SOME ARE MANAGED BY FISHERY MANAGEMENT PLANS (FMPS) OF REGIONAL MANAGEMENT BODIES INCLUDING THE ATLANTIC STATES MARINE FISHERIES COMMISSION (ASMFC), MID-ATLANTIC FISHERY MANAGEMENT COUNCIL (MAFMC), AND THE SOUTH ATLANTIC FISHERY MANAGEMENT COUNCIL (SAFMC). IN ADDITION, THE NORTH CAROLINA DIVISION OF MARINE FISHERIES (NCDMF) IS DIRECTED BY THE NORTH CAROLINA FISHERIES REFORM ACT (NCFRA) TO DEVELOP STATE FMPS FOR EXPLOITED SPECIES. QUANTITATIVE STOCK ASSESSMENTS ARE IMPORTANT COMPONENTS OF FMP DEVELOPMENT AND REVIEW. THEY ARE USED TO DETERMINE THE STATUS OF STOCKS, AND IDENTIFY AND ANALYZE HARVEST CONTROL STRATEGIES. DATA NECESSARY TO PREPARE STOCK ASSESSMENTS INCLUDE AGE-LENGTH DATA, GROWTH INFORMATION, CATCH-AT-AGE MATRICES, AND INDICES OF ABUNDANCE (RICKER 1975). THE FISHERIES INFORMATION MANAGEMENT AND SUPPORT SYSTEM (FIMSS) DATABASE HOUSES THE DATA FOR THESE ASSESSMENTS AND FMPS ON SECURE PLATFORMS THAT PROVIDE READY ACCESS TO DIVISION ANALYTICAL STAFF.

CONNECTICUT IS FORTUNATE TO HAVE AN ABUNDANCE OF FISHERIES RESOURCES AND THEREFORE THERE IS A NEED FOR THE STATE TO PROVIDE QUALITY FISHING ACCESS FACILITIES. THESE FACILITIES WILL ENSURE THAT OPPORTUNITIES FOR SPORT FISHING ARE AVAILABLE TO PEOPLE OF ALL ECONOMIC CLASSES, RESIDENTS AND NON-RESIDENTS, AND THOSE WITH DISABILITIES. THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE CONSTRUCTION AND/OR RENOVATION OF NEW AND EXISTING FRESHWATER AND SALTWATER FISHING ACCESS AREAS STATEWIDE.
AQUATIC EDUCATION - FRESHWATER (F-68) FY23

MANY IMPORTANT NORTH CAROLINA FISH STOCKS ARE MANAGED THROUGH FMPS ADOPTED BY REGIONAL MANAGEMENT BODIES INCLUDING THE ATLANTIC STATES MARINE FISHERIES COMMISSION (ASMFC), MID-ATLANTIC FISHERY MANAGEMENT COUNCIL (MAFMC), AND THE SOUTH ATLANTIC FISHERY MANAGEMENT COUNCIL (SAFMC), AND BY NOAA FISHERIES, HIGHLY MIGRATORY SPECIES (HMS) DIVISION. IN ADDITION, THE NORTH CAROLINA DIVISION OF MARINE FISHERIES (NCDMF) IS DIRECTED BY THE NORTH CAROLINA FISHERIES REFORM ACT (NCFRA) TO DEVELOP STATE FMPS FOR EXPLOITED SPECIES. NORTH CAROLINA IS A MAJOR HARVESTER OF MANY COASTAL FISH STOCKS AND THE ESTUARINE WATERS OF THE STATE SERVE AS CRITICAL HABITAT FOR AT LEAST ONE LIFE STAGE OF NUMEROUS SPECIES. MARINE RECREATIONAL FISHING IS AN IMPORTANT ACTIVITY IN COASTAL NORTH CAROLINA AND MANY OF THE SAME SPECIES DESIRED BY RECREATIONAL ANGLERS ARE TARGETED BY COMMERCIAL FISHERS. AS FISHING PRESSURE AND HARVEST HAVE INCREASED, THE NEED FOR A LONG-TERM DATABASE OF ESSENTIAL POPULATION PARAMETERS, BIOLOGICAL HARVEST CHARACTERISTICS, AND RELATIVE ABUNDANCE DATA HAS INCREASED AS THESE DATA ARE A SIGNIFICANT PART OF STATE AND REGIONAL STOCK ASSESSMENTS. QUANTITATIVE STOCK ASSESSMENTS ARE IMPORTANT COMPONENTS OF FMP DEVELOPMENT AND REVIEW. THEY ARE USED TO DETERMINE THE STATUS OF STOCKS, AND TO IDENTIFY AND ANALYZE HARVEST CONTROL STRATEGIES. DATA NECESSARY TO PREPARE STOCK ASSESSMENTS INCLUDES FISHERY-INDEPENDENT INDICES AND BIOLOGICAL DATA FROM MAJOR HARVEST SOURCES. IN ADDITION TO DIRECTLY BENEFITING NORTH CAROLINA MANAGEMENT EFFORTS, OTHER MANAGEMENT AGENCIES WILL BENEFIT FROM THE ABUNDANCE INDICES, BIOLOGICAL, AND HABITAT DATA COLLECTED FROM THIS PROGRAM. MANY IMPORTANT COASTAL FISH STOCKS RANGE ACROSS STATE BOUNDARIES, AND THEREFORE REQUIRE COOPERATIVE MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT EFFORTS. INTERSTATE MANAGEMENT OF FISHERY RESOURCES IN STATE WATERS IS COORDINATED THROUGH THE ASMFC; ONE TASK IS TO IDENTIFY RESEARCH AND MONITORING NEEDS THAT TRANSCEND STATE BOUNDARIES. SEVERAL ASMFC TECHNICAL COMMITTEES HAVE LISTED THE COLLECTION OF LONG-TERM FISHERY-INDEPENDENT DATA FOR DEVELOPING SIZE, AGE AND SEX SPECIFIC RELATIVE ABUNDANCE INDICES AS A TOP PRIORITY RESEARCH NEED.

GRANT FUNDING WILL SUPPORT COLORADO PARKS AND WILDLIFE'S WATER SECTION WORK TO ACQUIRE NEW AND MANAGE EXISTING CPW WATER RIGHTS, CONSULT WITH OTHER LOCAL, STATE AND FEDERAL WATER AGENCIES ON WATER RIGHTS AND IN-STREAM FLOW ISSUES, AND PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO CPW HATCHERIES AND OTHER WATER USERS.

SPORT FISHING IN THE BAY DELTA REGION (BDR) OF CALIFORNIA PROVIDES A WIDE VARIETY OF OUTDOOR RECREATION ANDADVENTURE. THE ABILITY TO MONITOR, MANAGE AND ENHANCE SPORT FISH OPPORTUNITIES IS ESSENTIAL TO MAINTAIN ANGLEROPPORTUNITIES AND SATISFACTION. THE BAY DELTA REGION DISTRICT BIOLOGIST SPORT FISH ENHANCEMENT PROJECT IS PARTOF THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE'S (CDFW) BAY DELTA REGION'S (BDR) FISHERIES MANAGEMENT PROGRAMAND IS COMPRISED OF THREE ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTISTS THAT OVERSEE THREE DISTRICTS: NORTH BAY (MARIN, SONOMA, NAPA,AND SOLANO COUNTIES), INNER SOUTH BAY (CONTRA COSTA, ALAMEDA, AND SANTA CLARA COUNTIES), AND THE SOUTH COAST (SANFRANCISCO, SAN MATEO, AND SANTA CRUZ COUNTIES). THESE ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTISTS ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR THEMANAGEMENT, CONSERVATION, RESTORATION, AND MONITORING OF FISHERIES AND AQUATIC RESOURCES WITHIN THE LAKES ANDSTREAMS OF THEIR RESPECTIVE DISTRICTS WITH SPECIAL EMPHASIS ON NATIVE SALMONIDS AND FUNCTION AS DISTRICTFISHERIES BIOLOGISTS. THIS GRANT WILL PROVIDE THE FUNDING NECESSARY FOR THREE DISTRICT BIOLOGISTS TO ASSESS ANDMANAGE THE SPORT FISH RESOURCES IN THE TEN OF THE COUNTIES LOCATED WITHIN THE BAY DELTA REGION. THEY ACCOMPLISHTHIS THROUGH CLOSE COORDINATION AND COMMUNICATION WITH OTHER CDFW REGIONAL PROGRAMS AND VARIOUS FEDERAL, STATE,AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES AND INTERESTED STAKEHOLDERS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO INCREASE AQUATIC RESOURCES AWARENESS, ANGLING TECHNIQUES AND ANGLER PARTICIPATION STATEWIDE. TO FULFILL THIS PURPOSE, THE ARKANSAS GAME AND FISH COMMISSION WILL CONTINUE ITS AQUATIC RESOURCES EDUCATION (ARE) PROGRAM TO EQUIP ARKANSANS WITH THE KNOWLEDGE NEEDED TO BE SUCCESSFUL ANGLERS AND GOOD STEWARDS OF OUR AQUATIC RESOURCES. THIS PROGRAM HAS REACHED OVER 200,000 PEOPLE ANNUALLY FOR THE LAST 20 YEARS.

IN MARYLAND, THERE IS A NEED FOR OUR STUDENTS, TEACHERS, COMMUNITIES, AND LEADERS TO BE INFORMED AND EDUCATED ABOUT AQUATIC ISSUES AND HAVE ACCESS TO OUTDOOR EXPERIENCES INCLUDING THE TOOLS TO BECOME ENVIRONMENTALLY LITERATE. THESE TOOLS AND ACCESSIBILITY WILL LEAD TO MORE INFORMED STUDENTS AND ANGLERS AND HELP CREATE FUTURE STEWARDS OF OUR NATURAL RESOURCES. THIS GRANT WILL MEET THIS NEED BY CREATING TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES FOR TEACHERS, MENTORS, AND STUDENTS TO LEARN ABOUT FISHING AS WELL AS PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES AND TOOLS TO PROMOTE MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EXPERIENCES AND ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY IN MARYLAND. THE PROJECT WILL FUND EDUCATION STAFF TO PROVIDE TEACHER TRAINING, AND ANGLER EDUCATION CLINICS AS WELL PROVIDE LOANER TACKLE OPPORTUNITIES. THROUGH THIS PROJECT TEACHERS, STUDENTS AND MENTORS WILL HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO RAISE FISH IN THE CLASSROOM AND PARTICIPATE IN A MEMORABLE RELEASE FIELD TRIP, AND STAFF WILL WORK WITH PARTNERS ACROSS THE STATE TO DEVELOP STRATEGIES AND TOOLS TO PROMOTE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION AS WELL AS OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENTS TO TAKE ACTIONS IN THEIR OWN COMMUNITIES. THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT TEACHERS, SCHOOLS, STUDENTS AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC. NEW RESOURCES AND TRAINING WILL BE PROVIDED TO TEACHERS AND STUDENTS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC WILL HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO PARTICIPATE IN PUBLIC FISHING EDUCATION AND AQUATIC EDUCATION-RELATED ACTIVITIES.

SCDNR RECEIVES A SIGNIFICANT AMOUNT OF FUNDING FOR SPORTFISH MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES THROUGH THE SPORTFISH RESTORATION (SFR) GRANT PROGRAM. BECAUSE A PORTION OF THE MONIES THAT FUND SFR ARE DERIVED FROM EXCISE TAXES PAID BY MANUFACTURES, IT IS BENEFICIAL TO SCDNR FOR THEM TO UNDERSTAND AND APPRECIATE HOW THOSE FUNDS ARE BEING SPENT ON THE GROUND. SCDNR BELIEVES THAT SUCH UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION WILL FOSTER MORE SUPPORT FOR ONE ANOTHER IN TERMS OF FISHERIES MANAGEMENT FOR ANGLERS IN SOUTH CAROLINA. IN DISCUSSIONS WITH SOME MANUFACTURERS IN 2015, IT BECAME APPARENT THAT THEY WERE VERY SUPPORTIVE OF OUR AGENCY EVEN THOUGH THEY DID NOT KNOW WHAT IT WAS EXACTLY THAT WE DID WITH THE MONEY. SCDNR FEELS THAT IT IS IMPERATIVE THAT WE WORK ON DEVELOPING RELATIONSHIPS WITH OUR INDUSTRY PARTNERS AND SUPPORT ONE ANOTHER IN THE CONSERVATION OF THE FISHERIES RESOURCES THAT WE BOTH VALUE. THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW US TO FACILITATE CONVERSATIONS ABOUT AND DEMONSTRATIONS OF HOW SFR FUNDS ARE USED IN SOUTH CAROLINA.

IT IS HYPOTHESIZED THAT SPRING STOCKING LARGER FINGERLINGS WILL RESULT IN INCREASED SURVIVAL IN SMALL IMPOUNDMENTS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO FUND STATE AGENCY RESEARCH THAT IS DESIGNED TO PROVIDE FISHERIES MANAGERS WITH THE INFORMATION AND TECHNIQUES THEY NEED TO MANAGE IOWA FISHERIES TO THEIR GREATEST POTENTIAL AND TO ULTIMATELY IMPROVE FISHING EXPERIENCES FOR IOWA ANGLERS.
