THE NORTH CAROLINA WILDLIFE RESOURCES COMMISSION (NCWRC) MANAGES PUBLIC FISHING AREAS ON SEVERAL FRESHWATER BODIES WITHIN THE STATE.THE NCWRC MUST ROUTINELY MAINTAIN APPROXIMATELY 165 PUBLIC FISHING ACCESS AREAS YEAR-ROUND TO KEEP THE FACILITIES OPERATING IN A SAFE AND SERVICEABLE CONDITION FOR ANGLERS.

THIS GRANT SUPPORTS THE N.C. WILDLIFE RESOURCES COMMISSION'S (NCWRC) ACTIVITIES TO MANAGE AND MAINTAIN SPORT FISH POPULATIONS, THEIR HABITATS AND THEIR USERS IN NORTH CAROLINA'S INLAND WATERS FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE ANGLING PUBLIC. SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM GRANT FUNDS WILL SUPPORT COORDINATION AND ADMINISTRATION OF PROGRAMS AND PROJECTS; MANAGEMENT OF SPORT FISH POPULATIONS, MANAGEMENT OF INLAND AQUATIC HABITATS TO BENEFIT SPORT FISHES; COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS OF DATA ON FISH POPULATIONS; MONITORING AND MITIGATION OF FISH DISEASES; DEVELOPMENT OF MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR VARIOUS SPORT FISHES; PROVISION OF SAFE AND ACCESSIBLE FISHING ACCESS FOR ANGLERS; AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO PRIVATE CITIZENS, GOVERNMENTAL ENTITIES AND ORGANIZATIONS.

THE UTAH DIVISION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES WILL MAINTAIN ITS 13 HATCHERY FACILITIES IN A MANNER THAT WILL ALLOW THEM TO PRODUCE THE EGGS AND FISH NEEDED TO MEET STATE REGIONAL REQUEST. ALL QUOTAS ARE ESTABLISHED BASED ON CONSERVATION NEEDS OR SPORTFISH STOCKING TO MEET ANGLER DEMANDS. OUR MANTUA AND EGAN HATCHERIES PRODUCE VARIOUS SPECIES OF SALMONID EGGS FOR SPORTFISH NEED AND SHIPPED TO THE OTHER HATCHERIES TO RAISE. MAMMOTH CREEK HATCHERY HOLDS BROOD CUTTHROAT TROUT TO PRODUCE EGGS FOR CONSERVATION AND SPORTFISH NEEDS. LEE KAY HATCHERY HOLDS BROOD (MUSKELLUNGE AND NORTHERN PIKE) TO PRODUCE TIGER MUSKIE. THE REST OF THE HATCHERIES RECEIVE EGGS FROM ONE OF THESE HATCHERIES TO PRODUCE FISH FOR STOCKING. EIGHT WILD TRAPS ARE OPERATED BY HATCHERY STAFF TO COLLECT EGGS FOR CONSERVATION AND SPORTFISH NEEDS THEY ARE THEN RAISED AT PRODUCTION HATCHERIES AND STOCKED. THE STATE OF UTAH DOES NOT HAVE THE CAPABILITY TO RAISE ALL OF THE WARM/COOL WATER FISH TO MEET THE NEEDS OF ANGLERS IN THE STATE. WHICH REQUIRES THE STATE TO BUY THEM OR OBTAIN THEM FROM OTHER STATES AFTER WHICH HATCHERY PERSONNEL DELIVER AND DISTRIBUTE THEM TO VARIOUS WATERS IN THE STATE.

THE PAPIO-MISSOURI RIVER NATURAL RESOURCE DISTRICT (PMRNRD) IS GOING TO CONSTRUCT A NEW RESERVOIR (WP4) NEAR204TH & SCHRAM RD IN GRETNA, NEBRASKA. THE NEBRASKA GAME AND PARKS COMMISSION (NGPC) HAS BEEN INVITED TO PARTNERON THE PROJECT BY PROVIDING TECHNICAL AND FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE FOR THE PUBLIC ACCESS AMENITIES AND TO DEVELOP THERESERVOIR AS A FISHERY. PROVIDING PUBLIC ACCESS ON A NEW RESERVOIR LIKE WP4 IS IMPORTANT IN AN AREA LIKE GRETNAAS IT IS PART OF THE OMAHA/METRO, NEBRASKA'S LARGEST URBAN CENTER. PROVIDING ACCESS TO RESERVOIRS ACROSS THEOMAHA/METRO HAS BEEN SHOWN TO BE VITAL TO CONTINUING THE TRADITIONS OF FISHING, BOATING AND OTHER WATERRECREATION ACTIVITIES. SURVEYS OF PUBLIC WATERBODY USERS IN NEBRASKA HAVE SHOWN URBAN USERS TEND TO TRAVELSHORTER DISTANCES TO REACH A PUBLIC WATERBODY COMPARED TO THE RURAL USERS (MARTIN 2013). THEREFORE, DEVELOPINGPUBLIC ACCESS ON NEWLY CREATED WATERBODIES BECOMES OF THE UTMOST IMPORTANCE IN THE OMAHA/METRO AREA. THE PURPOSEOF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE PUBLIC BOATING AND FISHING ACCESS AT WP4, A RESERVOIR BEING CONSTRUCTED IN GRETNA,NEBRASKA.

NEW MEXICO HAS LIMITED WATERS AVAILABLE FOR RECREATIONAL BOATING. AN INCREASING POPULATION AND A GROWING DEMAND BY RECREATIONAL ANGLERS FOR BOATING OPPORTUNITIES WILL CONTINUE TO DIRECT THE NEW MEXICO DEPARTMENT OF GAME AND FISH TO UPGRADE AND MAINTAIN EXISTING FACILITIES AS DAMS ARE REQUIRED TO MEET STATE AND FEDERAL REGULATIONS RELATED TO WOODY VEGETATION REMOVAL, RODENT CONTROL, EROSION CONTROL AND SPECIFIC OPERATIONAL CONTROLS TO SAFEGUARD PUBLIC SAFETY. THESE FACILITIES WILL BE OPERATED OR MAINTAINED BY CONDUCTING THE FOLLOWING ROUTINE OR RE-OCCURRING ACTIVITIES: EXTERMINATE OR REMOVE BURROWING ANIMALS; REPAIR ANIMAL BURROWS; REMOVE WOOD VEGETATION ON THE CREST, UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM SLOPES, TOE AND ABUTMENT AREAS; REMOVE DEBRIS AND WOODY VEGETATION FROM OUTLET WORKS/SERVICE SPILLWAY AND EMERGENCY SPILLWAY DISCHARGE CHANNELS; REPAIR EROSION; REPAIR GABIONS AT COMBINED SERVICE SPILLWAY/OUTLET WORKS CONDUIT OUTLET; REPAIR CONCRETE; REPAIR MECHANICAL EQUIPMENT; CLEAN AND LUBRICATE SLIDE GATE OPERATOR AND STEM; CYCLE SLIDE GATE; MAINTAIN SERVICE SPILLWAY/OUTLET WORKS STRUCTURE PERTINENT FEATURES FREE OF STRUCTURAL CORROSION; RIPRAP MAINTENANCE; CLEAN AND MAINTAIN TOE DRAIN SYSTEM; AND REMOVE SEDIMENT FROM THE RESERVOIR AREA.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO OPERATE AND MAINTAIN PUBLIC LAKES AND ACCESS AREAS FOR USE BY ANGLERS AND BOATERS. THIS INCLUDES BOATING ACCESS SITES (BOAT RAMPS, PARKING AREAS, AND BOAT COURTESY DOCKS) AND BANK FISHING SITES (INCLUDING FISHING PIERS, BANK FISH SITES, AND BANK FISHING PARKING AREAS).

THE CURRENT BOATING LAUNCH FACILITY AT PHILLIPS CANYON LAKE IS INADEQUATE. THE BOAT LAUNCH FACILITY IS PRIMITIVE,OFFERING A DIRT RAMP AND DILAPIDATED FLOATING DOCK, AND DUE TO TOPOGRAPHY AND EROSION, THE PARKING IS LIMITED.BASED ON THE MINIMAL ACCESS AND SITE CONDITIONS WHICH LIMIT SITE IMPROVEMENT OPTIONS, IT WAS DETERMINED A NEWBOAT LAUNCH SITE WAS NEEDED ON PHILLIPS CANYON LAKE. PHILLIPS CANYON LAKE IS LOCATED SOUTH OF LEXINGTON, NEWITHIN A 5.1-MILE-LONG PORTION OF THE CENTRAL NEBRASKA PUBLIC POWER AND IRRIGATION DISTRICT'S (CENTRAL) TRI-COUNTY CANAL BETWEEN THE J1 AND J2 HYDROPOWER PLANTS. THERE IS APPROXIMATELY 300 SURFACE ACRES OF PUBLICLYACCESSIBLE WATER IN THIS STRETCH THAT INCLUDES BOTH CANAL AND RESERVOIR AREAS. THE PHILLIPS CANYON LAKE SYSTEM ISA POPULAR RECREATION AREA FOR BOATERS AND ANGLERS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A NEW BOAT LAUNCHFACILITY TO PROVIDE ACCESS TO AN UNDERUSED AND UNDEVELOPED BODY OF WATER TO SPORT FISHING, WATER-BASED HUNTING,AND RECREATIONAL BOATING.

THIS ANNUAL GRANT PROVIDES CRUCIAL FUNDING FOR THE MAINTENANCE OF BOATING RAMPS AND BANK FISHING SITES THROUGHOUT KENTUCKY. OVER 160 RAMPS ARE MAINTAINED THROUGHOUT THE STATE, AND OVER 30 FISHING ACCESS SITES ARE MAINTAINED, ALL BY OUR ENGINEERING DIVISION. ACTIVITIES RANGE FROM SIMPLE MOWING AND TRASH CLEANUP TO PAVING AND ADDING GRAVEL TO EXISTING RAMPS/FACILITIES. THIS FUNDING ENSURES CLEAN, QUALITY ACCESS FOR BOATERS AND FISHERMEN IN KENTUCKY.

SPORT FISHING IN THE INLAND PORTION OF THE NORTHERN REGION OF THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE(CDFW) PROVIDES A HIGH LEVEL OF OUTDOOR RECREATION AND ADVENTURE. THE ABILITY TO MONITOR, MANAGE, AND ENHANCESPORT FISH OPPORTUNITIES IS ESSENTIAL TO MAINTAIN A HIGH LEVEL OF ANGLER OPPORTUNITIES, SATISFACTION AND NATURALRESOURCE CONSERVATION AND PROTECTION. IN THE NORTHERN REGION THE ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTISTS SERVING AS THE DISTRICTBIOLOGIST, ASSISTED BY SCIENTIFIC AIDES (TEMPORARY HELP) PLAY A MAJOR ROLE IN DEVELOPMENT AND MANAGEMENT OF SPORTFISH OPPORTUNITIES. MAD RIVER HATCHERY, OPERATED BY CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW), BEGAN REARING STEELHEAD IN1971 TO PROVIDE A VIABLE FISHERY FOR THE MAD RIVER. MAD RIVER HATCHERY IS THE ONLY SALMON AND STEELHEAD HATCHERYCONSTRUCTED AND OPERATED BY CDFW EXCLUSIVELY FOR ENHANCEMENT PURPOSES. SINCE INITIAL OPERATIONS BEGAN, MAD RIVERHATCHERY HAS, AND CONTINUES, TO PLAY A KEY ROLE IN RESTORATION EFFORTS ALONG THE CENTRAL AND NORTH COAST. MADRIVER HATCHERY WILL TRAP AND SPAWN NATURAL ORIGIN (NOR) FISH FROM THE MAD RIVER, CROSSED WITH HATCHERY ORIGINFISH (HOR) IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE HATCHERY GENETICS AND MANAGEMENT PLAN (HGMP). MAD RIVER HATCHERY IS LOCATED12.2 RIVER MILES (20 KILOMETERS) UPSTREAM OF THE PACIFIC OCEAN AND 63.4 RIVER MILES (101 KILOMETERS) DOWNSTREAMOF THE ROBERT L. MATTHEWS DAM IN TRINITY COUNTY

THE PURPOSE OF THIS ANNUAL GRANT IS TO INTRODUCE KENTUCKY'S RESIDENTS TO SPORT FISHING AND THE TECHNICAL AND PHYSICAL SKILLS ASSOCIATED WITH IT. SEVERAL COMMUNITY-BASED EVENTS, AQUATIC EDUCATION BASED VIDEOS, AND A MENTOR KAYAK GIVEAWAY ARE JUST A FEW OF THE ACTIVITIES THIS GRANT SUPPORTS. CHILDREN AND ADULTS THROUGHOUT KENTUCKY HAVE BENEFITED FROM THE EDUCATION PROVIDED AT THE IN-PERSON EVENTS AS WELL AS THE VIDEOS GENERATED AND POSTED ONLINE.

TO INCREASE HARVEST OPPORTUNITY AND ALLEVIATE PRESSURE ON NATIVE FISH, HATCHERY-REARED CHINOOK AND COHO SALMON HAVE BEEN STOCKED IN NUMEROUS LOCATIONS IN SOUTHCENTRAL ALASKA. STOCKING SITES ARE SELECTED TO IMPROVE OR CREATE A SERIES OF TERMINAL SPORT FISHERIES. KEY COMPONENTS OF THE STOCKING PROGRAM INVOLVE: 1) ESTIMATION AND ASSESSMENT OF THE CONTRIBUTION OF STOCKED FISH TO THE TERMINAL FISHERY; 2) ESTIMATION OF STOCK-SPECIFIC HARVESTS IN BOTH COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL FISHERIES; 3) ESTIMATION OF SPAWNING ESCAPEMENT IN STOCKED STREAMS; 4) ESTIMATION OF STRAYING OF RETURNING STOCKED FISH; AND 5) ASSESSMENT OF SPORT FISH EFFORT AND HARVEST AT TERMINAL LOCATIONS. THESE COMPONENTS WILL REQUIRE THAT ALL FISH IN EACH RELEASE GROUP OF STOCKED FISH BE MARKED WITH A THERMAL MARK, AND THAT SOME RELEASE GROUPS CONTAIN FISH MARKED WITH AN ADIPOSE FIN CLIP.

SUPPLEMENT RAINBOW TROUT, ARCTIC CHAR, LAKE TROUT, AND SALMON PRODUCTION IN THE INTERIOR OF ALASKA. THE CONTINUED STOCKING OF HATCHERY PRODUCED FISH WILL CONTRIBUTE SIGNIFICANTLY TO A WID VARIETY OF RECREATIONAL FISHERIES, PROVIDE A BROAD DIVERSITY OF FISHING OPPORTUNITIES, ALL FOR CONTINUED AND IMPROVED PROTECTION OF NATURAL STOCKS, MAKE APPROPRIATE USE OF SITE POTENTIAL AND BENEFIT ANGLERS DURING ALL SEASONS OF THE YEAR.

THIS PROJECT WILL FUND THE BOATING OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE BUDGETS FOR EACH OF THE THREE REGIONS IN ALASKA. THEPRIMARY PURPOSE OF THE SE ACCESS MAINTENANCE PROJECT (BOATING) IS TO MAINTAIN EXISTING BOATING ACCESS FACILITIES,PROVIDE TEMPORARY FACILITIES AT ACCESS SITES (SUCH AS SANITATION FACILITIES), DEVELOP OR MAKE MINOR IMPROVEMENTSTO EXISTING BOATING ACCESS SITES, AND COORDINATE CONSTRUCTION AND RENOVATION OF CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT PROJECT (CIP)BOATING ACCESS FACILITIES. THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THE SOUTHCENTRAL ACCESS MAINTENANCE PROJECT (BOATING) IS TO MAINTAIN AND DEVELOP BOATINGACCESS SITES, PROVIDE LAND AND EASEMENT RESEARCH, AND ACQUIRE EASEMENTS IN ORDER TO ACCOMMODATE THE RECREATIONALBOATING AND SPORT ANGLING DEMAND IN SOUTHCENTRAL ALASKA. THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING FOR BOATING ACCESSIMPROVEMENTS AND MAINTENANCE ACTIVITIES THAT COLLECTIVELY PROVIDE SIGNIFICANT SPORT FISHING OPPORTUNITIES TOSOUTHCENTRAL ALASKA'S ANGLERS. THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THE REGION III ACCESS MAINTENANCE PROJECT (BOATING) IS TO MAINTAIN EXISTING BOATING ACCESSFACILITIES, PROVIDE SIGNAGE AND REPAIRS, AND MAKE MINOR IMPROVEMENTS TO EXISTING BOATING ACCESS SITES.

THERE IS A STRONG DEMAND FOR RECREATIONAL BOATING AND SPORT FISHING OPPORTUNITIES IN ALASKA. RECREATIONALBOATING AND SPORT FISHING REMAIN ONE OF THE MOST POPULAR OUTDOOR ACTIVITIES IN THE STATE WITH AN AVERAGE OF OVER 431,000 ANGLERS TAKING PART IN ALASKA'S RECREATIONAL FISHERY ANNUALLY. ACCESS LIMITATIONS HAMPER RECREATIONAL FISHING OPPORTUNITIES AND SPORT HARVEST IN MANY WATERS THROUGHOUT THESTATE. RELATIVELY UNDEVELOPED ROAD SYSTEMS COUPLED WITH A PREPONDERANCE OF PRIVATE LAND ADJACENT TO EXISTINGROADS COMPOUND ACCESS PROBLEMS. LIMITED ACCESS IN TURN FOSTERS ELEVATED HARVEST RATES AND CROWDED CONDITIONS INACCESSIBLE AREAS, WHILE OTHER LESS ACCESSIBLE AREAS WITH HARVESTABLE SURPLUSES OF FISH RECEIVE MODEST BOATING ANDFISHING PRESSURE. RECOGNITION OF CURRENT DEMANDS AND PROJECTED FUTURE GROWTH REQUIRES THAT THE STATE PROVIDEOPPORTUNITIES THAT DISPERSE BOATERS AND ANGLERS THROUGH ACCESS DEVELOPMENT AND IMPROVED BOAT LAUNCHINGFACILITIES. THIS PROJECT WILL FUND ADF&G HEADQUARTERS (HQ) ACCESS STAFF THAT WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR PROVIDING NECESSARYCOORDINATION OF POTENTIAL AND ON-GOING STATEWIDE RECREATIONAL BOATING ACCESS PROJECTS. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSOFUND REGION III ACCESS COORDINATION STAFF THAT WILL PROVIDE FOR TIMELY AND PROPER BOATING ACCESS PROJECTIMPLEMENTATION, MANAGEMENT, AND COMPLETION WITHIN REGION III.

THIS PROJECT WILL FUND THE NON-BOATING OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE BUDGETS FOR EACH OF THE THREE REGIONS IN ALASKA. THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THE SE ACCESS SITE MAINTENANCE PROJECT (NON-BOATING) IS TO MAINTAIN EXISTING NON-BOATINGAND SHORELINE ANGLER ACCESS FACILITIES, PROVIDE SEASONAL FACILITIES AT ACCESS SITES (SUCH AS PORTA-POTTIES), ANDDEVELOP OR MAKE MINOR IMPROVEMENTS TO EXISTING ACCESS SITES.THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THE SOUTHCENTRAL ACCESS MAINTENANCE PROJECT (NON-BOATING) IS TO MAINTAIN AND DEVELOPANGLER ACCESS SITES, PROVIDE LAND AND EASEMENT RESEARCH, AND ACQUIRE EASEMENTS IN ORDER TO ACCOMMODATE THERECREATIONAL SPORT ANGLING DEMAND IN SOUTHCENTRAL ALASKA. THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING FOR ANGLER ACCESSIMPROVEMENTS THAT COLLECTIVELY PROVIDE SIGNIFICANT SPORT FISHING OPPORTUNITIES TO SOUTHCENTRAL ALASKA'S ANGLERS. THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THE REGION III ACCESS MAINTENANCE PROJECT (NON-BOATING) IS TO MAINTAIN EXISTING ANGLERACCESS SITES, PROVIDE SIGNAGE AND REPAIRS, DIRECT THE SPORT ANGLING PUBLIC TO AVAILABLE OPPORTUNITIES, AND MAKEMINOR IMPROVEMENTS TO EXISTING ANGLER ACCESS SITES AND AMENITIES SUCH AS PARKING AREAS, SANITARY SERVICES, PUBLICUSE CABINS, ROADS, AND TRAILS.

FUNDING FROM THIS GRANT IS USED TO EDUCATE THE PUBLIC REGARDING AQUATIC RESOURCES, TEACH INDIVIDUALS HOW TO FISH, AND INFORM THE PUBLIC ABOUT THE SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM AND SPECIFIC PROJECTS THROUGHOUT LOUISIANA.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO INTRODUCE MISSISSIPPI'S YOUTH TO FISHING AND FISH BY:CONDUCTING YOUTH FISHING EVENTS, MAINTAINING AND OPERATING 14 PUBLIC NATIVE FISH AQUARIA AT THE MISSISSIPPI MUSEUM OF NATURAL SCIENCE (MMNS) AND ONE AT THE VISITOR EDUCATIONCENTER (VEC), LOCATED AT THE NORTH MISSISSIPPI FISH HATCHERY, AND DEVELOPING OUTREACH MATERIALS AND FISHING/AQUATIC EDUCATION PROGRAMS.

THE SPORT FISH RESTORATION STATEWIDE FISHERIES MANAGEMENT PROGRAM IS DESIGNED TO ENSURE ANGLERS IN ARKANSAS WILL HAVE CONTINUED ACCESS TO FISHING OPPORTUNITIES THROUGH ACTIVE MANAGEMENT OF SPORT FISH AND HABITAT. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO ENHANCE STATEWIDE FISHING OPPORTUNITIES FOR ARKANSAS ANGLERS.

THE COASTAL LOWCOUNTRY OF SOUTH CAROLINA HOSTS MORE SALT MARSH HABITAT THAN ANY OTHER ATLANTIC COAST STATE. THIS HABITAT IS DISSECTED BY EXTENSIVE TIDAL CREEK SYSTEMS THAT DRAIN SURROUNDING UPLAND AREAS AND PROVIDE NURSERY HABITAT TO MANY ECONOMICALLY IMPORTANT FISHERY SPECIES. INCREASING HUMAN POPULATION GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT OF OUR COASTLINE CAN PLACE STRESS ON FISHERY SPECIES AND ESTUARINE HABITATS THROUGH BOTH INCREASING FISHING PRESSURE AND HABITAT DEGRADATION.THE SOUTH CAROLINA ESTUARINE AND COASTAL ASSESSMENT PROGRAM WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1999 TO ASSESS THE OVERALL HEALTH OF THE STATE'S ESTUARINE HABITATS ON A PERIODIC BASIS. SCECAP PROVIDES THE MOST COMPREHENSIVE DATA ON HABITAT QUALITY AVAILABLE FOR SOUTH CAROLINA'S COASTAL AND ESTUARINE ENVIRONMENTS. SINCE ITS INCEPTION, SCECAP HAS PROVIDED A SOURCE OF FISHERIES-INDEPENDENT MONITORING FOR SEVERAL RECREATIONALLY IMPORTANT SPECIES FOR WHICH LITTLE OR NO OTHER SUCH MONITORING INFRASTRUCTURE EXISTS.THE PROJECT PROPOSED HERE WOULD CONTINUE SCECAP MONITORING EFFORTS, TARGETING RECREATIONALLY IMPORTANT FISHERY SPECIES UTILIZING ESTUARIES AS NURSERY HABITATS DURING THE SUMMER (PARTICULARLY SPOT, WEAKFISH, AND CROAKER).

THE SOUTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES HAS A LONG HISTORY OF STRIPED BASS MANAGEMENT THROUGHOUT THE STATE, WITH STOCK ENHANCEMENT REPRESENTING A MAJOR COMPONENT. THE USE OF GENETIC TOOLS ALLOWS THE SCDNR HATCHERY PROGRAM TO BETTER DETERMINE STOCKING STRATEGIES. THESE EFFORTS ALLOW BETTER ACCOUNTABILITY TO STAKEHOLDER GROUPS AND MORE EFFICIENT USE OF DNR HATCHERY RESOURCES. THEY ALSO ALLOW THE DNR TO RESPONSIBLY DETERMINE THE GENETIC STRUCTURE OF THE POPULATION IN DIFFERENT DRAINAGES PRIOR TO STOCKING TO KEEP FROM IMPACTING EXISTING POPULATIONS BY STOCKING FISH THAT ARE GENETICALLY DIFFERENT. THE FY23 STRIPED BASS GENETICS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE THE GENETIC MANAGEMENT FOR ALL STRIPED BASS PRODUCTION AND STOCKING IN SOUTH CAROLINA. AS NATURAL POPULATIONS OF STRIPED BASS CONTINUE TO DECLINE WITHIN THE SOUTHERN PORTION OF ITS NATIVE RANGE, STOCK ENHANCEMENT HAS BECOME A CRITICAL PART OF THE SPECIES' MANAGEMENT. IT IS IMPERATIVE THAT EFFICIENT AND EFFECTIVE STOCKING PROTOCOLS ARE INCORPORATED IN 'RESPONSIBLE APPROACH' MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS; THE INCORPORATION OF GENETIC TOOLS FOR IDENTIFICATION OF HATCHERY FISH ALLOWS FOR IMPROVED OPTIMIZATION OF THOSE PROTOCOLS.

FISH HATCHERIES PLAY AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN SOUTH CAROLINA'S FISHERIES MANAGEMENT PROGRAM. PROVIDING FOR THE CONTINUAL OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF FRESHWATER FISH HATCHERIES IS ESSENTIALTO PROVIDING MANY OF THE SPORT FISHING OPPORTUNITIES IN SOUTH CAROLINA FOR 537,136 FRESHWATER ANGLERS. THE FISH PRODUCED AT SOUTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES' (SCDNR) HATCHERIES SIGNIFICANTLY CONTRIBUTE TO THE SUPPORT OF FRESHWATER SPORT FISHERIES IN SOUTH CAROLINA WHICH HAS AN ECONOMIC IMPACT EXCEEDING $897 MILLION. COLDWATER AND WARMWATER FISH HATCHERIES PRODUCE AND STOCK JUVENILE FISH TO SUPPORT REESTABLISHMENT OF NATURALLY REPRODUCING STOCKS THAT, IN TURN, SUPPORT PUT, GROW, AND TAKE FISHERIES. PRODUCTION OF CATCHABLE AND FINGERLING TROUT, STRIPED BASS, HYBRID STRIPED BASS, LARGEMOUTH BASS, SMALLMOUTH BASS, WHITE BASS, SUNFISH, AMERICAN SHAD AND CHANNEL CATFISH SUPPORT POPULAR REGIONAL FISHERIES. WITH CONTINUED POPULATION GROWTH AND INCREASED DEVELOPMENT IN SOUTH CAROLINA, IT IS LIKELY THE DEMANDS PLACED ON FISH HATCHERIES WILL CONTINUE TO INCREASE. PROVIDING FUNDING FOR THE OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE NEEDS FOR THESE FACILITIES WILL ENSURE CONTINUED SPORTFISHING OPPORTUNITIES ACROSS SOUTH CAROLINA. SCDNR WILL MAINTAIN, OPERATE, AND PRODUCE FISH AT THREE (3) FRESHWATER HATCHERY PRODUCTION LOCATIONS AND ONE (1) ASSOCIATED SATELLITE HATCHERY IN ORDER TO PRODUCE AND STOCK FRESHWATER SPORTFISH IN THE PUBLIC WATERS OF THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA.

THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) MANAGEMENT DATA AND REPORTING NEEDS FORFOUR SPORT FISHERIES INCLUDING EEL RIVER CATCH AND RELEASE CHINOOK SALMON AND STEELHEAD TROUT FISHERIES,MENDOCINO COASTAL RIVERS CATCH AND RELEASE STEELHEAD TROUT FISHERY, AND CALIFORNIA'S OCEAN SALMON FISHERY.FISHERIES CONDUCTED IN THE EEL RIVER AND MENDOCINO COASTAL RIVERS FISHERY ATTRACT NUMEROUS ANGLERS AND SUPPORTVISITOR, TACKLE, AND GUIDE SERVICE INDUSTRIES. CALIFORNIA'S RECREATIONAL OCEAN SALMON FISHERY IS CONDUCTED FROMPORTS THROUGHOUT THE STATE AND SIGNIFICANTLY CONTRIBUTES TO VISITOR, TACKLE, BOATING, AND CHARTER SERVICEINDUSTRIES. THE INCREASED ANGLER OPPORTUNITY FOR EEL RIVER CHINOOK SALMON AND CALIFORNIA OCEAN SALMON IS DIRECTLYASSOCIATED WITH THE DATA AND REPORTING WORK OF THIS PROJECT, AND THE EEL RIVER OFFERS CALIFORNIA'S ONLY IN-RIVERCALIFORNIA COASTAL CHINOOK SALMON CATCH AND RELEASE FISHERY.THE WATERS OF SOUTHERN HUMBOLDT AND MENDOCINO COUNTY PROVIDE EXCELLENT SPORT FISHING OPPORTUNITIES FOR CHINOOKSALMON AND STEELHEAD TROUT. A CLEAR UNDERSTANDING OF SALMONID POPULATION AND HABITAT STATUS IS AN ESSENTIALCOMPONENT TO PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTING CHINOOK SALMON AND STEELHEAD TROUT HABITAT IMPROVEMENT FOR SUSTAINED INRIVER AND OCEAN RECREATIONAL FISHERIES. THE NORTHERN REGION FISHERIES ASSESSMENT PROJECT CONTRIBUTES TO QUALITYFISHING OPPORTUNITIES BY CONDUCTING AND COORDINATING THE FISHERIES SCIENCE NEEDED TO IMPROVE SALMONIDPOPULATIONS, AND SUCCESSFULLY MANAGE THAT FISHERY.

ANADROMOUS FISH IN CALIFORNIA SUPPORT A MULTIMILLION-DOLLAR SPORT AND COMMERCIAL FISHING INDUSTRY THOUGH SOMECENTRAL VALLEY (SACRAMENTO-SAN JOAQUIN DELTA AND ITS TRIBUTARIES) SALMON (ONCORHYNCHUS TSHAWYTSCHA), STEELHEAD(ONCORHYNCHUS MYKISS), AND STURGEON (ACIPENSER SPP.) POPULATIONS HAVE DECLINED TO PRECIPITOUSLY LOW LEVELS.POPULATION DECLINES HAVE BEEN LINKED TO VARIOUS FACTORS SUCH AS CONSTRUCTION OF DAMS, WATER DIVERSIONS, ANDHABITAT DEGRADATION. SIGNIFICANT ALTERATIONS TO STREAM CHANNELS BEGAN WITH THE CALIFORNIA GOLD RUSH STARTING IN1849. TODAY URBAN EXPANSION, AGRICULTURAL AND INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT, AND WATER OPERATIONS CONTINUE TO NEGATIVELYAFFECT THESE POPULATIONS.THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW), AS TRUSTEE AGENCY FOR THE STATE'S FISH AND WILDLIFERESOURCES, NOT ONLY MANAGES CATCHABLE STOCKS AND HARVEST OPPORTUNITY BUT ALSO HAS BEEN STEADILY WORKING TOREVERSE POPULATION DECLINES IN ANADROMOUS STOCKS. SINCE THE LATE 1980'S SEVERAL STATE AND FEDERAL LEGISLATIVEACTIONS RECOGNIZED THESE DECLINES AND WERE TARGETED AT REVERSING THEM. THESE INCLUDE THE STATE SALMON, STEELHEADTROUT, AND ANADROMOUS FISHERIES PROGRAM ACT OF 1988, FEDERAL CENTRAL VALLEY PROJECT IMPROVEMENT ACT OF 1991, ANDTHE WATER RESOURCES AND DELTA RESTORATION ACT OF 1996.PRIOR TO THE 1940'S, IT IS GENERALLY UNDERSTOOD THAT SPRING-RUN CHINOOK SALMON WERE THE DOMINANT SALMON RUN INTHE SAN JOAQUIN RIVER BASIN (SJRB). FROM THE 1940'S THRU THE 1980'S, MAJOR CHANGES IN WATER USE AND DELIVERYOCCURRED. THE CUMULATIVE RESULT OF THESE ACTIONS HAVE BEEN THE EXTIRPATION OF SELF-SUSTAINING STOCKS OF SPRINGRUNCHINOOK SALMON, THE NEAR EXTIRPATION OF STEELHEAD (A SPECIES LISTED AS THREATENED BY THE FEDERAL ENDANGEREDSPECIES ACT), AND THE SUBSTANTIAL CURTAILMENT OF FALL-RUN CHINOOK SALMON PRODUCTION SINCE 2000 (I.E., CURRENTLY ACANDIDATE SPECIES FOR LISTING REVIEW UNDER THE FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT).TODAY FALL-RUN CHINOOK SALMON ARE THE DOMINATE RUN OF ANADROMOUS SALMONIDS REMAINING IN THE SJRB, AND THAT RUN ISA SHADOW OF ITS FORMER SELF. CONCURRENT WITH RECENT DECLINES IN BOTH THE SALMON AND STEELHEAD RUNS HAS BEEN THEREDUCTION OF ANGLING OPPORTUNITY AND SUCCESS, AS RESOURCE MANAGERS HAVE HAD TO CURTAIL SEASONS, EVENTUALLYREDUCING BAG LIMITS TO ZERO IN ORDER TO PROTECT THE REMAINING SALMON AND STEELHEAD STOCKS STILL PRESENT IN SANJOAQUIN RIVER BASIN TRIBUTARIES (E.G., STANISLAUS, TUOLUMNE, AND MERCED RIVERS). IN RECENT TIMES, THE SACRAMENTOFALL-RUN HAS ALSO HAD SEVERE DECLINES AND OCEAN FISHING WAS CURTAILED ALMOST COMPLETELY.THE SJRB, IN RECENT HISTORY, IS CAPABLE OF PRODUCING TENS OF THOUSANDS OF ADULT SALMON. IT IS BELIEVED THATGREATER, AND MORE FREQUENT PRODUCTION OF LARGE NUMBERS OF ADULT SALMON AND STEELHEAD IS POSSIBLE (I.E.,PRODUCTION DEFINED AS ADULT SALMON AND STEELHEAD ESCAPING INTO THE TRIBUTARIES TO SPAWN). AS SALMON AND STEELHEADPRODUCTION INCREASES, ANGLING SEASONS COULD BE REINSTATED AND AT LEAST SOME FISH COULD BE LEGALLY HARVESTED FROMTHESE RIVERS.WATER STORAGE PROJECT CHANGES OCCURRING IN THE SAN JOAQUIN, STANISLAUS, TUOLUMNE, AND MERCED RIVERS SINCE THE1940'S HAVE SIGNIFICANTLY ALTERED HYDROLOGIC PATTERNS AND REDUCED THE AMPLITUDE OF SPRING SNOW-MELT AND CHANNELFORMING (MAINTENANCE) STREAM FLOWS. THE CUMULATIVE EFFECT OF THESE STORAGE PROJECTS, IN COMBINATION WITH OTHERPRIVATE, STATE, AND FEDERAL WATER DIVERSIONS ALONG THE RIVERS AND IN THE SACRAMENTO-SAN JOAQUIN ESTUARY, IS ANINCREASE IN MORTALITY RATES FOR VARIOUS SALMONID LIFE STAGES, RESULTING IN LOWERED ADULT SALMON AND STEELHEADPRODUCTION.THESE DOCUMENTS PROVIDE BROAD GUIDELINES FOR RESTORATION AND RECOVERY ACTIONS AND ARE CRUCIAL DRIVERS IN CENTRALVALLEY ANADROMOUS FISHERIES MANAGEMENT IN AN ENVIRONMENT WHERE BOTH LISTED AND CATCHABLE STOCKS CO-OCCUR.

THE NORTH CENTRAL REGION (NCR) OF THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) PROPOSES TO CONDUCTSTUDIES OF FISH POPULATION STRUCTURE, POPULATION DYNAMICS, FISH SPECIES COMPOSITION, AND ANGLER UTILIZATION ANDPREFERENCE IN ORDER TO ASSESS RECREATIONAL FISHERIES ACROSS THE REGION. THIS INFORMATION WILL BE UTILIZED TOMANAGE SPORT FISHERIES INCLUDING WILD AND SELF-SUSTAINING FISHERIES AND HATCHERY-BASED SPORT FISHERIES. STUDIESWILL BE CONDUCTED ON COLD WATER (SALMONID SPECIES) AND WARM WATER (CENTRARCHID AND ICTALURID SPECIES) SPORT FISHTHAT OCCUR IN LAKES, RESERVOIRS, STREAMS, AND RIVERS THROUGHOUT THE REGION. DATA WILL BE COLLECTED USINGELECTROFISHING, SEINING, SNORKEL, MARK/RECAPTURE, GILL NET, CREEL SURVEY TECHNIQUES, AND ANGLER SURVEY BOXES(ASB). THESE METHODS ARE APPLICABLE TO COMPLETING GENERAL FISH SURVEYS (GFS) AND FISHERY ASSESSMENTS.

IN SOUTH CAROLINA'S ESTUARINE AND OFFSHORE WATERS, PRIMARY FISH HABITAT IS USUALLY FOUND IN AREAS WHERE THE OCEAN BOTTOM CONSISTS OF HARD SUBSTRATE SUCH AS ROCK OR SHELL WHICH BECOMES ENCRUSTED WITH MARINE ORGANISMS TO FORM A 'LIVE BOTTOM' REEF COMMUNITY. NATURALLY OCCURRING REEF AREAS ARE LIMITED OFF THE SOUTHEAST COASTAL AND BECAUSE OF THIS LIMITED AVAILABILITY, OFTEN OVERFISHED. IN AREAS WHERE HARD SUBSTRATE IS LACKING, MANMADE OR ARTIFICIAL REEFS CAN BE CREATED BY PROVIDING THIS HARD SUBSTRATE AND ALLOWING NATURAL COLONIZATION TO OCCUR. OYSTER REEFS ARE WELL DOCUMENTED PRIMARY FISH HABITAT WITHIN ESTUARINE ENVIRONMENTS FOR INSHORE SPECIES AND JUVENILE OFFSHORE SPECIES. FISHERIES RESOURCES ARE THEREBY ENHANCED BY INCREASING THE AMOUNT AND AVAILABILITY OF OFFSHORE HARD BOTTOMS AND ESTUARINE OYSTER REEFS.THE PRIMARY PROJECT GOAL IS THE CONTINUED DEVELOPMENT OF MARINE FINFISH HABITAT THROUGH THE CREATION AND ENHANCEMENT OF ARTIFICIAL REEFS IN SOUTH CAROLINA'S COASTAL AND OFFSHORE WATERS AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF OYSTER REEFS IN ESTUARINE WATERS.
FUNDING PROVIDED THROUGH THIS GRANT SUPPORTS THE ENHANCEMENT OF RECREATIONAL SPORT FISH POPULATIONS AND INCREASING RECREATIONAL FISHING OPPORTUNITIES THROUGH STOCKING EFFORTS THROUGHOUT LOUISIANA.

LOOKING TO PROVIDE A UNIQUE FISHING EXPERIENCE DURING THE WINTER MONTHS KDWP STARTED ITS TROUT PROGRAM IN 1995. THROUGH THE COMMERCIAL PURCHASE OF HARVESTABLE-SIZED RAINBOW TROUT KDWP CAN PROVIDE A UNIQUE FISHING EXPERIENCE THAT WOULD NOT BE POSSIBLE WITH THESE EFFORTS. KDWP SUPPLIES TROUT TO 16 LOCATIONS LOCATED THROUGHOUT THE STATE SO THAT KANSAN CAN ENJOY A DIFFERENT FISHING EXPERIENCE DURING THE WINTER MONTHS. A $14.50 ANNUAL PERMIT FEE IS REQUIRED TO FOR ADULTS AND A $7.50 FOR YOUTH 16 AND UNDER ARE USED TO OFFSET THE COST OF PURCHASING TROUT. WITH THE SUMMER WATER TEMPERATURE BEING LETHAL TO TROUT, THE SEASON RUNS FOR NOVEMBER 1 TO APRIL 15 WHEN WATER TEMPERATURES ARE BELOW LETHAL RANGE FOR TROUT. THE GOAL OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO PROVIDE A DIFFERENT OPPORTUNITY FOR ANGLERS.

COBIA (RACHYCENTRON CANADUM) IS A HIGHLY MIGRATORY AND EXTREMELY POPULAR SPORTFISH IN SOUTH CAROLINA. UNTIL RECENTLY, FISHING ACTIVITY SOARED FOR THIS SPECIES FROM LATE APRIL THROUGH EARLY JUNE IN THE SOUTHERN ESTUARIES OF SOUTH CAROLINA WHERE A GENETICALLY DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENT AGGREGATES FOR SPAWNING. DUE TO THE POPULARITY OF CATCHING LARGE FISH, WHICH ARE TYPICALLY FEMALES, THIS INSHORE MIGRATION EXPOSES THIS DPS TO HIGH FISHING MORTALITY DUE TO THEIR RELATIVE EASE OF ACCESS.THE MOST RECENT ASSESSMENT OF THE ENTIRE SOUTH ATLANTIC COBIA POPULATION INDICATED THE STOCK WAS NOT OVERFISHED AND OVERFISHING WAS NOT OCCURRING, BUT DID NOTE EVIDENCE OF DECLINING TOTAL BIOMASS, DECLINING SPAWNING STOCK BIOMASS, INCREASING FISHING MORTALITY RATES, AND INCREASING LANDINGS. SCDNR INITIATED A RESEARCH-SCALE COBIA STOCK ENHANCEMENT PROGRAM IN 2001. WHILE CURRENT REGULATORY AND STOCKING EFFORTS HAVE BEGUN, WE ARE STRUGGLING WITH A NEW CHALLENGE OF HOW TO MONITOR THE INSHORE DPS UNDER SEASONAL HARVEST LIMITATIONS. AS COBIA ARE NOT SUSCEPTIBLE TO FISHERY-INDEPENDENT SAMPLING GEAR, SCDNR HAS LONG STANDING PARTNERSHIPS WITH RECREATIONAL AND CHARTER FISHERMEN IN THE PORT ROYAL SOUND AREA THAT PROVIDE CATCH DATA AND GENETIC FIN CLIPS FOR OUR ROUTINE ASSESSMENT OF THE INSHORE PORT ROYAL SOUND COBIA. IN RESPONSE TO A TREND OF RECREATIONAL COBIA FISHING ACTIVITIES SHIFTING OFFSHORE WE ARE EXPLORING ALTERNATIVE OPTIONS TO INDIRECTLY MONITOR THE INSHORE COBIA DPS DURING THEIR RECOVERY. SPECIFICALLY, WE ARE TARGETING ENVIRONMENTAL DNA (EDNA) TECHNOLOGIES AND ACOUSTIC TELEMETRY AS POTENTIALS TO INCREASE OUR MONITORING CAPABILITIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT MARINE RECREATIONAL FISHERIES OUTREACH AND EDUCATION STRATEGIES TO HELP MAINTAIN OR ENHANCE THE QUALITY OF MARINE FISHERIES RESOURCES. ACTIVITIES UNDER THIS GRANT WILL CONSIST OF CREATING AND IMPLEMENTING COMMUNICATIONS, PARTICIPATING IN OR SUPPORTING EVENTS, AND DEVELOPING AND CONDUCTING AQUATIC EDUCATION ACTIVITIES. THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF THESE ACTIVITIES IS TO ENGAGE CURRENT AND FUTURE ANGLERS IN MARINE FISHERIES RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP. WITHOUT THESE EFFORTS, THE QUALITY OF MARINE RECREATIONAL FISHERIES AND THE HABITATS THAT SUPPORT THEM COULD BE SIGNIFICANTLY COMPROMISED.

THE SOUTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES HAS A LONG HISTORY OF BLACK BASSMANAGEMENT THROUGHOUT THE STATE, WITH STOCK ENHANCEMENT REPRESENTING A MAJORCOMPONENT. OVER THE YEARS, BLACK BASS SPECIES HAVE BEEN MOVED AROUND BY ANGLERS ANDSPOTTED/ALABAMA BASS HAVE BEEN INTRODUCED BY WELL-MEANING FISHERMEN. THE USE OF GENETIC TOOLSALLOWS THE SCDNR TO BETTER DETERMINE DEGREES OF HYBRIDIZATION WITHIN THE BLACK BASS COMPLEXAND DISTRIBUTION OF ALL THE BLACK BASS SPECIES IN THE STATE. THESE EFFORTS ALLOW BETTERACCOUNTABILITY TO STAKEHOLDER GROUPS AND A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF BLACK BASS DISTRIBUTION FORREGIONAL MANAGEMENT. THEY ALSO ALLOW THE DNR TO RESPONSIBLY DETERMINE THE GENETIC STRUCTURE OFTHE POPULATION IN DIFFERENT DRAINAGES SO THAT SCDNR CAN REDUCE ANY IMPACTS TO EXISTINGPOPULATIONS BY STOCKING FISH THAT ARE GENETICALLY DIFFERENT.

MAINTAIN 18 STATE-MANAGED LAKES (APPROXIMATELY L,415 ACRES) IN A MANNER THAT PROVIDES SATISFACTORY RECREATIONAL FISHING AND BOATING OPPORTUNITIES TO THE PUBLIC.PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR PUBLIC FISHING AND BOATING ON SCDNR OWNED AND LEASED LAKES THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA. THESE LAKES ALLOW FOR ANGLERS AND BOATERS TO FISH MORE LOCALLY TO THEIR HOMES AND TEND TO BE MORE AVAILABLE TO THOSE ANGLERS WITHOUT ACCESS TO BOATS AND/OR THOSE THAT ARE UNABLE TO TRAVEL TOO FAR FROM HOME.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE'S (CDFW) SOUTH COAST REGION (SCR) IS RESPONSIBLE FOR MONITORINGAND MANAGING MANY POPULATIONS OF WILD TROUT LOCATED THROUGHOUT THE SCR. THIS GRANT WILL FUND THE MONITORING,ASSESSMENT, AND MANAGEMENT OF THESE HERITAGE AND WILD TROUT POPULATIONS.

CALIFORNIA HAS A LONG HISTORY OF STOCKING FISH SPECIES IN LAKES AND RESERVOIRS TO IMPROVE RECREATIONAL ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES (DILL AND CORDONE 1997). BY THE LATE 1800S, MULTIPLE SPECIES OF TROUT AND BLACK BASS (LARGEMOUTH, SMALLMOUTH, ALABAMA/SPOTTED) WERE INTRODUCED. TODAY, THE CALIFORNIA BLACK BASS FISHERY PRODUCES TROPHY-SIZE, STATE RECORD, AND WORLD RECORD LANDINGS; OF THE LARGEST 25 LARGEMOUTH BASS CAUGHT IN THE UNITED STATES, 21 WERE LANDED IN CALIFORNIA. THIS QUINTESSENTIAL SPORTFISH AND KEYSTONE PREDATOR CONTRIBUTE TO MANY IMPORTANT FISHERIES ACROSS CALIFORNIA. WHILE BLACK BASS POPULATIONS ARE NOW SELF-SUSTAINING, TROUT REQUIRE ONGOING STOCKING EFFORTS TO REPLENISH POPULATIONS IN MANY PARTS OF THE STATE.SINCE 2014, 520 DIFFERENT WATERS THROUGHOUT CALIFORNIA WERE STOCKED WITH CATCHABLE-SIZE TROUT, AVERAGING 419 WATERS PER YEAR. MANY OF THESE WATERS ALSO HAVE HEALTHY, SELF-SUSTAINING POPULATIONS OF BLACK BASS, PARTICULARLY LARGEMOUTH BASS (MICROPTERUS SALMOIDES). IT IS UNCLEAR WHAT EFFECT, IF ANY, THESE TROUT STOCKING EVENTS HAVE ON THE EXISTING BLACK BASS POPULATIONS OR VICE VERSA.THIS STUDY AIMS TO EXAMINE THE EFFECTS OF STOCKED TROUT ON THE ABUNDANCE AND SIZE STRUCTURE OF LARGEMOUTH BASS FISHERIES IN CALIFORNIA. RESULTS FROM THIS RESEARCH WILL INFORM FISHERIES MANAGERS OF THE INFLUENCE THAT TROUT STOCKING HAS ON THE LARGEMOUTH BASS FISHERY IN MIXED-STOCK LAKES AND RESERVOIRS.AS EARTH'S CLIMATE CONTINUES TO CHANGE (IPCC 2018) AND CALIFORNIA EXPERIENCES RISING TEMPERATURES WITH EXTREME DROUGHTS (SAFEGUARDING CALIFORNIA PLAN 2018), MAINTENANCE OF OUR NATURAL ECOSYSTEMS IS SUBJECT TO INCREASING MANAGEMENT CHALLENGES. FOR CALIFORNIA'S LAKES AND RESERVOIRS, EXTENDED SUMMERS AND INCREASED TEMPERATURES ARE ALREADY CAUSING ECOLOGICAL ISSUES; FOR EXAMPLE, IN 'TWO-STORY' WATERS, THE UPPER STORY IS SUSTAINING WARMER WATER FOR LONGER PERIODS, CAUSING THE COOLER WATERS IN THE LOWER STORY TO SUFFER GREATER OXYGEN DEPLETION AND CREATE DETRIMENTAL CONDITIONS FOR THE COLD WATER FISHERIES. UNDERSTANDING THESE FISHERY DYNAMICS, ESPECIALLY FOR BIOLOGICALLY AND ECONOMICALLY VALUABLE SPECIES, IS IMPORTANT FOR THE ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT OF OUR RESOURCES IN THE FACE OF A CHANGING CLIMATE.CALIFORNIA'S HISTORY OF STOCKING FISH SPECIES IN LAKES AND RESERVOIRS TAKES ADVANTAGE OF AVAILABLE TWO-STORY WATERS TO INCREASE RECREATIONAL ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES. FINDING BOTH COLD AND WARM WATER FISHES IN THE SAME WATER, SUCH AS LARGEMOUTH BASS AND RAINBOW TROUT, IS A COMMON OCCURRENCE BUT WOULD NOT HAPPEN NATURALLY WITHOUT A ROBUST STOCKING PROGRAM. ALTHOUGH TROUT STOCKING EFFORTS MAY PROVIDE EXCEPTIONAL ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES IN VARIOUS LOCATIONS AND SEASONS IN CALIFORNIA, IT IS UNKNOWN IF THE INTRODUCTION AND CONTINUED PRESENCE OF STOCKED TROUT INFLUENCE THE ABUNDANCE AND SIZE STRUCTURE OF THE LARGEMOUTH BASS FISHERY.TO OUR KNOWLEDGE, NO ONE HAS QUANTIFIED THE EFFECTS OF STOCKED TROUT ON LARGEMOUTH BASS ABUNDANCE AND SIZE STRUCTURE IN CALIFORNIA, OR IF THERE ARE TEMPORAL RESTRAINTS TO THEIR CONSUMPTION. THIS STUDY IS IMPORTANT BOTH BIOLOGICALLY AND ECONOMICALLY TO INFORM MANAGEMENT OF THE INFLUENCE THAT TROUT STOCKING HAS ON LARGEMOUTH BASS FISHERIES AND VICE VERSA.ULTIMATELY, THIS INFORMATION WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE LARGER GOAL OF UNDERSTANDING HEALTH AND SIZE OF NATURALLY REPRODUCING LARGEMOUTH BASS POPULATIONS TO EFFECTIVELY MANAGE AND IMPROVE ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES. RESULTS FROM THIS RESEARCH MAY BE USED BY REGIONAL FISHERY MANAGERS TO MAKE SCIENCE-BASED DECISIONS FOR MAINTAINING AND IMPROVING SELF-SUSTAINING FISHERIES AND REFINING STOCKING ALLOTMENTS IN HATCHERY-BASED SPORT FISHERIES.

THE PROJECT CONDUCTS MONITORING AND INVESTIGATIONS OF WARMWATER AND HATCHERY TROUT FISHERIES THROUGHOUT OREGON TODETERMINE THEIR STATUS AND ANY FACTORS THAT MAY BE LIMITING THE FISH POPULATIONS AND THE ANGLING OPPORTUNITY THEYPROVIDE. WHERE FAVORABLE BIOLOGICAL AND HABITAT CONDITIONS EXIST, THE PROJECT WORKS WITH AREA BIOLOGISTS, OTHERAGENCIES, AND THE PUBLIC TO ENHANCE THESE FISHERIES AND THEIR RECREATIONAL USE THROUGH HABITAT AND ACCESSIMPROVEMENT, FISH STOCKING, AND BY PROMOTING AND PROVIDING INFORMATION ABOUT THE ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES AVAILABLE.

MANAGEMENT DECISIONS RELY ON EVALUATING FISH POPULATIONS, ESTIMATING FISH POPULATION SIZES, SURVEYING FISH ANDWILDLIFE USERS, AND EVALUATING HATCHERY RELEASES TO UNDERSTAND THE CONTRIBUTION OF THESE FISH TO ENHANCE FISHINGOPPORTUNITY AND ACCESS. INFORMATION REGARDING EACH OF THESE ACTIVITIES RELIES ON DATA COLLECTED IN ASTATISTICALLY MEANINGFUL WAY TO PRODUCE SCIENTIFICALLY CREDIBLE INFORMATION. IN ORDER TO ENSURE THAT APPROPRIATESTATISTICAL DESIGNS AND ANALYSES ARE CONSISTENTLY USED IN ALL FISH DISTRICTS, CONSULTATION WITH A QUANTITATIVEFISHERIES SCIENTIST IS NECESSARY. A TRAINED QUANTITATIVE FISHERIES SCIENTIST CAN ALSO ENSURE THAT DATA COLLECTEDIS COMPATIBLE WITH OTHER PROJECTS OCCURRING ACROSS REGIONAL AND DISTRICT BOUNDARIES, SO THAT IT IS COMPARABLE ANDCAN HELP TO FORMULATE A STATEWIDE PERSPECTIVE ON CERTAIN FISHERIES. THIS PROJECT PROVIDES A QUANTITATIVEFISHERIES SCIENTIST THAT CAN BE ACCESSED BY ALL FIELD AND STAFF BIOLOGISTS FOR CONSULTATION TO REVIEW AND ENSUREDATA IS COLLECTED CORRECTLY, AND CAN BE USED IN SOPHISTICATED ANALYSES THAT WOULDN'T OTHERWISE BE POSSIBLE. BYPRODUCING SCIENTIFICALLY CREDIBLE INFORMATION, THE QUANTITATIVE FISHERIES SCIENTIST CAN RELIABLE PROVIDEINFORMATION TO MANAGERS THAT ACCURATELY REFLECTS THE CURRENT STATUS OF OREGON'S SPORT FISH RESOURCES. THIS HELPSTO INFORM DECISIONS TO MANAGE AND ENHANCE OREGON'S ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES. RESEARCH CONDUCTED BY THE PROGRAM MAYALSO GUIDE MANAGERS WHILE CREATING NEW FISHING OPPORTUNITIES, CONTRIBUTING TO ONGOING R3 EFFORTS.

THE DESCHUTES RIVER IS RECOGNIZED FOR ITS WORLD CLASS SPORT FISHERIES, IMPORTANT TRIBAL CEREMONIAL ANDSUBSISTENCE FISHERIES, AND ITS CONTRIBUTION TO COMMERCIAL FISHERIES. THE LOWER DESCHUTES FISH POPULATION STUDYPROVIDES INFORMATION NECESSARY TO INFORM, MONITOR, AND GUIDE FISHERIES MANAGEMENT ON THE LOWER DESCHUTES RIVER.PRIMARY OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE TO PROVIDE ESTIMATES OF IN-BASIN HARVEST, ESTIMATE RUN-YEAR SPECIFICESCAPEMENT, AND PROVIDE RELATIVE STATUS INFORMATION ON RESIDENT FISH. INFORMATION COLLECTED FROM THIS PROJECTPROVIDE NEEDED INFORMATION GOVERNING INTERNATIONAL, COMMERCIAL, SPORT AND TRIBAL FISHERIES, ALONG WITHINFORMATION NECESSARY TO MONITOR THE RECOVERY OF ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT PROTECTED STEELHEAD.
SPORT FISHING SURVEYS AND FISH COMMUNITY INVESTIGATIONS IN THE ILLINOIS WATERS OF LAKE MICHIGAN, F-196-R-6

ONCE VALUED PRIMARILY AS A FISHERIES RESOURCE, OYSTERS ARE NOW BROADLY RECOGNIZED AS ECOSYSTEM ENGINEERS, AND CONSIDERED ESSENTIAL FISH HABITAT IN THE SOUTHEAST REGION BY THE SOUTH ATLANTIC FISHERY MANAGEMENT COUNCIL. OYSTER REEFS PROVIDE ESSENTIAL HABITAT FOR RED DRUM AND PENAEID SHRIMP, AND OTHER SPECIES SUCH AS CROAKER, SPOT, BLUE CRAB, AND SEA TROUT.THIS FUNDING WILL PROVIDE FOR SAMPLING 34 LOCATIONS IN SOUTH CAROLINA TO BE PROCESSED BY THE MRRI SHELLFISH LABORATORY TO ESTIMATE REGIONALLY EXPLICIT RATES OF NATURAL OYSTER MORTALITY AND OTHER POPULATION DEMOGRAPHIC PARAMETERS.A CRAB TRAP-BASED OYSTER REEF RESTORATION PROJECT WILL BE COMPLETED IN THE INTERTIDAL ZONE HABITAT TO CREATE ESSENTIAL FISH HABITAT, AND EXISTING CRAB TRAP-BASED REEFS WILL BE MONITORED AND MAINTAINED THROUGH THIS FUNDING.

THIS GRANT IS INTENDED TO PROVIDE ADMINISTRATIVE OVERSIGHT, ENVIRONMENTAL COMPLIANCE, AND GRANT COORDINATION TO THE SC MARINE SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM AND EDUCATE THE ADMINISTRATIVE STAFF AND PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS ON THE ADMINISTRATIVE REQUIREMENTS OF THE FEDERAL GRANT PROGRAM.

SCDNR HAS SEVERAL OCCURRENCES OF DISEASE, PARASITE INFESTATION, AND UNKNOWN MORTALITIES WITHIN OUR FRESHWATER FISH POPULATIONS. IT IS IMPERATIVE THAT WE HAVE A WAY TO DETERMINE BOTH THE CAUSES OF MORTALITIES/INFECTION AND A PRESCRIPTIVE METHOD FOR ADDRESSING THESE ISSUES WHEN ONE EXISTS.THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW SCDNR TO HAVE ACCESS TO A PROFESSIONAL AND REPUTABLE LABORATORY WHERE FISH SAMPLES CAN BE SENT IMMEDIATELY FOR DISEASE AND PARASITE DIAGNOSIS AND TO CONTRIBUTE TO AN UNDERSTANDING OF FISH DISEASES AND PARASITES IN THE SOUTHEAST. FURTHER, WE WILL HAVE THE ABILITY TO PROVIDE FISH DISEASE TRAINING TO STAFF BY QUALIFIED INSTRUCTORS.
FISH PRODUCTION AND STOCKING, F-121-D-32

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) FISH HEALTH LABORATORY (FHL) PERFORMS DISEASE DIAGNOSIS AND TREATMENT OF HATCHERY FISH AND SCREENING OF WILD BROODSTOCKS. THE CDFW FHL ALSO ENGAGES IN RESEARCH OF FISH PATHOGENS AND RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT OF DIAGNOSTIC TESTS AND TREATMENTS FOR THOSE PATHOGENS.EARLY AND ONGOING DISEASE DETECTION ENSURES OPTIMAL PERFORMANCE AND SURVIVAL OF FISH PRODUCED BY HATCHERIES AND HELPS MINIMIZE THE RISK TO WILD FISHES. FISH DISEASES THAT OCCUR AT HATCHERIES ARE DETRIMENTAL TO HATCHERY PRODUCED FISH, CAUSING DECREASED GROWTH RATES, DISFIGUREMENT, AND MORTALITY. IN ADDITION TO SALMONID FISHES, THE DEPARTMENT'S FISH PATHOLOGIST/RESEARCH SCIENTISTS ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR HEALTH MONITORING FOR ALL SPORT FISH, DOMESTIC OR WILD, WHICH MAY ADVERSELY IMPACT THE FISHERY RESOURCES OF THE STATE DUE TO DISEASE. THESE SPECIES INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO, STRIPED BASS, BLACK BASS, CATFISH, SUNFISHES, ETC. TO HELP MINIMIZE STATEWIDE FISH HEALTH ISSUES, FISH PATHOLOGIST/RESEARCH SCIENTISTS ARE NEEDED TO STAFF AND OPERATE THE DEPARTMENT'S FISH HEALTH LABORATORY.THE FISH HEALTH LABORATORY EXISTS TO MINIMIZE FISH MORTALITIES DURING FISH PRODUCTION AT HATCHERIES AND TO INVESTIGATE HEALTH CONCERNS OF WILD FISH POPULATIONS. THIS IS DONE THROUGH DIAGNOSTIC VISITS WHEN HATCHERIES ARE EXPERIENCING INCREASED LOSSES, THOUGH FISH HEALTH INSPECTIONS AND CERTIFICATIONS IN HATCHERIES AND SURVEILLANCE OF DISEASE IN BOTH DOMESTIC AND WILD FISH. FISH HEALTH LAB FISH PATHOLOGIST/RESEARCH SCIENTISTS ALSO INVESTIGATE NEW AND ESTABLISHED FISH PATHOGENS AND PARTICIPATE IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW TREATMENTS AND DETECTION TECHNIQUES FOR FISH PATHOGENS AND DISEASES.

THE OVERALL PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO ASSIST IN FUNDING NDOW'S AQUATIC/ANGLER EDUCATION PROGRAM TO INFORM ANGLERS OF THE FISHING OPPORTUNITIES NEVADA HAS TO OFFER AND GIVE NEW AND EXISTING ANGLERS THE SKILLS NECESSARY TO MAKE THEIR FISHING OUTINGS SAFE, PRODUCTIVE AND MORE ENJOYABLE. ALL ANGLERS WILL BE EDUCATED TO BE MORE COURTEOUS AND SHOW GREATER RESPECT FOR LANDOWNERS, LAND MANAGERS, OTHER ANGLERS AND USERS OF PUBLIC LANDS AND AQUATIC RESOURCES.

STREAMS AND RIVERS IN ILLINOIS OFFER GREAT FISHING AND RECREATION OPPORTUNITIES TO THE PUBLIC AND SUPPORT HIGH DIVERSITY OF AQUATIC LIFE. OUR RESEARCH TEAM IN THE ILLINOIS NATURAL HISTORY SURVEY HAS CONDUCTED MULTIPLE-YEAR FISHERIES MONITORING IN SEVERAL MAJOR TRIBUTARIES OF THE ILLINOIS RIVER, INCLUDING THE MACKINAW, VERMILION, AND KANKAKEE RIVER TO SUPPORT THE MANAGEMENT AND DECISION-MAKING PROCESSES OF ILLINOIS DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (IDNR), FISHERIES DIVISION. THIS PARTICULAR PROJECT CONTINUES OUR EFFORT TO INVESTIGATE THE POSSIBLE CAUSES OF THE SMALLMOUTH BASS POPULATION DECLINE AND POOR SUCCESS OF STOCKING IN THE MACKINAW RIVER. OUR APPROACH IS TO COMPARE THE POPULATIONS AND HABITATS OF THE SPECIES IN DIFFERENT RIVERS, PARTICULARLY THE MACKINAW AND VERMILION RIVER, WHICH ARE SIMILAR IN MANY WAYS (E.G., SIZE AND STOCKING). WE SHALL CONDUCT FISH SAMPLING WITH BOAT AND TOW-BARGE SHOCKING, RIVERBED SIDE-SCANNING WITH SONAR, AND ASSESS FISH-WINTERING HABITATS WITH TELEMETRY (RADIO TRACKING). THE DATA COLLECTED FROM THESE TOOLS SHALL BE ANALYZED AND SYNTHESIZED TO ASSESS THE POTENTIAL LIMITING FACTORS FOR THE SMALLMOUTH BASS POPULATION IN THE MACKINAW RIVER. THE INFORMATION THEN CAN BE USED TO SUPPORT MANAGEMENT DECISIONS BY IDNR AND HELP US TO BETTER UNDERSTAND HOW THIS POPULAR SPORTFISH SPECIES INTERACTS WITH ITS ENVIRONMENT.

THIS PROJECT INCLUDES THE ADMINISTRATION OF THE STATE OF UTAH'S BOATING ACCESS PROGRAM, WHICH PROVIDES FOR IMPROVEMENTS MADE TO ENHANCE THE EXPERIENCES OF RECREATIONAL BOATERS AND BOATING ANGLERS IN UTAH.PROPOSALS FOR NEW PROJECTS, SUCH AS NEW BOAT RAMPS, COURTESY DOCKS, RESTROOMS, AND FISH CLEANING STATIONS, AMONG OTHER AMENITIES, ARE SUBMITTED ANNUALLY FOR FUNDING CONSIDERATION. LIKEWISE, PROPOSALS ARE SUBMITTED TO MAINTAIN EXISTING BOATING FACILITIES. PROJECTS APPROVED FOR FUNDING REQUIRE ADMINISTRATION AND OVERSIGHT, INCLUDING THE DRAFTING AND SUBMISSION OF FEDERAL GRANT PROPOSALS, MONITORING OF CONTRACTS AND AGREEMENTS, BILLING, PAYMENT, REPORTING, AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF OUTREACH MATERIAL TO HIGHLIGHT PROJECTS. IN ADDITION, PROJECT FUNDING ALSO PROVIDES FOR THE MAINTENANCE OF UTAH DIVISION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES-OWNED BOATING ACCESS FACILITIES.

IN THE YEAR 2000, THE DNER RECREATIONAL AND SPORTFISH DIVISION BEGAN PARTICIPATING IN THE MARINE RECREATIONAL FISHERIES STATISTICS SURVEYS. THE PROJECT'S FINDINGS COMPLETELY ALTERED OUR PERCEPTION AND UNDERSTANDING OF PUERTO RICO'S MARINE RECREATIONAL FISHERY IN THE YEARS THAT FOLLOWED. PRIOR TO THIS PROJECT, THE ONLY DATA ON MARINE FISHERIES AVAILABLE WERE COMMERCIAL FISHERIES DATA. THE DOCUMENTATION THAT THE RECREATIONAL FISHERY ACCOUNTS FOR 50% OR MORE OF THE TOTAL MARINE FISH HARVEST IN PUERTO RICO EACH YEAR WAS EXTREMELY SIGNIFICANT. THIS KNOWLEDGE FUNDAMENTALLY ALTERED DNER'S AND OTHER AGENCIES' PERCEPTIONS OF THE FISHERY AND ITS MANAGEMENT. AS DATA ACCUMULATED, IT BECAME CLEAR THAT MARINE RECREATIONAL ANGLERS WERE THE MOST NUMEROUS SECTORS BY A FACTOR OF 100, AND THAT THEIR ACTIVITY WAS FOCUSED ON PELAGIC SPECIES, WHICH DIFFERED SIGNIFICANTLY FROM THE REPORTED COMMERCIAL CATCH, WHERE IT REPRESENTS A LOW PERCENTAGE.THE IMPORTANCE OF SHORELINE ANGLERS (ROUGHLY 60% OF THE TOTAL ANGLER COMMUNITY) AND THE STEEP DECLINE IN THEIR HARVEST IN RECENT YEARS BECAME CLEAR. ALL THIS INFORMATION IS NOW BEING CONSIDERED AS PART OF THE REVIEW OF SPECIES MANAGEMENT REGULATIONS, IN THE PLANNING AND DESIGN OF RECREATIONAL FISHING FACILITIES, THE ESTABLISHMENT OF RESEARCH PRIORITIES, AND NOVEL APPROACHES TO STOCK ASSESSMENTS ARE TESTED. SINCE THE BEGINNING OF THE PROJECT, PROJECT PERSONNEL HAVE WORKED HARD TO TRACK CATCH AND EFFORT AT VARIOUS TYPES OF FISHING TOURNAMENTS HELD THROUGHOUT PUERTO RICO. THIS HAS BEEN AN ADDED BENEFIT, YIELDING VALUABLE INFORMATION FOR RECREATIONAL FISHERIES MANAGEMENT.

SUSITNA LANDING IS THE LARGEST ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH & GAME (ADF&G), DIVISION OF SPORT FISH (DSF) OWNEDBOATING ACCESS FACILITY IN THE STATE AND ONE OF THE PRIMARY BOAT LAUNCH SITES IN THE SUSITNA RIVER DRAINAGE.NUMEROUS SITE IMPROVEMENTS HAVE PROVIDED SERVICES THAT FEW BOAT LAUNCH FACILITIES IN SOUTHCENTRAL ALASKA CANMATCH. A STATE-HIRED CONTRACTOR IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE DAY-TO-DAY OPERATIONS OF THE FACILITY AND IS REQUIRED TOPROVIDE AN ON-SITE PRESENCE YEAR-ROUND. HOUSING IS PROVIDED FOR THE CONTRACTOR, BUT THEY MUST PAY FOR THE COSTOF UTILITIES. REQUIRED ROUTINE OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE (O&M) TASKS INCLUDE: YEARLY DREDGING OF THE BOAT LAUNCHAND BOAT MOORING AREA; ROAD AND PARKING LOT GRADING; VAULT TOILET AND SHOWER BUILDING CLEANING; SNOW AND TRASHREMOVAL; COLLECTION OF FEES; AND, GENERAL MAINTENANCE OF MOORING FLOATS, BUILDINGS, FISH CLEANING TABLES,CAMPSITES, AND OTHER AMENITIES. LARGER AND MORE COMPLEX MAINTENANCE TASKS AND CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS ARECONTRACTED SEPARATELY BY DSF THROUGH THE STATE'S COMPETITIVE BIDDING PROCESS. FEES COLLECTED FOR FACILITY USEHELP PAY FOR O&M COSTS. PUBLIC USE AND REVENUE GENERATED ARE LARGELY DEPENDENT ON SEASONAL SPORT FISHERYSUCCESS, WEATHER AND WATER CONDITIONS, AND TOURISM. HISTORICALLY, THE ANNUAL AMOUNT OF REVENUE GENERATED THROUGHFEE COLLECTION HAS ONLY PROVIDED A PORTION OF THE COSTS REQUIRED TO MANAGE AND MAINTAIN THE FACILITY.SUSITNA LANDING SERVICES A SOLID CLIENTELE OF RETURN CUSTOMERS THAT HAS DEVELOPED LARGELY AS A RESULT OFEXCEPTIONAL ON-SITE MANAGEMENT AND CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS TO THE SITE. THOUGH THIS SITE WAS ESTABLISHED AS ARECREATIONAL BOAT LAUNCH FACILITY, SOME WINTER USE ALSO OCCURS BY FOLKS USING SNOW MACHINES TO ACCESS NEARBYRECREATIONAL CABINS AND THE SURROUNDING LAKES AND BACKCOUNTRY TO ENJOY TRAIL RIDING AND ICE FISHING.SUSITNA LANDING IS LOCATED AT THE END OF A ONE-MILE GRAVEL ROAD (SUSITNA LANDING ROAD) OFF THE PARKS HIGHWAY,APPROXIMATELY 84 MILES NORTH OF ANCHORAGE. DUE TO THE SOMEWHAT REMOTE NATURE OF THE FACILITY, MAINTAINING AN ONSITEPRESENCE SEVEN DAYS A WEEK, YEAR-ROUND, IS A NECESSITY. WITH A LACK OF LAW ENFORCEMENT PERSONNEL AT THESITE (OR ANYWHERE NEARBY), THE CONTRACTOR'S YEAR-ROUND RESIDENCE PREVENTS THEFT AND VANDALISM FROM OCCURRING ANDPROVIDES A SECURE PRESENCE TO ASSIST THE PUBLIC UTILIZING THE SITE. OTHER MEASURES THAT DSF HAS TAKEN TO PROVIDEA SAFE SITE AND PROTECT FACILITY INVESTMENTS HAVE INCLUDED INSTALLATION OF A MOTORIZED GATE TO CONTROL TRAFFICINTO AND OUT OF THE FACILITY, MOTION DETECTORS NEAR THE ENTRANCEWAY, AND SECURITY CAMERAS.FACILITY IMPROVEMENTS INCLUDE ACCESSIBLE SHOWERS AND VAULT TOILETS, ELECTRIC AND NON-ELECTRIC RV CAMPING SITES,BOAT LAUNCH AND DOCK, AND ENHANCEMENTS TO PARKING AND TRAFFIC FLOW. THESE IMPROVEMENTS, ALONG WITH WEATHERCONDITIONS DURING THE WINTER MONTHS, COMPOUND THE MAINTENANCE NEEDS OF THE FACILITY WHERE TEMPERATURES CAN DROPBELOW MINUS-FORTY DEGREES FAHRENHEIT. REGULAR INSPECTION AND MAINTENANCE OF ON-SITE BUILDINGS AND AMENITIES ISREQUIRED TO HELP PREVENT COSTLY REPAIRS FURTHER NECESSITATING A TWELVE-MONTH ON-SITE PRESENCE.THE DSF HAS INVESTED SIGNIFICANT TIME AND FUNDING INTO SUSITNA LANDING TO PROVIDE RECREATIONAL BOATERS AND SPORTANGLERS UP-TO-DATE AMENITIES AND IMPROVEMENTS TO MAKE THEIR RECREATIONAL EXPERIENCES MORE PLEASURABLE ANDACCOMMODATING. DSF NOT ONLY HAS AN OBLIGATION TO THE FEDERAL AID IN SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM TO MAINTAINTHE SITE, BUT MUST CONTINUE TO PROVIDE SAFE, RESPONSIBLE, AND SECURE MANAGEMENT OF THE FACILITY FOR THERECREATING PUBLIC. WITHOUT A YEAR-ROUND PRESENCE, FACILITY IMPROVEMENTS AND ON-SITE STRUCTURES WOULD MOSTCERTAINLY GET PILFERED AND VANDALIZED AT THIS REMOTE SITE. THIS PROJECT IS NEEDED TO PROVIDE PAYMENT OF THECONTRACTOR'S SALARY AND, IF NEEDED, TO HELP FUND UNFORESEEN REPAIR OR MAINTENANCE PROJECTS THAT FALL OUTSIDE OFCONTRACT STIPULATIONS.

CONSTRUCTION OF THE LITTLE SUSITNA PUBLIC USE FACILITY (LSPUF), LOCATED ON THE LITTLE SUSITNA RIVER NEAR RIVERMILE (RM) 29, WAS COMPLETED IN 1990 USING FEDERAL AID IN SPORT FISH RESTORATION FUNDS UNDER PROJECT F-13-D-6.FACILITY CONSTRUCTION ALLOWED FOR EXCELLENT BOATING ACCESS TO UPPER AND LOWER SECTIONS OF THE RIVER IN THE POINTMACKENZIE AREA SOUTHWEST OF THE COMMUNITY OF WASILLA. THE FACILITY IS OWNED BY THE STATE OF ALASKA DEPARTMENT OFFISH AND GAME (ADF&G) DIVISION OF SPORT FISH (DSF) AND IS LOCATED WITHIN THE SUSITNA FLATS STATE GAME REFUGE.OVER THE YEARS, NUMEROUS FEDERAL AID PROJECTS HAVE IMPROVED AND MAINTAINED THE FUNCTION OF THE FACILITY,INCLUDING: LSPUF BOAT LAUNCH RAMP REPLACEMENT, PROJECT F-13-D-53; LITTLE SUSITNA RIVER TRAIL DEVELOPMENT, PROJECTF-13-D-68; LSPUF REMOTE CAMPSITE DEVELOPMENT, PROJECT F-13-D-75; AND LSPUF VAULT LATRINE REPLACEMENT, PROJECTF-13-D-138.THE LSPUF IS A HIGH USE SITE THAT PROVIDES ACCESS AND RECREATIONAL USE FOR SPORT ANGLERS, CAMPERS, ANDRECREATIONAL BOATERS. THE FACILITY IS LOCATED AT AN END-OF-THE ROAD LOCATION THAT SEASONALLY REQUIRES AN ON-SITEPRESENCE TO ENSURE PROPER SITE MANAGEMENT, MAINTENANCE, AND SECURITY. THESE SERVICES ARE PROVIDED BY A STATEHIREDCONTRACTOR. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE FUNDS TO ENSURE THAT THE FACILITY IS BEING PROPERLY MANAGED ANDMAINTAINED IN A SAFE AND SECURE MANNER FOR PUBLIC USE.
THIS GRANT PROVIDES FUNDING FOR THE MONITORING, MANAGEMENT, AND CONSERVATION OF FRESHWATER FISHES THROUGHOUT LOUISIANA.

THE RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE FISHERIES MANAGEMENT SECTION OF THE GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF NATURALRESOURCES WILDLIFE RESOURCES DIVISION (FMS) ARE TO CONSERVE, ENHANCE, AND PROVIDE FOR THE UTILIZATION OFGEORGIA'S FRESHWATER FISHERY RESOURCES. THE QUANTITY AND QUALITY OF WATER AND HABITAT WITHIN STREAMSDETERMINES THE INTEGRITY OF THE FISHERIES RESOURCES. THE OVERALL OBJECTIVES OF THIS GRANT ARE:1. ASSESS FISH COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE STATE TO DESCRIBE THE QUALITY OF STREAM FISH COMMUNITIES2. ASSESS THE DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF ALTAMAHA BASS IN STREAMS WITHIN THEIR NATIVE RANGE OF THEALTAMAHA RIVER BASIN.

THIS GRANT WILL BE USED TO OPERATE/MAINTAIN 9 STATE FISH HATCHERIES, WHICH ARE EXPECTED TO PRODUCEAPPROXIMATELY 50 MILLION SPORT FISH HATCHLINGS TO BE RELEASED INTO APPROXIMATELY 841 LAKES ANDRESERVOIRS AND 22 RIVERS OR STREAMS THROUGHOUT MONTANA DURING THE 2022-2023 FIELD SEASONS. THESERELEASES WILL PROVIDE OR AUGMENT POPULATIONS TO OFFER FISHING OPPORTUNITIES AND TO HELP RESTORENATIVE POPULATIONS.

NORTH CAROLINA HAS OVER 350,000 ACTIVE REGISTERED BOATERS AND HUNDREDS OF VISITING AND NON-RESIDENT BOATERS WHO USE NORTH CAROLINA WILDLIFE RESOURCES COMMISSION BOATING ACCESS AREA FACILITIES TO ACCESS THE STATE'S INLAND PUBLIC WATERS. TO ACCOMMODATETHESE DEMANDS THE COMMISSION MUST PROVIDE SAFE, CLEAN, AND SERVICEABLE BOATING ACCESS AREAS FOR THE LAUNCH AND RETRIEVAL OF BOATS IN NORTH CAROLINA'S MARINE WATERS. COMMISSION STAFF OPERATE AND MAINTAIN APPROXIMATELY 68 COASTAL AND JOINT WATERS BOATING ACCESS AREAS ACROSS THE STATE.

THE MARINE GAME FISH TAGGING PROGRAM IS AN ASMFC-CERTIFIED ANGLER-BASED PROJECT THAT UTILIZES RECREATIONAL ANGLERS FOR DEPLOYING EXTERNAL FISH TAGS IN MARINE GAME FISH. THE PROGRAM PROVIDES DATA ON MOVEMENT AND MIGRATORY PATTERNS, LENGTH FREQUENCY CHARACTERIZATION FOR RELEASED FISH, HABITAT UTILIZATION, AND MORTALITY ESTIMATES. THIS EFFORT SUPPLEMENTS BOTH FISHERY DEPENDENT AND INDEPENDENT DATA COLLECTION AND ALLOWS FOR MORE INFORMED MANAGEMENT DECISIONS IN SOUTH CAROLINA.
THIS GRANT PROVIDES FUNDING FOR THE EVALUATION AND CONTROL OF AQUATIC NUISANCE VEGETATION TO MAINTAIN BOATING ACCESS ON PUBLIC WATERBODIES THROUGHOUT LOUISIANA.

THIS GRANT PROVIDES FUNDING TO PROCESS AGE, GROWTH, REPRODUCTIVE AND MORTALITY DATA, EVALUATE MANAGEMENT OPTIONS, DEVELOP RECOMMENDATIONS, AND DEVELOP STOCK ASSESSMENTS AND MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR RECREATIONALLY IMPORTANT SPORT FISHES.
FUNDING FROM THIS GRANT IS USED TO MONITOR, MANAGE, AND CONSERVE MARINE FISHERIES THROUGHOUT COASTAL LOUISIANA.

MONITORING THE EXISTING STATUS OF FISH POPULATIONS OF THE STATE'S RIVERS AND STREAMS IS AN ESSENTIALELEMENT IN PRIORITIZING THE NEED FOR AND EVALUATING THE SUCCESS OF RESTORATION PROJECTS, HABITATIMPROVEMENT PROJECTS, RIVER MANAGEMENT, AND STEWARDSHIP OF THE ASSOCIATED FISH COMMUNITY. THISPROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THESE EFFORTS BY ANALYZING HISTORICAL DATA RECORDS FOR SPECIES OCCURRENCES INCOMBINATION WITH NEW, TARGETED FIELD COLLECTIONS FROM ACROSS THE STATE. THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TOMANAGE, RESTORE, PROTECT, AND MAINTAIN THE DIVERSITY OF FISH COMMUNITIES AND ASSOCIATED HABITATS INHISTORIC RIVER LANDSCAPES AND ECOSYSTEM FUNCTIONS FOR PRESENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS. THIS PROJECT WILLALSO STRIVE TO MAXIMIZE THE OPPORTUNITY FOR RECREATIONAL ANGLERS TO USE THE FISHERY RESOURCES IN NEBRASKARIVERS AND STREAMS BY ENHANCING THESE NATURAL RESOURCES FOR THE BENEFIT OF FISH AND ANGLERS.

AQUATIC RESOURCES EDUCATION IS A PROGRAM DESIGNED TO EDUCATE THE PUBLIC ABOUT THE ABUNDANT RESOURCES OUR STATE HAS TO OFFER TOWARDS SPORT FISHING AND RESOURCES THAT ARE IN AND AROUND OUR NUMEROUS LAKES AND RIVERS. THIS PROGRAM WILL ALSO BE AN INTEGRAL PART IN RECRUITING, REACTIVATING AND RETAINING ANGLERS IN THIS STATE. THIS GRANT HAS OBJECTIVES OF CONDUCTING FOUR INSTRUCTOR TRAININGS TO TEACH INSTRUCTORS HOW TO TEACH ABOUT THE AQUATIC RESOURCES EDUCATION, PRODUCE 265,000 PRINTED PRODUCTS TO INFORM THE PUBLIC OF THE AQUATIC RESOURCES DURING FISHING CLASSES, SCHOOLS, EDUCATIONAL EVENTS, TRAIN 4,000 NEW STUDENTS IN FISHING EDUCATION, AND TO RENOVATE 1 AQUATIC EDUCATION FACILITY BY RENOVATING A DIRT TRAIL TO AN ADA ACCESSIBLE FISHING PIER TO MAKE IT CONCRETE AND ADA COMPLIANT.

FUNDING FROM THIS GRANT SUPPORTS ADMINISTRATIVE TASKS ASSOCIATED WITH CARRYING OUT THE OBJECTIVES OF ALL SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROJECTS. TASKS INCLUDE GRANT APPLICATION AND MANAGEMENT, TRAINING ACTIVITIES, BUDGET MANAGEMENT, AND OTHER COORDINATION ACTIVITIES.

THIS PROPOSAL COVERS YEAR 6 OF AN EFFORT TO MAINTAIN A VITAL ACOUSTIC TELEMETRY ARRAY FOR MONITORING THE OCCURRENCE OF (AND SEASONAL AND INTER-ANNUAL FIDELITY BY) A MULTITUDE OF MANAGED MARINE SPECIES TAGGED BY SCDNR RESEARCHERS AS WELL AS NUMEROUS RESEARCH GROUPS ALONG THE EASTERN SEABOARD. THIS COASTAL RECEIVER ARRAY WAS ESTABLISHED BY A FEDERAL GRANT FROM THE NATIONAL MARINE AS EXTENSION OF AN INSHORE RECEIVER ARRAY FOR MONITORING TWO SPECIES OF STURGEON BUT ALSO DETECTED A MYRIAD OF SPECIES TAGGED WITH VENDOR-COMPATIBLE TRANSMITTERS. THE AIM OF THE PROJECT IS TO MAINTAIN A KEY COMPONENT OF REGIONAL ACOUSTIC TELEMETRY RECEIVER ARRAY, WHICH FORMS AN IMPORTANT LEG OF A NATIONAL ANIMAL TELEMETRY NETWORK (ATN) ALONG THE U.S. EASTERN SEABOARD. BETWEEN 2 JULY 2022 AND 1 JULY 2023, WE WILL MAINTAIN AN ARRAY OF 74 ACOUSTIC RECEIVERS OFF THE COAST OF SOUTH CAROLINA WHICH ENCOMPASS STATE AND FEDERAL WATERS. SEVENTEEN OF THESE RECEIVERS ARE LOCATED BETWEEN WINYAH BAY, SC AND THE SC/NC BORDER, 37 OCCUR OFFSHORE OF CHARLESTON, AND 20 OCCUR BETWEEN TWO LARGE SOUND SYSTEMS (ST. HELENA AND PORT ROYAL) IN THE SOUTHERN PART OF THE STATE. FIVE ADDITIONAL RECEIVERS FUNDED BY THE USACE ARE LOCATED OFF CHARLESTON, SC.

FUNDING FROM THIS GRANT IS USED TO DETERMINE THE GENETIC COMPOSITION OF LARGEMOUTH BASS COLLECTED FROM PUBLIC WATERS THAT HAVE BEEN STOCKED WITH FLORIDA LARGEMOUTH BASS. SAMPLES ARE ANALYZED THROUGH A CONTRACT WITH LOUISIANA STATE UNIVERSITY.

THE DIVISION OF AQUATIC RESOURCES' EDUCATION PROGRAM IS DESIGNED TO ENHANCE PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING OF HAWAI'I'SAQUATIC ENVIRONMENTS, DEVELOP RESPONSIBLE ATTITUDES AND A SENSE OF STEWARDSHIP TOWARD HAWAI'I'S AQUATICRESOURCES, ENCOURAGE PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT IN CONSERVATION ISSUES, AND PROMOTE SAFE AND ETHICAL AQUATIC RESOURCEBASEDRECREATION. THIS IS ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH FISHING EDUCATION CLASSES EMPHASIZING CONSERVATION; IN-SERVICETRAINING FOR TEACHERS; CLASSROOM PRESENTATIONS; PARTICIPATION IN OUTREACH EVENTS; PRESENTATIONS TO COMMUNITYGROUPS; AND OUTREACH THROUGH VARIOUS TYPES OF MEDIA INCLUDING WEBSITES, TELEVISION SPOTS, AND PRINTED MATERIALS.THE GOAL IS TO PROVIDE RESIDENTS AND VISITORS WITH INFORMATION THAT WILL HELP THEM MAKE WISE DECISIONS REGARDINGUSE OF OUR AQUATIC RESOURCES.

PROJECT 1 - SURVEY OF FISH & HABITAT: THE DEPARTMENT OF LAND AND NATURAL RESOURCES, DIVISION OF AQUATICRESOURCES' SURVEY OF FISH AND HABITAT PROJECT WAS ESTABLISHED TO MONITOR THE HEALTH AND QUALITY OF HAWAII'SMARINE RECREATIONAL FISHERIES STOCKS AND THEIR HABITAT. SURVEYS ARE CONDUCTED TO DETERMINE THE IMPACT OF FISHINGPRESSURE AND MANAGEMENT ACTIONS ON SPORT FINFISH AND THEIR ASSOCIATED HABITATS. ON-GOING MARINE FISH AND HABITATSURVEYS WILL QUANTIFY THE RESOURCE STATUS AND TRENDS WITHIN THE MARINE ENVIRONMENT. FISHING EFFORT AND INTERCEPTSURVEYS WILL QUANTIFY CHANGES IN FISHING SUCCESS WHILE HELPING ANTICIPATE POTENTIAL FISHING IMPACTS TO THERESOURCES. ROUTINE COLLECTION OF WATER QUALITY AND TEMPERATURE DATA WILL MEASURE BOTH NATURAL AND ANTHROPOGENICIMPACTS TO THE NEARSHORE MARINE ENVIRONMENT. INFORMATION FROM THIS PROJECT WILL GUIDE ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT FORSUSTAINABLE RECREATIONAL FISHING AND HELP TO PROMOTE WISE USE OF LIMITED AQUATIC RESOURCES.PROJECT 2 - HAWAII MARINE RECREATIONAL FISHING SURVEY: THE HAWAI'I DIVISION OF AQUATIC RESOURCES (DAR) IS THESTATE RESOURCE AGENCY RESPONSIBLE FOR MANAGING RECREATIONAL (NON-COMMERCIAL) AND COMMERCIAL FISHING ACTIVITIES INSTATE WATERS. UNLIKE COMMERCIAL FISHERS WHO ARE REQUIRED TO REPORT FISHING ACTIVITIES MONTHLY TO DAR, NONCOMMERCIALFISHERS DO NOT HAVE ANY REPORTING MANDATES. NEARSHORE FISHERIES IN HAWAI'I ARE PRIMARILY NONCOMMERCIALIN NATURE AND THUS NEED TO BE ACTIVELY MONITORED TO PROVIDE ESSENTIAL DATA WHEN ASSESSING RESOURCEHEALTH. THUS, TO FACILITATE PROACTIVE MANAGEMENT, THE HAWAI'I MARINE RECREATIONAL FISHING SURVEY (HMRFS) WASINITIATED IN 2001 AS A STATEWIDE MARINE CREEL SURVEY THAT COLLECTS NON-COMMERCIAL FISHING CATCH AND EFFORTINFORMATION FROM BOTH SHORELINE AND PRIVATE BOAT FISHERS. HMRFS SURVEYORS ROUTINELY INTERVIEW FISHERS AT PUBLICBOAT RAMPS AND POPULAR SHORELINE FISHING AREAS YEAR-ROUND. FIELD DATA ARE THEN DELIVERED TO THE MAIN OFFICE INHONOLULU WHERE THE DATA IS KEY-ENTERED INTO A DATABASE, PROCESSED USING STANDARDIZED QA/QC PROTOCOLS, THENSUBMITTED TO NOAA FISHERIES' MARINE RECREATIONAL INFORMATION PROGRAM (MRIP) WHERE FISHERY LANDINGS ANDPARTICIPATION ESTIMATES ARE CALCULATED AND SHARED WITH THE PUBLIC. THE COMBINATION OF COMMERCIAL AND NONCOMMERCIALDATA SETS ULTIMATELY PROVIDES STATE MANAGERS WITH A HOLISTIC VIEW OF FISHERY DYNAMICS AND TRENDS THATHELP GUIDE EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES AND ENSURE THAT HEALTHY STOCKS WILL CONTINUE TO THRIVE FOR CURRENT ANDFUTURE GENERATIONS.

HAWAII'S DIVISION OF AQUATIC RESOURCES (DAR), STATEWIDE MARINE FISHERIES TECHNICAL GUIDANCE PROJECT WORKSCOLLABORATIVELY WITH BOTH PUBLIC AND PRIVATE ENTITIES TO BEST MANAGE AND CONSERVE THE MARINE FISHERIES RESOURCESOF THE STATE AND TO MEET THE NEEDS AND EXPECTATIONS OF FISHERMEN AND OCEAN USERS. IN ORDER TO PREVENT ADVERSEECOLOGICAL DISTURBANCES, THIS PROJECT PROVIDES TECHNICAL GUIDANCE AND ASSISTANCE TO PRIVATE INDIVIDUALS, FIRMS,AND FEDERAL, STATE AND COUNTY AGENCIES THROUGH THE PROCESS OF ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW OF PROPOSED OCEAN RELATEDPROJECTS THAT MAY AFFECT FISHING AND MARINE RESOURCES. THESE PROPOSED PROJECTS MAY INCLUDE, BUT NOT LIMITED TO,SHORELINE REPLENISHMENT OR DEVELOPMENT AND MARINE CONSTRUCTION, RENEWABLE ENERGY PROJECTS, RESEARCH ACTIVITIESAND MILITARY TESTING AND TRAINING. EXAMPLES OF REVIEWS CONDUCTED INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO REVIEW OFENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENTS (EA), ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT STATEMENTS (EIS), MARINE RESEARCH OR SURVEY PROPOSALS ANDREPORTS. IN ADDITION, THE DAR RESPONDS TO AND CONDUCTS INVESTIGATIONS OF FISH OR INVERTEBRATE KILLS, OIL SPILLSAND OTHER POLLUTION INCIDENTS, DOCUMENTING IMPACTS TO MARINE AND ESTUARINE RESOURCES. INFORMATION COLLECTED FROMSPORT FISH RESTORATION STUDIES SUCH AS MARINE RESEARCH OR SURVEYS, ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEWS AND FISH OR INVERTEBRATEKILLS WILL BE USED IN THE EVALUATION AND PREPARATION OF COMMENTS AND RECOMMENDATIONS TO MINIMIZE IMPACT, ORREQUIRED DOCUMENTATION FOR THESE TYPES OF PROJECTS, AND ALLOWS THE STATE TO BETTER MANAGE AND CONSERVE MARINE ANDESTUARINE FISHES AND THEIR HABITATS.

THE STATEWIDE FRESHWATER RESEARCH AND SURVEYS PROJECT WAS ESTABLISHED TO MAINTAIN AND PROVIDE NEW OPPORTUNITIESFOR FRESHWATER SPORT FISHING IN HAWAII. THE WAHIAWA RESERVOIR PUBLIC FISHING AREA (PFA) ON THE ISLAND OF OAHUPROVIDES ONE OF THE FEW AREAS FOR FRESHWATER SPORT FISHING. THEREFORE, MONITORING AND MAINTAINING THIS AREA ISCRITICAL TO ACHIEVING THIS OBJECTIVE. WAHIAWA PFA HOSTS AN ENTIRELY EXOTIC FISHERY COMPOSED OF SPECIES FOUND INCOMBINATION NOWHERE ELSE IN THE WORLD SUCH AS PEACOCK BASS, LARGEMOUTH BASS, SMALLMOUTH BASS, CHANNEL CATFISH ANDBLUEGILL. CREEL SURVEYS ARE CONDUCTED TO MONITOR FISH POPULATIONS AND TO DETERMINE IF HATCHERY CULTUREDLARGEMOUTH BASS ARE MAKING AN IMPACT ON THE EXISTING LARGEMOUTH BASS POPULATIONS IN THE RESERVOIR. IN ADDITION,SURVEYS ARE CONDUCTED TO MONITOR ANY NEW AND EXOTIC INTRODUCTIONS (FLORA AND FAUNA). MITIGATION MEASURES ARE ALSOTAKEN TO AVOID FISH POPULATION IMBALANCES, OUTBREAKS OF FISH DISEASE, FISH KILLS OR THE ESTABLISHMENT OF INVASIVESPECIES. MONTHLY OXYGEN READINGS ARE TAKEN THROUGHOUT THE RESERVOIR AND A PORTABLE EMERGENCY AERATION SYSTEM ISOPERATED AND MAINTAINED IN THE EVENT LOW DISSOLVED OXYGEN LEVELS ARE PRESENT TO MITIGATE ANY POTENTIAL FISH KILLSDUE TO ANOXIA.

THE STATEWIDE FRESHWATER TECHNICAL GUIDANCE PROJECT PROVIDES PROFESSIONAL AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO PRIVATELANDOWNERS, GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, PUBLIC ENTITIES, LAND MANAGERS, AND NON-GOVERNMENT ORGANIZATIONS DURING PROJECTPLANNING AND PERMIT REVIEW PROCESSES TO PREVENT AND/OR REDUCE NEGATIVE IMPACTS TO FRESHWATER HABITATS ANDRESOURCES FROM HUMAN DEVELOPMENT AND ACTIVITIES. PROVIDING EXPERT ADVICE AND INFORMATION ON FISH ASSESSMENTS,RESEARCH TECHNIQUES, SPECIES AND/OR HABITAT MANAGEMENT HELPS THESE ENTITIES BETTER UNDERSTAND THE IMPACTS THEIRPROPOSED PROJECTS (I.E., STREAM DE-WATERING, DAMMING, OR CHANNELIZING; HIGHWAY/BRIDGE CONSTRUCTION; HOUSING ANDOTHER LAND DEVELOPMENTS; HYDROPOWER DEVELOPMENT; INTRODUCTION OF EXOTIC ORGANISMS; PESTICIDE USAGE; WASTEDISPOSAL; AND WATERSHED MANIPULATION) MAY HAVE ON FRESHWATER FISH AND THEIR HABITAT RESOURCES.

THE HAWAII DEPARTMENT OF LAND AND NATURAL RESOURCES, DIVISION OF AQUATIC RESOURCES, SUPPORTS 13 PROJECTS UNDEREIGHT GRANTS WHICH ARE FUNDED BY THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE'S SPORT FISH RESTORATION (WSFR) PROGRAM ON AN ANNUALBASIS. HAWAII'S STATEWIDE SPORT FISH RESTORATION COORDINATION PROGRAM WAS ESTABLISHED TO PROVIDE EFFECTIVE GRANTMANAGEMENT AND OVERSIGHT CONTROLS TO ENSURE THAT THE ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS OF THE PROGRAM ARE MAINTAINED. USEOF PROGRAM FUNDS REQUIRES CONSIDERABLE ADMINISTRATION, SUPERVISION AND COORDINATION FROM THE APPLICATION PROCESSTHROUGH POST-CLOSEOUT; AND STAFF MUST ENSURE GRANTS/PROJECTS COMPLY WITH ALL STATE AND FEDERAL LAWS ANDREGULATIONS. STATEWIDE SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM COORDINATION, INVOLVING FRESHWATER, ESTUARINE AND MARINEDEVELOPMENT AND OPERATION PROJECTS, TECHNICAL GUIDANCE, RESEARCH, SURVEYS AND INVENTORIES, AQUATIC RESOURCESEDUCATION, AND RECREATIONAL BOATING ACCESS, IS VITAL IN VIEW OF THE SIZE, DIVERSITY AND SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION OFALL ACTIVITIES INVOLVED. IN ADDITION, LIAISON WITH EXTERNAL ENTITIES SUCH AS THE REGIONAL AND AREA FISH ANDWILDLIFE SERVICE OFFICES, OTHER FEDERAL, STATE AND MUNICIPAL AGENCIES, COUNCILS, PRIVATE AND PUBLICORGANIZATIONS, IS NECESSARY, AS IS MONITORING OF LEGISLATION THAT MAY POTENTIALLY IMPACT THE SPORT FISHRESTORATION PROGRAM.

PROJECT 1 - ARTIFICIAL REEF FISH/HABITAT ENHANCEMENT: THE STATE OF HAWAII ARTIFICIAL REEF FISH/HABITATENHANCEMENT PROJECT STARTED IN 1961 WITH THE ESTABLISHMENT OF THE MAUNALUA BAY ARTIFICIAL REEF OFF THE SOUTHSHORE OF OAHU. IT WAS THE FIRST OF FIVE ARTIFICIAL REEFS, WITH THE OTHERS BEING THE WAIANAE, KEAWAKAPU, KUALOAAND EWA DEEPWATER, THAT THE STATE ESTABLISHED FOR ADDITIONAL RECREATIONAL FISHING OPPORTUNITIES. THE HAWAIIANISLANDS HAVE A NARROW BAND OF NATURAL CORAL REEFS CONFINING RECREATIONAL FISHING OPPORTUNITIES IN THE NEARSHOREAREA. MUCH OF THE NEARSHORE AREA IS BARREN IN APPEARANCE. ARTIFICIAL REEFS PLACED IN THESE AREAS PROVIDE THENECESSARY SHELTER FOR A VARIETY OF FISH SPECIES. SOME OF THE BENEFITS FROM THIS PROJECT ARE INCREASED FISHPRODUCTIVITY, INCREASED FISHING OPPORTUNITIES, AND MOVING FISHING PRESSURE AWAY FROM NATURAL REEFS. THE STATEPLANS TO OBTAIN THE NECESSARY PERMITS AND CERTIFICATIONS TO ADD MATERIAL TO EXISTING ARTIFICIAL REEFS ANDPOSSIBLY TO ESTABLISH NEW ARTIFICIAL REEFS. UNDERWATER VISUAL SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED TO DETERMINE PRODUCTIVITYOF THE ARTIFICIAL REEFS AND DETECT ANY CHANGES OVER TIME. THIS SURVEY DATA WILL BE USED TO ASSESS THE STATUS OFREEF FISH AND HABITATS AROUND EXISTING ARTIFICIAL REEFS AND TO AID IN PLANNING FOR FUTURE ARTIFICIAL REEFENHANCEMENTS (ADDING MORE MODULES).PROJECT 2 - FISH AGGREGATING DEVICES DEVELOPMENT AND OPERATION: THE FISH AGGREGATING DEVICES DEVELOPMENT ANDOPERATION PROGRAM MAINTAINS A NETWORK OF 55 ANCHORED FISH AGGREGATING DEVICES (FADS) AROUND THE MAIN HAWAIIANISLANDS AT VARYING DISTANCES FROM SHORE. ANCHORED FADS CAPITALIZE ON THE FACT THAT PELAGIC FISHES SUCH AS TUNA,MAHIMAHI AND MARLIN ARE ATTRACTED TO FLOATING OBJECTS. BECAUSE OF THIS, ANCHORED FADS ALLOW SPORT FISHERS TOMAXIMIZE THEIR FISHING SUCCESS WHILE REDUCING THE AMOUNT OF TIME NEEDED TO SEARCH FOR FISH. FADS ALSO REDIRECTFISHING EFFORT AWAY FROM NEAR SHORE AREAS WHERE RESOURCES ARE EASILY DEPLETED TO OFFSHORE AREAS WHERE THERESOURCE IS MUCH LARGER AND MORE RESILIENT. FADS CAN ALSO SERVE TO FACILITATE RESEARCH IN TO THE BIOLOGY OFPELAGIC FISHES THEREBY CONTRIBUTING TO BETTER MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION. THE FAD PROGRAM'S OUTREACH COMPONENTCONSISTS OF A "HOT LINE" FOR PROVIDING INFORMATION TO FISHERS AND RECEIVING PUBLIC COMMENT AND A DEDICATED WEBSITE DESCRIBING THE PROGRAM'S MISSION, THE LOCATION OF THE FADS AND WHETHER OR NOT THEY ARE CURRENTLY ON STATION.

THE DEPARTMENT OF LAND AND NATURAL RESOURCES/ DIVISION OF AQUATIC RESOURCES (DLNR/DAR) STATEWIDE FRESHWATERFISHERIES DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM MAINTAINS AND ENHANCES FRESHWATER SPORT FISH POPULATIONS AND PROVIDES QUALITYFRESHWATER RECREATIONAL FISHING OPPORTUNITIES IN HAWAII. NOT ONLY DOES THIS INCREASE CATCH AND SATISFACTIONRATES, BUT ALSO BENEFITS THE LOCAL ECONOMY THROUGH THE SALE OF FISHING SUPPLIES AND EQUIPMENT, ALONG WITH FOODAND LODGING FROM TRAVELING ANGLERS.EFFORTS ARE FOCUSED ON THE STOCKING OF RAINBOW TROUT IN PUU LUA RESERVOIR ON KAUAI, AND LARGEMOUTH BASS IN LAKEWILSON ON OAHU, TWO POPULAR AREAS FOR THE FRESHWATER RECREATIONAL FISHING COMMUNITY.EYED RAINBOW TROUT EGGS ARE IMPORTED FROM MT. SHASTA HATCHERY IN CALIFORNIA AND GROWN AT HAWAII'S DLNR/DARANUENUE FISHERY RESEARCH CENTER'S TROUT HATCHERY. A TARGET AMOUNT OF 20,000 TO 40,000 TROUT FINGERLINGS ARESHIPPED TO KAUAI'S PUU LUA RESERVOIR, KOKEE PUBLIC FISHING AREA. THIS IS WHERE THOUSANDS OF ANGLERS, BOTH LOCALAND VISITING, ENJOY THE ANNUAL TROUT FISHING OPEN.THE WAHIAWA MIDDLE SCHOOL FISH HATCHERY IS OPERATED BY THE SCHOOL STAFF AND VOLUNTEERS. DLNR/DAR HELPS MAINTAINTHE FISH HATCHERY BY PROVIDING FEED, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND ASSISTING WITH MAINTENANCE. THE HATCHERY RAISESLARGEMOUTH BASS AND BLUEGILL FROM EGGS OBTAINED FROM BROOD STOCK RAISED IN THE HATCHERY. JUVENILE BASS ANDBLUEGILL ARE THEN STOCKED IN LAKE WILSON, WAHIAWA PUBLIC FISHING AREA. STOCKING SUPPLEMENTS THE POPULATION OFLARGEMOUTH BASS (INTRODUCED IN 1911) AND BLUEGILL (INTRODUCED IN THE LATE 1940'S) IN LAKE WILSON. ALTHOUGH BOTHSPECIES ARE REPRODUCING NATURALLY, REPRODUCTION IS NOT SUBSTANTIAL ENOUGH TO SUSTAIN A VIABLE RECREATIONAL SPORTFISHING PROGRAM.

THE KARNES BOATING ACCESS SITE, LOCATED IN WASHINGTON COUNTY, IDAHO IS A .93 ACRE, PRIVATELY OWNED, ACCESS SITEALONG THE SNAKE RIVER IN IDAHO'S SOUTHWEST REGION. THE SITE HAS PROVIDED CONVENIENT RIVER ACCESS FORRECREATIONAL BOATERS, ANGLERS AND OTHER OUTDOOR RECREATIONAL USERS SINCE THE 1950'S. THE SITE IS HEAVILY USEDANNUALLY FROM MARCH THROUGH NOVEMBER WITH ADDITIONAL LIMITED WINTER USE, AND IT CONTINUES TO GROW IN POPULARITY.THE CURRENT LANDOWNER APPROACHED THE IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME (DEPARTMENT) AND IS INTERESTED IN SELLINGTHE SITE TO THE DEPARTMENT FOR CONTINUED PUBLIC ACCESS TO THE SNAKE RIVER. IF THE DEPARTMENT DOES NOT ACQUIRETHIS SITE, THERE IS A HIGH PROBABILITY THE LAND WILL BE SOLD FOR PRIVATE USE AND/OR DEVELOPMENT AND THE BOATING,FISHING AND RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES THE PROPERTY CURRENTLY PROVIDES WILL BE LOST TO THE GENERAL PUBLIC.THIS PROJECT ENABLES THE DEPARTMENT TO ACQUIRE THE .93 ACRE PARCEL TO PROVIDE CONTINUED PUBLIC ACCESS TO THISHIGHLY UTILIZED AREA OF THE SNAKE RIVER.
AL- MONITORING ABUNDANCE AND MOVEMENT OF RED SNAPPER (F-105-12)

THE URBAN CATFISH PROGRAM WAS CREATED TO PROVIDE A SUSTAINABLE FISHERY IN URBAN COMMUNITIES THAT EXPERIENCE HIGH FISHING PRESSURE. THE STATE HATCHERY SYSTEM WOULD NOT BE ABLE TO SUPPLY THE NEEDED FISH AT PRESENT PRODUCTION LEVELS. TO PROVIDE A VALUABLE ANGLING EXPERIENCE THE DEPARTMENT PURCHASES CHANNEL CATFISH FROM COMMERCIAL PRODUCERS TO SUPPLY THOSE OF HARVESTABLE SIZE TO URBAN WATERS, MANY OF WHICH ARE PART OF OUR COMMUNITY FISHERIES ASSISTANCE PROGRAM (CFAP). DUE TO THE EARLY SUCCESS OF THIS PROGRAM, IT WAS EXPANDED TO INCLUDE AREAS IN LESS POPULATED REGIONS OF THE STATE IN COUNTIES THAT FUNCTION AS "COMMUNITY FISHING HUBS". IN THIS GRANT APPROXIMATELY 133,862 CHANNEL CATFISH WILL BE STOCKED ACROSS THE STATE TO BEING FISHING OPPORTUNITIES TO THE GREATEST NUMBER OF ANGLERS.
THIS GRANT PROVIDES FUNDING TO STOCK COMMUNITY FISHING PONDS THROUGHOUT LOUISIANA.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT FISH AND WILDLIFE THROUGH THE REVIEW OF FEDERALLY FUNDED, PERMITTED, AND/OR LICENSED ACTIVITIES THROUGHOUT ARKANSAS. DURING THE GRANT PERIOD, THE ENVIRONMENTAL COORDINATION DIVISION WILL REVIEW PROJECT PROPOSALS FOR THE POTENTIAL TO AFFECT FISH AND WILDLIFE AND WORK TO MINIMIZE IMPACTS ON THESE RESOURCES.

THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THE RECREATIONAL FISHERY STATISTICS PROGRAM IS TO COLLECT SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION ON THE MAJOR FINFISH SPECIES THAT ARE CAUGHT BY RECREATIONAL ANGLERS IN SOUTH CAROLINA, AS WELL AS INFORMATION ON THE FISHING ACTIVITIES OF THOSE ANGLERS. THESE DATA ARE USED BY BIOLOGISTS TO ASSESS THE STATUS AND HEALTH OF THE FISH POPULATIONS, AND ARE VITAL FOR MAKING MANAGEMENT DECISIONS THAT AFFECT THE LONG-TERM SUSTAINABILITY OF THESE FISHERIES. THE TARGET SPECIES FOR THE PROJECT ARE THE MOST POPULAR SPORTFISH IN SOUTH CAROLINA: FLOUNDER, SPOTTED SEATROUT, RED DRUM, AND THE SNAPPER GROUPER COMPLEX. THIS GRANT WILL HELP FUND TWO FISHERY DEPENDENT DATA COLLECTION PROGRAMS: ACCESS POINT ANGLER INTERCEPT SURVEY AND CHARTER BOAT LOGBOOK PROGRAM.

FISH HATCHERIES PLAY AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN NORTH CAROLINA'S FISHERY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM. PROVIDING FOR THE CONTINUAL OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE IS ESSENTIAL TO PROVIDING MANY OF THE SPORT FISHING OPPORTUNITIES IN NORTH CAROLINA. THE FISH PRODUCED AT THE N.C. WILDLIFE RESOURCES COMMISSION'S (NCWRC) HATCHERIES SIGNIFICANTLY CONTRIBUTE TO THE SUPPORT OF FRESHWATER SPORT FISHERIES IN NORTH CAROLINA.HATCHERY-SUPPORTED SPORT FISH ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES IN NORTH CAROLINA ARE DIVERSE AND INCREASING. COLDWATER, COOLWATER AND WARMWATER FISH HATCHERIES PRODUCE AND STOCK JUVENILE FISH, TO SUPPORT RE-ESTABLISHMENT OF NATURALLY REPRODUCING STOCKS AND SUPPORT PUT-GROW-AND-TAKE FISHERIES. PRODUCTION OF CATCHABLE AND FINGERLING TROUT, MUSKELLUNGE, WALLEYE, STRIPED BASS, HYBRID STRIPED BASS, LARGEMOUTH BASS, SMALLMOUTH BASS, WHITE BASS, SUNFISH, WHITE CATFISH AND CHANNEL CATFISH SUPPORT POPULAR REGIONAL FISHERIES. THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDS FOR THE OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF SIX STATE FISH HATCHERIES PROPAGATING SPORT FISH FOR RESTORATION, AUGMENTATION AND RECREATIONAL PURPOSES. WITH CONTINUED POPULATION GROWTH AND INCREASED DEVELOPMENT IN NORTH CAROLINA, IT IS LIKELY THE DEMANDS PLACED ON FISH HATCHERIES WILL CONTINUE TO INCREASE. THE SUCCESS OF PROGRAMS SUCH AS HATCHERY SUPPORTED AND DELAYED HARVEST TROUT WATERS AND THE COMMUNITY FISHING PROGRAM REQUIRE SUBSTANTIAL DEDICATION OF HATCHERY PRODUCTION RESOURCES.

JIMS' LANDING IS A GRAVEL BOAT RAMP AND DAY USE PARKING AREA LOCATED WITHIN THE SKILAK WILDLIFE RECREATION AREA.IT LIES ON THE KENAI RIVER BETWEEN THE CONFLUENCE OF THE RUSSIAN RIVER AND SKILAK LAKE NEAR THE TOWN OF COOPERLANDING. THIS SITE IS PART OF THE KENAI NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE AND IS MANAGED BY THE U.S. FISH & WILDLIFESERVICE (USFWS). THE SECTION OF RIVER THAT FLOWS PAST JIMS' LANDING IS PART OF THE UPPER KENAI RIVER AND ISREGULATED BY THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES AS PART OF THE KENAI RIVER SPECIAL MANAGEMENT AREA.THE UPPER KENAI RIVER FLOWS OUT OF KENAI LAKE AND STEADILY RUNS SEVENTEEN MILES DOWNSTREAM THROUGH THE CHUGACHNATIONAL FOREST AND THE KENAI NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE BEFORE ENTERING SKILAK LAKE. ONE OF THE MANYCHARACTERISTICS THAT MAKES THE UPPER KENAI RIVER VERY SPECIAL IS THAT IT IS NONMOTORIZED USE ONLY, AND IT ISDESIGNATED A DRIFT-ONLY RIVER CORRIDOR. THIS STRETCH OF THE KENAI RIVER IS WORLD FAMOUS FOR REACTIONAL SALMON ANDTROUT FISHING. BEING ONLY 100 MILES FROM ANCHORAGE IT IS A VERY POPULAR FISHING AND BOATING AREA FOR BOTH ALASKARESIDENTS AND SEASONAL TOURIST.JIMS' LANDING IS PRIMARILY USED BY, AND ESSENTIAL TO, RECREATIONAL BOATERS AND SPORT ANGLERS WHO FLOAT THE UPPERPORTION OF THE KENAI RIVER BETWEEN KENAI LAKE AND SKILAK LAKE. SPORT ANGLERS AND OTHER RECREATIONAL BOATERSLAUNCH THEIR BOATS AT EITHER THE COOPER LANDING STATE RECREATION SITE OR SPORTSMEN'S LANDING, NEAR THE CONFLUENCEOF THE RUSSIAN RIVER. A SECTION OF THE KENAI RIVER BELOW JIMS' LANDING FLOWS THROUGH A CANYON AND CAN BE A HAZARDTO NOVICE BOATERS, MAKING IT IMPORTANT FOR MANY TO EXIT THE RIVER AT THIS POINT. HOWEVER, SOME SKILLEDRECREATIONAL BOATERS DO LAUNCH THEIR BOATS AT JIM'S LANDING TO ACCESS THE LOWER SECTION OF THE UPPER KENAI RIVERAND SKILAK LAKE. MOST BOATERS DRIFTING THIS SECTION OF RIVER CARRY A 'KICKER' OUTBOARD MOTOR AS THE NONMOTORIZEDBOAT RESTRICTION IS LIFTED UPON REACHING SKILAK LAKE. UPON FINISHING THEIR DRIFT, THE MAJORITY OF THESE BOATERSMOTOR TO THE BOAT RAMP AT THE USFWS UPPER SKILAK LAKE CAMPGROUND TO EXIT THE LAKE.DUE TO RIVER FLOWS AND EROSION, THE GRAVEL BOAT LAUNCH AND RETRIEVAL AREA CAN BECOME QUITE STEEP AND INCLUDELOOSE AND UNEVEN TERRAIN THAT CREATES HAZARDOUS AND DIFFICULT CONDITIONS FOR GETTING BOATS INTO AND OUT OF THEWATER. COMBINED WITH THE EXTREME GRADE BREAK FROM THE ROADWAY DOWN INTO THE RETRIEVAL AREA, SUCCESSFULLYLAUNCHING AND RETRIEVING CAN BE CHALLENGING DUE TO POOR TRACTION AND THE STEEP GRADE, WHICH CAN CAUSE DAMAGE TOVEHICLES AND TRAILERS; A FOUR-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE IS A MUST. CURRENT STAGING AND TIE-DOWN AREAS ARE MINIMAL, ANDTHE MAJORITY OF VEHICLE/BOAT TRAILER PARKING IS LOCATED OFF-SITE, WHICH ADDS TIME TO LAUNCH/RETRIEVAL ACTIVITIESAND EXACERBATES SITE CONGESTION.THIS PROJECT WILL COMPLETELY RENOVATE THE ENTIRE SITE BY WIDENING AND ADDING ANGLED PARKING ALONG THE ROADWAY,PAVING THE ROADWAY AND PARKING AREAS, HARDENING THE BOAT RAMP USING ARTICULATED CONCRETE MATTING, AND ADDING ANEW PAVED PARKING LOT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO PROVIDE FUNDING NEEDED FOR A GRANT SPECIALIST POSITION AS WELL AS FUNDING FOR TRAININGS/MEETINGS/CONFERENCES AND SUPPLIES ASSOCIATED WITH MANAGING THE FEDERAL BOATING ACCESS PROGRAM. THIS IS THE FOURTH SEGMENT OF A FIVE YEAR GRANT.

NORTH CAROLINA HAS OVER 350,000 ACTIVE REGISTERED BOATERS AND HUNDREDS OF VISITING AND NON-RESIDENT BOATERS WHO USE NORTH CAROLINA WILDLIFE RESOURCES COMMISSION BOATING ACCESS AREA FACILITIES TO ACCESS THE STATE'S INLAND PUBLIC WATERS. TO ACCOMMODATE THESE DEMANDS THE COMMISSION MUST PROVIDE SAFE, CLEAN, AND SERVICEABLE BOATING ACCESS AREAS FOR THE LAUNCH AND RETRIEVAL OF BOATS IN NORTH CAROLINA'S INLAND WATERS. COMMISSION STAFF OPERATE AND MAINTAIN APPROXIMATELY 180 INLAND BOATING ACCESS AREAS ACROSS THE STATE.

N.C. WILDLIFE RESOURCES COMMISSION (NCWRC) HABITAT CONSERVATION PROGRAM STAFF WILL PROTECT AND ENHANCE FISHERIES RESOURCES BYPROVIDING PERMIT AND ENVIRONMENTAL DOCUMENT REVIEW AND BY PROVIDING TECHNICAL GUIDANCE REGARDING HABITAT CONSERVATION TOGOVERNMENTAL AND PRIVATE AGENCIES OR INDIVIDUALS.
